Description: GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA, INC.PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE 03 31 2023   08 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE (AVOID ACRONYMS OR FEDERAL OR AGENCY SPECIFICTERMINOLOGY) THIS AWARD FUNDS A GEOSCIENTIST TO SPEND A YEAR IN A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE OR COMMITTEE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE FELLOW WILL CONTRIBUTE SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE TO A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE THROUGH CONSTITUENT MEETINGS, DRAFTING LEGISLATION AND COMMUNICATIONS. THE FELLOW WILL ALSO PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT THE POLICY PROCESS TO THE LARGER GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY, ALLOWING FOR MORE EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE TWO.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES.IN ADDITION TO BRINGING SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE TO A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE, THE FELLOW WILL PUBLISH 2 ARTICLES IN GSA TODAY AND SPEAK TO THE GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE NEXUS OF SCIENCE AND POLICY.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)AS THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT CONTINUES TO ADDRESS MANY ISSUES WITH GEOSCIENCE COMPONENTS, TIMELY, ACCURATE GEOSCIENCE INFORMATION AND ANALYSIS ARE VITAL TO INFORMED POLICY DECISIONS. A CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOW IS IN A UNIQUE POSITION TO PROVIDE SUCH EXPERTISE. PREVIOUS GSA USGS CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOWS HAVE WORKED IN THE U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND SENATE ON A WIDE RANGE OF ISSUES, INCLUDING NATURAL RESOURCE POLICY, SCIENCE EDUCATION, CLIMATE CHANGE, INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND SCIENTIFIC COOPERATION, AND NATURAL HAZARD MITIGATION. THE PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM THESE CONTRIBUTIONS TO POLICY AND THE GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY BENEFITS FROM INCREASED ENGAGEMENT AND UNDERSTANDING ABOUT POLICY.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES FACED IN RESTORING DEGRADED HABITATS IN HAWAII, SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE, INVASIVE SPECIES, COST, AND KNOWLEDGE SHARING. THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO ENHANCE INNOVATION AND SUCCESS IN FOREST RESTORATION WHILE TESTING STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF DROUGHT INTENSIFICATION ON RESTORATION OUTCOMES. OBJECTIVE 1 FOCUSES ON ACCELERATING LEARNING AND INNOVATION BY INCREASING ACCESS TO INSIGHTS AND PRODUCTS. THE PROJECT PLANS TO DEVELOP A SEARCHABLE WEB DATABASE OF RESTORATION REFERENCES SPECIFIC TO HAWAII, INCLUDING TECHNICAL REPORTS AND PEER-REVIEWED LITERATURE.

PROJECT TITLE: NEW COLLABORATIVE AVENUES TO ADDRESS KNOWLEDGE GAPS ASSOCIATED WITH NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS TO EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS.PROJECT DATES: 08 21 2023 - 08 20 2024AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT WILL HOLD WORKSHOPS TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE ON THREE RELEVANT TOPICS (FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION, POLICY INCENTIVES AND DISINCENTIVES, AND COMMUNICATING NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS THROUGH THE ARTS). THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE THUS TO: A) DEVELOP LEARNING QUESTIONS TO INFORM A BROADER ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK AND DEVELOP A SUITE OF CRITERIA TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE THE LOCATION OF FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION OPPORTUNITIES, B) IDENTIFY IMPORTANT FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT POLICIES AND PROGRAM GUIDANCE THAT ARE WORKING TO ENCOURAGE OR DETER IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER RETENTION STRATEGIES IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN, AND C) IDENTIFY KEY AUDIENCES AND DEVELOPED INITIAL STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNICATING NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS IN AGRICULTURAL SETTINGS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TASK 1: THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN ASSOCIATION (UMRBA) WILL HOLD WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP LEARNING QUESTIONS TO INFORM A BROADER ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK AND DEVELOP A SUITE OFCRITERIA TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE THE LOCATION OF FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION OPPORTUNITIES. TASK 2: UMRBA WILL TRANSFER FUNDS TO AMERICAS WATERSHED INITIATIVE (AWI) TO HOLD WORKSHOPS TO IDENTIFY NBS INCENTIVES AND DISINCENTIVES.TASK 3: UMRBA WILL TRANSFER FUNDS TO AMERICAN FARMLAND TRUST (AFT) TO HOLD WORKSHOPS ON COMMUNICATING NBS THROUGH THE ARTSDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A) NEW COLLABORATIONS AND STRENGTHENED EXISTING COLLABORATIONS AROUND FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION B) PROJECT UPDATE: DUE TO USGS ON NOVEMBER 1, 2023  WRITTEN BY UMRBAC) REPORT WITH HIGH-LEVEL SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION KNOWLEDGE AND PLANNING AS WELL AS LEARNING QUESTIONS, PROJECT PRIORITIZATION CRITERIA, AND EVALUATION METRICS AS WELL AS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE COLLABORATIONS - DUE TO USGS ON DECEMBER 1, 2023  WRITTEN BY UMRBA.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT FLOODPLAIN COMMUNITIES BY ILLUMINATING THE WILLINGNESS OF SOME LANDOWNERS (E.G., PRIVATE LEVEE DISTRICTS) TO IMPLEMENT FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY ON THEIR RESPECTIVE LANDS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: AWI AND AFT WILL SUPPORT EFFORTS IN HOLDING WORKSHOPS.

THE PROJECT AIMS TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES OF HABITAT RESTORATION IN HAWAII BY COMBINING SYNTHESIS AND EXPERIMENTAL APPROACHES. THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO INCREASE INNOVATION AND SUCCESS IN FOREST RESTORATION WHILE TESTING STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF DROUGHT INTENSIFICATION ON RESTORATION OUTCOMES. THE DESIRED OUTCOME IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A VIBRANT RESTORATION COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE IN HAWAII AND INCREASED ADAPTIVE CAPACITY FOR RESTORATION ORGANIZATIONS AND THE ECOSYSTEMS THEY STEWARD.

GRANTEE NAME: DELTARES USA INC.GRANT NUMBER: G22AC00597-00PROJECT TITLE: USGS NON-COMPETITIVE ASSISTANCE FY 2023 - SACRAMENTO ACQUISITION BRANCHPROJECT PERIOD: 10 01 2023 - 09 30 2024PROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPING, IMPLEMENTING, AND IMPROVING MODELS AND METHODS TO ACCURATELY REPRESENT WATERAND SUBSURFACE RESOURCES RELEVANT FOR PREDICTING WATER AVAILABILITY AND USE CONCERNS.BUDGET PERIOD: 10 01 2023 - 09 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS PART OF A LARGER PROJECT AIMED AT DEVELOPING AN ENTERPRISE ECOSYSTEM OF INTEGRATED AND INTEROPERABLE MODELS AND OR MODEL CODES THAT, WHEN LINKED THROUGH ONE OR MORE MODEL COUPLING FRAMEWORKS, PROVIDE A FLEXIBLE REPRESENTATION OF WATER AVAILABILITY SUITABLE FOR ADDRESSING WMA PROGRAMMATIC NEEDS, BROADER MODELING NEEDS, AND OR EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDER, PARTNER, AND AGENCY NEEDS. IMPLEMENTED MODELS IN THE ECOSYSTEM WILL BE CONSIDERED THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE FOR EACH RESPECTIVE WATER AVAILABILITY COMPONENT INCLUDING THE STATES OF THE WATER CYCLE, WATER USES, WATER-QUALITY CONSTITUENTS, AND HYDROECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS. MODFLOW6 IS PROVIDING THE INITIAL FRAMEWORK WHICH THE ECOSYSTEM OF CODES MODELS WILL BE COUPLED WITH, AND INTIMATE KNOWLEDGE OF THIS CODE IS IMPERATIVE. PARALLELIZATION SOLUTIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED USING INTEROPERABLE COMPONENTS AND MODERN SOFTWARE ENGINEERING TECHNIQUES AS PART OF THIS PROJECT TO ENHANCE THE EXECUTION TIME OF EXISTING NUMERICAL MODELS PROBLEMS AND PROVIDE AN ABILITY TO COMPUTE LARGER AND MORE RESOURCE INTENSIVE PROBLEMS. THESE SOFTWARE SOLUTIONS WILL BE DOCUMENTED AND IMPLEMENTED THAT INEVITABLY WILL IMPROVE MODELS AND METHODS THAT ACCURATELY AND RAPIDLY REPRESENT ADVANCED, CONSISTENT APPROACHES FOR FORECASTING HYDROLOGIC STATES, FLUXES, AND OUTCOMES FOR WATER AVAILABILITY TO IMPROVE PREDICTIONS OF WATER AVAILABILITY AT A RANGE OF TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL SCALES. ADDITIONALLY, THE CAPACITY OF AN INTEROPERABLE DESIGN ALLOWS MODELS OF FEDERAL, ACADEMIC, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO CONNECT AND INTEGRATE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED1.PROVIDE A SENIOR LEVEL SOFTWARE ARCHITECT FAMILIAR WITH ENTERPRISE CAPACITY SOFTWARE (MODFLOW 6) DEVELOPMENT TO AID WITH DESIGN, REVIEW ONGOING DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS, AND PROVIDE MENTORSHIP TO USGS AND DELTARES TEAM MEMBERS.2.CONTINUE COLLABORATIVE PARALLEL DEVELOPMENTA.ENHANCE THE PERFORMANCE AND FUNCTIONALITY OF PARALLEL CAPABILITIES.B.IMPLEMENT  WINDOWS  DISTRIBUTION STRATEGIES FOR PETSC SOLVER.C.EVALUATE FEASIBILITY OF PARALLELIZING THE IMS SOLVER AND IMPLEMENT, IF FEASIBLE.3.COLLABORATIVE DEVELOPMENT OF ONE-DIMENSIONAL RICHARDS EQUATION FORMULATION APPROPRIATE FOR LARGE-SCALE REGIONAL APPLICATIONS.4.PROVIDE DELTARES STAFF TO ASSIST WITH MAINTENANCE AND SUPPORT OF ENTERPRISE CAPACITY SOFTWARE (MODFLOW 6). DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESDELTARES USA WILL DELIVER SUPPORT FOR ENTERPRISE ECOSYSTEM OF INTEGRATED AND INTEROPERABLE MODELS TO COMPLETE THE BUILDOUT OF THE SYSTEM THUS PERMITTING THE STATEWIDE APPLICATION OF THE MODELING SYSTEM.DELTARES USA WILL DELIVER PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE VIA A PEER REVIEWED ARTICLE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) ALL PERSONS CONCERNED WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE VIA THE PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLE.

ABSTRACT:THE USGS - TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION SPACE AGREEMENT IS A UNIQUE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS), LOWER MISSISSIPPI-GULF WATER SCIENCE CENTER AND THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION (TDEC) ON TOPICS RELATED TO WATER RESOURCES WHICH MAY INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF STREAM GAGING DATA, INVESTIGATION OF GROUNDWATER RESOURCES, COLLECTION OF WATER-QUALITY DATA, AND ASSESSMENT OF AQUATIC HABITAT. THE USGS WILL SELECT STAFF FOR ASSIGNMENT TO THE TDEC MEMPHIS LOCATION AND CAN HELP TDEC WITH STATE SCIENCE PLAN DEVELOPMENT, AND PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FIELD-BASED DATA-COLLECTION METHODS FOR USGS PROJECTS. THE USGS TDEC RELATIONSHIP WILL BE FURTHER STRENGTHEN THROUGH THE COLOCATION OF USGS FACILITIES FOR THE DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT. THE TOTAL SPACE FOR THE 6 OFFICE SPACES (600SQ FT), STORAGE SPACE (160SQ FT), AND 1 LAB SPACE (160 SQ FT) AT THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION BUILDING LOCATED AT 8383 WOLF LAKE DRIVE, BARTLETT, TN 38133.
JOINT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED POST-FIRE DEBRIS-FLOW HAZARD ASSESSMENT IN OREGON

GRANTEE NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OREGONGRANT NUMBER: G23AS00059PROJECT TITLE: DEBRIS FLOW RESEARCH IN SUPPORT OF THE RAINIER LAHAR DETECTION SYSTEMPROJECT DATES: 09 15 2023 TO 09 14 2026AWARD PURPOSE: MOUNT RAINIER IN WASHINGTON, USA, HAS HISTORICALLY PRODUCED WATER-LADENMASS WASTING EVENTS, REFERRED TO AS DEBRIS FLOWS OR LAHARS, THAT HAVE REACHED THE DENSELYPOPULATED PUGET SOUND LOWLANDS. THE RAINIER LAHAR DETECTION SYSTEM (RLDS) IS AN EARLYWARNING SYSTEM CURRENTLY BEING DEVELOPED BY THE USGS IN RESPONSE TO THIS HAZARD. THE RLDSCOMPRISES BOTH THE INSTALLATION OF ADDITIONAL SEISMOMETERS TO RECORD LAHARS AND OR DEBRIS FLOWS INMULTIPLE DRAINAGES ON THE FLANKS OF MT. RAINER AND DEVELOPMENT OF SOFTWARE CAPABLE OF RAPIDLYIDENTIFYING LAHARS AND QUANTIFYING FEATURES RELEVANT TO EARLY WARNING (E.G. LOCATION, SIZE, ANDVELOCITY). THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUCH A SYSTEM IS CHALLENGING FOR MULTIPLE REASONS. FIRST, THERE IS APAUCITY OF SEISMIC RECORDINGS OF DEBRIS FLOWS THAT CAN BE USED TO VALIDATE PHENOMENOLOGICALMODELS. SECOND, WE LACK BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF HOW LAHARS GENERATE SEISMIC WAVES AND HOWTHEIR SEISMIC SIGNATURE CHANGES AS DEBRIS FLOW PROPERTIES CHANGE. FINALLY, COMPLEX NEAR-SURFACEPATH AND SITE EFFECTS ALTER THE SEISMIC SIGNALS BETWEEN THE SOURCE AND THE RECEIVER IN WAYS THAT AREDIFFICULT TO MODEL. THE PRINCIPAL GOALS OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS MAKE PROGRESS ON EACH OF THEAFOREMENTIONED CHALLENGES.ACTIVES TO BE PERFORMED: FIRST, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE THE DENSE, TEMPORARY DEPLOYMENTS OFTHE TAHOMA CREEK DRAINAGE AND MT. ST. HELENS TO OBTAIN MORE RECORDINGS OF NATURAL DEBRIS FLOWSTHAT CAN BE USED TO VALIDATE MODELS OF DEBRIS FLOW PHYSICS. SECOND, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOWLAHARS GENERATE SEISMIC WAVES WE PROPOSE TO APPLY EXISTING ANALYTIC AND NUMERICAL MODELS OFDEBRIS FLOWS TO BOTH MAN-MADE (I.E. THOSE CREATED AT THE USGS DEBRIS FLUME IN THE HJ ANDREWSEXPERIMENTAL FOREST IN BLUE RIVER, OR) AND NATURAL FLOWS RECORDED ON A DENSE NETWORK AT MT. ST.HELENS. FINALLY, TO ACCOUNT FOR PATH EFFECTS, WE HAVE APPLIED TECHNIQUES TAKEN FROM SEISMICIMAGING STUDIES THAT DERIVE EMPIRICAL GREENS FUNCTIONS FROM THE AMBIENT SEISMIC FIELD. THISWORK WILL FURTHER IMPROVE AND VALIDATE THESE TECHNIQUES THROUGH ADDITIONAL COMPARISONS WITHHAMMER BLOWS AND EXPLORATION OF AMPLITUDE CALIBRATIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PREPARED SEISMIC DATASETSFROM EACH DEPLOYMENT HOSTED AT THE EARTHSCOPE ARCHIVE. OTHER DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PUBLISHEDPAPERS, CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS AND FINDINGS USEFUL FOR THE RAINIER LAHAR DETECTION SYSTEM.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STAKEHOLDERS IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE RAINIER LAHAR DETECTIONSYSTEM, COMMUNITIES ALONG THE TAHOMA CREEK AND PUYALLUP DRAINAGESSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 24PROJECT TITLE: BILL WILLIAMS RIVERINE ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW DECISION SUPPORT TOOL (REFDSS) AND GREEN RIVER ANALYSISTHE AWARDED PROJECT EXAMINES CHANGES IN THE COLORADO RIVER WATERSHED FROM CLIMATE CHANGE AND WATER MANAGEMENT. CLIMATE CHANGE AND WATER MANAGEMENT HAVE DECREASED FLOWS IN THE GREEN AND YAMPA RIVERS, TRIBUTARIES TO THE COLORADO RIVER, CAUSING CHANNEL NARROWING AND SIMPLIFICATION RESULTING IN NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO THE RIVERINE ECOSYSTEMS FOR RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND ENDANGERED FISH IN UTAH AND COLORADO. THIS TREND IS EXPECTED TO WORSEN IN COMING DECADES AND WILL BE AFFECTED BY ONGOING NEGOTIATIONS TO UPDATE ALLOCATION OF WATER IN THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN. SPECIFICALLY, THE BILL WILLIAMS RIVER IN THE BILL WILLIAMS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE IN ARIZONA AND THE GREEN AND YAMPA RIVERS IN CANYONLANDS NATIONAL PARK AND DINOSAUR NATIONAL MONUMENT ARE THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT.THE FIRST ACTIVITY OF THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE RIVERINE ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEM (REFDSS) TO THE BILL WILLIAMS RIVER IN ARIZONA. REFDSS WAS ORIGINALLY DEVELOPED FOR THE DELAWARE RIVER THEN UPDATED AND EXPANDED TO THE VERDE RIVER IN ARIZONA. BILL WILLIAMS RIVER HYDRAULIC MODEL AND VEGETATION PLOT SURVEY DATA WILL BE COMBINED AND ADDED TO THE REFDSS TOOL AND THIS CACHED DATASET WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE REFDSS WEB TOOL. AFTER INTEGRATION OF THE BILL WILLIAMS RIVER DATASETS, REFDSS WILL BE USED TO EXAMINE CURRENT AND POTENTIAL FLOW SCENARIOS AND THEIR EFFECTS ON THE AVAILABILITY OF APPROPRIATE HABITAT NECESSARY TO SUPPORT FISH AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION POPULATIONS ALONG THE RIVER.THE SECOND ACTIVITY OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF MODELS RELATING TO RIVER FLOW, CHANNEL CHANGE AND HABITAT FOR RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND FISH IN THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN. A DETAILED ANALYSIS OF LONG-TERM MONITORING SITE DATA FROM THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE NORTHERN COLORADO PLATEAU INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROGRAM ON THE YAMPA AND GREEN RIVERS WILL BE MADE TO IDENTIFY THRESHOLDS FOR INUNDATION FREQUENCIES FOR THE OBSERVED CHANGES IN CHANNEL TO FLOODPLAIN. AFTER IDENTIFYING THESE THRESHOLDS AND RELATIONSHIPS, THEY WILL BE APPLIED TO DETERMINE LOCATIONS AND PLANT SPECIES MOST STRONGLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE OBSERVED NARROWING AND SIMPLIFICATION OF WESTERN RIVERS. THESE RELATIONS WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE IMPACTS OF POSSIBLE FUTURE NARROWING FROM POTENTIAL FLOWS RESULTING FROM COMBINED DROUGHT, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS ON THE RIVERS.APPLICATION OF THE REFDSS WEB TOOL TO THE BILL WILLIAMS RIVER ALLOWS MANAGERS TO ASSESS AND PLAN FOR MULTIPLE POSSIBLE FUTURE FLOW CONDITIONS. THIS AIDS IN THE MISSION OF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES TO CONSERVER, MANAGE, AND WHERE APPROPRIATE RESTORE FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT RESOURCES AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE UNITED STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS OF AMERICANS. FURTHER, THE ASSESSMENT OF CHANNEL CHANGE AND HABITAT FOR RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND FISH ALONG THE YAMPA AND GREEN RIVERS WILL ALLOW MANAGERS AND AGENCIES TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF FLOW CHANGES ON HABITAT AVAILABILITY THROUGH CHANNEL NARROWING AND VEGETATION CHANGE. THIS IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND BECAUSE IT DRIVES THE LOSS OF HABITAT FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FISH AND DISTURBANCE-DEPENDENT NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION. THERE ARE OVER 1,3000 ENDANGERED OR THREATENED SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES AND THROUGH STUDY AND UNDERSTANDING OF THESE SPECIES WE CAN IDENTIFY HOW BEST TO PROTECT THEM FOR THE BETTERMENT OF NOT ONLY THE NATURAL SYSTEMS IN WHICH THEY LIVE BUT ALSO THE REMARKABLE VALUES OF OUR WILDERNESSES TO BE PRESERVED FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS

ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE:  DEVELOPMENT OF COASTAL CHANGE CAPACITY IN PUERTO RICO PROJECT PERIOD: 08 16 2023 THROUGH 08 15 2025AN ASSESSMENT OF POST FIONA BEACH ASSESSMENT WILL BE DONE FOR SELECTED TEN (10) MUNICIPALITIES IN THE NORTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO FOR 2023. A COMBINATION OF GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS), ANALYSIS OF HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGES, FIELDWORK AND EVALUATION OF PREVIOUS WORK WILL BE USED FOR ASSESSING SHORELINE, SHORELINE TYPES, BACKBEACH AND BEACH WIDTH CHANGES FOR THE SELECTED COASTAL SITES. A GEODATABASE (GDB) WILL BE DEVELOPED AS A MAIN PRODUCT OF THIS RESEARCH THAT INCLUDE DATASETS OF SHORELINE, BACKBEACH, SHORELINE TYPES, BEACH WIDTH CHANGES, ATTRIBUTES OF THE SHORELINE AS GENERAL NATURAL BARRIERS, PRESENCE OF HARD MITIGATION STRUCTURE AND TYPES OF HARD MITIGATION STRUCTURES FOR THE SELECTED SITES AT THE ISLAND. SUBTYPES AND DOMAINS WERE USED TO INCREASE THE QUALITY OF THE SHORELINE CLASSIFICATION AND CHANGE ANALYSIS. THE DATA ACQUIRE IN THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE INITIATIVES OF THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TOTAL WATER LEVEL (TWL) TEAM TO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING AND ABILITY TO ACCURATELY RESOLVE COASTAL CHANGE HAZARDS IN PUERTO RICO THROUGH RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION OF SHORELINE INFORMATION. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO CONTINUE THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH WORK IN COASTAL CHANGES IN THE COASTAL RESEARCH AND PLANNING INSTITUTE OF PUERTO RICO (COREPI).

PROJECT TITLE: 2023 2024 QUATERNARY 3D GEOLOGIC MAPPING OF MINNESOTAPROJECT PERIOD: 8 21 2023 THROUGH 8 20 2024AWARD PURPOSE: THE GREAT LAKES GEOLOGIC MAPPING COALITION SUPPORTS MAPPING TO CHARACTERIZE THE THREE-DIMENSIONAL FRAMEWORK OF GLACIAL SEDIMENTS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION. MUCH EFFORT HAS GONE INTO THE REFINEMENT OF THE QUATERNARY STRATIGRAPHY IN MINNESOTA. THROUGH THE GREAT LAKES GEOLOGIC MAPPING COALITION PROGRAM, SURVEY STAFF CONTINUE TO ANALYZE AND CORRELATE SEDIMENTS IN CORES, WHICH SERVE AS BENCHMARKS FOR CROSS SECTIONS AS WELL AS GEOLOGIC AND GROUNDWATER MODELS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PART OF THE COUNTY ATLAS MAPPING PROGRAM INCLUDES DRILLING HIGH-QUALITY ROTARY SONIC CORES TO SAMPLE THE SEQUENCE OF GLACIAL SEDIMENTS. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT STAFF TIME TO MONITOR AND COLLECT CORES IN THE FIELD, DESCRIBE AND SAMPLE CORES IN THE LAB, AND PROCESS THESE SAMPLES FOR TEXTURE AND LITHOLOGIC COMPOSITION. DRILLING WILL TAKE PLACE IN THREE COUNTIES IN SOUTHWESTERN MINNESOTA WHERE MAPPING IS ALREADY UNDERWAY. IN ADDITION, THE ONE DEEP DRILL HOLE WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT IS MISSING FROM THE BOTTOM OF THEGLACIAL SEDIMENT SEQUENCE. THIS WILL ALLOW GEOLOGISTS TO CHARACTERIZE THE ENTIRE SEDIMENT PACKAGE. THIS INFORMATION, DESCRIBED PREVIOUSLY AS UNDIFFERENTIATED GLACIAL SEDIMENT, IS VITAL TO GROUNDWATER MODELS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DETAILED GRAPHIC LOGS, INCLUDING DOWN-HOLE GEOPHYSICS, AND TEXTURAL AND LITHOLOGIC ANALYSES, FOR APPROXIMATELY 12 CORES WILL BE DELIVERED. THESE CORES PROVIDE BENCHMARKS TO GUIDE SUBSURFACE MAPPING IN COUNTIES BASED ON 1-KM SECTIONS. ADDITIONAL DATA SUCH AS POLLEN, RADIOCARBON, PALEOMAGNETICS, MAGNETIC SUSCEPTIBILITY, AND GEOCHEMISTRY MAY BE FORTHCOMING AS PART OF THE RESPECTIVE COUNTY GEOLOGIC ATLASES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: IN MINNESOTA, THE MAIN MAPPING PROGRAM, THE COUNTY GEOLOGIC ATLASES, INFORMS MANAGEMENT OF GROUNDWATER, WHILE CONCURRENTLY SUPPORTING RESEARCH, EDUCATION, MINERAL RESOURCE, AND CIVIL ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS. MGS QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC MAPPING IS USED BY GROUNDWATER PROFESSIONALS THROUGHOUT THE STATE FOR APPLICATIONS SUCH AS SUPPORTING ASSESSMENT OF AGGREGATE RESOURCES, FOR ENGINEERING AND INFRASTRUCTURE DESIGN SUCH AS PLANNING OF FIBER OPTIC CABLE INSTALLATION, AND ALSO TO DIRECTLY SUPPORT RESEARCH ON GLACIAL GEOLOGY AND QUATERNARY HISTORY.SUBRECIPIENTS: N A

PROJECT TITLE: ENHANCING DELIVERY OF POLLINATOR RESEARCH AND IDENTIFICATION IN THE UNITED STATES: A COOPERATIVE APPROACHA COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM (USGS CRU) AND THE POLISTES FOUNDATION PROJECT PERIOD: AUGUST 15, 2023 THROUGH AUGUST 15, 2027PROJECT ABSTRACT: ENHANCING DELIVERY OF POLLINATOR RESEARCH AND IDENTIFICATION IN THE UNITED STATES: A COOPERATIVE APPROACHPROJECT OVERVIEW: FACED WITH DRAMATIC INCREASES IN INTEREST IN POLLINATOR SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION, THE STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL WILDLIFE MANAGERS IN THE UNITED STATES ARE NOW CONFRONTED WITH SEVERAL CRITICAL BOTTLENECKS: AN INSUFFICIENT NUMBER OF SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS WHO HAVE EXPERTISE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF FIELD SURVEYS, INVENTORIES, AND MONITORING PROGRAMS FOR NATIVE POLLINATORS  A LACK OF MODERN SYSTEMATICS AND TAXONOMIC RESEARCH ON MANY POLLINATOR GROUPS  AND THE LACK OF INDIVIDUALS WHO CAN ACCURATELY IDENTIFY THE THOUSANDS OF NATIVE POLLINATOR SPECIES (ESPECIALLY BEES) WHICH ARE SAMPLED IN THESE SURVEYS. OVER A FOUR-YEAR TIMEFRAME, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TO DEVELOP THE PARTNERSHIPS, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND PROGRAMS NEEDED TO DIRECTLY ADDRESS THESE GAPS, THROUGH A JOINT COLLABORATIVE VENTURE BETWEEN THE USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM (CRU), THE USGS EASTERN ECOLOGICAL SCIENCE CENTER (EESC), AND THE POLISTES FOUNDATION, A 501(C)(3) NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION.SPECIFIC OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE: 1) IDENTIFICATION OF OPPORTUNITIES AND APPROACHES FOR ENHANCING THE DELIVERY OF POLLINATOR SCIENCE AND TRAINING THROUGH COLLABORATIVE INTERAGENCY PARTNERSHIPS  2) IDENTIFICATION OF CURRENT AND PROSPECTIVE STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL PARTNERS WHO HAVE INTEREST AND CAPACITY TO PARTICIPATE IN POLLINATOR SCIENCE ACTIVITIES WITH USGS SCIENTISTS AND PROGRAMS, SUCH AS CRUS AND THE USGS BEE LAB  3) ESTABLISHMENT AND SUPPORT OF COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS THAT DELIVER HANDS-ON RESEARCH AND TRAINING OF NEW POLLINATOR SCIENTISTS, USING EXISTING PATHWAYS SUCH AS THE CRU GRADUATE PROGRAMS  AND 4) DEVELOPMENT OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND APPROACHES FOR ENHANCEMENTS OF EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE AND PROGRAMS TO ACCOMMODATE NEW PARTNERS AND ADDRESS JOINT RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL CAPACITIES (E.G. ADDITIONAL SPACE FOR EDUCATION AND TRAINING OF BEE IDENTIFICATION SPECIALISTS, FIELD STUDIES, EDNA ANALYSIS, AND DNA BARCODING).BACKGROUND: POLLINATORS  BEES, BATS, BIRDS, BUTTERFLIES, BEETLES, MOTHS, FLIES, AND OTHERS.PROJECT FOCUS IN THIS CURRENT COLLABORATION IS ON ENHANCING THE CAPABILITIES OF PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE USGS CRU PROGRAM AND THE USGS EESC BEE LAB TO PROVIDE THE TRAINING THAT WILL BE NEEDED TO MEET DEMANDS FROM STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES FOR TRAINED POLLINATOR SCIENTISTS.THE THREE MAJOR PARTNERS INCLUDE:THE USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM (USGS CRU OR CRU, THE USGS EASTERN ECOLOGICAL SCIENCE CENTER (USGS EESC OR EESC), THE POLISTES FOUNDATION.POLISTES WILL PROVIDE STAFF SUPPORT TO THE PROJECT WHICH WILL BE FUNDED THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. POLISTES WILL HAVE FULL DISCRETION IN HIRING STAFF TO IMPLEMENT THIS PROJECT. POLISTES FOUNDATION STAFF WILL COORDINATE CLOSELY WITH THE USGS CRU CHIEF AND OTHER CRU AND EESC LEADERSHIP, AS APPROPRIATE, THROUGHOUT THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT.ANTICIPATED OUTREACH AND FURTHER PARTNER ENGAGEMENT: THROUGH THE COMBINED EFFORTS OF CRU, EESC, AND POLISTES, ANTICIPATED OPPORTUNITIES FOR ENGAGEMENT WITH ADDITIONAL FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL PARTNERS IN THE COMBINED EFFORTS TO ADVANCE POLLINATOR SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 28PROJECT TITLE: MONITORING AND TECHNICAL TRANSFER TO IMPROVE EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ACTIONS IN THE SAGEBRUSH BIOMETHE RECENTLY RELEASED SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION DESIGN PROVIDES PERSPECTIVE ON THE STAGGERING LOSS OF INTACT SAGEBRUSH RANGELANDS IN THE WESTERN US, AND HIGHLIGHTS THE NEED FOR STRATEGIC, PROACTIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO DEFEND AND GROW CORE SAGEBRUSH RANGELANDS. TO OUTPACE THIS DECLINE, MANAGERS MUST USE THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND HARNESS DATA, INFORMATION, AND PRACTITIONER KNOWLEDGE TO GUIDE THEIR EFFORTS TOWARD CONSERVATION OF INTACT CORE RANGELANDS AND RESTORATION OF AREAS TO STRATEGICALLY GROW THE CORE. MILLIONS OF ACRES OF CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ACTIONS HAVE OCCURRED IN SAGEBRUSH RANGELANDS ACROSS PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS, BUT TREATMENT SUCCESS RATES ARE HIGHLY VARIABLE AND INFORMATION TO GUIDE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT IS OFTEN LACKING.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLECT AND CURATE INFORMATION TO HELP ADAPTIVELY MANAGE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION TREATMENTS IN THE SAGEBRUSH BIOME. THIS WORK WILL ADVANCE PROGRESS TOWARD THIS GOAL BY EFFICIENTLY GENERATING INFORMATION ABOUT TREATMENT OUTCOMES WITHIN MULTIPLE TREATED AREAS IN OREGON, INCLUDING BOTH RECENT TREATMENTS AND TREATMENTS CONDUCTED SEVERAL YEARS AGO, TO HELP DETERMINE IF AND WHERE TREATMENTS WERE EFFECTIVE IN RESTORING FUNCTIONAL SAGEBRUSH STEPPE HABITAT. THIS DATA WILL FEED INTO TECHNICAL TOOLS AND DATA REPOSITORIES SUCH AS THE CONSERVATION EFFORTS DATABASE, LAND TREATMENT DIGITAL LIBRARY, AND LAND TREATMENT EXPLORATION TOOL TO FACILITATE DATA ACCESS AND KNOWLEDGE SHARING AMONG A WIDE AUDIENCE OF SCIENTISTS, MANAGERS AND PRACTITIONERS.IN THE SUMMER OF 2023, SCIENTISTS AND FIELD TECHNICIANS FROM THE INSTITUTE FOR NATURAL RESOURCES AT OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY WILL COLLECT FIELD DATA AT 115-120 LOCATIONS WITHIN AND ADJACENT TO TREATMENT AREAS. METHODS INCLUDE QUANTITATIVE LINE POINT INTERCEPT AT A SUBSET OF PLOTS AS WELL AS RAPID QUALITATIVE COVER ASSESSMENT AND ECOSTATE ASSESSMENT AT MULTIPLE SITES WITHIN EACH TREATMENT PERIMETER. THIS DATA WILL BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH EXISTING ON-THE-GROUND DATA (E.G., EXISTING ASSESSMENT INVENTORY AND MONITORING PLOTS ON PUBLIC LAND) AND REMOTELY SENSED DATASETS TO EVALUATE TREATMENT OUTCOMES. INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE USED TO INFORM THE EFFICACY AND METHODS NEEDED FOR MEANINGFUL EVALUATION OF TREATMENT EFFECTIVENESS AND SUPPORT EFFORTS TO BETTER INTEGRATE MONITORING DATA INTO DECISION-MAKING. THE INSTITUTE FOR NATURAL RESOURCES WILL COLLECT FIELD DATA, ASSIST USGS AND PARTNERS IN SYNTHESIZING DATA AND INFORMATION INTO USEFUL AND ACTIONABLE SUMMARIES, AND MAY ASSIST WITH TECHNICAL TRANSFER AND KNOWLEDGE SHARING RELATED TO RESTORATION ACTIVITIES IN FUTURE YEARS.

PROJECT TITLE: ENHANCING THE DELIVERY OF COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SCIENCE: A COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN OAK GROVE INITIATIVE AND THE USGS CRU PROGRAMPROJECT PERIOD: 08 14 2023  08 13 2024PROJECT ABSTRACT: THIS COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIP WILL ENGAGE CURRENT AND POTENTIAL COOPERATORS AND COLLABORATORS IN A ROBUST SERIES OF INVESTIGATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS. STAFF FROM THE CRU PROGRAM AND OGI WILL DEVELOP A SHARED VISION FOR COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SCIENCE THAT CAN HELP GUIDE THE PRODUCTION OF COLLABORATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SCIENCE AND RESEARCH FOR MANY YEARS TO COME.THE USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM (USGS CRU OR CRU), WHICH CONDUCTS ORIGINAL SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH ON A BROAD RANGE OF FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE SCIENCE TOPICS, INCLUDING THE BIOLOGY, IDENTIFICATION, AND CONSERVATION OF NATIVE POLLINATORS, AND WHICH PROVIDES TRAINING TO OVER 600 STUDENTS ANNUALLY THROUGH COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIPS WITH 43 UNIVERSITIES AND INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION IN 41 STATES.  THE CRU PROGRAM HAS EXISTING COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIPS WITH 43 STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES WHO PARTICIPATE IN REGULAR DISCUSSIONS WITH THE INDIVIDUAL CRUS.  THE CRU CHIEF AND OTHER CRU STAFF, AS APPROPRIATE, WILL DEDICATE TIME TO THIS PROJECT.THE OAK GROVE INITIATIVE (OGI), A FISCALLY SPONSORED ORGANIZATION UNDER A 501(C)(3) UMBRELLA, RECOMMENDS POLICIES TO DECISION-MAKERS AND DELIVERS ON-THE-GROUND PROJECT SUPPORT THROUGH PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR THE BENEFIT OF COMMUNITIES AND CONSERVATION. OGI ALSO SUPPORTS GOVERNMENT AGENCIES BY MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE THEIR INTERNAL PROCESSES AND POLICIES TO DELIVER CONSERVATION AND NATURAL-RESOURCE BENEFITS.  MARGARET EVERSON SERVES AS OGIS EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND WORKS WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS BOARD AND STAFF TO IMPLEMENT ITS MISSION. AS THE FIRST PERSON TO LEAD BOTH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, MARGARET IS A PROVEN LEADER IN NATURAL RESOURCES AND CONSERVATION. IN 2020, MARGARET CHAIRED THE TASK FORCE FOR IMPLEMENTING THE GREAT AMERICAN OUTDOORS ACT, OVERSEEING THE PROVISION OF NEARLY  2 BILLION ANNUALLY FOR DEFERRED MAINTENANCE TO FEDERAL AGENCIES AND  900 MILLION FOR THE LAND AND WATER CONSERVATION FUND. SHE SPEARHEADED THE CREATION OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICES BUSINESS AND STRATEGIC INVESTMENT PLAN TO MANAGE AN ADDITIONAL  1.2 BILLION IN DISCRETIONARY FUNDS PROVIDED THROUGH THIS ACT TO ADDRESS MAINTENANCE AND BACKLOG ISSUES.DELIVERABLES: SIGNIFICANT FINDINGS ARE ANTICIPATED RELEVANT TO THE PRODUCTION OF COLLABORATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SCIENCE IN THE UNITED STATES.  THE MAJOR FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED WITH SENIOR CRU LEADERSHIP AND KEY PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, AGENCIES, AND COLLABORATORS THROUGH A SERIES OF REPORTS AND IN-PERSON TEAMS PRESENTATIONS.  AT MINIMUM, DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A BEST PRACTICES GUIDE FOR THE COLLABORATIVE PRODUCTION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SCIENCE, AND WILL ALSO INCLUDE A SET OF MORE DETAILED AND SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONSIDERATION BY THE COOP PROGRAM AS A WHOLE, ITS 43 INDIVIDUAL UNITS, AND ITS DOZENS OF CURRENT PARTNERS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT NSETGRANTEE NAME: NATIONAL SOCIETY FOR EARTHQUAKE TECHNOLOGY-NEPAL (NSET)FAIN NUMBER: G23AC00524PROJECT TITLE: TOWARDS THE DEVELOPMENT OF SEISMIC HAZARDS ASSESSMENT AND RISK MITIGATION CAPABILITIES IN NEPAL.  PROJECT PERIOD: 25 JULY 2023  24 JULY 2025BUDGET PERIOD: 25 JULY 2023  24 JULY 2024AWARD PURPOSE: BUILDING ON THE MOMENTUM OF AN INITIAL EARTHQUAKE DISASTER ASSISTANCE TEAM (EDAT) MISSION TO NEPAL FOLLOWING THE 25 APRIL 2015 GORKHA EARTHQUAKE, THE OFFICE OF FOREIGN DISASTER ASSISTANCE (OFDA) PROVIDED SUPPORT TO THE USGS TO CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE WITH AND PROVIDE TRAINING FOR NEPALESE EARTHQUAKE PROFESSIONALS.  USAID PROVIDED FUNDING TO CONTINUE THIS PARTNERSHIP IN FY17, INCLUDING A WEEK-LONG TRAINING WORKSHOP TO BE HELD IN KATHMANDU IN MAY 2017, AND A TRAINING AND PLANNING VISIT BY NSET PERSONNEL TO THE USGS.  ADDITIONAL FUNDING WAS PROVIDED IN 2018. DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, MANY OF THE PLANNED ACTIVITIES IN 2020 WERE POSTPONED.  IN-PERSON TRAINING AND STRATEGIC PLANNING ACTIVITIES CONTINUED THROUGH 2019  SINCE EARLY 2020, ACTIVITIES CONTINUED WITH ONLINE ENGAGEMENT.  IN FY23 THE USAID BUREAU OF HUMANITARIAN AFFAIRS (BHA) PROVIDED FUNDING TO SUPPORT RENEWED ENGAGEMENT BETWEEN THE USGS AND NSET.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE FOCUS OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE THREEFOLD: 1) TO CONTINUE WORK TOWARDS CREATION OF A NATIONAL PSHA (PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT) PROGRAM IN NEPAL, UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND GEOLOGY, WITH NSET SERVING AS THE SECRETARIAT, 2) TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO NSET AND OTHER PARTNER AGENCIES REGARDING PSHA, AND 3) TO SUPPORT NSET ENGAGEMENT WITH REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS.  THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ADVANCE NSETS ONGOING EFFORTS IN EARTHQUAKE RISK REDUCTION IN NEPAL AND CONTRIBUTE TO SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE USAID-SUPPORTED PHASE II EDAT MISSION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RESULT 1: FORMATION OF A CONSORTIUM OF INSTITUTIONS AND EXPERTS TO PROVIDE AN INSTITUTIONAL SYSTEM OF SEISMIC STUDIES IN NEPAL. THIS PLATFORM WILL CONTINUOUSLY WORK TO UPDATE THE SEISMIC HAZARD AND RISK MODELS AND MAPS FOR NEPAL. A SYSTEM OF REGULAR ANNUAL AND SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS WILL ALSO BE ESTABLISHED.RESULT 2: MORE SEISMIC DATA WILL BE COLLECTED WHICH ARE CRUCIAL FOR NEPAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL AND EVALUATION.RESULT 3: ENHANCED CAPACITY OF THE NEPALI PROFESSIONALS ON SEISMIC HAZARD STUDIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE USGS, NEPAL AND THE PUBLIC.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.
JOINT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED POST-FIRE DEBRIS-FLOW HAZARD ASSESSMENT IN WASHINGTON

PROJECT TITLE: SOUTHEASTERN ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN STRATIGRAPHIC AND NOMENCLATURAL EQUIVALENCY AND RECONCILIATIONPROJECTPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THE STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS OF VIRGINIA, NORTH CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA, AND FLORIDA WILL COOPERATE ON A PROJECT TO MAKE IT EASIER TO COMPARE ROCK LAYERS IN THE AREA. BY DOING THIS, THEY WILL CREATE IMPROVED MAPS AND EVENTUALLY A NATIONAL GEOLOGIC MAP. THEY WILL UPDATE EXISTING INFORMATION ON ROCK LAYERS AND GET MORE ACCURATE DATES FOR HOW OLD THEY ARE. THEY WILL ALSO WORK TOGETHER TO SOLVE ANY PROBLEMS THEY FIND. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A FINAL REPORT AND NEW CHARTS AND TABLES. EACH STATE WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THEIR OWN PART OF THE PROJECT, AND THE FINAL REPORT WILL BE PRODUCED BY THE GROUP. ULTIMATELY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP MAKE IT EASIER TO UNDERSTAND THE GEOLOGY OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE SOUTH CAROLINA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (SCGS) WILL COORDINATE A SOUTHEASTERN ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN STRATIGRAPHIC WORKING GROUP THAT WILL DEVELOP A CONSISTENT REGIONAL STRATIGRAPHIC NOMENCLATURAL FRAMEWORK AND CREATE A WORKFLOW FOR IDENTIFYING AND RESOLVING ISSUES. THE GROUP WILL CREATE UPDATED INTERSTATE AND REGIONAL STRATIGRAPHIC CHARTS AND CROSS SECTIONS, PUBLISH UPDATED VERSIONS OF THE FINAL PRODUCTS, AND ENSURE THAT ROCK UNIT DESCRIPTIONS IN GEOLEX REFLECT CURRENT KNOWLEDGE. WORK ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:1) COMPILE EXISTING STRATIGRAPHIC DATA FOR USERS,2) IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE UNRESOLVED STRATIGRAPHIC ISSUES FOR FUTURE WORK AND DRAFT A PLAN FORFUTURE COOPERATIVE PROJECTS FOCUSED ON RESOLVING OUTSTANDING ISSUES,3) USING NEW AGE-DATING RESULTS, DEVELOP A WORKING STRATIGRAPHIC CHART OF UNITS, AND4) UPDATE GEOLEX WITH REFINED TERMINOLOGY.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1) SUMMARY NOTES FROM ALL WORKSHOP MEETINGS AND ACTION ITEMS DEVELOPED2) STATE STRATIGRAPHIC TABLES AND REGIONAL STRATIGRAPHIC CORRELATION CHARTS3) DATA INVENTORY OF RELEVANT MATERIALS FOR THE SOUTHEASTERN ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN4) A DRAFT PLAN FOR FUTURE COOPERATIVE PROJECT(S)5) NOMENCLATURE CHANGES - DOCUMENTED IN FORMAL-SERIES PUBLICATIONSINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STATE AGENCIES INCLUDING DEPARTMENTS OF TRANSPORTATION, SOUTH CAROLINA OFFICE OF RESILIENCE, NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION. ADDITIONALLY, ALL USERS OF GEOLOGIC MAPS AND INFORMATION (ACADEMICS, CONSULTANTS, BUILDERS, LAND-USE PLANNERS) WILL BENEFIT FROM COORDINATED STRATIGRAPHIC WORK EXTENDING ACROSS STATE LINES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: SUBRECIPIENTS WILL CONDUCT INVENTORIES OF AVAILABLE CORES, HAND SAMPLES, GEOPHYSICAL LOGS, OUTCROPS, PUBLICATIONS, AND OTHER RELATED STRATIGRAPHIC INFORMATION, AND WILL ASSESS GAPS IN THESE DATASETS. SUBRECIPIENTS WILL ALSO PRODUCE STATE-LEVEL STRATIGRAPHIC TABLES AND CORRELATION CHARTS, AND THE COOPERATIVE GROUP WILL CREATE A WORKING REGIONAL CORRELATION CHART. PARTNERS WILL SAMPLE UNITS IN THE FIELD THAT ARE CURRENTLY UNRESOLVED AND WILL SEND SAMPLES FOR GEOCHRONOLOGY ANALYSES TO BETTER CONSTRAIN DEPOSITIONAL AGES OF IDENTIFIED STRATA. ALL SUBRECIPIENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN TWO WORKSHOPS TO IDENTIFY ZONES OF AGREEMENT OF UNIT EQUIVALENCY BETWEEN STATES AND IDENTIFY WHERE ADDITIONAL WORK IS NEEDED. ALL SUBRECIPIENTS WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO A DRAFT PLAN FOR FUTURE PROJECTS AIMED AT RESOLVING REMAINING STRATIGRAPHIC ISSUES BETWEEN NEIGHBORING STATES IN THE SOUTHEAST. COPIES OF ANY FORMAL-SERIES PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING NOMENCLATURAL CHANGES WILL BE PROVIDED.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 24PROJECT TITLE: INTEGRATING EDDMAPS INTO THE NATIONAL EDRR FRAMEWORKTHE NATIONAL EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) INFORMATION SYSTEM IS WEB TOOL BEING DEVELOPED TO UNITE INVASIVE SPECIES EFFORTS THAT SUPPORT A NATIONAL EDRR FRAMEWORK. THE AIM OF THE NATIONAL EDRR INFORMATION SYSTEM IS TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO EXISTING AND EMERGING INVASIVE SPECIES INFORMATION RESOURCES AND FACILITATE EDRR COLLABORATION ACROSS THE US STATES AND TERRITORIES.  EDDMAPS (WWW.EDDMAPS.ORG) WAS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE A MORE ACCURATE PICTURE OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES. EDDMAPS ALLOWS LAND MANAGERS, AGENCIES AND OTHERS TO SET PRIORITIES FOR EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE AND FORMULATE OVERALL INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT ACTION PLANS. IT IS A TOOL TO DEVELOP MORE COMPLETE LOCAL, STATE AND REGIONAL LEVEL DISTRIBUTION DATA OF INVASIVE SPECIES, IDENTIFY LEADING EDGE RANGES OF NEW INVASIVE THREATS, PROVIDE A MEANS OF IMPLEMENTING EDRR, AND HELP CORROBORATE THREATS AND REFINE INVASIVE SPECIES LISTS AND MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES.  EDDMAPS IS ACTIVELY USED ACROSS THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA.  EDDMAPS CURRENTLY CONTAINS 7.6 MILLION OCCURRENCE RECORDS FROM 42,436 REPORTERS SOURCES COVERING 5629 SPECIES.   THIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE EDDMAPS INTO THE NATIONAL EDRR INFORMATION SYSTEM AND INTEGRATE INFORMATION AND RESOURCES FROM THE NATIONAL EDRR INFORMATION SYSTEM INTO EDDMAPS TO BETTER SUPPORT THE NEEDS OF THE PUBLIC, PROFESSIONALS AND RESEARCHERS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 15 23-8 14 24PROJECT TITLE: FUNCTIONAL CHARACTERIZATION OF THE PHYSIOLOGICAL FUNCTION OF FATHEAD MINNOWS (PIMEPHALES PROMELAS) RAISED ACROSS DIFFERENT THERMAL REGIMESTO SURVIVE THERMAL STRESS, MANY ORGANISMS MUST INDUCE COSTLY PHYSIOLOGICAL MODIFICATIONS THAT REQUIRE AN INCREASE IN OXYGEN DEMAND LEADING TO HIGHER METABOLIC RATES.  SUSTAINED INCREASES IN METABOLIC RATE CAN LEAD TO DEPLETION OF ENERGETIC RESERVES REQUIRED FOR AEROBIC RESPIRATION THAT ULTIMATELY IMPEDE AN ORGANISMS ABILITY TO RESPOND TO THERMAL STRESS. THUS, THERMAL TOLERANCE IS CLOSELY LINKED TO AN ORGANISMS CAPACITY TO MAINTAIN A HIGHER AEROBIC METABOLIC RATE. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL INVESTIGATE CHANGES IN METABOLIC AND PHYSIOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS IN RESPONSE TO CHRONIC THERMAL STRESS IN AN EFFORT TO ADVANCE OUR SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN AN ORGANISMS METABOLIC CAPACITY AND THEIR THERMAL TOLERANCE LIMITS. IN THIS PROJECT WE WILL USE THE FATHEAD MINNOW (PIMEPHALES PROMELAS) AS A MODEL SPECIES TO DETERMINE HOW VARIATION IN METABOLIC AND PHYSIOLOGICAL MECHANISMS CONTRIBUTE TO DIFFERENCES IN THERMAL TOLERANCE BY COMPARING TWO DISTINCT POPULATIONS THAT ORIGINATE FROM TEMPERATE LATITUDINAL. ADULT FATHEAD MINNOWS WILL BE COLLECTED FROM NORTHERN ALABAMA AND MINNESOTA TO GENERATE POPULATION-SPECIFIC COHORTS OF OFFSPRING THAT WILL BE RAISED UNDER CONTROLLED EXPERIMENTAL CONDITIONS TO ADULTHOOD UNDER DIFFERENT THERMAL REGIMES (20, 24 AND 28 C). IN ADDITION TO MEASURING TEMPERATURE-DEPENDENT CHANGES IN EARLY LARVAL GROWTH, A SERIES OF METABOLIC AND PHYSIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENTS WILL BE PERFORMED AT 3, 6 AND 9 MONTHS OF AGE UNDER EXPERIMENTAL TEMPERATURES, AS WELL AS AFTER A SERIES OF SECONDARY ACUTE TEMPERATURE CHALLENGES. TEMPERATURE-DEPENDENT CHANGES IN GLYCOGEN AND TRIGLYCERIDE LEVELS WILL BE COUPLED WITH MEASURABLE CHANGES IN ACTIVITY OF KEY MITOCHONDRIAL ENZYMES AND GATEWAY ENZYMES FOR THE CARBOHYDRATE FLUX IN AEROBIC VERSUS ANAEROBIC PATHWAYS.  IN ADDITION, WE WILL COMPARE WHOLE ORGANISM AEROBIC SCOPE AS DETERMINED BY INTERMITTENT-FLOW RESPIROMETRY AGAINST MITOCHONDRIAL OXYGEN CONSUMPTION AS DETERMINED BY THE IN VITRO ELECTRON TRANSPORT SYSTEM (ETS) ASSAY.  THESE CHANGES IN ENERGY USAGE, AND METABOLIC AND PHYSIOLOGICAL PROCESSES WILL BE PHENOTYPICALLY ANCHORED TO GLOBAL GENE EXPRESSION PATTERNS TO DEVELOP GENE REGULATORY NETWORKS THAT CAN ELUCIDATE COMPLEX CELLULAR MECHANISMS RELATED TO DIFFERENCES IN THERMAL TOLERANCE.  THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE GREATER INSIGHT INTO THE DEGREE OF PHYSIOLOGICAL PLASTICITY OF FATHEAD MINNOWS FROM DIFFERENT LATITUDINAL POPULATIONS. IN ADDITION, THE USE OF LONG-TERM THERMAL CHALLENGES WILL EXPAND OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPORTANCE OF PHYSIOLOGICAL ACCLIMATION TO THERMAL TOLERANCE AND HOW PHYSIOLOGICAL ACCLIMATION EFFECTS THERMAL SENSITIVITY OF THE OXYGEN CONSUMPTION RATE.  FINALLY, THE COMPLETION OF THE PROPOSED EXPERIMENTS WILL ALLOW US TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL ROLE OF THE ETS ASSAY TO SERVE AS A PHYSIOLOGICAL PROXY FOR ASSESSING THERMAL TOLERANCE AS COMPARED TO MORE COMPLEX ASSESSMENTS, SUCH AS RESPIROMETRY AND OTHER METABOLIC OR PHYSIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENTS.  TO VALIDATE THE UTILITY OF THE ETS ASSAY, WE WILL ALSO MEASURE MITOCHONDRIAL OXYGEN CONSUMPTION FROM TISSUE SAMPLES TAKEN FROM A RANGE OF MULTIPLE POIKILOTHERMIC FISH SPECIES WITH PRESUMED DIFFERENCES IN THERMAL TOLERANCE.  INFORMATION GAINED FROM THE PROPOSED EXPERIMENTS WILL BE COMBINED WITH OBSERVATIONS OF SPECIES ABUNDANCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS TO DEVELOP PHYSIOLOGICALLY-GUIDED ABUNDANCE MODELS THAT COULD BE USED TO AID RESEARCHERS AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES IN PREDICTING SPECIES GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTIONS AND ABUNDANCE IN RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. SUCH MODELS CAN INCORPORATE VARIABILITY IN LABORATORY-DERIVED THERMAL RESPONSE CURVES BASED ON POPULATION OF ORIGIN AND OR REARING TEMPERATURES TO PROVIDE RANGE-WIDE ESTIMATES OF THERMAL HABITAT SUITABILITY AND EXTINCTION PROBABILITY UNDER FUTURE TEMPERATURE SCENARIOS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 7 23-8 6 24PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING POPULATION STATUS AND TRENDS OF OF TRANSBOUNDARY BULL TROUT POPULATIONSAWARD PURPOSE:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH FOCUSED ON THE CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF BULL TROUT (SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS), A SIGNIFICANT COLD-WATER SALMONID SPECIES IN THE TRANSBOUNDARY REGIONS OF THE ST. MARY AND KOOTENAI RIVER SYSTEMS. BULL TROUT POPULATIONS IN THESE AREAS HAVE EXPERIENCED DECLINES IN ABUNDANCE IN PREVIOUS CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND ANGLING REGULATIONS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO COMPREHENSIVELY EVALUATE THE CURRENT STATUS OF BULL TROUT POPULATIONS AND INVESTIGATE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF CHANGES IN WATER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON THEIR ABUNDANCE AND POPULATION TRENDS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE AWARDED PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AN IN-DEPTH STUDY UTILIZING BIOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING DATA TO CREATE AN INTEGRATED BULL TROUT POPULATION MODEL. BY INCORPORATING VARIOUS DATA SETS SUCH AS BULL TROUT REDD (SPAWNING NESTS) AND JUVENILE DATA, ALONG WITH ABIOTIC FACTORS LIKE TEMPERATURE AND DISCHARGE, AND BIOTIC FACTORS LIKE FISH COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE SPECIES, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE FACTORS INFLUENCING BULL TROUT POPULATION DYNAMICS. THIS INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELING FRAMEWORK WILL ALLOW FOR A DETAILED ASSESSMENT OF HOW BULL TROUT POPULATIONS ARE CHANGING OVER TIME AND SPACE, AS WELL AS IDENTIFYING THE KEY ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS CONTRIBUTING TO THESE CHANGES. THROUGH THESE ACTIVITIES, THE PROJECT SEEKS TO PROVIDE CRUCIAL INSIGHTS THAT WILL INFORM EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE TRANSBOUNDARY BULL TROUT POPULATIONS IN THE ST. MARY AND KOOTENAI RIVER SYSTEMS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1)INTEGRATED BULL TROUT POPULATION MODEL AND ASSESSMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS: THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE AND ROBUST BULL TROUT POPULATION MODEL THAT INCORPORATES BIOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATA WILL PROVIDE A VALUABLE TOOL FOR ASSESSING THE CURRENT STATE OF BULL TROUT POPULATIONS AND PREDICTING THEIR FUTURE TRENDS UNDER DIFFERENT SCENARIOS.2)RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONSERVATION STRATEGIES: BASED ON THE ANALYSIS OF THE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL AND ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS, THE PROJECT CAN PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED CONSERVATION STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE THE DECLINES IN BULL TROUT POPULATIONS. THESE RECOMMENDATIONS MAY INVOLVE ADJUSTMENTS IN WATER MANAGEMENT, HABITAT RESTORATION, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, OR OTHER TARGETED INTERVENTIONS.3)STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT: THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE COLLABORATION WITH VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. ENGAGING THESE STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT THE RESEARCH PROCESS WILL FOSTER KNOWLEDGE SHARING AND ENHANCE THE IMPACT OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS.4)SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS: THE PROJECTS FINDINGS WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION(S), CONTRIBUTING TO THE BROADER BODY OF KNOWLEDGE ON BULL TROUT CONSERVATION AND PROVIDING A VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND POLICYMAKINGINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STATE (E.G., MONTANA FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PARKS) AND FEDERAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES (E.G., NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, BUREAU OF RECLAMATION) MANAGING TRANSBOUNDARY BULL TROUT POPULATIONS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 24PROJECT TITLE: QUANTIFYING RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN REMOTELY SENSED RIPARIAN AND UPLAND WETLAND AREAS AND STREAM TEMPERATURE AND FLOW IN THE UPPER DONNER UND BLITZEN RIVER BASINUNDERSTANDING OF LINKAGES BETWEEN RIVERINE AND UPLAND HYDROLOGIC PROCESSES IN THE GREAT BASIN IS NEEDED TO INFORM DECISION-MAKING AND PROTECT THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE WATER-SUPPLY RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL USE REMOTELY SENSED IMAGERY (E.G., LIDAR, THERMAL INFRARED, AND TRUE COLOR) AND OTHER SPATIALDATA SOURCES TO IDENTIFY AND MAP WETLAND AREAS IN RANGELANDS. THIS RESEARCH WILL IMPROVE CHARACTERIZATION, MODELING, AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHYSICAL PROPERTIES AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF TOPOGRAPHIC FEATURES ASSOCIATED WITH DROUGHT RESISTANCE, WHICH MAY BE CORRELATED WITH GROUNDWATER INPUTS AND COOL-WATER AREAS IN RIVERSCAPES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS WILL COLLABORATE IN PRODUCING MODELS AND FINAL PRODUCTS THAT QUANTIFY ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN WETLAND AREAS AND STREAM TEMPERATURE AND FLOW IN THE DONNER UND BLITZEN RIVER BASIN.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 15 23-8 14 24PROJECT TITLE: HAYWIRED SCENARIO TOOLKIT OUTREACHTHE PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON PREVIOUS SUPPORT THAT CREATED AND PUBLISHED THE HAYWIRED SCENARIO EXERCISE TOOLKIT AND 17 SETS OF FACILITATOR TOOLS AND OFFERED 4 IN-PERSON TRAINING WORKSHOPS (SEE WWW.EARTHQUAKECOUNTRY.ORG HAYWIRED). EACH FACILITATOR TOOL SET INCLUDES A FACILITATOR GUIDE AND AN IMAGERY SLIDE SET. WITH NEW SUPPORT, 3 NEW SETS OF TOOLS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND PUBLISHED, AND 8 TOOLKIT WORKSHOPS WILL BE FACILITATED IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO MAKE THE FINDINGS OF THE USGS HAYWIRED EARTHQUAKE SCENARIO (MAGNITUDE 7.0 ON THE HAYWARD FAULT) ACCESSIBLE FOR MITIGATION, PREPAREDNESS, RESPONSE, AND RECOVERY EXERCISES. THE AUDIENCES OF THESE WORKSHOPS AND TOOLS ARE BUSINESS CONTINUITY AND RECOVERY PLANNERS AND ORGANIZATIONS WITH BUSINESS INTERESTS (E.G., ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE), AND GOVERNMENT PARTNERS WHO COORDINATE WITH THESE GROUPS.THE HAYWIRED EXERCISE TOOLKIT IS A MULTI-AGENCY EFFORT WHICH INCLUDES THE USGS, SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE CENTER (SCEC), EARTHQUAKE COUNTRY ALLIANCE (ECA), CALIFORNIA OFFICE OF EMERGENCY SERVICES, CALIFORNIA SEISMIC SAFETY COMMISSION, CALIFORNIA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, FEDERAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY, AND CALIFORNIA RESILIENCE ALLIANCE (CRA). SCEC (WHICH ADMINISTERS ECA) AND THE CRA WILL IMPLEMENT THE 8 NEW WORKSHOPS AND 3 NEW TOOLS. WITH USGS SUPPORT, SCEC ECA AND CRA WILL: FACILITATE FOUR HAYWIRED SCENARIO TOOLKIT WORKSHOPS BASED ON EXISTING TOOLS (EACH WITH 40-80 ATTENDEES)DEVELOP AND PUBLISH THREE NEW TOOLS FOR THE HAYWIRED SCENARIO TOOLKIT INCLUDING ONE THAT ADDRESSES THE THEME OF FOOD SUPPLY SECURITY (ALL WILL BE ADDED TO WWW.EARTHQUAKECOUNTRY.ORG HAYWIRED TOOLKIT)  AND IMPLEMENT FOUR ADDITIONAL TOOLKIT WORKSHOPS BASED ON THE NEW TOOLS (EACH WITH 40-80 ATTENDEES).AS A SUBRECIPIENT, CRA SPECIFICALLY WILL:DEVELOP NEW TOOLS: IN ADDITION TO A NEW FOOD SUPPLY SECURITY TOOL, CRA WILL RECOMMEND TWO OTHER TOOLS AND ONCE APPROVED DRAFT THE CONTENT OF EACH TOOL, INCLUDING COORDINATION WITH USGS FOR POTENTIAL DATA AND CHARTS IMAGERY NEEDED IF NOT ALREADY WITHIN EXISTING HAYWIRED REPORTS AND THE FOOD SECURITY DATA BEING DEVELOPED. THE NEW TOOLS WILL BE COMPLETE BY OCTOBER 31.  CO-FACILITATE TRAINING WORKSHOPS: CRA WILL DEVELOP, PROMOTE, AND IMPLEMENT EIGHT 3-4 HOUR WORKSHOPS WITH 40-80 ATTENDEES EACH, FOCUSED ON BUSINESS AND COMMUNITY GROUPS, INCLUDING WITHIN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.

PROJECT TITLE: NATIONAL GEOLOGIC MAP DATABASE SUPPORTPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8 16 2023 THROUGH 8 15 2027AWARD PURPOSE: TO COMPILE AND EDIT THE PROCEEDINGS VOLUMES FOR PREVIOUS DIGITAL MAPPING TECHNIQUES (DMT) WORKSHOPS  ORGANIZE AND HOST WEBINAR TRAINING FOR NGMDB-RELATED OBJECTIVES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: (1) DIGITAL MAPPING TECHNIQUES (DMT) MEETING PLANNING AND OPERATION  (2) PUBLICATION OF DMT PROCEEDINGS  (3) PRODUCE AND HOST DMT WEBINAR  AND (4) DMT WORKING GROUP COORDINATION DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: FINALIZED DMT PROCEEDINGS, WORKING GROUP REPORTS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STATE AND ACADEMIC ENTITIES PRODUCING GEOLOGIC MAPS  NGMDB STAFFSUBRECIPIENTS: N A

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE: PUERTO RICO LANDSLIDE HAZARD REDUCTION PROJECT 2023-2026PROJECT PERIOD: 08 31 2023- 07 31 2026 AWARD PURPOSETHE PROJECT WILL FACILITATE LANDSLIDE HAZARD SCIENCE, RESEARCH, AND DATA COLLECTION IN PUERTO RICO.  LANDSLIDES AFFECT U.S. CITIZENS IN PUERTO RICO DISPROPORTIONATELY COMPARED TO THEIR CONTINENTAL COUNTERPARTS. MORE THAN 1 MILLION RESIDENTS OF PUERTO RICO ARE VULNERABLE TO THE EFFECTS OF MASS WASTING AND LANDSLIDES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH DISASTER DECLARATIONS THERE NEARLY EVERY YEAR.  THIS AWARD EXPANDS ON A STANDING AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE USGS LANDSLIDE HAZARDS PROGRAM AND THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MAYAGUEZ TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE A NEAR-REAL-TIME SOIL HYDROLOGICAL MONITORING NETWORK. THE NEW AGREEMENT WILL HELP EXPAND THE CURRENT HYDROLOGICAL MONITORING NETWORK (FROM 15 CURRENT STATIONS TO AT LEAST 20 STATIONS), AND PROVIDE A MEANS TO MAINTAIN THE NETWORK FUNCTIONAL THEREBY COMPLEMENTING A NEW PUERTO RICO LANDSLIDE HAZARD MITIGATION OFFICE ON-CAMPUS AT UPRM. THE GOAL OF THE RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION ENDEAVOR IS TO DEVELOP LANDSLIDE FORECASTING METRICS ACROSS THE ISLAND TERRITORY TO BE USED IN AN OPERATION SYSTEM.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDTHE CURRENT PROJECT AIMS TO EXPAND AND FORMALIZE THESE EFFORTS TO REDUCE LANDSLIDE HAZARDS IN PUERTO RICO VIA RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION THAT COMPLEMENTS A NEW PUERTO RICO LANDSLIDE HAZARD MITIGATION OFFICE ON-CAMPUS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MAYAGUEZ. THIS CENTER OF RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WILL BE DIRECTED BY FACULTY IN THE INSTITUTIONS GEOLOGY AND CIVIL ENGINEERING DEPARTMENTS AND COLLABORATE VERY CLOSELY WITH THE USGS LANDSLIDE HAZARDS PROGRAM. SUPPORT OF RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION CARRIED OUT BY THE NEW LANDSLIDE HAZARD MITIGATION OFFICE WILL BE USED IN A DEDICATED PHYSICAL SPACE OF APPROXIMATELY 1,000 SQUARE FEET, AND ALSO PROVIDE A SUITABLE FIELD VEHICLE FOR RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION FOR THE PROJECT. THE OFFICE SPACE WILL HOUSE MONITORING, RESEARCH, AND ANALYSIS FOR RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION FOR THE PROJECT. IN ADDITION, FUNDS WILL BE USED TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF MONITORING STATIONS, MAINTAIN AND OR IMPROVE CURRENT NETWORK STATIONS, AND TO PROVIDE TELECOMMUNICATIONS, COMPUTING, AND ANALYSIS TOOLS NECESSARY FOR THE PROJECT. FUNDS EACH YEAR WILL ALSO BE USED FOR PARTIAL UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIPS. THE STUDENTS THAT ARE FUNDED BY THE PROGRAM WILL BE ACTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN DATA ANALYSIS, FIELD WORK, AND ALL RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION ACTIVITIES.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESIMPORTANT MILESTONES WILL INCLUDE:Y1:  ACQUISITION OF OFFICE LAB FIELD RESEARCH MATERIALS AND FIELD VEHICLE.Y1:  INSTALLATION OF AT LEAST 2 MORE MONITORING STATIONS.Y1:  INITIAL PRECIP SOIL MOISTURE THRESHOLDS DEVELOPED.  MS STUDENT COMPLETES THESIS. Y2:  INSTALLATION OF AT LEAST 2 MORE MONITORING STATIONSY2:  LANDSLIDE FORECAST SYSTEM EXPERIMENTAL VERSION 1. Y3:  INSTALLATION OF AT LEAST 2 MORE MONITORING STATIONSY3:  LANDSLIDE FORECAST SYSTEM EXPERIMENTAL VERSION 2. MS STUDENT COMPLETES THESIS. INTENDED BENEFICIARYTHIS PROJECT WILL BE A PIONEERING EFFORT TO ADDRESS THE LOCAL VULNERABILITY TO LANDSLIDING EFFECTS IN PUERTO RICO. THE AMERICAN CITIZENS THAT RESIDE IN PUERTO RICO IN ADDITION TO LOCAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING GROUPS, AMONG OTHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS OF THE PROJECT.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD.  NONE

PROJECT TITLE: COMMUNITY BASED WATER PLANNING  SURFACE WATERPROJECT PERIOD: 01 JULY 2023  31 MAY 2025BUDGET PERIOD: 01 JULY 2023  31 MAY 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THIS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AWARD WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT TWO MAJOR PROJECTS, AND THE WATER PLANNING EFFORT: 1) BEAVER SURVEY AND ANALYSIS OF HARNEY BASIN STREAMS, AND 2) SPRING FLOOD FLOW DISTRIBUTION MODELING OF THE HARNEY VALLEY UNDER DIFFERENT FLOW REGIMES.  FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE COMMUNITY BASED WATER PLANNING COLLABORATIVE THROUGH TO THE COMPLETION OF THE INTEGRATED WATER RESOURCES PLAN.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: BEAVER STUDY DELIVERABLES: MAPS SHOWING BEAVER LOCATIONS, POTENTIAL LOCATIONS AND PRIORITY REESTABLISHMENT SITES. REPORT DOCUMENTING POTENTIAL WATER AND CARBON STORAGE. SILVIES FLOOD FLOW STUDY DELIVERABLES: MEMO ON LIMITATIONS OF THE MODEL, REPORT ON THE MODEL RESULTS, 2-D MODEL OF THE FLOODPLAIN BETWEEN FIVE MILE DAM AND MALHEUR LAKE.A DRAFT INTEGRATED WATER RESOURCES PLAN AND REPORTS READY TO SUBMIT TO THE OREGON WATER RESOURCES COMMISSION FOR APPROVAL AND ADOPTION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE BEAVER STUDY WILL RESULT IN AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE WATER STORAGE POTENTIAL FROM BEAVER REINTRODUCTION AND PRIORITY LOCATIONS FOR SUCH ACTIONS. THE FLOW DISTRIBUTION STUDY WILL PROVIDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF AREAS FREQUENTLY FLOODED AS FLOODPLAIN RECHARGE AREAS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE INDIVIDUALS LIVING, WORKING, AND MANAGING LAND BOTH ON AND ADJACENT TO THE HARNEY BASIN. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: SUBRECIPIENTS CONTRACTORS WILL SUPPORT PROJECT EFFORTS IN THE FIELD AS WELL AS COLLECTING DATA. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: PLAN AND FACILITATE MONTHLY COLLABORATIVE MEETINGS.  WORK WITH WORK GROUPS  ECOLOGICAL, VEGETATION MGT, SURFACE WATER MGT AND SURFACE GROUNDWATER INTERACTION WORK GROUP. DEVELOP WRITTEN MATERIALS IN LINE WITH OWRD PLACE-BASED PLANNING GUIDANCE.

PROJECT TITLE: VT GEOLOGICAL MAP SCHEMA (GEMS)PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2027AWARD PURPOSE: TO UNIFY THE STANDARDS OF ALL GEOLOGICAL MAPS PRODUCED BY FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. INSUFFICIENT STAFFING WITHIN THE NGMDB CURRENTLY STYMIES THEIR ABILITY TO CARRY OUT THIS MISSION, AND THE VERMONT GEOLOGICAL SURVEY PROPOSES TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT PARTICULARLY AS IT RELATES TO STATES WITHIN THE NEW ENGLAND GEOLOGIC MAPPING COALITION (NEGMC).ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE VERMONT GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT OF THE GEMS STANDARD DATABASE SCHEMA, SPECIFICALLY HELPING TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS AND ISSUES POSED BY USERS TO THE USGS GEMS TECHNICAL SUPPORT GROUP, REGARDING THE SOFTWARE TOOLS AND WORKFLOWS THAT ARE NEEDED FOR STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS TO EFFICIENTLY IMPLEMENT GEMS. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH GEMS IMPLEMENTATION FOR THE NEW ENGLAND GEOLOGIC MAPPING COALITION (NEGMC), SPECIFICALLY PROVIDING GIS AND RELATED SUPPORT TO STATES THAT REQUEST IT,WITH THE GOAL OF PRODUCING PRIORITY GEOLOGIC MAPS THAT ARE GEMS COMPLIANT. THE RECIPIENT WILL DOCUMENT COMMON METHODS AND WORKFLOWS AS NEEDED AND PROVIDE THESE TO THE NGMDB. THE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE NGMDB, USGS, AND THE NEGMC WILL ALLOW FOR IDENTIFICATION OF COMMONALITIES IN CONTENT AND STRUCTURE FOR BOREHOLE DATABASES MANAGED BY THESE ENTITIES AND DETERMINE WHETHER IT IS FEASIBLE TO DESIGN A BOREHOLE DATA EXTENSION TABLE FOR THE GEMS SCHEMA.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE GEMS-COMPLIANT GEOLOGIC MAPS PRODUCED ON BEHALF OF OTHER STATES IN THE NEGMC  A DRAFT GEMS WORKFLOW FOR USE BY OTHER GEOLOGIC MAP CARTOGRAPHERS IN THE NEGMC  A BRIEF SYNTHESIS REPORT SUMMARIZING COMMONALITIES IN CONTENT AND STRUCTURE FOR BOREHOLE DATABASES MANAGED BY NEGMC STATES FOR A FEASIBILITY ASSESSMENT OF A GEMS BOREHOLE DATA EXTENSION TABLE  AND MEETING MINUTES FOR THE NEGMC OPEN OFFICE MEETINGS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS AWARD ARE RECIPIENT PARTNERS IN THE NATIONAL GEOLOGIC MAP DATABASE AT THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND OTHER MEMBER STATES IN THE NEGMC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 13 23-7 12 25PROJECT TITLE: RISK FROM TURBINES TO BALD AND GOLDEN EAGLES CROSSING THE GREAT LAKESTHIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW EAGLE FLIGHT BEHAVIOR MAY EXPOSE THEM TO RISK FROM OFFSHORE AND NEAR-SHORE WIND TURBINES IN THE GREAT LAKES. ITS FINDINGS WILL AID THE UNITED STATES FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IN PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO WIND ENERGY DEVELOPERS. DEVELOPMENT OF WIND ENERGY CAN HAVE NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES FOR WILDLIFE, ESPECIALLY VIA FATALITIES CAUSED BY COLLISION WITH TURBINE BLADES. A HOTSPOT FOR WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IS THE OFFSHORE AND NEAR-SHORE ENVIRONMENT, INCLUDING THE GREAT LAKES. HOWEVER, MANY SPECIES OF MIGRATORY BIRDS, INCLUDING EAGLES PROTECTED UNDER THE BALD AND GOLDEN EAGLE PROTECTION ACT, CROSS THE GREAT LAKES. THE FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING POPULATIONS OF MIGRATORY BIRDS AND THUS HAS A ROLE IN ASSESSING THE EFFECT OF WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON MIGRATORY BIRDS AND PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO WIND ENERGY DEVELOPERS. AS SUCH, THE FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS A STRONG INTEREST IN UNDERSTANDING HOW FLIGHT BEHAVIOR OF EAGLES MAY EXPOSE THEM TO RISK FROM COLLISION WITH WIND ENERGY FACILITIES BUILT IN THE GREAT LAKES. CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL WILL WORK WITH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TO ANALYZE MILLIONS OF GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) DATA POINTS COLLECTED FROM TRACKING UNITS CARRIED BY AT LEAST 226 BALD AND 108 GOLDEN EAGLES AS THEY HAVE FLOWN, AND CONTINUE TO FLY, THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES REGION. WE WILL IDENTIFY AND DESCRIBE THESE BIRDS WATER CROSSINGS FOR EACH OF THE FIVE GREAT LAKES. ANALYSIS WILL FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING MOVEMENT PATHWAYS OVER AND ADJACENT TO THE GREAT LAKES AND FLIGHT BEHAVIOR ALONG THOSE MOVEMENT PATHWAYS. INFORMATION FROM THIS STUDY CAN THUS IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE PLACEMENT OF WIND TURBINES MAY REPRESENT ESPECIALLY LOW OR HIGH RISK TO EAGLES AND, ALSO, HOW FLIGHT BEHAVIOR OF EAGLES OVER WATER COULD EXPOSE THEM TO RISK. THIS INFORMATION CAN HELP INFORM SITING OF OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY FACILITIES IN THE GREAT LAKES AND WILL HELP THE FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE EVALUATE RISK OF PROPOSED DEVELOPMENTS.IN ADDITION TO INFORMAL REPORTING THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT, WE WILL PROVIDE A FINAL FORMAL REPORT AND PUBLISH THE RESULTS IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL. FINALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A PUBLICLY AVAILABLE MAPPING PRODUCT THAT THE FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE AND OTHER ENTITIES CAN USE TO PLAN DEVELOPMENT.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 24PROJECT TITLE: WEB APPLICATION FOR FORECASTING AVIAN INFLUENZA RISK IN POULTRY POPULATIONSAWARD PURPOSE:TRANSBOUNDARY DISEASES, WHERE PATHOGENS ARE EXCHANGED BETWEEN WILD AND DOMESTIC SPECIES,CAN HAVE DETRIMENTAL IMPACTS ON WILDLIFE, HUMAN HEALTH, AND THE ECONOMY. AVIAN INFLUENZA IS ATRANSBOUNDARY DISEASE THAT CAN HAVE PARTICULARLY OVERWHELMING IMPACTS, AS DEMONSTRATED BYTHE HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA OUTBREAK IN 20142015, WHICH COST U.S. TAXPAYERS  950MILLION DOLLARS AND CARRIED AN OVERALL ECONOMIC IMPACT ESTIMATED AT  3.3 BILLION. THE 2022-2023OUTBREAK OF THE HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA VIRUS H5N1 IS LIKELY TO HAVE A GREATERECONOMIC IMPACT, GIVEN ITS LONGEVITY.AIM TO HELP DECREASE AVIAN INFLUENZA IN BIRD POPULATIONS BY PROVIDING A TOOL TO POULTRYPRODUCERS THAT INFORMS THEM ABOUT FORECASTED RISK. WILL DEVELOP A WEB APPLICATION WITH ANINTUITIVE, USER-FRIENDLY INTERFACE THAT ALLOWS POULTRY PRODUCERS TO ASSESS THE RISK OF AVIANINFLUENZA IN THE AREA BY MONITORING LOCALIZED, SPECIES-SPECIFIC BIRD MIGRATORY PATTERNS, ALLOWINGTHEM TO TAKE NECESSARY BIOSECURITY MEASURES TAILORED TO THE SPECIFIC LOCATION. THIS TOOL ALLOWSFOR INTERACTIVE FORECASTING AND HINDCASTING OF WHERE WILD BIRDS IN THOSE LOCATIONS ARE LIKELY TO GO,OR LIKELY TO HAVE COME FROM.PLANNED ACTIVITIES METHODS:PROPOSE TO DELIVER A MOBILE-ENABLED, CLOUD-HOSTED PROTOTYPE WEB APPLICATION. THEAPPLICATION WILL USE DATA FROM EBIRD, WHICH HAS A DATABASE OF OVER ONE BILLION BIRD OBSERVATIONS,AND BIRDFLOW, WHICH MODELS PREDICT MOVEMENT PATTERNS. WILL INCORPORATE FEATURES THAT MAYINCLUDE FORECASTS, SPECIES SELECTION, LOCATION, TIME HORIZON, LOCATION SEARCH AND ACTIVE MAPDISPLAYS. AS THIS DEVELOPMENT IS A PROTOTYPE, WE AIM TO BUILD A USER INTERFACE THAT ALLOWS FORITERATIVE DESIGN AND FUTURE DEVELOPMENT.DELIVERABLES EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THE DEVELOPMENT IS TO PRODUCE AN INTUITIVE AND ACCURATE PROTOTYPE TOOLTHAT IS USABLE BY POULTRY FARMERS. DURING THE GRANT PERIOD, WILL HAVE UP TO 20 POULTRY FARMERSTEST THE SOFTWARE, AS THEY ARE THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES OF WORK. FOLLOWING THE GRANT PERIOD,EXPECT THE WORK TO LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF MACHINE-LEARNINGAPPROACHES TO LINK BIRDFLOW MODELS WITH NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE ADVANCED RADAR DATA AND THEINTEGRATION OF THESE DEVELOPMENTS TO THE APPLICATION. THE MODULAR DESIGN WILL ENSURE THAT FUTUREITERATIONS ARE POSSIBLE WITHOUT MAJOR RESTRUCTURING. IN ADDITION, THE APPLICATION AND ITS DATA WILLBE AVAILABLE IN AN OPEN SOURCE CODE REPOSITORY, WHICH WILL ENCOURAGE FUTURE USE AND DEVELOPMENTOF THE APPLICATION. THIS TOOL WILL ALLOW POULTRY FARMERS TO REDUCE THE RISK OF AVIAN INFLUENZATRANSMISSION IN THEIR FLOCKS IN THE SHORT TERM AND WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR FUTURE RESEARCH ANDDEVELOPMENT EFFORTS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 26 23-7 25 24PROJECT TITLE: STRUCTURED DECISION MAKING IN TICK AND TICK-BORNE DISEASE MANAGEMENT IN NEW ENGLANDTICK AND TICK-BORNE DISEASE CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT IS CARRIED OUT BY A VARIETY OF SHAREHOLDERS WITH UNIQUE NEEDS, BASES OF KNOWLEDGE, AND MOTIVATIONS. THE GOAL OF TICK MANAGEMENT IS THE REDUCTION OF TICK BITES TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF TICK-BORNE DISEASE. THE AIM OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP GENERAL FRAMEWORKS AT BROAD AND LOCAL SCALES THAT CAN GUIDE TICK MANAGEMENT IN MAKING DECISIONS WITHIN EXISTING VECTOR MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS OR INSTITUTING NEW PROGRAMS TO REDUCE THERISK OF TICK BITES OR TICK-BORNE DISEASE. PROPOSE A THREE-PRONG APPROACH. FIRST, CONSOLIDATING THE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE INTO AN ACCESSIBLE DATABASE FOR MANAGERS WILL CURATE THE MOST RELEVANT AND UP TO DATE EVIDENCE AROUND TICK CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT TO INFORM DECISION MAKING. SECOND, WORKING WITH VECTOR MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO GATHER VALUES AND PRIORITIES, WILL THOUGHTFULLY OVERLAY A GENERAL DECISION-MAKING FRAMEWORK AND DECISIONANALYSIS ON THE MORE SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK CURRENTLY USED IN THE MANAGEMENT OF PRIMARILY MOSQUITO CONTROL. THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A STRUCTURED GUIDE TO THE CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT OF TICKS THAT CAN BE READILY SCALED DOWN TO MORE LOCAL PROJECTS. FINALLY, WILL IMPLEMENT THE MANAGEMENT GUIDE TO WORK THROUGH THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF TICK CONTROLAND MANAGEMENT LOCALLY, USING THE ECO-SOCIAL-POLITICAL MICROCOSM OF A COLLEGE CAMPUS AS A CASE STUDY. THE DELIVERABLES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE THE DATABASE OF MANAGEMENT-RELEVANT SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE, THE BROAD SCALE MANAGEMENT GUIDE, AND THE MODIFIED GUIDE FOR LOCAL IMPLEMENTATION. THIS WORK IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY FACILITATING EFFECTIVE TICK CONTROL IN NEW ENGLAND,THUS REDUCING THE BURDEN OF TICK-BORNE DISEASE.

ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE: GEOPHYSICAL MONITORING AND ANALYSIS TO SUPPORT LANDSLIDE AND TSUNAMI HAZARDASSESSMENT AND EARLY WARNING IN PRINCE WILLIAM SOUNDPROJECT PERIOD:08 01 2023- 07 31 2025 AWARD PURPOSETHE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO STRENGTHEN RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND OUTREACH FOR THE ALASKALANDSLIDE PROGRAM. FOR THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT STATE OF THE ARTGEOPHYSICAL RESEARCH AND MONITORING, WHICH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) WILL USE TOINFORM REGIONAL ASSESSMENT OF LANDSLIDE AND LANDSLIDE-GENERATED TSUNAMI HAZARDS, AND WHICH WILLAID IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF LANDSLIDE AND TSUNAMI HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND EARLY WARNING AND RISKMITIGATION EFFORTS. THE PROGRAM GOAL IS NEAR REAL-TIME LANDSLIDE DETECTION AND LOCATION USINGGEOPHYSICAL DATA AND METHODS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED(1) DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN A ROBUST SEISMOGRAPH NETWORK FOR CONDUCTING GEOPHYSICAL RESEARCHRELATED TO LANDSLIDE OCCURRENCE AND HAZARD (2) ANALYZE SEISMIC DATA TO DETECT THE OCCURRENCE OF CATASTROPHIC FAILURE OF LANDSLIDES AND THESUBTLE SEISMOACOUSTIC SIGNALS THAT MAY BE INDICATIVE OF SLOW LANDSLIDE DEFORMATION AND ORPRECURSORS TO LARGER EVENTS (3) DEVELOP ALGORITHMS THAT CAN DETECT INCREASES IN SEISMIC ACTIVITY THAT MAY BE INDICATIVE OFIMMINENT OR REAL-TIME LANDSLIDE FAILURE (4) ACQUIRE RESEARCH-GRADE SEISMIC AND RELATED DATA IN THE BARRY ARM VICINITY COORDINATED WITHTHE INSTRUMENTATION EFFORTS OF USGS, DGGS   NTWC (5) SUPERVISE STUDENTS, POSTDOCS, AND UNIVERSITY FACULTY AFFILIATED WITH THE PROJECT IN THE USE OFGEOPHYSICAL METHODS FOR DETECTING AND LOCATING CATASTROPHIC LANDSLIDE FAILURES, AND IN THEDEVELOPMENT OF METHODS FOR ASSESSING THE POTENTIAL FOR SLOPE FAILURE FROM PRECURSORY SIGNALS (6) IMPROVE UPON THE VISIBILITY OF THE APPLIED RESEARCH THROUGH ESTABLISHED REGULAR AND SOCIALMEDIA CHANNELS AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES  AND(7) ENGAGE IN ACTIVE AND REGULAR COLLABORATION WITH USGS SCIENTISTS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES(1) PRODUCE ANNUAL REPORTS SUMMARIZING THE PROGRESS MADE AT THE END OF EACH YEAR OF THE AWARD.(2) PUBLISH DATASETS IN ACCORDANCE WITH FAIR DATA PRINCIPLES, PUBLISH ALGORITHMS IN OPENREPOSITORIES, AND PUBLISH RELATED RESEARCH PAPERS IN OPEN-ACCESS JOURNALS.(3) CONTRIBUTE TO REAL-TIME OPERATIONAL WARNING EFFORTS AND SITUATIONAL AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS BYCONTRIBUTING INFORMATION RELATED TO GEOPHYSICAL PRECURSORY SIGNALS, DETECTION AND LOCATION OFNEW LANDSLIDES USING GEOPHYSICAL METHODS, AND PUBLICATION OF APPLIED RESEARCH IN SUPPORT OFHAZARD AND RISK ASSESSMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) WILL USE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT TO INFORM REGIONALASSESSMENT OF LANDSLIDE AND LANDSLIDE-GENERATED TSUNAMI HAZARDS, AND WHICH WILL AID IN THEDEVELOPMENT OF LANDSLIDE AND TSUNAMI HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND EARLY WARNING AND RISK MITIGATIONEFFORTS AT THE NATIONAL TSUNAMI WARNING CENTER (NTWC), U.S. COAST GUARD (USCG), ANDALASKA DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY AND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT (DHSEM).

PROJECT TITLE: ADVANCING A NATIONWIDE BIODIVERSITY DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: A COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM (USGS CRU) AND WMIPROJECT PERIOD: 06 29 2023 -06 14 2026PROJECT ABSTRACT: ADVANCING A NATIONWIDE BIODIVERSITY DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:A COOPERATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE USGS COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PROGRAM USGS CRU) AND THE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT INSTITUTE (WMI)AWARD PURPOSE IS TO ADDRESS DEFICIENCIES IN THE EXISTING DATABASES. NUMEROUS DATABASES AND DATA SOURCES ALREADY EXIST AT STATE, REGIONAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL LEVELS, BUT ARE LACKING A COHERENT STRUCTURE AND FRAMEWORK THAT WILL ALLOW AGENCIES AND CONSERVATIONISTS TO INTEGRATE DATA FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES INTO A SINGLE PLATFORM TO INFORM THEIR CONSERVATION DECISION-MAKING.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDED DISCUSSIONS AND COORDINATION WITH STATE AGENCIES AND REGIONAL ASSOCIATIONS OF STATESREGULAR CONVERSATIONS AND DIALOGUE WITH STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, INCLUDING DIRECTORS, WILDLIFE CHIEFS, AND FISH CHIEFS, REGARDING BIODIVERSITY DATA, INFORMATICS, MANAGEMENT, AND POTENTIAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLABORATION AND COOPERATIVE RESEARCH WITH THE CRUS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: 1) EXPLORE THE INTEREST AND UTILITY IN A NATION-WIDE INTEGRATED DATABASE WITH THE REGIONAL ASSOCIATIONS AND THEIR STATES  2) IDENTIFY A POSSIBLE HOME FOR ANY SUCH REGIONAL AND NATIONAL DATABASES AND ASSOCIATED DATA  3) EXAMINE ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH DATA SHARING WITH STATES AND PARTNERS  4) EXPLORE POTENTIAL IMPROVEMENTS TO THE EXISTING REGIONAL DATABASES FOR DECISION-SUPPORT AND CONSERVATION APPLICATIONS.WRITTEN SYNTHESIS PRODUCTS, INCLUDING 1) A PAPER COMPARING THE EXISTING REGIONAL DATABASE SYSTEMS, WITH DISCUSSION OF SUITABILITY AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONTRIBUTING TOWARDS A NATIONAL BIODIVERSITY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND 2) A REVIEW PAPER SYNTHESIZING INFORMATION ON THE CREATION, ENHANCEMENT, AND MAINTENANCE OF BIODIVERSITY DATA AND DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS FOR STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, SUMMARIZING KEY FINDINGS FROM THE EXISTING LITERATUREINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) THE EXPECTATION IS THAT THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A STATE-LED AND NATIONALLY COORDINATED INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. SUCH A SYSTEM WILL HELP INFORM GOVERNMENT AND CONSERVATION DECISIONS RELATED TO FISH, WILDLIFE, HABITAT, AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCES. THE OVERALL SYSTEM WILL HELP MANAGERS DEVELOP CONSERVATION PLANS FOR STRATEGIC SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS  IMPROVE OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLABORATIVE MANAGEMENT AND PROBLEM SOLVING  AND INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT CAN LEAD TO DESIRED OUTCOMES FOR FISH, WILDLIFE, AND THEIR HABITATS.

PROJECT TITLE:  COOPERATIVE EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT AGREEMENT FOR THE USGS HYDROLOGICAL INSTRUMENTATION FACILITY IN TUSCALOOSA, ALPROJECT PERIOD: 08 01 2023 THROUGH 9 30 2025ABSTRACT:THE COOPERATIVE EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT AGREEMENT FOR THE USGS HYDROLOGICAL INSTRUMENTATION FACILITY IN TUSCALOOSA, ALABAMA IS A UNIQUE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) HYDROLOGIC INSTRUMENTATION FACILITY (HIF) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA (UA). THE TWO-YEAR AGREEMENT ESTABLISHES NEW PATHWAYS FOR A LONG-TERM SYMBIOTICRELATIONSHIP BETWEEN USGS AND UA FACULTY, RESEARCHERS, STAFF, AND STUDENTS. THE PRINCIPAL PURPOSE OF THE AGREEMENT IS TO ENABLE COOPERATIVE WORK BETWEEN THE USGS AND UA IN EARTH SCIENCE ANDTERRESTRIAL HYDROLOGY RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH RELATED TO SURFACE AND NEAR-SURFACE HYDROLOGIC, GEOPHYSICAL, AND WATER-RESOURCES INVESTIGATIONS. THROUGH THIS PARTNERSHIP THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOCUSES ON THE DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF INNOVATIVE WATER OBSERVING SENSOR, PLATFORM, AND SYSTEM TECHNOLOGIES AND HYDROLOGICAL METHODS TO SUPPORT TERRESTRIAL HYDROLOGY INVESTIGATIONS  IMPLEMENTS BEST PRACTICES FOR METHODS OF SCIENTIFIC TESTING AND PERFORMING RELEVANT SCIENCE  AND PROMOTES THE TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW GENERATION OF WATER SCIENTISTS. THE INITIAL COLLABORATIONS, UNDER THE AGREEMENT, WILL FOCUS ON THREE EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND INFRASTRUCTURAL SUPPORT EFFORTS. BOTH THE RECIPIENT AND USGS WILL MAINTAINSUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT IN THE EDUCATION PROGRAMS, FOSTERING COLLABORATION IN SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATION, AND THE PROVISION OF ESSENTIAL INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT SERVICES AS PART OF THE UA CAMPUS COMMUNITY
