PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 25PROJECT TITLE: DRYLAND SOIL CARBON INVENTORYTHIS PROJECT WILL COMBINE DATA SYNTHESIS (OBJECTIVE 1) WITH FIELD AND REMOTE SENSING DATA (OBJECTIVE 2) TO SUBSTANTIVELY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE DRIVERS AND POTENTIAL FOR ABOVE AND BELOWGROUND CARBON SEQUESTRATION ON RANGELANDS IN DRYLANDS ECOSYSTEMS OF THE WESTERN US IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE. CARBON IS A VALUABLE RESOURCE. IT NOT ONLY PROVIDES A HOST OF LOCAL BENEFITS, INCLUDING INCREASED SOIL FERTILITY AND WATER RETENTION AS WELL AS PLANT GROWTH FOR WILDLIFE AND LIVESTOCK, BUT ALSO PROVIDES EXCEPTIONAL HOPE FOR MITIGATING CLIMATE CHANGE. THERE ARE NUMEROUS EFFORTS CURRENTLY UNDERWAY ATTEMPTING TO INCREASE CARBON SEQUESTRATION IN LAND SYSTEMS. HOWEVER, FOR CARBON MANAGEMENT TO MATTER IN MITIGATING CLIMATIC CHANGE, THE CARBON MUST STAY SEQUESTERED FOR SIGNIFICANT PERIODS OF TIME AND MUST OCCUR ACROSS A LARGE SPATIAL SCALE. FURTHER, OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW WIDESPREAD PUBLIC LAND USES, SUCH AS GRAZING, AFFECT CARBON REMAINS EXCEEDINGLY POOR, AS DOES OUR COMPREHENSION OF THE POTENTIAL FOR ENHANCED MANAGEMENT TO PROTECT OR INCREASE CARBON POOLS. ACCORDINGLY, THE DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PLANS THAT INTEGRATE CARBON MANAGEMENT WITH EXISTING LAND MANAGEMENT GOALS OFFERS AN EXCEPTIONAL OPPORTUNITY TO SUPPORT OUR NATION IN MITIGATING CLIMATE CHANGE AND ENHANCING LOCAL CO-BENEFITS. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE NOVEL, ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO DIRECTLY ADDRESS ONGOING MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS RELATED TO CARBON SEQUESTRATION IN THE WEST THAT WILL BE OF IMMEDIATE USE TO LAND MANAGERS. SPECIFICALLY, THIS WORK WILL ADDRESS THREE OVERARCHING QUESTIONS: (Q1) WHAT IS THE STATUS OF THE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CARBON SEQUESTRATION POTENTIAL IN RANGELANDS ACROSS A DIVERSITY OF DRYLAND ECOSYSTEMS  (Q2) HOW DOES GRAZING INTERACT WITH CLIMATE AND SOIL TYPE TO REGULATE CARBON STORAGE  (Q3) COULD GRAZING PRACTICES BE REFINED IN THE FACE OF GLOBAL CHANGE TO OPTIMIZE SOIL CARBON STORAGE BOTH ABOVE AND BELOWGROUND  TO ADDRESS THESE QUESTIONS, WE WILL (OBJECTIVE 1) SYNTHESIZE DATA FROM THE PUBLISHED AND GREY LITERATURE TO INFORM HOW GRAZING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN DRYLAND ECOSYSTEMS AFFECT CARBON STORAGE AND (OBJECTIVE 2) ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN CARBON STORAGE, GRAZING INTENSITY, AND SOIL TYPE ACROSS A SOIL AND CLIMATIC GRADIENT IN UTAH BY JOINING ON-THE-GROUND ASSESSMENT, REMOTE SENSING DATA, AND BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) ASSESSMENT, INVENTORY, AND MONITORING (AIM) DATA. FINALLY, WE WILL SHARE THE NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TOOLS CREATED THROUGH THE DIVERSE COLLABORATIONS AND OUTREACH STRATEGIES DEVELOPED BY OUR TEAM TO ENSURE THE UTILITY AND ACCESSIBILITY OF OUR RESULTS. COLLABORATORS, PARTNERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS WILL BE ENGAGED THROUGHOUT THIS PROJECT THROUGH IN PERSON AND VIRTUAL MEETINGS, FIELD VISITS AND THE CO-CREATION OF PRODUCTS, INCLUDING PAPERS, INFORMATIONAL 2-PAGERS, AND REPORTS. THE VAST PUBLIC LANDS OF THE WESTERN U.S. HAVE ENORMOUS POTENTIAL TO HELP US PROTECT AND RESTORE CARBON IN STABLE POOLS, AND THE GOAL IS TO SIGNIFICANTLY ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF CARBON CYCLING ON THESE LANDS AND TO WORK ALONGSIDE THE MANAGER PARTNERS TO DEVELOP METHODS FOR INFORMED CARBON MANAGEMENT.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 23-6 30 24PROJECT TITLE: ENGAGING POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHERS IN ADVANCED, NATIONAL-SCALE SYNTHESIS COLLABORATIONSWATER IS CENTRAL TO THE FUNCTIONING OF ECOSYSTEMS, HUMAN COMMUNITIES AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, AND IN EXTREMES (FLOODS, DROUGHTS) CAN LEAD TO CATASTROPHIC OUTCOMES. THUS, SOME OF THE MOST PRESSING QUESTIONS WE FACE IN MANAGING OUR NATURAL RESOURCES AND SUPPORTING COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIES INCLUDE UNDERSTANDING HOW CLIMATE CHANGE IS ALTERING AQUATIC FLOWS ACROSS THE COUNTRY, AND HOW CLIMATE CAN BE INTEGRATED INTO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT. ADDRESSING THESE NATIONAL-SCALE QUESTIONS REQUIRES A LARGER-SCALE APPROACH, WHICH IN TURN REQUIRES ANALYTICAL AND SYNTHETIC APPROACHES TO RESEARCH THAT LEVERAGE LOCAL AND REGIONAL DATA, EXPERTISE, AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS. THIS PROJECT WILL BRING TOGETHER THE NINE POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHERS AFFILIATED WITH THE REGIONAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS (CASCS) IN THEIR CLIMATE ADAPTATION POSTDOCTORAL (CAP) FELLOWS PROGRAM AT THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR ECOLOGICAL ANALYSIS AND SYNTHESIS, A WORLD LEADER IN SYNTHESIS AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATA SCIENCE, TO DEVELOP AND CONDUCT THIS RESEARCH. RESEARCH WORKSHOPS WILL BE A COMBINATION OF INSTRUCTIONAL LESSONS AND HANDS-ON APPLICATION OF TOOLS AND WORKFLOWS TO DEVELOP AND ADVANCE POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHERS COLLABORATIVE SYNTHESIS RESEARCH PROJECTS. RESULTS FROM THIS WORK WILL ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF AQUATIC FLOWS NOW AND IN THE FUTURE, IN TURN INFORMING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 24PROJECT TITLE: SALMON RIVER BASIN CULTURAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICESTHE PURPOSE OF THIS EFFORT IS TO UNDERSTAND INTERGROUP DIFFERENCES IN CULTURAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICE (SOCIAL VALUES) COMPOSITION AND INTENSITY IN THE SALMON RIVER BASIN, AS WELL AS PERCEPTIONS OF CHANGE RELATED TO THOSE SOCIAL VALUES. ACHIEVING THE FOLLOWING THREE OBJECTIVES WILL SUPPORT THAT GOAL: 1) DEVELOP A GEOGRAPHICALLY AND CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE SOCIAL VALUE TYPOLOGY THROUGH COMMUNITY-OUTREACH, 2) ADMINISTER A RIGOROUS, REPRESENTATIVE, AND INCLUSIVE SURVEY OF SELECTED SALMON RIVER BASIN RESIDENTS, VISITORS, AND STAKEHOLDERS  AND 3) DEVELOP A ROBUST SOCIAL SCIENCE DATASET FOR USE BY THE SPONSOR AND IN RELATED PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: 1)SOCIAL VALUES TYPOLOGY: AS SOON AS FUNDS ARE OBLIGATED, THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL BEGIN OUR EFFORT BY HOLDING FOCUS GROUPS IN THE SALMON RIVER BASIN OR AT KEY STAKEHOLDER LOCATIONS TO CO-DESIGN A CULTURALLY RELEVANT SOCIAL VALUE TYPOLOGY FOR USE IN THE BASIN-WIDE SURVEY. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL IDENTIFY AND SELECT SPECIFIC SITES AMONG RIGGINS, STANLEY, CHALLIS, SALMON, MCCALL, BOISE, AND GRANGEVILLE AND HOLD STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS. PENDING TRIBAL APPROVAL, THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO VISIT LAPWAI AND FORT HALL TO INFORM THE NEZ PERCE AND SHOSHONE-BANNOCK TRIBES OF THE INTENT OF THE SOCIAL VALUE MAPPING APPROACH AND SEEK THEIR INVOLVEMENT IN FOCUS GROUPS AND FUTURE SURVEY EFFORTS. 2)SOCIAL VALUES MAIL SURVEY: STARTING IN SUMMER 2024, THE CULTURAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ONLINE SURVEY WILL BE ADMINISTERED TO HOUSEHOLDS WITHIN THE SALMON RIVER BASIN. MULTIPLE MAILINGS TO A DEMOGRAPHICALLY REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF HOUSEHOLDS AND OR STAKEHOLDERS WILL PROVIDE PARTICIPANTS ACCESS TO ONLINE QUESTIONNAIRE OPTIONS WITH A QR CODE AND LINK. 3)ON-SITE SURVEY: IN SUMMER 2024 AND 2025, AS WELL AS THROUGH TARGETED EFFORTS IN SPRING 2025 AND FALL 2025, ON-SITE SAMPLING INTERCEPTS WILL OCCUR AT POPULAR TAKE-OUT LAUNCH SPOTS ON THE LOWER, SOUTH, AND MIDDLE FORKS, AND THE MAIN SALMON RIVER. RESPONDENTS WILL BE PROVIDED THE OPTION TO COMPLETE THE SURVEY ON-SITE OR AFTER THEIR VISIT USING A QR CODE AND LINK PROVIDED ON A POSTCARD. PENDING AVAILABILITY OF ADDITIONAL FUNDING, ADDITIONAL ON-SITE INTERCEPTS CAN OCCUR AT LAND OF THE YANKEE FORK AND CHALLIS HOT SPRINGS STATE PARKS AND OTHER SITES TO BE DETERMINED IN CONSULTATION WITH AGENCY PERSONNEL OR KEY STAKEHOLDERS (I.E., UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOREST SERVICE).DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A SUMMATIVE TECHNICAL REPORT DETAILING SURVEY FINDINGS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE SPONSOR. ANONYMIZED SURVEY DATA FILES WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO THE SPONSOR. THE TECHNICAL REPORT WILL BE SHARED WITH OTHER LOCAL, STATE, REGIONAL AND FEDERAL AGENCIES (E.G., IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, ETC.), AS WELL AS SURVEY PARTICIPANTS WHO VOLUNTARILY PROVIDED THEIR EMAIL ADDRESS FOLLOWING QUESTIONNAIRE COMPLETION. A MINIMUM OF TWO CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS AT NATIONAL OR INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES AND TWO OPEN ACCESS PEER-REVIEWED ARTICLES WILL BE SUBMITTED FOR PUBLICATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO IS THE RECIPIENT OF THE FUNDS, BUT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE SPONSOR, AS WELL AS AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, RESIDENTS, AND VISITORS OF THE SALMON RIVER BASIN.

PROJECT TITLE: THE ECONOMIC CASE FOR NATURE: MISSISSIPPI BASIN ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROJECT SCOPING WORKSHOP (HYBRID)PROJECT DATES: JULY 10, 2023 THROUGH JULY 09, 2024AWARD PURPOSE: THIS WORKSHOP, TO BE HELD HYBRID AT THE INSTITUTE ON THE ENVIRONMENT (IONE), UNIVERSITYOF MINNESOTA, WILL BRING TOGETHER 17 EXPERTS FROM 14 INSTITUTIONS TO DEVELOP A RESEARCH PROGRAM ONNATUREBASED SOLUTIONS (NBS) FOR REDUCING HARM FROM EXTREME HYDROCLIMATIC RISKS (FLOODS ANDDROUGHTS) IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. THE RESEARCH PROGRAM WILL HIGHLIGHT POTENTIAL FORVARIOUS TYPES OF NBS TO REDUCE HARM, BUILD ECOLOGICAL AND INFRASTRUCTURE RESILIENCE. THE RESEARCHPROGRAM WILL EXTEND CURRENT WORK ON ECOSYSTEM SERVICES TO INCORPORATE CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS,DISTRIBUTIONAL CONSIDERATION PARTICULARLY SHOWING POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO LOWINCOME AND MINORITYGROUPS, AND METHODS OF EXPRESSING VALUE IN BOTH MONETARY AND NONMONETARY TERMS AS APPROPRIATEFOR DIFFERENT SOCIOCULTURAL SETTINGS. ONE OF OUR MAIN OUTCOMES WILL BE A FULL RESEARCH PROPOSAL TOIMPLEMENT THE RESEARCH PROGRAM WE HAVE DEVELOPED.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WITH SUPPORT FROM 17 EXPERTS FROM 14 INSTITUTIONS, THIS WORKSHOP WILLUSE STATEOFTHEART METHODOLOGY TO ESTIMATE THE VALUES OF NATUREBASED SOLUTIONS. WE WILL USE OURINVEST URBAN FLOOD MITIGATION MODEL TO CALCULATE RUNOFF REDUCTION, I.E. THE AMOUNT OF RUNOFFRETAINED PER PIXEL COMPARED TO THE STORM VOLUME. FOR EACH WATERSHED, WE WILL THEN CALCULATE THEPOTENTIAL ECONOMIC DAMAGE BY OVERLAYING INFORMATION ON FLOOD EXTENT POTENTIAL AND BUILTINFRASTRUCTURE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WORKSHOP WILL DEVELOP GOALS AND METHODOLOGIESFOR THE LATER VIRTUAL MEETINGS AND FOLLOWUP WORK. VIRTUAL MEETINGS WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF A RESEARCH AGENDA AND PROPOSAL. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE INDIVIDUALS LIVING, WORKING AND MANAGING LAND SURROUNDING THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 25 23-7 24 24PROJECT TITLE: A SAMPLE-BASED APPROACH FOR ANALYZING THE DRIVER OF COASTAL TIDAL WETLAND CHANGESCOASTAL LANDSCAPES, THE NARROW TRANSITION AREAS THAT CONNECT TERRESTRIAL AND MARINE ENVIRONMENTS, ARE OUR PLANETS MOST PRODUCTIVE AND VALUED ECOSYSTEMS. TIDAL WETLANDS, MAINLY COMPOSED OF TIDALLY INFLUENCED VEGETATION (E.G., MANGROVE AND TIDAL MARSH) AND NON-VEGETATION (E.G. TIDAL FLATS), PROVIDE A DISPROPORTIONATELY LARGER VALUE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES RELATIVE TO TERRESTRIAL ENVIRONMENTS. CONTINENTAL U.S. IS ONE OF THE MAJOR TIDAL WETLAND COUNTRIES WITH AN ESTIMATION OF 26,818 KM2. GIVEN THAT APPROXIMATELY 29  OF THE U.S. POPULATION LIVES IN COASTAL REGIONS, TIDAL WETLANDS ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE ECOSYSTEMS, THREATENED BY INTENSE HUMAN ACTIVITIES (E.G., HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, ALTERED HYDROLOGY). KNOWING WHERE AND WHEN THE CHANGES HAVE OCCURRED WITH DIRECT HUMAN ACTIVITIES, ESPECIALLY FOR THE COASTAL TIDAL WETLAND WITH ALTERATION OF THE HYDROLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS, IS IMPORTANT FOR COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.HERE, PROPOSE TO UTILIZE SPATIALLY EXTENSIVE REMOTE SENSING DATASETS TO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON COASTAL TIDAL WETLANDS AND QUANTIFY THE RELEVANT DRIVERS. WILL REPLY ON THE RECENTLY CREATED COASTAL WETLAND CHANGE MAPS AND A SET OF RANDOM SAMPLES STRATIFIED IN TIDAL WETLAND CHANGE AREAS AND MANUALLY INTERPRETED THE CHANGE DRIVERS INCLUDING HUMAN ACTIVITIES (E.G., HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, ALTERED HYDROLOGY DERIVED FROM MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION) AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROCESSES. WILL ALSO USE OUR RESULTS TO EXPLORE THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON COASTAL WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS, WHICH WILL BENEFIT IMPROVING COASTAL PLANNING AND GUIDING LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.LARGE-SCALE MAPPING OF COASTAL TIDAL WETLAND CHANGES IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT DUE TO THEIR INHERENT DYNAMIC NATURE. WILL CHARACTERIZE THE TIDAL WETLAND DISTURBANCE (BOTH COVER CHANGE WITH LAND COVER CONVERSION AND CONDITION CHANGE WITH COVER MODIFICATION) AND COVER TYPES (I.E., TIDAL MARSH, MANGROVE, TIDAL FLATS, OPEN WATER, AND OTHERS) BY USING A RECENTLY DEVELOPED TIME SERIES MODEL, NAMELY DETECTION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF TIDAL WETLAND CHANGE (DECODE), FROM LANDSAT OBSERVATIONS DURING THE LAST 40 YEARS. DECODE IS CHARACTERIZED BY ITS CAPABILITY TO ADDRESS THE UNCERTAINTY OF THE VARYING TIDAL FLUCTUATIONS AND DETECTION OF CONDITION CHANGE. FOR EXAMPLE, OUR PREVIOUS STUDY ESTIMATED THAT CONDITION CHANGES OCCUPIED ALMOST 84.3  OF THE TIDAL WETLAND CHANGES IN THE NORTHEASTERN US. WILL FURTHER USE A SAMPLE-BASED ESTIMATE TO ANALYZE THE DRIVERS THAT TRIGGER TIDAL WETLAND CHANGES. DRIVERS CAN BE HUMAN-INDUCED (INCLUDING LAND USE AND INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT, MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION) AND NATURE-INDUCED (SUCH AS SEA LEVEL RISE AND EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS). WILL RANDOMLY GENERATE A SET OF SAMPLES IN THE CHANGED REGIONS AND THE PROPORTION CAN INDICATE THE IMPACTS OF DIFFERENT DRIVERS.THUS, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE POINT-BASED SPATIAL DATA TO ESTIMATE THE COASTAL WETLAND CHANGE DRIVERS AND THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES, WHICH ARE BENEFICIAL TO SCIENTISTS FROM THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AS WELL AS NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 23-8 13 24PROJECT TITLE: PATTERNS IN UNGULATE GENETICS IN GLACIER NATIONAL PARKHE MOUNTAIN GOAT IS ONE OF GLACIER NATIONAL PARKS MOST ICONIC SPECIES.  CONSERVATION OF THIS KEYSTONE SPECIES HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED IN THE PARKS GENERAL MANAGEMENT PLAN, FOUNDATION STATEMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONDITION ASSESSMENT AS BEING PARAMOUNT TO SUCCESSFUL PARK MANAGEMENT, IN PART BECAUSE THE PRESENCE OF MOUNTAIN GOATS IN ALPINE COMMUNITIES SHAPES BIODIVERSITY AND PLANT COMMUNITY PRODUCTIVITY. HOWEVER, THE MOST RECENT PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS OF GLACIERS MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATION SIZE SUGGESTS AN OVERALL DECLINING TREND, BUT DOES NOT INCORPORATE RECENT INFORMATION ON MOVEMENTS AND HABITUATION.  THUS, THE PARK NEEDS TO ANALYZE EXISTING LONG-TERM DATA TO UNDERSTAND HOW TO BEST TRACK GOAT POPULATION TRENDS AND INCORPORATE GOAT CONSERVATION INTO MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING. BIGHORN SHEEP ARE ALSO PRESENT AND OF CONSERVATION INTEREST. THE PURPOSE OF THIS WORK IS TO ANALYZE EXISTING UNGULATE GENETIC SAMPLES TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS FOR GENETIC STRUCTURE ANALYSES AND SPATIAL CAPTURE RECAPTURE ESTIMATES OF MOUNTAIN GOAT ABUNDANCE AND TREND.  FIRST, WILL DEVELOP AND ANALYZE GENETIC MARKERS FOR MOUNTAIN GOATS IN A NATIONAL PARK. ASSESSING THE NUMBER OF UNIQUE INDIVIDUALS AND GENETIC DIVERSITY AT THE SCALE OF A NATIONAL PARK REQUIRES DEVELOPMENT OF GENETIC MARKERS SPECIFIC TO THAT REGION. IN GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, FECAL PELLETS WERE COLLECTED BY USGS AND NPS PERSONNEL AND CITIZEN SCIENTISTS.  MOUNTAIN GOAT AND BIGHORN SHEEP PELLETS LOOK VERY SIMILAR EXTERNALLY AND THEIR HABITATS OVERLAP, SO IDENTIFICATION TO SPECIES IS NECESSARY AS WELL. WILL DISTINGUISH MOUNTAIN GOAT FECAL SAMPLES FROM BIGHORN FECAL SAMPLES GENETICALLY. SECONDLY, WILL USE GENETIC ANALYSES TO IDENTIFY WHICH FECAL SAMPLES CAME FROM WHICH INDIVIDUAL MOUNTAIN GOATS, AND IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS IF ADDITIONAL FUNDING IS AVAILABLE, BIGHORN SHEEP. IN YEAR 1 WILL IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL MOUNTAIN GOATS AND EXTEND GENOTYPES OF 120 OF THOSE INDIVIDUALS TO DESCRIBE GENETIC STRUCTURE, REQUIRING US TO SCREEN ADDITIONAL GENETIC MARKERS (MICROSATELLITES) FOR MOUNTAIN GOATS. RECAPTURES ACROSS SPACE AND TIME WILL BE IDENTIFIED USING THOSE GENOTYPES, INCLUDING ACCOUNTING FOR GENOTYPING ERROR. WILL PROVIDE THAT INFORMATION TO USGS, AS WELL AS THE GENOTYPES OF ALL DETECTED INDIVIDUALS, AND WILL COLLABORATE ON THE RESULTING ASSESSMENT OF GENETIC STRUCTURE AND POPULATION ESTIMATES: THESE STATISTICAL ASSESSMENTS WILL BE LED BY USGS  WILL PROVIDE INPUT AND FEEDBACK AND MEET RESPONSIBILITIES ASSOCIATED WITH CO-AUTHORSHIP INCLUDING INPUT ON THE APPROACH TO ANALYSIS AND REVIEW OF DRAFT AND FINAL MANUSCRIPT. THE DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE 1) DEVELOPMENT OF 8-20 MICROSATELLITES (GENETIC MARKERS) APPROPRIATE FOR DISTINGUISHING MOUNTAIN UNGULATE SPECIES AND MOUNTAIN UNGULATE INDIVIDUALS IN THE FOCAL AREAS AND FOR DESCRIBING GENETIC STRUCTURE, 2) PARAGRAPHS ON METHODS SUITABLE FOR INCLUSION IN A MANUSCRIPT THAT WERE USED FOR MICROSATELLITE DEVELOPMENT, THE MICROSATELLITES THEMSELVES, AND ASSESSMENTS OF THE ABILITY TO DISTINGUISH INDIVIDUALS AND SUITABILITY OF MICROSATELLITES FOR DESCRIBING POPULATION DIVERSITY, 3) GENOTYPES OF INDIVIDUAL GOATS (AND BIGHORN SHEEP IF OUTYEAR FUNDED) FROM GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, AND 4) INPUT ON USGS-LED STATISTICAL ASSESSMENT AND COLLABORATIVE DRAFT MANUSCRIPT, WITH PARTICULAR ATTENTION TO THE STRENGTH AND APPROPRIATENESS OF INFERENCE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (SPECIFICALLY GLACIER NATIONAL PARK), USGS, AND THE STATE OF MONTANA, AS THE WORK MAY INFORM REGIONAL MANAGEMENT OF MOUNTAIN GOATS AND BIGHORN SHEEP.

PROJECT TITLE: DATA MINING EARTH MRIS AIRBORNE MAGNETIC, RADIOMETRIC, AND ELECTROMAGNETIC DATA FOR CRITICALMINERAL MAPPINGPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2026AWARD PURPOSE: THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BRING A TEAM OF GEOPHYSICAL AND ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) EXPERTS TO SUPPORT THE HIGH-PRIORITY NEED OF THE EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES (EMRI) TO INTERPRET NEWLY ACQUIRED AIRBORNE GEOPHYSICAL DATA FOR CRITICAL MINERAL POTENTIAL IN THE US. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:1.DEVELOP AND APPLY INNOVATIVE APPROACHES FOR MINING AIRBORNE GEOPHYSICAL DATA FROM SURVEYS COLLECTED AS PART OF THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE (EMRI). WE SEEK TO EXTRACT UNPRECEDENTED INSIGHT INTO THE POTENTIAL PROSPECTIVITY OF SEVERAL CRITICAL MINERAL SYSTEMS THAT ARE ON THE CRITICAL MINERAL LIST IN THE US  AND2.REVIVE THE CAPABILITY FOR RADIOMETRIC GEOPHYSICS RESEARCH IN THE US AND BUILD BACK THE KNOWLEDGE CAPACITY TO INTEGRATE RADIOMETRIC DATA INTO THE PORTFOLIO OF GEOSCIENTIFIC TOOLS FOR MINERAL EXPLORATION. A MAJOR COMPONENT OF THIS GOAL IS TO TRANSFER THE RADIOMETRIC EXPERTISE TO USGS GEOSCIENTISTS ASSOCIATED WITH EARTH MRI AND OTHER USGS MISSION AREA PROJECTS THAT USE GEOPHYSICAL DATA IN THEIR MAPPING EFFORTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:REVIVE RADIOMETRIC GEOPHYSICS RESEARCH IN THE USBUILD STRONGER PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THE ACADEMIC COMMUNITY, THE USGS, STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS, AND INDUSTRY TO ADVANCE CRITICAL MINERAL MAPPING IN THE USREDUCE THE SEARCH SPACE (I.E., THE GEOLOGICAL AREAS REQUIRING DETAILED MINERAL EXPLORATION) TO SUPPORT INDUSTRY EFFORTS TO EXPLORE AND DISCOVER CRITICAL MINERAL DEPOSITS IN THE USESTABLISH AI-AUGMENTED JOINT INTERPRETATION METHODOLOGIES TO INTEGRATE EXISTING AND FUTURE EARTH MRI RADIOMETRIC, MAGNETIC DATA, AND ELECTROMAGNETIC (EM) DATATRANSFER KNOWLEDGE ON ADVANCED AIRBORNE RADIOMETRIC PROCESSING AND MODELING WITH INTERNATIONAL PARTNERS UNDER THE CRITICAL MINERALS MAPPING INITIATIVE (HTTPS:  PUBS.ER.USGS.GOV PUBLICATION FS20203055 ) AND WITH OTHER USGS MISSIONS RELATED TO GEOLOGIC MAPPING, HAZARDS, AND WATER RESOURCE RESEARCHESTABLISH A CENTER OF EXCELLENCE AT CSM FOR RADIOMETRIC GEOPHYSICS IN THE USINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: EARTHMRI PROGRAM AT THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 10 23-7 9 24PROJECT TITLE: MONITORING AND FORECASTING THE STATUS OF GROUNDWATER AND RANGELAND RESOURCES IN SUPPORT OF FEWS NETIN THE HORN OF AFRICA, GROUNDWATER IS A CRITICAL RESOURCE TO SUPPORT LIVESTOCK AND LIVELIHOODS, HOWEVER, INFORMATION ABOUT THIS RESOURCE, INCLUDING ITS CHARACTER OF SUPPLY (SHALLOW VS DEEP), AND DEMANDS (BY WHICH HOUSEHOLDS) IS DIFFICULT TO TRACK. WILL USE THE DROUGHT RESILIENCE IMPACT PLATFORM (DRIP) TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON GROUNDWATER UTILIZATION AND MANAGEMENT, COUPLED WITH IMPROVED RANGELAND DROUGHT-RISK ASSESSMENT, TO ENHANCE FAMINE EARLY WARNING SYSTEM (FEWS NET) ASSESSMENT OF WATER AND FOOD SECURITY FOR PASTORALISTS IN NORTHERN KENYA. THE DRIP PLATFORM FUSES IN-SITU DATA TO COLLECT ON RAINFALL, GROUNDWATER LEVELS AND GROUNDWATER PUMP FUNCTION AND USE WITH REMOTE SENSING DATA PRODUCTS AND MODELS, INCLUDING SURFACE WATER, GROUNDWATER STORAGE, SPATIALLY INTERPOLATED GROUNDWATER DEMAND, VEGETATION, AND SOIL PROPERTIES TO SUPPORT ESTIMATES OF WATER AND FODDER AVAILABILITY. MOREOVER, THIS PLATFORM PROVIDES DECISION SUPPORT PRODUCTS FOR GROUNDWATER AQUIFER HEALTH AND RECHARGE, GROUNDWATER PUMP OPERATION, GROUNDWATER DEMAND AND RANGELAND PASTURE DROUGHT RISK. WILL PARTNER WITH THE USGS EARTH RESOURCES OBSERVATION AND SCIENCE (EROS) CENTER TO IMPROVE THESE SERVICES AND DIRECTLY INTEGRATE THEM WITH FEWS NET OPERATIONS, FOLLOWING THE MODEL ESTABLISHED BY THE USGS EROS DEVELOPED FEWS WATER POINT VIEWER. WE WILL ALSO EXPLORE THE USE AND INTEGRATION OF A NEW ATWI (ACTUAL TOPOGRAPHIC WETNESS INDEX) PRODUCT OF EROS THAT WILL BE GENERATED IN PARALLEL. ATWI WILL QUANTIFY A PIXEL-BASED REGION-WIDE SURFACE RUNOFF AVAILABILITY AND ITS SPATIOTEMPORAL DYNAMICS FOR GROUNDWATER RECHARGE IN THE STUDY AREA AND REGION. ATWI WILL COMPLEMENT THE WATER POINT VIEWER WITH A SPATIALLY CONTINUOUS SURFACE, ALLOWING THE REGIONALIZING OF THE POINT-BASED WATER POINT MONITOR. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE SCENARIO BUILDING PROCESS BY PROVIDING IMPORTANT GROUNDWATER AND RANGELAND RESOURCE MONITORING AND FORECASTING INFORMATION. WILL INCORPORATE DRIP WATER AND RANGELAND DATA SERVICES WITH COMPLEMENTARY DATA SERVICES PRODUCED BY FEWS NET AND THE REGIONAL CENTRE FOR MAPPING OF RESOURCES FOR DEVELOPMENT (RCMRD) TO INFORM FEWS NETS IPC-COMPATIBLE FOOD SECURITY CLASSIFICATIONS AND KENYA NATIONAL DROUGHT MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY (NDMA) DROUGHT PHASE CLASSIFICATIONS FOR THE REGION. THESE CLASSIFICATIONS SUPPORT INSTITUTIONAL DECISIONS TO TAKE DROUGHT EARLY ACTIONS THAT ADDRESS LIVESTOCK HEALTH AND THE LIVELIHOODS OF PEOPLE. THE WORK WILL ALSO ENHANCE FEWS NETS NETWORK DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS WHICH IS CRITICAL FOR PROVIDING THE BEST INFORMATION AND PROJECTIONS OF FOOD SECURITY CLASSIFICATIONS. THE DRIP PROJECT PARTNERS WITH RCMRD, THE MILLENNIUM WATER ALLIANCE (MWA), THE NATIONAL DROUGHT MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY (NDMA), THE KENYA RED CROSS SOCIETY (KRCS), MERCY CORPS AND NATIONAL PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS AND THE COUNTY GOVERNMENTS OF TURKANA, GARISSA, MARSABIT, ISIOLO AND WAJIR.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 23-6 30 25PROJECT TITLE: SHALLOW GROUNDWATER MODELING IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN: ANALYSIS OF IRRIGATION, AERIAL ELECTROMAGNETICS, AND NITRATE FOR ASSESSING WATER AVAILABILITYPLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION:RECENTLY, THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) INITIATED A SERIES OF INTENSIVE STUDIES ON TEN INTEGRATED WATERSHED SCIENCE BASINS, INCLUDING THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN THAT COVERS MOST OF NORTHERN ILLINOIS. IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN, THE USGS AND THE COLLABORATING PARTNERS AT THE ILLINOIS STATE WATER SURVEY (ISWS) WILL USE NEXT GENERATION WATER OBSERVING SYSTEMS TO OBTAIN HIGH-QUALITY, REAL-TIME DATA TO FACILITATE INTEGRATED WATER AVAILABILITY ASSESSMENTS. THESE WATER AVAILABILITY ASSESSMENTS WILL INVESTIGATE THE CORRELATIONS AND CAUSES OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS. THIS WILL INCLUDE SPATIOTEMPORAL ANALYSES OF NITRATE AND PHOSPHORUS DISTRIBUTION THROUGHOUT THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN, AND GROUNDWATER MODELING OF WATER TRANSFERRED FROM NEAR SURFACE AQUIFERS TO THE ILLINOIS RIVER.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE PERFORMED IN THIS PROJECT INCLUDE, SHARING DATABASE RECORDS OF NITRATE FROM THE ISWS TO THE USGS, DEVELOPING A GROUNDWATER MODEL OF THE SHALLOW AQUIFERS IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN, INTERPRETING AND ANALYZING AERIAL ELECTROMAGNETIC DATA FOR INCORPORATION INTO THE GROUNDWATER MODEL, AND COLLABORATING WITH REGIONAL IRRIGATORS AND WATER OPERATORS TO UNDERSTAND WATER USE THROUGHOUT THE BASIN.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:A SUMMARY OF EXPECTED DELIVERABLES IS PROVIDED BELOW FOR EACH AWARD YEAR:YEAR 1: COMPLETION OF ARCHIVAL ASSISTANCE AND DATA SHARING OF NITRATE DATA.INITIATION OF GROUNDWATER MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND DOCUMENTATION.COMPLETION OF FIRST ITERATION OF GROUNDWATER FLOW SIMULATION OF ILRB.IDENTIFY FARMER STAKEHOLDER COLLABORATORS WILLING TO INSTALL METERS ON THEIR LAND.BEGIN INTERPRETATION OF AEM DATA FOR MODELED HYDROSTRATIGRAPHIC INFORMATION, AS THE DATA BECOMES AVAILABLE.YEAR 2: INSTALLATION OF IRRIGATION FLOW METERS.DRAFT AND INITIATE REVIEW OF MODELS AND ASSOCIATED MANUSCRIPTS.COMPLETION OF FIRST-ITERATION BASIN-SCALE NITRATE SIMULATION OF ILRB.ASSISTANCE WITH WORKFLOWS TO LOAD IRRIGATION FLOW DATA INTO USGS DATABASES.INCORPORATION OF AEM-DERIVED BEDROCK SURFACES INTO GROUNDWATER FLOW MODEL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, ILLINOIS STATE WATER SURVEY, PRAIRIE RESEARCH INSTITUTE, UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, AND THE REGIONAL PUBLIC STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT THE ILLINOIS RIVER BASIN.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 14 2023-8 13 24PROJECT TITLE: LIDAR-DERIVED FUELS ESTIMATESTERRESTRIAL LIDAR SCANNING (TLS) IS BECOMING A POPULAR TOOL FOR FAST AND OBJECTIVE SAMPLING IN FUELS MONITORING. HOWEVER, ITS CAPABILITIES NEED TO BE FURTHER TESTED FOR DESCRIBING FUELS IN VARIOUS FUEL TYPES, VEGETATION DENSITY, AND FIRE MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS. PROPOSE TO TEST THE UTILITY OF TLS IN ESTIMATING SPECIFIC FUELS VARIABLES INCLUDING TONS PER ACRE OF FUEL LOAD, PERCENT COVER OF UNDERSTORY VEGETATION, AND VERTICAL PROFILE OF PLANT AREA AND DENSITY. SUCH VARIABLES ARE KEY TO ACCURATELY ESTIMATING AND PREDICTING WILDFIRE SPREAD AND BEHAVIOR. WILL DEVELOP METHODS TO ESTIMATE THESE VARIABLES FROM TLS DATA COMBINED WITH OTHER REMOTE SENSING DATA SOURCES. WILL ASSESS THE ACCURACIES OF THE RESULTING ESTIMATES ACROSS A GRADIENT OF FUEL TYPES, VEGETATION COVER TYPES AND DENSITY, AND FIRE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. TO DEVELOP AND VALIDATE THE FUELS ESTIMATES FROM TLS DATA, WILL ESTABLISH FIELD PLOTS, WHERE WILL MEASURE VEGETATION COVER, DENSITY, AND FUEL TYPES. THESE MEASUREMENTS WILL THEN BE COMPARED TO THE TLS-DERIVED ESTIMATES. BOTH FIELD-BASED AND TLS-BASED MEASUREMENTS WILL TAKE PLACE OVER SUMMER GROWING SEASONS OF 2023-2024. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT ONE PHD STUDENT FOR 2 YEARS. THE DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE:TLS MEASUREMENTS OF FIELD PLOTS ACROSS VARYING VEGETATION COVER TYPES, DENSITY, AND FUEL TYPESFIELD-BASED MEASUREMENTS OF VEGETATION COVER, DENSITY, AND FUEL TYPESCOMPARISON OF THESE PRODUCTS AND VALIDATION OF THE TLS-BASED ESTIMATES OF VEGETATION COVER, DENSITY, AND FUEL LOADSTATISTICAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN TLS-BASED ESTIMATES COMBINED WITH OTHER REMOTE SENSING DATA SOURCES VERSUS FIELD-BASED MEASUREMENTS OF VEGETATION COVER, DENSITY, AND FUELS

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 13 23-7 12 25PROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF A MIGRATORY BIRD MONITORING FRAMEWORK USING MOTUS DATA AND CAPTURE-RECAPTURE MODELSTHE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF MIGRATORY BIRDS REQUIRES RELIABLE INFORMATION DESCRIBING POPULATION DYNAMICS, DISTRIBUTION, AND MIGRATION PATTERNS THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL CYCLE. MUCH OF OUR CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF MIGRATORY BIRD ECOLOGY AND SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT IS BASED ON CAPTURING AND RELEASING BANDED BIRDS. RECOVERY OR RE-SIGHTING OF BANDED BIRDS PROVIDES DATA FOR INVESTIGATING SURVIVAL, CAUSES OF MORTALITY, PRODUCTIVITY, AND MIGRATION PATTERNS. HOWEVER, THE AMOUNT OF DATA COLLECTED PER MARKED BIRD IS OFTEN LOW DUE TO LOW ENCOUNTER RATES.  RECENT ADVANCEMENTS IN WILDLIFE MARKING TECHNOLOGY, OFFER NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO ADVANCE MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT BASED ON MARKED BIRDS. THE MOTUS TRACKING TECHNOLOGY IS ONE SUCH TECHNOLOGY. WILL WORK WITH MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND ASSOCIATED STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP CONTINUOUS-TIME AND CONTINUOUS-SPACE CAPTURE-RECAPTURE MODELS SUITABLE FOR USE WITH DATA COLLECTED ON THE MOTUS NETWORK. WILL ALSO USE SIMULATION-BASED STUDIES TO QUANTIFY STATISTICAL POWER AND OTHER SAMPLING OR DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS (E.G., NUMBER AND PLACEMENT OF TOWERS) TO IMPROVE INFERENCE FROM MOTUS DATA.  PREVIOUSLY, OUR RESEARCH GROUP DEMONSTRATED HOW CONTINUOUS-TIME APPROACHES COULD BE EXTENDED TO MOTUS DETECTIONS FROM RELATIVELY SIMPLE MOVEMENT SCENARIOS (SINGLE POPULATION MODELING BETWEEN DISTINCT WINTERING AND BREEDING SITES). FOR THIS PROJECT. WILL EXTEND THIS APPROACH TO INCLUDE MORE COMPLEX MOVEMENT SCENARIOS COMMON IN WATERFOWL POPULATIONS (MULTIPLE BREEDING OR NON-BREEDING POPULATIONS) AND WILL EXPLORE THE USE OF BOTH DISCRETE SPACE AND CONTINUOUS SPACE APPROACHES TO THESE SCENARIOS. TO INCORPORATE CONTINUOUS SPACE INTO THE ANALYSIS OF MOTUS DATA, WILL DEVELOP SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT MOVEMENT MODELS THAT TREAT DETECTIONS OF TAGGED BIRDS AS STEMMING FROM A LATENT MOVEMENT PATH (I.E., STATE PROCESS) AND THE PLACEMENT AND OPERATION OF MOTUS RECEIVERS (I.E., OBSERVATION PROCESS). WILL ALSO INVESTIGATE SAMPLING DESIGN TO IMPROVE MOTUS-BASED MONITORING OF PRIORITY BIRD SPECIES. WILL SIMULATE MOVEMENT TRACKS OF MIGRATORY BIRDS AND THE OVERLAY ALTERNATIVE RECEIVER DESIGNS TO GENERATE SAMPLING DATA. RECEIVER DESIGNS WILL DIFFER IN THE NUMBER AND ARRANGEMENT OF MOTUS TOWERS, ALLOWING US TO QUANTIFY HOW ALTERNATIVE ARRANGEMENTS INFLUENCE INFERENCE ABOUT PARAMETERS OF INTEREST TO DECISION MAKERS. THE WORK DESCRIBED ABOVE IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN AT LEAST 2-3 PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS AND WILL ALSO BE COMMUNICATED THROUGH CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS AT RELEVANT PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS. WILL ALSO PROVIDE USGS COLLABORATORS WITH REGULAR PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING OUR APPROACHES AND RESULTS. TO AID DECISION MAKERS, WILL ALSO CREATE DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS TO GUIDE SAMPLING CONSIDERATIONS FOR INVESTMENT IN MOTUS RECEIVERS AND TAGGING EFFORTS FOR PRIORITY SPECIES. THESE TOOLS WILL BE IN THE FORM OF REPRODUCIBLE ANALYSIS CODE AND OR WEB-BASED APPLICATIONS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 26 23-6 25 28PROJECT TITLE: GENETIC STRUCTURE OF DIAMONDBACK TERRAPINSTHIS AWARD AIMS TO CHARACTERIZE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE IN DIAMONDBACK TERRAPINS, MALACLEMYS TERRAPIN. THIS OBLIGATE ESTUARINE TURTLE SPECIES IS ENDEMIC TO THE UNITED STATES AND BERMUDA AND IS CONSIDERED A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN IN MANY RANGE STATES DUE TO HISTORICAL OVERHARVEST FOR THE FOOD MARKET, HABITAT LOSS AND ALTERATION, ROAD MORTALITY, CRAB TRAP BYCATCH, AND POACHING FOR THE PET TRADE. WILL USE MITOCHONDRIAL DNA MARKERS TO ASSESS GENETIC DIVERSITY AND GENETIC STRUCTURE OF DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN FORAGING AGGREGATIONS AT LOCAL (EVERGLADES TIDAL CREEKS) AND REGIONAL SCALES IN THE GULF OF MEXICO (COMPARISONS OF FLORIDA AND ALABAMA AGGREGATIONS). THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CHARACTERIZATION OF A REPEAT ARRAY IN THE MITOCHONDRIAL GENOME AND TESTING FOR HAPLOTYPE FREQUENCY DIFFERENTIATION BETWEEN ADJACENT TIDAL CREEK FORAGING GROUPS, AMONG LOCAL CLUSTERS OF TIDAL CREEKS, AND AMONG REGIONAL SITES SPANNING THE EVERGLADES AND MOBILE BAY. ADDITIONALLY, WILL OPTIMIZE MICROSATELLITE PANELS FOR ASSESSING INDIVIDUAL IDENTITY AND FIRST ORDER RELATIVES FOR USE IN FUTURE STUDIES. THIS WILL INCLUDE TESTING OF MARKERS ISOLATED FROM MARINE TURTLES AND OTHER EMYDID TURTLE SPECIES TO IDENTIFY POLYMORPHIC LOCI THAT AMPLIFY WELL, AND TESTING OF VARIOUS MULTIPLEX SCHEMES TO IDENTIFY THE BEST COMBINATIONS OF MARKERS.PRELIMINARY DATA FROM THE ATLANTIC COAST SUGGESTS THAT THE MITOCHONDRIAL MARKERS MIGHT BE ABLE TO IDENTIFY GENETIC STRUCTURE AT FINER SCALES THAN WITH PREVIOUS MICROSATELLITE LOCI. ANTICIPATE THAT THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE AN UPDATED PICTURE OF THE SCALE OF CONNECTIVITY ACROSS MULTIPLE SPATIAL SCALES IN NORTHEASTERN GULF OF MEXICO ESTUARIES. THESE DATA WILL PROVIDE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES, FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION, AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS WITH DATA ON THE APPROPRIATE SCALE FOR MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 3 23-7 2 24PROJECT TITLE: HARNESSING THE POWER OF GENOMICS TO INFORM RECOVERY STRATEGIES FOR THE THREATENED OREGON SPOTTED FROG (RANA PRETIOSA)THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO APPLY THE POWER OF CUTTING-EDGE GENOMIC TECHNIQUES TO THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG. THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG HAS DECLINED ACROSS ITS RANGE DUE TO LOSS, DEGRADATION, AND FRAGMENTATION OF ITS WETLAND HABITATS CAUSED BY ALTERED HYDROLOGY AND INVASIVE VEGETATION AND PREDATORS. THE SPECIES WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2014. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE NEEDS INFORMATION ON RANGEWIDE, WITHIN-SUBBASIN (THE PLANNING UNIT FOR RECOVERY), AND WITHIN-POPULATION LEVEL GENOMICS TO INFORM THE ONGOING DEVELOPMENT OF THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG RECOVERY PLAN AND RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY. NEW GENOMIC APPROACHES OFFER MUCH MORE DETAILED ANALYSES THAN PREVIOUS GENETIC APPROACHES TO INFORM RECOVERY OF IMPERILED SPECIES.FUNDING IN THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS PHASE I OF OUR RESEARCH PROGRAM, WHICH USES GENOMIC DATA TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES ACROSS THE RANGE OF OREGON SPOTTED FROGS IN THE STATE OF OREGON: (1) DELINEATE CONSERVATION UNITS. (2) QUANTIFY CONNECTIVITY AMONG POPULATIONS. (3) EVALUATE ADAPTIVE DIVERGENCE AMONG POPULATIONS. (4) TEST FOR EVIDENCE OF GENETIC DECLINES (BOTTLENECKS). (5) ESTIMATE WITHIN POPULATION GENETIC VARIATION, INCLUDING EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZES AND INBREEDING COEFFICIENTS.THE MAIN DELIVERABLE FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS THE SEQUENCE DATA DERIVED FROM THE TISSUE SAMPLES TO BE ANALYZED IN 202324. PRESENTLY HAVE ABOUT 3000 TISSUE SAMPLES. THE PARTNER GROUP WILL CONSULT ON THE ORDER FOR PROCESSING OF SAMPLES. EXPECT TO HAVE SEQUENCE DATA FROM ABOUT 250 SAMPLES BY DECEMBER 31, 2023. THIS PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP AMONG COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM SCIENCE CENTER, AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE BEND FIELD OFFICE (THE LEAD OFFICE ON THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG RECOVERY PLAN). COMMUNICATION AMONG THE PARTIES WILL BE REGULAR. COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL SUBMIT A REPORT TO THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY FOREST BY 31 DECEMBER 2024 THAT SUMMARIZES SEQUENCING AND GENOTYPE DATA GENERATED.

PROJECT TITLE: COMMITTEE ON SOLID EARTH GEOPHYSICS (COSEG) AND IT ACTIVITIESPROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2025DESCRIPTION: THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT A NATIONAL ACADEMIES OF SCIENCES, ENGINEERING, AND MEDICINE (NATIONAL ACADEMIES) STANDING COMMITTEE ON SOLID EARTH GEOPHYSICS. THE COMMITTEE CONSISTS OF VOLUNTEER EXPERTS IN DIVERSE FIELDS OF GEOPHYSICS INCLUDING SEISMOLOGY, GEODESY, GEODYNAMICS, MINERAL PHYSICS, AND ROCK MECHANICS. THE COMMITTEES MISSION IS TO ADVISE THE GOVERNMENT AND SOCIETY ON SCIENTIFIC, TECHNICAL, AND POLICY MATTERS RELATED TO GEOPHYSICS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE COMMITTEE WILL HOLD TWO TWO-DAY MEETINGS PER YEAR. THE MEETINGS WILL BE HYBRID, WITH AN IN-PERSON COMPONENT HELD AT A NATIONAL ACADEMIES FACILITY OR ANOTHER LOCATION, AS APPROPRIATE, AND A REMOTE VIRTUAL COMPONENT. IN PREPARATION FOR THESE MEETINGS, THE COMMITTEE WILL DISCUSS AND DETERMINE A TOPIC FOR THE MEETING AND INVITE SPEAKERS AND PANELISTS FOR PUBLIC TALKS AND SEMINARS ON THE TOPIC. ADDITIONALLY, THE COMMITTEE WILL MEET WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM USGS AND THE COMMITTEES OTHER SPONSORING AGENCIES (CURRENTLY THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY, THE NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION, AND NASA) TO DISCUSS GEOPHYSICS-RELATED WORK AT THOSE AGENCIES AND ACT AS ACADEMIC REPRESENTATIVES TO THOSE AGENCIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS ACTIVITY CONSIST OF THE BIANNUAL MEETINGS, WHICH INCLUDE A RECORDING POSTED ON THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES WEBSITE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PUBLIC MEETINGS RECEIVE HUNDREDS OF VIRTUAL REGISTRANTS FROM MEMBERS OF ACADEMIA, FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS, INDUSTRY, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, STUDENTS, AND MEDIA. MANY MORE VIEW THE RECORDINGS AFTER THE MEETINGS AS WELL. THE EXECUTIVE SESSIONS BETWEEN THE COMMITTEE MEMBERS, STAFF, AND AGENCY REPRESENTATIVES BENEFIT BOTH THE AGENCIES AND THE ACADEMIC COMMUNITY, AS THE COMMITTEE MEMBERS ACT AS A CONDUIT FOR COMMUNICATING IDEAS, PROGRESS, AND PRIORITIES BETWEEN THE AGENCIES AND ACADEMIC FIELDS. THERE IS ALSO AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN FROM OTHER SECTORS, SUCH AS PRIVATE INDUSTRY AND STATE GOVERNMENT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE ANTICIPATED.

TITLE: SPONSORSHIP OF GORDON RESEARCH CONFERENCE - COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICSPROJECT PERIOD: 05 18 2023- 07 23 2023CONTACTS: CONFERENCE CO-CHAIRS: KRISTEN DAVIS (UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, IRVINE) AND WEIFENG (GORDON) ZHANG (WOODS HOLE OCEANOGRAPHIC INSTITUTION)GORDON RESEARCH CONFERENCES (GRC) SEEKS FUNDING FROM USGS AS A PARTIAL CONTRIBUTION TOWARD ATTENDEE COSTS FOR THE GORDON RESEARCH SEMINAR (GRS) ON COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICS, TO BE HELD AT THE BRYANT UNIVERSITY ON JUNE 17-23, 2023. USGSS SUPPORT WILL BE NECESSARY FOR THE CONFERENCE PROGRAM COMMITTEE TO ACHIEVE THE STRONGEST POSSIBLE, CUTTING-EDGE SCIENTIFIC PROGRAM. IT WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE ATTENDANCE OF GRADUATE STUDENTS, POST-DOCS, EARLY CAREER RESEARCHERS, INVITED SPEAKERS AND DISCUSSION LEADERS. THE GORDON RESEARCH CONFERENCES HAS A LONG HISTORY OF PROVIDING AN INTERNATIONAL FORUM FOR THE PRESENTATION AND DISCUSSION OF FRONTIER RESEARCH IN A VARIETY OF SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING FIELDS, INCLUDING THE COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICS. THE THEME OF THE 2023 GRC ON COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICS IS COASTAL OCEAN PHYSICS AND ITS CONNECTIONS TO MARINE ECOSYSTEM, WHICH IS DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE RESEARCH OF USGS SCIENTISTS IN THE COASTAL OCEANS. THE TOPICS TO BE DISCUSSED AT THE CONFERENCE ARE HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE USGS MISSION OF MONITORING, ANALYZING, AND PREDICTING CURRENT AND EVOLVING EARTH-SYSTEM INTERACTIONS AND DELIVERING ACTIONABLE INFORMATION AT SCALES AND TIMEFRAMES RELEVANT TO DECISION MAKERS. OVER THE YEARS, USGS SCIENTISTS HAVE BEEN ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN THE GRC COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICS, INCLUDING SERVING AS THE CHAIRS, DISCUSSION LEADERS AND SPEAKERS. FOUR USGS SCIENTISTS WILL ATTEND THE 2023 GRC COASTAL OCEAN DYNAMICS, AND CHRISTOPHER SHERWOOD, ANOTHER USGS SCIENTIST, HAS BEEN SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN THE CONFERENCE PLANNING, INCLUDING BUILDING A PROGRAM THAT FEATURES NOVEL IDEAS AND RECENT ADVANCES IN DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE COASTAL OCEANOGRAPHY.IN 2023, GRC WILL CONTINUE THE SUCCESSFUL ADDITION OF A GORDON RESEARCH SEMINAR ON THE WEEKEND BEFORE THE GRC. THE GRS SPECIFICALLY TARGETS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF STUDENTS AND EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS, THEREBY GREATLY EXPANDING THE BROADER IMPACT OF THE GRC ITSELF.THERE WILL ALSO BE A GRC POWER HOUR DURING THE CONFERENCE DEDICATED TO ADDRESSING THE DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION IN THE SCIENTIFIC WORKPLACE BY PROVIDING A SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR INFORMAL AND MEANINGFUL CONVERSATIONS AMONGST COLLEAGUES OF ALL CAREER STAGES. AS AN EXPECTED OUTCOME, THE CONFERENCE WILL FOSTER AN ENVIRONMENT FOR PEOPLE TO SHOWCASE CUTTING EDGE SCIENCES, TO CARRY OUT PROVOCATIVE AND CONSTRUCTIVE DISCUSSIONS, TO ESTABLISH INTELLECTUAL CONNECTIONS, AND TO BUILD A VIBRANT COMMUNITY WITH DIVERSE BACKGROUND AND PERSPECTIVES.

ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN IS THE SITE OF A NEXT GENERAON WATERSHED OBSERVATION ON SYSTEM(NGWOS) PROJECT RUN BY THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. OUTCOMES OF NGWOS PROJECTS INCLUDEENHANCED SENSING OF ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS (ESPECIALLY WITH RESPECT TO WATER FLOWS ANDQUALITY) AND GREATER INVESTIGATION OF THE DYNAMICS OF SURFACE WATER SOURCES IN TIME AND SPACE. TOCOMPLEMENT AND ENHANCE THESE ACTIVITIES, WE PROPOSE TO INVESTIGATE THE SPATIAL CHANGES INWATER QUALITY THAT ARE LIKELY TO INDICATE CHANGES IN SURFACE WATER SOURCES. THE PROJECT HAS 3 OBJECTIVES: 1) TO CHARACTERIZE SPATIAL VARIATION IN WATERQUALITY CONDITIONS FOR GIVEN HIGH ANDLOWFLOW CONDITIONS, WHICH CAN INFORM ANALYSIS OF POINT AND NONPOINT SOURCE SOLUTE SOURCES, 2)TO CHARACTERIZE THE TEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN WATERQUALITY CONDITIONS FOR HIGH AND LOWFLOWCONDITIONS, AND 3) TO PROVIDE BROAD INTERPRETATIONS OF THE WATERQUALITY DATA SETS TO BETTEREVALUATE DOWNSTREAM WATERQUALITY INFLUENCES OF POINT AND NONPOINT SOURCES AND TO IDENTIFYREACHES OF NOTABLE GROUNDWATER EXCHANGE. TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES, WE PLAN TO CONDUCT.REPEAT LAGRANGIAN DATA COLLECTION CAMPAIGNS TWICE ANNUALLY ALONG THE MAINSTEMS OF THECOLORADO AND GUNNISON RIVERS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THESE FIELD CAMPAIGNS INCLUDE MEASUREMENT OF A NUMBER OFWATER QUALITY PARAMETERS AT HIGH FREQUENCY (1060 SECONDS DEPENDING ON THE PARAMETER), ANDCOLLECTION OF SURFACE WATER SAMPLES AT PREIDENTIFIED NWIS SITES (I.E., STREAM GAGES). DATACOLLECTED FROM THESE CAMPAIGNS WILL BE INTERPRETED BY THE PROJECT TEAM AND PUBLISHED AS USGSDATA RELEASES IN THE USGS SCIENCE BASE ONLINE DATABASEINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): ALL INTERESTED PARTIES ACCESSING CU AND USGS DATA RELEASESSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, NONE IDENTIFIED

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 23-6 30 24PROJECT TITLE: INFLUENCE OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING AND INTRINSIC PHYSICAL PROPERTIES ON SLOPE STABILITY AND PALEOSEISMOLOGICAL STUDIES IN SUBDUCTION ZONE SETTINGSPLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY: THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO UNDERSTAND THE INFLUENCE OF EARTHQUAKE-SHAKING ON SEDIMENTS IN OCEANIC AND LAKE SETTINGS. THIS INCLUDES THE PROCESSES ASSOCIATED WITH EARTHQUAKE-GENERATED SEDIMENT FAILURE HAZARDS (LANDSLIDES, DEBRIS FLOWS, SLUMPS, TURBIDITY FLOWS) AND THE EFFECTS OF NON-FAILURE SEISMIC WAVES THAT DO NOT TRIGGER SEDIMENT MOTION. GEOTECHNICAL MEASUREMENTS FOCUS ON STRENGTH OF SEDIMENTS, WHICH WILL THEN BE USED TO QUANTIFY SLOPE STABILITY WITH AN INTEGRATION OF HIGH-RESOLUTION MULTIBEAM BATHYMETRY AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO UNDERSTAND HOW THE MECHANICAL STRENGTH PROPERTIES AND SOURCE CHARACTERISTICS OF MARINE AND LAKE SEDIMENT INFLUENCES SLOPE STABILITY ALONG EARTHQUAKE-PRONE ACTIVE MARGINS. SYSTEMATIC CHARACTERIZATION OF SEABED AND LAKE-BED SEDIMENTS AND COMPARISON WITH LANDSLIDE DISTRIBUTION WILL IMPROVE ASSESSMENT OF EARTHQUAKE-SHAKING PROXIES AND GROUND MOTION HAZARD PREDICTIONS. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL AID IN THE MISSION TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE COASTAL AND MARINE GEOHAZARDS AND TO IMPROVE PROBABILISTIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS. IN ADDITION, RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION AND DATA VALUABLE TO THE OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY INDUSTRY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED FOCUS ON HIGH-RESOLUTION (EVERY 2 CM) DOWN-CORE UNDRAINED SHEAR STRENGTH MEASUREMENTS AND ASSOCIATED PLASTICITY PROPERTIES ON SPLIT SEDIMENT CORES. DEVICES TO BE USED INCLUDE THE FALL CONE PENETROMETER AND SEMI-AUTOMATED VANE SHEAR DEVICE. CALCULATIONS OF THE FACTOR OF SAFETY AT CORE LOCATIONS WILL ALSO BE PERFORMED WITH DENSITY VALUES FROM EXISTING MULTISENSORY CORE LOGS, AND GRAIN SIZE DATA. PREDICTIONS OF POTENTIAL LANDSLIDES WILL FOLLOW USING NUMERICAL MODELING THAT WILL EXAMINE STABILITY WITH AND WITHOUT EARTHQUAKE-SHAKING SCENARIOS. FINALLY, POTENTIAL LANDSLIDE MOBILITY (SLOW VERSUS FAST) WILL BE MADE USING ESTABLISHED METHODS, WHICH WILL FEED VALUABLE INSIGHTS INTO EFFORTS FOCUSED ON TSUNAMI MODELING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DETAILED CHARACTERIZATIONS OF FUNDAMENTAL SEDIMENT PROPERTIES, INCLUDING SHEAR STRENGTH AND OTHER FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE SLOPE STABILITY, COMPARISONS OF SEDIMENT PROPERTIES AND LANDSLIDE DISTRIBUTIONS WITH GROUND SHAKING MODELS TO REFINE HAZARD PREDICTIONS, DEVELOPMENT OF PHYSICS-BASED MODELS TO EVALUATE THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF SEDIMENT PROPERTIES, STRATIGRAPHIC DEVELOPMENT AND SEAFLOOR LAKEFLOOR MORPHOLOGY IN PRECONDITIONING SLOPES FOR FAILURE, AND ASSESS THE ROLE OF SEISMIC STRENGTHENING. THESE RESEARCH DELIVERABLES WILL YIELD PRODUCTS AND OUTCOMES THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY VIA PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES AND WORKSHOPS. ANNUAL PROGRESS, FINANCIAL, AND FINAL TECHNICAL REPORTS WILL BE PROVIDED. ALL DATA AND ANALYSES WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED ON A REGULAR BASIS TO USGS COLLABORATORS AND ARCHIVED AS REQUESTED BY USGS. AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT, A HARD DRIVE OF ALL PRODUCTS WILL BE PROVIDED. THE RESULTS OF THIS SCIENTIFIC PROGRAM SUPPORT NATIONAL PRIORITIES IN BECOMING MORE PREPARED AND RESILIENT TO IMPACTS OF NATURAL HAZARDS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

GRANTEE NAME:  UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON GRANT NUMBER: TBD PROJECT TITLE: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH IN ARRAY SEISMOLOGY FOR EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING. PROJECT DATES:  06 01 2023 TO 05 31 2025 AWARD PURPOSE: THIS AWARD AIMS TO FOSTER COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH BETWEEN USGS AND UW FOR A SPECIFIC RESEARCH AREA WITHIN THE SHAKEALERT PROGRAM.  THE PROJECT FOCUSES ON INVESTIGATING SEISMIC ARRAY PROCESSING TECHNIQUES TO DETECT EARTHQUAKE RUPTURES THAT START OFFSHORE MORE RAPIDLY AND OR ACCURATELY THAN IS POSSIBLE WITH THE CURRENT SHAKEALERT ALGORITHMS ALONE. ACTIVES TO BE PERFORMED: THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON (UW), IN COLLABORATION WITH THE USGS, WILL DESIGN A SMALL-APERTURE ( 1X1 KM), TEN-ELEMENT SEISMIC ARRAY AND INSTALL IT ON THE OLYMPIC PENINSULA NEAR FORKS, WA. UW AND USGS WILL COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOP AND TEST VARIOUS ARRAY ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES TO BE EVALUATED FOR SUITABILITY OF INCLUSION IN THE SHAKEALERT SYSTEM. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: ALL DATA RECORDED BY THE TEN-ELEMENT ARRAY WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE USE. ANY SOFTWARE OR METHODOLOGIES THAT WILL BE DEVELOPED WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WHETHER ARRAY-BASED METHODS COULD BENEFIT THE USGS SHAKEALERT SYSTEM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: USGS SHAKEALERT EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING SYSTEM SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NOT APPLICABLE

GRANTEE NAME:  THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTEGRANT NUMBER: G23AC00346PROJECT TITLE: THE GREAT UPDATE: NEW STREAM PERMANENCE CLASSIFICATIONS FOR STREAMS IN THE GREAT BASINPROJECT DATES:  06 01 2023 TO 10 31 2023AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO INCREASE OBSERVATIONS THROUGHOUT THE GREAT BASIN REGION OF STREAM PERMANENCE CLASSIFICATIONS INFORMING ON STREAM CHANNEL PRESENCE AND AVAILABLE HYDROGRAPHY. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE DATA THAT WILL INFORM ON ROAD-STREAM CROSSINGS, STREAM HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, WET AND DRYING PATTERNS IN NON-PERENNIAL STREAMS, AND THE PRESENCE OF SURFACE FLOWS IN STREAMS THROUGHOUT THE REGION.    ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FOUR 2-PERSON CREWS WILL NAVIGATE TO DESIGNATED POINTS AND OR ROUTES PROVIDED BY USGS PERSONNEL THROUGHOUT NORTHERN NEVADA AND EASTERN CALIFORNIA TO RECORD STREAM FLOW PERMANENCE (FLOWPER) OBSERVATIONS AND ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS (ROADXSTR) OBSERVATIONS ON TABLETS. EACH OBSERVATION LOCATION WILL BE RECORDED USING A BAD ELF GPS UNIT TO RECORD THE OBSERVATIONS SUBMETER LOCATION. DATA COLLECTION WILL TAKE PLACE ON 8-DAY HITCHES TO ENSURE EFFICIENCY AND SUMMARIES OF DATA COLLECTION WILL BE SENT BY THE CREW LEAD TO USGS PERSONNEL AT THE END OF EACH HITCH AS WELL AS A PROGRESS REPORT EACH MONTH. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE MAIN DELIVERABLES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE STREAM FLOW PERMANENCE (FLOWPER) OBSERVATIONS COLLECTED BY CREWS AND UPLOADED VIA WI-FI ONTO THE FLOWPER PUBLIC DATABASE.  AND ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS (ROADXSTR) OBSERVATIONS COLLECTED BY CREWS AND UPLOADED VIA WI-FI ONTO THE ROADXSTR PUBLIC DATABASE. THIS IS A PILOT YEAR FOR THIS WORK, SO THERE ARE NO EXPECTATIONS SET FOR THE NUMBER OF OBSERVATIONS MADE. INSTEAD, THE EXPECTATION WILL BE THE COMPLETION OF 11,520 PERSON HOURS WORKED BETWEEN FOUR 2-PERSON CREWS. MORE OF THESE HOURS WILL BE ALLOCATED TO CONDUCTING FLOWPER SURVEYS THAN ROADXSTR SURVEYS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: LAND MANAGERS WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) AND US FOREST SERVICE (USFS) WILL BE ABLE TO UTILIZE THIS DATA TO MAKE MORE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING THE HABITAT NEEDS FOR AQUATIC AND SEMI-AQUATIC SPECIES, AS WELL AS ANY SPECIES THAT DEPENDS ON AVAILABLE SURFACE WATER FOR SURVIVAL. THIS INCLUDES MANY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES, AS WELL AS SPECIES SUCH AS NORTH AMERICAN BEAVER.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NOT APPLICABLE

PROJECT TITLE: BUILDING CAPACITY TO MEET CURRENT AND FUTURE CHALLENGES AND NEEDS FACING THE U.S. MINERALRESOURCES WORKFORCE: A WORKSHOPPROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2024DESCRIPTION:  THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT A NATIONAL ACADEMIES OF SCIENCES, ENGINEERING, AND MEDICINE (NATIONALACADEMIES) WORKSHOP ON BUILDING THE U.S. CAPACITY FOR MINERAL WORKFORCE NEEDS. AN AD HOC WORKSHOP PLANNING COMMITTEE WILL EXPLORE SKILLS NEEDED FOR THE WORKFORCE, HOW HIGHER EDUCATION PROGRAMS CAN PREPARE THEIR STUDENTS FOR CAREERS, PROGRAMS THAT MIGHT SERVE AS MODELS, AND THE TYPES OF SUPPORT NEEDED TO MEET FUTURE DEMANDS AND INCREASE THE SUPPLY OF TRAINED WORKERS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: COMMITTEE FORMATION. FOLLOWING A BROAD CALL FOR NOMINATIONS, THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES LEADERSHIP WILL APPOINT A WORKSHOP PLANNING COMMITTEE. WORKSHOP PLANNING. WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A NATIONAL ACADEMIES BOARD ON EARTH SCIENCES AND RESOURCES STAFF TEAM, THE WORKSHOP PLANNING COMMITTEE WILL DISCUSS WORKSHOP OBJECTIVES, DEVELOP AN AGENDA, AND WILL INVITE SPEAKERS AND PARTICIPANTS. THE WORKSHOP WILL BE HYBRID, WITH AN IN-PERSON COMPONENT HELD AT A NATIONAL ACADEMIES FACILITY AND A REMOTE VIRTUAL COMPONENT.THE WORKSHOP WILL INCLUDE PEOPLE WITH EXPERTISE IN WORKFORCE TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENT AND IN CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES, MINING, AND RELATED FIELDS.WORKSHOP PROCEEDINGS PREPARATION, REVIEW, AND RELEASE. A STAFF MEMBER WILL AUTHOR A WRITTEN PROCEEDINGS THAT CAPTURES THE DISCUSSIONS PRESENTED DURING THE WORKSHOP. THIS PROCEEDINGS WILL BE EXTERNALLY PEER-REVIEWED AND INSTITUTIONALLY REVIEWED BEFORE ITS RELEASE. IT WILL BE MADE FREELY AVAILABLE TO THE USGS AND THE PUBLIC UPON ITS RELEASE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS ACTIVITY INCLUDE A WORKSHOP, A STAFF-AUTHORED WRITTEN PROCEEDINGS, AND A SHORT HIGHLIGHTS DOCUMENT BASED ON THE PROCEEDINGS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE REPORT WILL BE USEFUL TO FEDERAL AGENCIES, ACADEMIA, AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR INTERESTED IN BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF THE U.S. MINERAL RESOURCES WORKFORCE. IT MAY ALSO PROVE VALUABLE FOR STATE, LOCAL, AND TRIBAL AGENCIES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOR CO-LOCATED SPACE WITH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2028AWARD PURPOSE: COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO PROVIDE USE OF SPACE TO THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS).ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THE RECIPIENT SHALL PROVIDE SPACE TO THE USGS IN A VACANT MOVE IN CONDITION, READY FOR USGSS OCCUPANCY, NOT INCLUDING USGSS FURNITURE, FIXTURES AND EQUIPMENT. PROJECT PERIOD: 7 17 23-7 16 24PROJECT TITLE   UPGRADING PRE AND POST-PROCESSING TOLLS OF THE BISCAYNE AND SOUTHERN EVERGLADES COASTAL TRANSPORT (BISECT) MODELTHE BISCAYNE AND SOUTHERN EVERGLADES COASTAL TRANSPORT (BISECT) APPLICATION WAS DEVELOPED BY USGS TO SIMULATE HYDROLOGY IN SOUTHERN FLORIDA, INCLUDING MODELING SEA LEVEL RISE, WATER FLOW AND THE NUMBER OF DAYS PER YEAR THAT AN AREA OF LAND IS WET AT A LOCATION, GROUNDWATER LEVELS AND SALINITY. HOWEVER, IN ITS CURRENT FORM BISECT REMAINS CHALLENGING TO RUN FOR SEVERAL REASONS, BECAUSE IT DEPENDS ON THE INPUT OF TWO OTHER SUB-MODELS THAT ARE NOT CODED IN THE CURRENT WORKFLOW OF BISECT. THIS IS SUSCEPTIBLE TO ERRORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO A LACK OF REPRODUCIBILITY OF RUNNING SEA LEVEL RISE SCENARIOS THROUGH BISECT AT THIS TIME. THE MAIN GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE USABILITY OF THE MODEL BY STREAMLINING THE MODEL WORKFLOW AND REMOVING ANY POST-PROCESSING STEPS WITHIN THE WORKFLOW. PRE-PROCESSING CODES WILL BE DEVELOPED TO CREATE THE INPUT VARIABLES FIELD FROM THE SUB-MODELS WHOSE OUTPUT WILL BE USED IN BISECT.  ALL INPUT DATA TO BISECT WILL BE CONSOLIDATED INTO ONE NETCDF FILE. IT CONSISTS OF A SET OF INTERFACES FOR ARRAY-ORIENTED DATA ACCESS AND A FREELY DISTRIBUTED COLLECTION OF DATA ACCESS LIBRARIES FOR VARIOUS LANGUAGES. THE NETCDF LIBRARIES SUPPORT A MACHINE-INDEPENDENT FORMAT FOR REPRESENTING SCIENTIFIC DATA. BISECT MODEL OUTPUT WILL ALSO BE CHANGED TO THE NETCDF FORMAT IN ORDER TO FACILITATE POST-PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS WITH EXISTING OFF-THE-SHELF SOFTWARE PACKAGES. PRODUCTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL CONSIST OF NEW PRE AND POST PROCESSING CODES IN THE LANGUAGES MOST RELEVANT TO THE USAGE AND THE USERS AT USGS FOR THEIR WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 23-6 30 25PROJECT TITLE: TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENTS TOWARDS BUILDING A NATIONAL TOPOGRAPHIC CHANGE MAPPINGTHE THREE-DIMENSIONAL (3D) SHAPE OF THE EARTH IS CONSTANTLY CHANGING, REQUIRING THAT WE QUANTIFY THE PROCESSES THAT DRIVE CHANGE IN FOUR DIMENSIONS (4D  SPACE AND TIME). HOWEVER, NO CONSISTENT AND BROAD-SCALE EFFORT HAS BEEN DEVELOPED TO SYSTEMATICALLY MAP AND MONITOR 3D LAND SURFACE CHANGES OVER ANY SIGNIFICANT TIME-PERIOD. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE POWELL CENTER WORKING GROUP ON NATIONAL TOPOGRAPHIC CHANGE IS TO WORK TOWARDS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A A NATIONAL TOPOGRAPHIC CHANGE MAPPING AND MONITORING SYSTEM. THIS SYSTEM WOULD ENABLE ONGOING NATIONWIDE ASSESSMENT OF MULTI-SCALE 3D CHANGES IN THE EARTHS SURFACE. PROPOSE THREE MAJOR ACTIVITIES THAT BUILD TOWARDS THE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL REQUIREMENTS OF A BROAD-SCALE CHANGE MONITORING SYSTEM: (1) THE DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF AN AUTOMATIC TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING WORKFLOW APPLIED TO THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 3D ELEVATION PROGRAM (3DEP) TOPOGRAPHY OVER A MAJOR GEOGRAPHIC AREA OF THE UNITED STATES. (2) CENTURY-SCALE TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING FOCUSED ON THE PUGET SOUND AREA, WASHINGTON, USING AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY FROM AS EARLY AS 1937, THE NATIONAL ELEVATION DATASET (NED), AND MULTI-TEMPORAL LIDAR TOPOGRAPHY. (3) ADVANCING THE ANALYSIS AND COMPUTATION OF UNCERTAINTY IN TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING RESULTS, PARTICULARLY TOWARDS A VISION OF AN AUTOMATIC SPATIALLY VARIABLE ERROR CALCULATION. IN TERMS OF DELIVERABLES, EXPECT TO DEVELOP SEMI- TO- FULLY- AUTOMATIC WORKFLOWS THAT PERFORM TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING WITH ADVANCED ERROR CALCULATIONS. THESE WORKFLOWS AND THE NEW INSIGHT ON TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING WILL BE DESCRIBED IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL. WILL PRODUCE LARGE-SCALE TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING RESULTS THAT ANTICIPATE PUBLISHING AS AN ORIGINAL SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION OR AS A DATA PUBLICATION. ANTICIPATE BROAD INTEREST IN THE TOPOGRAPHIC CHANGE RESULTS TO BE PRODUCED BY A NATIONAL-SCALE TOPOGRAPHIC CHANGE AND MONITORING SYSTEM: THE PUBLIC WILL BE ABLE TO MAP LANDSCAPE CHANGE IN THE COMMUNITY, STUDENTS CAN LEARN ABOUT STATE-OF-THE-ART REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGY AND APPROACHES TO MEASURING CHANGE, URBAN PLANNERS AND ENGINEERS CAN REVIEW CHANGE IN CRITICAL AREAS, AND SCIENTISTS CAN USE THE RESULTS TO INFORM RESEARCH ACTIVITIES.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 23-5 31 24PROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPING EXPERIMENTAL RESEARCH TO SUPPORT COREGONINE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION IN THE LAURENTIAN GREAT LAKESTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AND CONDUCT EXPERIMENTS THAT SUPPORT THE NATIVE DEEPWATER PREY FISH COMMUNITY, SPECIFICALLY FOCUSED ON IMPERILED COREGONINES, IN THE LAURENTIAN GREAT LAKES. THERE ARE TWO MAIN FOCI OF THE PROJECT. FIRST, THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP TECHNOLOGIES THAT IMPROVE THE OUTCOMES OF COREGONINE HATCHERY STOCKING. EXAMPLE TECHNOLOGIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING GENETIC TOOLS TO SUPPORT RESTORATION EFFORTS AND DEVELOPING NEW APPROACHES IN THE HATCHERY TO HELP PRODUCE MORE WILD-LIKE FISH, WHICH HAVE BEEN SHOWN IN OTHER SPECIES TO IMPROVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP LARGE PANELS OF GENETIC MARKERS THAT MONITOR MEASURES OF GENETIC DIVERSITY. THESE GENETIC PANELS WILL ALSO BE USED AS A TOOL TO TRACK OFFSPRING PRODUCED IN THE HATCHERY THROUGH SPACE AND TIME.  IN ADDITION, EXPERIMENTS WITH HATCHERY FISH THAT MANIPULATE FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH HABITAT, AS WELL AS THE TIMING AND LOCATION FOR RELEASING FISH WILL BE EXPLORED TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL REARING AND RELEASE APPROACH TO MAXIMIZE THE SUCCESS OF THIS RESTORATION EFFORT. WORK WILL ALSO FOCUS ON UNDERSTANDING IMPEDIMENTS IN THE GREAT LAKES THAT HINDER RESTORATION EFFORTS SUCH AS POOR SPAWNING HABITAT, AND STUDYING HOW THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT CAN BE ALTERED TO IMPROVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES. SECONDLY, THIS BODY OF WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH STUDENTS, ESPECIALLY SEEKING TO EXPAND OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, THAT WILL BE TRAINED IN CUTTING-EDGE TECHNIQUES AND APPROACHES USED BY FISHERIES TECHNICIANS, BIOLOGISTS, AND RESEARCHERS. ULTIMATELY, WORK ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT AIDS IN THE RESTORATION OF THE GREAT LAKES AND IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A DIVERSE GROUP OF FUTURE FISHERIES SCIENTISTS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 23-5 31 24PROJECT TITLE: EVALUATING ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES AT BUS STOPS IN DENVERTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN GREEN SPACE AND AIR POLLUTION, AS WELL AS BETWEEN THE LEVELS OF DIFFERENT AIR POLLUTANTS AND HEAT IN DENVER. WILL USE DATA FROM DEPLOYING AIR POLLUTION MONITORS AND TEMPERATURE SENSORS AT BUS STOPS WITH DIFFERENT DEGREES OF GREEN COVER AROUND DENVER FOR A MONTH IN SUMMER TO EVALUATE THESE RELATIONSHIPS. IN ADDITION TO THE STATIONARY DATA, WILL ALSO COLLECT MOBILE AIR POLLUTION AND TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENTS FROM MONITORS DEPLOYED ON A MOBILE LABORATORY WHICH WILL BE OPERATED ON PREDETERMINED ROUTES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED1)PURCHASE AIR QUALITY MONITORS2)HIRE AND TRAIN TWO STUDENTS WHO WILL DEPLOY THE MONITORS AT BUS STOPS AROUND THE CITY, AND CHECK ON THEIR STATUS EVERY DAY3)VERIFY THAT ALL MONITORS ARE PERFORMING WELL OVER THE COURSE OF THE SUMMER DEPLOYMENT4)DESIGN A ROUTE THAT WILL TRAVERSE THE BUS STOPS SELECTED FOR MOBILE MONITORING. STUDENTS WILL BE HIRED TO DRIVE AN ELECTRIC VEHICLE EQUIPPED WITH AIR QUALITY MONITORS TO MEASURE TRAFFIC RELATED POLLUTANTS AROUND DENVER.5)ANALYZE THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF AIR POLLUTION IN DENVER6)ANALYZE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN GREEN COVER, AIR POLLUTION AND HEAT AT BUS STOPS AROUND DENVER WITH USGS.7)IN PARTNERSHIP WITH USGS, ANALYZE HOW AIR POLLUTION AND HEAT CAN IMPACT BUS RIDERSHIP IN DIFFERENT NEIGHBORHOODS WITH DIFFERENT SOCIOECONOMIC STATUSES.8)DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH THE DENVER URBAN FIELD STATION AND THE REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION DISTRICT.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE:1)A RICH DATASET OF AIR POLLUTION MEASUREMENTS (PM2.5, NO2, O3, CO) AT 36-40 BUS STOPS IN DENVER OVER THE COURSE OF A MONTH WHICH WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC2)MOBILE AIR POLLUTION MEASUREMENTS OVER PREDETERMINED ROUTES OVER THE COURSE OF A MONTH WHICH WILL ALSO BE MADE PUBLIC3)DATA VISUALIZATIONS TO HELP THE PUBLIC INTERPRET GRADIENTS OF AIR POLLUTION IDENTIFIED OVER THE CITY THAT WILL BE EMBEDDED ON A WEBSITE4)HIGH QUALITY PUBLICATIONS THAT CHARACTERIZE THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN AIR POLLUTION, HEAT, GREENSPACE, AND SOCIOECONOMIC FACTORS IN DENVER  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) AS WELL AS  PRIYANKA DESOUZA AND THREE STUDENTS (HIRING ONGOING) SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES,  IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD  NONE

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 23-5 31 24PROJECT TITLE: ESTIMATION OF RELATIVE DEPTHS USED BY BLACK CARP IN MAINSTEM SECTIONS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE MISSISSIPPI, LOWER MISSOURI, AND ILLINOIS RIVERSAWARD PURPOSE:  THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO DETERMINE RELATIVE RIVER DEPTHS ASSOCIATED WITH BLACK CARP BEING TRACKED IN MAINSTEM SECTIONS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE MISSISSIPPI, LOWER MISSOURI, AND ILLINOIS RIVERS AND TO ATTRIBUTE CARP LOCATIONS WITH METRICS DESCRIBING PROXIMITY TO WING DIKES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: BATHYMETRY AND DEPTH DATASETS WILL BE OBTAINED FOR SECTIONS OF THE UPPER AND MIDDLE MISSISSIPPI, LOWER MISSOURI, AND ILLINOIS MAINSTEMS TO CREATE A UNIFORM RIVER DEPTH LAYER THAT WILL BE STANDARDIZED FOR A UNIFORM WATER SURFACE ELEVATION. SOURCES OF DEPTH DATA WILL INCLUDE U.S. ARMY CORP OF ENGINEERS AND USGS, AND ANY OTHER SOURCES LOCATED THAT INCLUDE ADEQUATE METADATA TO DETERMINE HOW THE DATA LAYER WAS DEVELOPED. BATHYMETRY DATASETS ARE LIKELY TO BE OF DIFFERENT SPATIAL PROJECTIONS AND RESOLUTIONS SO THE DATASETS WILL BE CONVERTED TO A COMMON PROJECTION, AND RESOLUTION OF THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE STANDARDIZED TO THE COARSEST DATASET OBTAINED. SPATIAL GAPS BETWEEN DATASETS WILL BE FILLED IN USING ANISOTROPIC KRIGING WHICH WAS FOUND TO BE THE MOST ACCURATE FOR BATHYMETRIC MAPPING IN THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI. ANISOTROPIC KRIGING IS A FORM OF ORDINARY KRIGING WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR DIRECTIONAL DEPENDENCIES.IN ADDITION TO THE RIVER DEPTH DATASETS, A SPATIAL LAYER REPRESENTING THE LOCATION AND TYPE OF WING DIKES AND OTHER ENGINEERED RIVER CONTROL STRUCTURES WITHIN THE FOCAL MAINSTEMS WILL BE ACQUIRED OR CREATED. THIS LAYER WILL BE ATTRIBUTED WITH SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION ABOUT THE CONTROL STRUCTURES, SUCH AS LENGTH, AND COMPOSITION.CARP LOCATIONS PROVIDED BY USGS WILL BE ATTRIBUTED WITH A SET OF METRICS WHICH DESCRIBE PROXIMITY TO THE NEAREST CONTROL STRUCTURES INCLUDING ATTRIBUTES OF THE STRUCTURES. AT A MINIMUM, THESE METRICS WILL INCLUDE RIVER DISTANCE BETWEEN THE CARP LOCATION AND NEAREST STRUCTURE, LENGTH OF AND MAXIMUM HEIGHT OF THE STRUCTURE, AND TYPE OF STRUCTURE. ADDITIONAL METRICS TO ASSOCIATE WITH THE CARP LOCATIONS WILL BE DETERMINED THROUGH LITERATURE REVIEW AND DISCUSSIONS WITH USGS TO DETERMINE RELEVANT MEASURES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: USGS WILL BE PROVIDED WITH THE ORIGINAL BATHYMETRIC LAYERS, THE LAYERS MODIFIED TO REFLECT A UNIFORM WATER DEPTH, AND THE INTEGRATED LAYER RESCALED TO A UNIFORM RESOLUTION. ALSO INCLUDED WILL BE A SPATIAL LAYER FOR THE WING DIKES WITHIN THE FOCAL AREA. METADATA WILL BE PROVIDED WITH EACH DATA LAYER. BLACK CARP LOCATIONS PROVIDED BY USGS WILL BE ATTRIBUTED WITH RIVER DEPTH AS A RELATIVE MEASURE OF HABITAT USE AND METRICS DESCRIBING FISH PROXIMITY TO WING DIKES. THE FINAL REPORT WILL INCLUDE THE METHODS USED, DATA SOURCES, AND SUMMARY INFORMATION FOR RIVER MAINSTEMS. THE UNIFORM SPATIAL LAYER OF BATHYMETRY INCLUDING METADATA AND THE FINAL REPORT WILL BE POSTED ON SCIENCEBASE TO BE AVAILABLE FOR FURTHER USE AND REFERENCING. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):  USGS, COLUMBIA ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH CENTER

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 23-5 31 25PROJECT TITLE: ARKSTORM TAHOE 2.0  IMPACT ASSESSMENT, DATA VISUALIZATION, AND IDENTIFYING STRATEGIES FOR RESILIENCE PLANNINGAS DEMONSTRATED IN RECENT YEARS OF 1997, 2006, 2017, AND 2023, EXTREME WINTER STORMS IN CALIFORNIA AND NEVADA POSE DIRE RISKS TO PEOPLE, INFRASTRUCTURE, ECOSYSTEMS, AND LOCAL ECONOMIES. THESE RISKS ARE BEING COMPOUNDED AS CLIMATE CHANGE BRINGS WARMER AND MORE INTENSE ATMOSPHERIC RIVER (AR) STORMS WITH GREATER FLOOD POTENTIAL, WHILE BOOMING POPULATION GROWTH IN URBAN CENTERS INCREASES POPULATION EXPOSURES TO STORM HAZARDS. THE CALIFORNIA-WIDE ARKSTORM SCENARIO WAS CREATED TO DEMONSTRATE AND QUANTIFY RISKS FROM EXTREME STORMS IN THE REGION AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO ALLOW PLANNERS AND EMERGENCY MANAGERS TO EXPLORE WAYS TO PREPARE, RESPOND TO, AND MITIGATE POTENTIAL IMPACTS.IN THIS PROJECT, WILL ASSESS EXPOSURE AND IMPACTS TO COMMUNITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE WITHIN THE TRUCKEE RIVER BASIN AND SURROUNDING REGIONS TO AN UPDATED ARKSTORM 2.0 SCENARIO WHICH BETTER REPRESENTS STORM CHARACTERISTICS UNDER A WARMING CLIMATE. IN DOING SO, WILL CONDUCT A COMPREHENSIVE IMPACT ASSESSMENT THAT INCORPORATES SPATIAL DATASETS OF POPULATION AND INFRASTRUCTURE CHARACTERISTICS, AS WELL AS HYDROLOGIC, HYDRAULIC, AND GEOLOGICAL MODEL OUTPUTS PROVIDED BY PARTNERING AGENCIES THAT USE ARKSTORM 2.0 AS INPUTS. SECOND, WILL DEVELOP A LIBRARY AND VISUALIZATION TOOL THAT ENABLES STAKEHOLDERS TO OVERLAY HAZARD, POPULATION, AND INFRASTRUCTURE DATA THAT CAN PROVIDE A TANGIBLE CONCEPTUALIZATION OF POTENTIAL IMPACTS AND CAN SERVE FOCAL POINTS FOR DISCUSSION. THIRD, WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH ON HOW TO BEST INTERFACE WITH LOCAL AND STATE AGENCIES ON INCORPORATING ARKSTORM SCENARIOS INTO RESILIENCE PLANNING, TAKING ADVANTAGE OF EXPERIENCE AND INFORMATION GAINED FROM THE MOST RECENT SET OF EVENTS.OUTCOMES AND DELIVERABLES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A DATA RESOURCE LIBRARY AND WEB APPLICATION CONTAINING IMPACT ANALYSIS RESULTS AND OTHER PERTINENT DATASETS THAT CAN BE USED IN DISCUSSIONS WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO IDENTIFY RISKS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVING RESILIENCE. RESULTS WILL FURTHER BE PRESENTED IN STAKEHOLDER AND FLOOD MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS, SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES, AND TWO PEER-REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS WILL BE DEVELOPED. TOGETHER THESE ACTIVITIES CONTRIBUTE TOWARD MEETING THE USGS MISSION TO MINIMIZE LOSS OF LIFE AND PROPERTY FROM NATURAL DISASTERS BY DEMONSTRATING APPROACHES FOR USING A PLAUSIBLE EXTREME FLOOD HAZARD SCENARIO UNDER WARMING CLIMATE TO QUANTIFY IMPACTS AND FACILITATE DISCUSSIONS OF RESILIENCE OPTIONS AND SCIENCE NEEDS WITHIN LOCAL COMMUNITIES.

PROJECT TITLE: A REVIEW OF TRANSMISSION AND GEOGRAPHIC SPREAD OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IN U.S. CERVIDPOPULATIONSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION OF AWARD PURPOSE: THE AWARD WILL SUPPORT A 14-MONTH CONSENSUS STUDY OF AN AD HOC COMMITTEE OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES OF SCIENCES, ENGINEERING, AND MEDICINE TO EVALUATE THE STATE OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE TRANSMISSION AND GEOGRAPHIC SPREAD OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IN FREE-RANGING AND CAPTIVE CERVIDS (DEER, ELK, MOOSE, OTHERS). SPECIFICALLY, THE COMMITTEE WILL DRAW CONCLUSIONS ABOUT THE STATE OF KNOWLEDGE REGARDING:  THE INFECTIOUS DOSE OF CWD AND DIFFERENT MODES OF DISEASE TRANSMISSION AMONG CERVIDS  THE MEANS OF GEOGRAPHIC SPREAD THROUGH CERVID DISPERSAL, SCAVENGER ACTIVITY, AND HUMAN ACTIONS SUCH AS CARCASS HANDLING AND TRANSPORTING LIVE ANIMALS  THE EFFECTIVENESS OF INTERVENTIONS TO REDUCE TRANSMISSION AND OR GEOGRAPHIC SPREAD OF THE DISEASE  AND  THE POPULATION-LEVEL AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF CWD AND THE EFFECTIVENESS OF DIFFERENT INTERVENTIONS TO REDUCE THOSE IMPACTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  COMMITTEE FORMATION. FOLLOWING A BROAD CALL FOR NOMINATIONS, THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES LEADERS WILL APPOINT A 12-MEMBER COMMITTEE AND STAFF TEAM TO CARRY OUT THE INVESTIGATION OF THE BULLETED ISSUES LISTED ABOVE. INFORMATION-GATHERING. AS THE STUDY IS BEGINNING, THE STUDY ISSUES WILL BE DISCUSSED WITH MEMBERS OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AT AN INTERNATIONAL CWD CONFERENCE IN DENVER (JUNE2023). ONCE APPOINTED, THE COMMITTEE WILL HOLD A SERIES OF INFORMATION-GATHERING MEETINGS FROM AUGUST 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 2023, WHICH WILL BE IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL, WITH OPEN AND CLOSED SESSIONS, TO GATHER INFORMATION FROM SCIENTISTS, PRACTITIONERS, AND OTHER EXPERTS. THE PUBLIC WILL BE ABLE TO SEND COMMENTS TO THE COMMITTEE AND ATTEND OPEN SESSIONS OF COMMITTEE MEETINGS. THECOMMITTEE WILL CONDUCT A LITERATURE REVIEW, EXAMINE DATA COLLECTED BY STATE AND FEDERAL WILDLIFE OFFICIALS, AND VISIT CONFINED CERVID OPERATIONS. THE COMMITTEE CHAIR AND STUDY DIRECTOR WILL SEEK INFORMATION FROM AGENCY LEADERS OF THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES AT ITS ANNUAL MEETING IN SEPTEMBER 2023.REPORT PREPARATION, REVIEW, AND REVISION. THE COMMITTEE WILL PREPARE A DRAFT REPORT ADDRESSING THE RELEVANT ISSUES. A SET OF REVIEWERS ANONYMOUS TO THE COMMITTEE WILL CRITIQUE THE REPORT, WHICH WILL BE REVISED UNDER THE OVERSIGHT OF AN INDEPENDENT REPORT COORDINATOR AND MONITORAPPOINTED BY THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES REPORT REVIEW OFFICE BEFORE BEING FINALIZED AND APPROVED. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AN APPROVED PREPUBLICATION, FINAL PUBLICATION, AND REPORT HIGHLIGHTS WILL BE PREPARED AND DELIVERED TO THE FEDERAL AGENCY SPONSORS OF THE STUDY AND CONGRESS, WHO WILL ALSO RECEIVE BRIEFINGS FROM THE COMMITTEE, AFTER WHICH THE REPORT WILL BE PUBLICLY RELEASED AND DISSEMINATED THROUGH A PUBLIC WEBINAR. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE REPORT WILL BE USEFUL TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES INVOLVED IN ACONTEMPLATED TASK FORCE TO CREATE CWD ACTION PLAN, AND WILL ALSO BENEFIT TRIBAL NATIONS, THE HUNTING, CONSERVATION, AND CERVID-FARMING COMMUNITIES, CWD RESEARCHERS, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE ANTICIPATED

UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  GEOHAZARDS INTERNATIONALSUPPORTING PRACTICAL FAMILY PREPAREDNESS IN HAITI AND THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC ANDSUPPORTING EARTHQUAKE MONITORING CAPABILITIES IN HAITICOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYMANY FAMILIES IN HAITI AND THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC LIVE IN AREAS THREATENED BY EARTHQUAKES AND THE HAZARDS THEY TRIGGER, INCLUDING TSUNAMIS AND LANDSLIDES. DEADLY EARTHQUAKES IN HAITI IN 2010, 2018 AND 2021 SERVE AS THE MOST RECENT REMINDERS OF THE THREAT. MORE THAN 500 YEARS OF HISTORICAL RECORDS REVEAL NUMEROUS SIGNIFICANT EARTHQUAKES, AND NUMEROUS SCIENTIFIC STUDIES BY THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) AND OTHERS CORROBORATE THE RISK. HISPANIOLAS EARTHQUAKE AND TSUNAMI RISKS ARE PART OF A MULTI-HAZARD CONTEXT  THE ISLAND IS ALSO FREQUENTLY AFFECTED BY HURRICANES AND TROPICAL STORMS, AND MULTIPLE INFECTIOUS DISEASE OUTBREAKS HAVE OCCURRED IN THE PAST 15 YEARS. BEING INLAND, THE CIBO VALLEY IS AFFECTED BY HEAVY RAINFALL AND FLOODING INCLUDING FROM TROPICAL CYCLONES. PEOPLE IN BOTH COUNTRIES ARE MORE AWARE OF HURRICANE RISKS AND SAFETY MEASURES THAN THOSE FOR EARTHQUAKES AND TSUNAMIS, BUT HOLISTIC PREPAREDNESS MEASURES ARE NEEDED THAT ADDRESS EARTHQUAKES AND TSUNAMIS IN THE FULL MULTI-HAZARD CONTEXT. THIS INCLUDES A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW HAITIAN VERNACULAR BUILDINGS IN PARTICULAR RESPOND TO EARTHQUAKES, AND HOW DAMAGE TO THESE BUILDINGS CAN HELP TO ESTIMATE HOW STRONG EARTHQUAKE SHAKING HAS BEEN. (HAITI CONTINUES TO HAVE FEW CONTINUOUSLY OPERATING INSTRUMENTS THAT CAN MEASURE THE STRENGTH OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING.)INDIVIDUAL FAMILIES AND THE ORGANIZATIONS AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WORKING TO BUILD RESILIENT COMMUNITIES OFTEN LACK DETAILED, PRACTICAL, SCIENCE-BASED GUIDANCE ABOUT HOW TO REDUCE EARTHQUAKE RISK. THE PROJECT AIMS TO (1) EQUIP FAMILIES AND REPRESENTATIVES OF KEY SOCIAL INSTITUTIONS WITH THIS INFORMATION, AND (2) UTILIZE DAMAGE AND IMPACT DATA FROM THE 2021 EARTHQUAKE TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW VERNACULAR HAITIAN CONSTRUCTION BEHAVES IN EARTHQUAKES, TO IMPROVE USGS PRODUCTS USED BY HUMANITARIAN AGENCIES AFTER EARTHQUAKES. THE PROJECT WILL CARRY OUT FORMATIVE RESEARCH AND FAMILY DISASTER PREPAREDNESS ACTIVITIES IN HAITI AND THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC  COLLECT AND ANALYZE DAMAGE DATA FROM THE 2021 M7.2 EARTHQUAKE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME, AND PROVIDE OUTREACH AND TRAINING. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATABASE OF OVER 12,000 BUILDING DAMAGE RECORDS, AND MORE THAN 2,400 DID YOU FEEL IT QUESTIONNAIRE RESPONSES FOR SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS TO USE. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE SOURCEBOOKS FOR DISASTER SAFETY ADVOCATES AND LOCAL PROFESSIONALS IN LOCAL LANGUAGES AND ENGLISH, TRAIN LOCAL SOCIAL INSTITUTION REPRESENTATIVES AND OTHER KEY GROUPS, AND PROVIDE FAMILIES AND THE PUBLIC WITH ACTIONABLE PREPAREDNESS INFORMATION THROUGH COMMUNICATIONS CAMPAIGNS.

PROJECT TITLE: ADAPTING WATER CONTROL OPERATIONS AND FLOODPLAIN CONSERVATION PLANNING TO GLOBAL CHANGEPROJECT PERIOD: 06 01 2023  04 30 2025PROJECT ABSTRACT: CLIMATE CHANGE IS ALTERING THE PATTERNS OF RAIN AND THE AMOUNT OF WATER ENTERING OUR RIVERS. THIS IS ESPECIALLY DIFFICULT FOR LARGE DAM OPERATORS, WHO HAVE TO OPERATE ON TIMELINES OF 7-14 DAY WEATHER FORECASTS WHEN MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT WATER RELEASES WHEN THE CLIMATE IS CHANGING OVER SEASONS AND YEARS. THE ROANOKE RIVER BASIN HAS EXPERIENCED SOME OF THE WETTEST YEARS ON RECORD IN THE PAST FIVE YEARS, ESPECIALLY AFFECTING THE SPRINGTIME. THIS RESEARCH EXAMINES THE PAST 80 YEARS OF DATA TO SEE IF THE CLIMATE IS CHANGING AT KEY TIMES OF YEAR IN THE ROANOKE RIVER, IT USES A CLIMATE MODEL TO PROJECT INFLOWS TO THE RESERVOIR THROUGH 2100, AND IT RELATES ANY CHANGES TO IMPLICATIONS TO DOWNSTREAM ECOLOGY AND RISK FOR PEOPLE THROUGH SIMULATING RESERVOIR OPERATIONS. AS PART OF A TEAM, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL ANALYZE THE PAST PERIOD OF RECORD INFLOWS INTO KERR RESERVOIR ON THE ROANOKE RIVER, ASSIST USGS WITH THE CLIMATE PROJECTIONS USING THE PRMS MODEL, ASSIST NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY AS THEY SIMULATE DAM OPERATIONS, AND PROVIDE A LEAD ROLE ON THE RESULTS TO THE DOWNSTREAM ECOLOGY. RESULTS WILL BE WRITTEN IN PAPERS AND THE LARGE DAM OWNERS, THE ARMY CORPS AND DOMINION, AS WELL AS DOWNSTREAM LANDOWNERS WILL BE BRIEFED ABOUT THE FINDINGS SO BASIN STAKEHOLDERS CAN COLLECTIVELY MANAGE THE RISK POSED BY CLIMATE CHANGE.
USGS - UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON COOPERATIVE JOINT RESEARCH AGREEMENT WITH SPACE

PROJECT TITLE  CRITICAL MINERALS IN VOLCANOGENIC MASSIVE SULFIDE, LOW SULFIDATION EPITHERMAL, SEDIMENT HOSTED CU, AND SEDIMENTARY EXHALATIVE ZN DEPOSITS  CASE STUDIES FROM ARIZONA, WISCONSIN, IDAHO, MONTANA, AND ALASKAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  8 15 2023 THROUGH 8 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  WITH THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR CRITICAL MINERALS AND THE LACK OF AVAILABLE INFORMATION AND LITERATURE ON THEIR OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND SEQUESTRATION WITHIN PRIMARY MINERAL DEPOSITS, WASTE ROCK AND PROCESSED TAILINGS, UNDERSTANDING KNOWN CRITICAL MINERAL BEARING DEPOSITS IS CRITICAL TO ASSESS EXISTING RESOURCES AND FOR FUTURE EXPLORATION EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ADD VALUE TO EXISTING EFFORTS UNDERTAKEN AT THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TO ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE AVAILABILITY OF DOMESTIC CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  IT IS THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT TO INTEGRATE GEOCHEMICAL AND MINERALOGICAL DATA FROM THIN SECTIONS, HAND SAMPLES, AND DRILL CORE WITH PRODUCTION AND RESOURCE DATA WHICH WILL ALLOW US TO ESTIMATE THE AMOUNT AND VALUE OF CRITICAL MINERALS IN PROCESSED MINE WASTE AND UNMINED RESOURCES FOR THESE DEPOSITS. THE STUDY IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE PUBLIC DATA SETS THAT PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR FUTURE CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENTS AND FOSTER RESEARCH TO IDENTIFY PROCESSES FROM SOURCE TO SINK AND THE CONCENTRATION MECHANISMS FOR CRITICAL MINERALS IN MINERAL SYSTEMS, WHICH IN COMPARISON TO PRIMARY COMMODITIES ARE POORLY KNOWN.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND RESIDENCE AND DEPORTMENT OF CRITICAL MINERALS IN PRIMARY ORE FROM FOUR DIFFERENT DEPOSIT TYPES, NAMELY VMS, LS EPITHERMAL, SEDIMENT HOSTED CU, AND SEDIMENTARY EXHALATIVE ZN DEPOSITS. REPRESENTATIVE ORE SAMPLES FROM A DIVERSE RANGE OF DEPOSIT TYPES OCCURRING IN DIFFERENT GEOTECTONIC SETTINGS WILL BE USED FOR WHOLE ROCK 60  ELEMENT GEOCHEMISTRY AND SUBSEQUENT MICRO ANALYTICAL OBSERVATIONS TO ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE CRITICAL MINERAL ENDOWMENT AND THEIR SEQUESTRATION IN THESE DEPOSITS. THERE IS CURRENTLY A DEARTH OF MODEM GEOCHEMICAL ANALYSES THAT INCLUDE CRITICAL MINERAL CONCENTRATIONS, HINDERING OUR ABILITY TO ASSESS AND PLAN FURTHER STUDIES ON THE EXTRACTABILITY AND CONCOMITANT ECONOMICS OF THESE CRITICAL MINERAL OCCURRENCES.  THIS MINERALOGICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL STUDY WILL ELUCIDATE THE RESIDENCE OF CRITICAL MINERALS, PROCESSES OF ORE FORMATION, TRANSPORT FROM SOURCE TO SINK, AND CONTROLS RELATED TO GEOGRAPHIC POSITION, TECTONIC SETTING, AGE OF MINERALIZATION, HOST ROCKS, AND OTHER FACTORS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT BY THIS PROJECT AS THE RESULTS WILL HELP TO FILL THE KNOWLEDGE GAP ON THE OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, RESIDENCE, AND DEPORTMENT OF CRITICAL MINERALS IN THESE DEPOSITS. INFORMATION ON THE AMOUNT, RESIDENCE, AND VALUE OF CRITICAL MINERALS IN THESE DEPOSIT TYPES WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION TO AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE CRITICAL MINERAL ENDOWMENT IN THESE DEPOSITS AND DEPOSIT TYPES AND MAY FOSTER FUTURE EFFORTS TO RECOVER THEM FROM PROCESSED MINE WASTE AND UNMINED RESOURCES AND LOWER THE NATIONS IMPORT RELIANCE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 5 15 23-5 14 25PROJECT TITLE: THE CURRENT AND FUTURE STATE OF BIG SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMSCLIMATE CHANGE IS WIDELY EXPECTED TO ALTER ECOSYSTEMS IN SMALL AND LARGE WAYS AND THOSE OCCUPYING THE DRIEST PORTIONS OF THE WESTERN UNITED STATED ARE LIKELY TO BE AMONG THE MOST HEAVILY INFLUENCED. AREAS OCCUPIED BY MIXTURES OF THE SHRUB, BIG SAGEBRUSH, WITH GRASSES AND FORBS COVER A VERY LARGE PORTION OF THE WEST AND ARE IMPORTANT FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE WELFARE OF BOTH HUMAN AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES. THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL INVESTIGATE THE CURRENT MECHANISMS CONTRIBUTING TO THE SUCCESS OF THESE BIG SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS AND HOW DISTURBANCES AND A CHANGING CLIMATE WILL INFLUENCE THEM IN THE FUTURE. WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY VISITING AND COLLECTING INFORMATION ABOUT THESE ECOSYSTEMS OVER A RANGE OF CONDITIONS THAT OCCUR IN THE BIG SAGEBRUSH REGION.IMPORTANT PRODUCTS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE THE STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE TRAINING DURING THE PROJECT AND A LARGE AMOUNT OF FIELD DATA THAT WILL MAKE AVAILABLE TO OTHER RESEARCHERS, LAND MANAGERS, AND THE PUBLIC BY POSTING IT ON PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATA LIBRARIES. ADDITIONAL PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE THE NEW KNOWLEDGE GENERATED AND DISSEMINATION OF IT BY PUBLISHING IT IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 6 2023-9 15 2023PROJECT TITLE: SUPPORT FOR GIRLS ON WATER- INSPIRING GIRLS EXPEDITIONSIN THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT, INSPIRING GIRLS EXPEDITIONS ALASKA (INSPIRINGGIRLS.ORG IGE-ALASKA) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS WILL PARTNER WITH USGS COLLEAGUES TO DELIVER A SCIENCE OUTREACH EXPERIENCE FOR HIGH SCHOOL-AGED YOUTH THAT INCLUDES SCIENTIFIC DATA COLLECTION FOR A SATELLITE GROUND TRUTHING EFFORT. INSPIRING GIRLS EXPEDITIONS ALASKA OFFERS 12-DAY UNIQUE, TUITION FREE, BACKCOUNTRY EXPEDITIONS THAT COMBINE SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH (STEM), ART, AND OUTDOOR EXPLORATION. THE PROVEN EDUCATIONAL MODEL IS DESIGNED TO REVEAL THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF PHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL, AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF THE ECOSYSTEM. WELCOME 16 TO 18 YEAR-OLD GIRLS AND GENDER-EXPANSIVE YOUTH WITH IDENTITIES UNDERREPRESENTED IN STEM FIELDS, AND THE INSTRUCTORS ARE PROFESSIONAL EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS, ARTISTS, AND OUTDOOR GUIDES. PROPOSE TO HOST OUR 12-DAY COASTAL ECOSYSTEM-FOCUSED GIRLS ON WATER SEA KAYAKING EXPEDITION (KACHEMAK BAY SELDOVIA LAND) IN SUMMER 2023, TO ENGAGE NINE PARTICIPANTS IN AN AUTHENTIC FIELD SCIENCE EXPEDITION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED INTEREST IN STEM FIELDS BY YOUTH PARTICIPANTS, AS WELL AS REMOTE FIELD DATA COLLECTION.LAUNCHED IN 2019, GIRLS ON WATER EXPLORES THE ALASKA COASTAL ECOSYSTEM AROUND KACHEMAK BAY, NEAR HOMER, AK. AUTHENTIC FIELD SCIENCE PRACTICE IS SCAFFOLDED EARLY FOR PARTICIPANTS THROUGH INSTRUCTOR-LED OBSERVATIONS, LESSONS INSPIRED BY SURROUNDINGS, AND MINI-EXPERIMENTS NEAR CAMP. VISITING GUEST INSTRUCTORS JOIN MID-WAY THROUGH THE EXPEDITION TO LEAD AN ACTIVITY ON A NEW SCIENCE TOPIC, USING SPECIALIZED AND ENGAGING INSTRUMENTS. LATER IN THE PROGRAM, PARTICIPANTS GAIN MORE OWNERSHIP OVER THE SCIENTIFIC PROCESS, AND FORM SMALL GROUPS TO DESIGN AND LEAD THEIR OWN SCIENCE PROJECTS, CULMINATING IN A PUBLIC PRESENTATION OF THEIR FINDINGS IN THE TOWN OF HOMER.WE LEVERAGE SUPPORT FROM USGS TOWARDS HOSTING A GIRLS ON WATER EXPEDITION IN SUMMER 2023, TO INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION FOR A USGS GROUND TRUTHING EFFORT FOR THE RECENTLY LAUNCHED SURFACE WATER OCEAN TOPOGRAPHY SATELLITE MISSION. PARTICIPANTS WILL BE INSTRUCTED ON COLLECTING ACCURATE GPS DATA OF OCEAN SURFACE ELEVATIONS USING USGS-PROVIDED GPS UNITS ABOARD SEA KAYAKS, TO BE COMPARED AGAINST INLAND USGS STREAM GAUGE DATA. THE TEAM WILL PROVIDE A MINIMUM OF 10 HOURS OF ELEVATION DATA TOTAL, WITH TIME STAMPS OF  15 MINUTES EACH, AT 3MACCURACY.
