PROJECT PERIOD: 5 15 23-5 14 24PROJECT TITLE: MOJAVE DESERT SHRUB COMMUNITY RESPONSES TO MICROCLIMATE ALTERATION AND ENHANCED HEAT LOADING AT THE GEMINI SOLAR PROJECTAWARD PURPOSE: IN RESPONSE TO GREATER NEED FOR CLEAN ENERGY, THE UNITED STATES IS COMMITTING GREATER LAND AREA TO SOLAR ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. WHEN INSTALLED IN DRYLANDS OF THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES, LARGE SOLAR FACILITIES CHANGE THE PHYSICAL LANDSCAPE AND OFTEN HAVE NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO ECOSYSTEMS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. THE GEMINI SOLAR PROJECT, LOCATED IN THE MOJAVE DESERT IN SOUTHERN NEVADA, SEEKS TO MINIMIZE THESE IMPACTS BY LEAVING VEGETATION IN TACT, THUS MAINTAINING A DESERT ECOSYSTEM WITHIN THE SOLAR FACILITY. THIS AWARDED PROJECT WILL DEPLOY AND MAINTAIN SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTATION WITHIN AND OUTSIDE THE GEMINI FACILITY TO DETERMINE THE ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES ASSOCIATED WITH THE FACILITY  TEMPERATURE AND HEAT LOADING, ATMOSPHERIC WATER DEMAND, SHADING BY PANELS, AND BELOWGROUND WATER AVAILABILITY. THIS AWARDED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON HOW THE IMPACT OF LARGE SOLAR FACILITIES MAY BE LESSENED BY THE GEMINI FACILITYS APPROACH, HELPING TO IMPROVE THE ECOLOGICAL AND HABITAT OUTCOMES OF SOLAR DEVELOPMENT IN THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE DESIGN, PROGRAMMING, INSTALLATION, AND MAINTENANCE OF 14 INSTRUMENTED METEOROLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL STATIONS WITHIN AND OUTSIDE THE GEMINI FACILITY. THESE STATIONS WILL BE LOCATED IN KEY SOLAR FACILITY ENVIRONMENTS  BETWEEN PANELS, UNDER PANELS, AND IN PANEL DRIP LINES. WITHIN AND OUTSIDE THE FACILITY, STATIONS WILL ALSO BE POSITIONED TO INFORM ADDITIONAL COMPONENTS OF A LARGER RESEARCH PROGRAM EXPLORING FACILITY IMPACTS TO DIFFERENT MOJAVE DESERT PLANT SPECIES, AND ON DIFFERENT SOIL TYPES. THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES DATA COLLECTION, DATA PROCESSING, AND ASSISTANCE WITH DELIVERABLES ASSOCIATED WITH THE LARGER RESEARCH PROGRAM INCLUDING REPORT WRITING, DATA ANALYSIS, AND PUBLICATION OF RESEARCH FINDINGS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE MAIN PROJECT DELIVERABLE WILL BE POST-PROCESSED, GAP FILLED DATASETS FOR EACH OF THE 14 INSTRUMENTED STATIONS. THESE DATASETS WILL BE PROVIDED TO USGS PERSONNEL LEADING THE LARGER RESEARCH PROGRAM AT THE GEMINI FACILITY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR (BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY). SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

PROJECT PERIOD: 5 1 23-4 30 24PROJECT TITLE: ADVANCING STATISTICAL METHODS FOR COLLECTION AND USE OF REFERENCE DATA FOR USGS LAND COVER MONITORING MONITORING LAND COVER IN THE UNITED STATES PROVIDES CRITICAL INFORMATION TO SCIENTISTS AND POLICY MAKERS ON THE SPATIAL LOCATION AND AREA OF LAND COVER AND LAND COVER CHANGE. THESE MONITORING EFFORTS RELY ON MAPS DERIVED FROM SATELLITE IMAGERY. TO ASSESS MAP ACCURACY, A SAMPLE OF PIXELS (I.E., MAP UNITS) IS SELECTED, WHERE A SAMPLE IS A PORTION OF THE AREA MAPPED. THE REFERENCE CONDITION OF EACH SAMPLE PIXEL IS DETERMINED BY HUMAN INTERPRETERS EXAMINING SATELLITE IMAGERY AND OTHER DETAILED SPATIAL INFORMATION ASSOCIATED WITH EACH PIXEL. THIS REFERENCE CONDITION IS THEN COMPARED TO THE MAP INFORMATION TO DETERMINE ACCURACY. ANOTHER USE OF REFERENCE SAMPLE DATA IS TO ESTIMATE AREA OF LAND COVER AND LAND COVER CHANGE. THESE SAMPLE-BASED ESTIMATES ARE CONSIDERED GOOD PRACTICE BECAUSE THEY ARE BASED ON THE INTENSIVELY INTERPRETED REFERENCE CONDITION OF EACH PIXEL. THE PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP ADVANCED STATISTICAL METHODS THAT WILL MAKE COLLECTION OF REFERENCE SAMPLE DATA MORE COST EFFICIENT AND USE OF DATA MORE EFFECTIVE FOR ASSESSING ACCURACY OF LAND COVER MAPS AND ESTIMATING AREA OF LAND COVER CHANGE. STATISTICAL METHODS ARE NEEDED TO QUANTIFY UNCERTAINTY OF ESTIMATES PRODUCED FROM THE REFERENCE SAMPLE DATA. THIS UNCERTAINTY IS TYPICALLY REPRESENTED BY THE STANDARD ERROR OF AN ESTIMATE. TWO FEATURES OF STANDARD ERRORS WILL BE ADDRESSED: 1) IMPLEMENTING PROTOCOLS THAT RESULT IN SMALL STANDARD ERRORS  AND 2) DEVELOPING METHODS THAT ENHANCE ESTIMATION OF STANDARD ERRORS. THE RESEARCH FOCUSING ON THE FIRST FEATURE ENTAILS IMPROVING THE SAMPLING DESIGN USED TO COLLECT THE REFERENCE DATA. TYPICALLY, STRATIFIED SAMPLING IS IMPLEMENTED. A FIRST STEP TO IMPROVE STRATIFICATION IS TO UNDERSTAND TRADE-OFFS IN PRECISION OF DIFFERENT ESTIMATES RESULTING FROM CHOICE OF STRATA AND SAMPLE SIZE ALLOCATION TO STRATA. FOR EXAMPLE, A SAMPLE SIZE ALLOCATION THAT REDUCES STANDARD ERRORS OF ACCURACY ESTIMATES WILL LIKELY NOT BE ADVANTAGEOUS TO STANDARD ERRORS OF AREA ESTIMATES, SO COMPROMISE SOLUTIONS MUST BE IDENTIFIED THAT ACCOMMODATE MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES. ANOTHER RESEARCH TOPIC IS INVESTIGATING METHODS THAT INCORPORATE FLEXIBILITY TO ADAPT THE SAMPLING TO TARGET NEW OBJECTIVES AS MONITORING PROCEEDS OVER TIME. THIS ADAPTABILITY WOULD BE ACHIEVED BY RE-DEFINING THE STRATA AND INTENSIFYING AN AUGMENTED SAMPLE IN THOSE STRATA. IN ADDITION TO UNCERTAINTY ATTRIBUTABLE TO SAMPLING VARIABILITY, INCONSISTENCY AMONG HUMAN INTERPRETERS DETERMINING THE REFERENCE CONDITION CONTRIBUTES ANOTHER SOURCE OF UNCERTAINTY TO SAMPLE-BASED AREA ESTIMATES. TWO ASPECTS OF INTERPRETER VARIABILITY WILL BE STUDIED. FIRST, THE MAGNITUDE OF THE VARIANCE ATTRIBUTABLE TO INTERPRETERS WILL BE QUANTIFIED. TWO METHODS FOR ESTIMATING THIS VARIANCE WILL BE EXPLORED, ONE BASED ON A MEASUREMENT ERROR MODEL, THE OTHER USING A METHOD CALLED INTERPENETRATING SUBSAMPLING. THE FORMER METHOD REQUIRES A SECOND INTERPRETER TO PROVIDE AN INDEPENDENT DETERMINATION OF REFERENCE CONDITION, WHEREAS THE LATTER METHOD REQUIRES A CONSTRAINED RANDOMIZATION OF INTERPRETERS TO THE SAMPLE PIXELS BUT NOT REPEAT INTERPRETATIONS. THESE ESTIMATES WILL DEMONSTRATE THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS TO UNCERTAINTY OF SAMPLING VARIABILITY VERSUS INTERPRETER VARIABILITY AS WELL AS IDENTIFY OPTIONS FOR REDUCING THESE CONTRIBUTIONS TO VARIANCE.THE DELIVERABLES FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL BE STATISTICALLY RIGOROUS YET PRACTICAL METHODS FOR ENHANCING THE EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF SAMPLING TO COLLECT REFERENCE DATA. IMPROVEMENTS IN SAMPLING DESIGN WILL YIELD INFORMATION AT LOWER COST, AND ADVANCES IN ESTIMATION OF UNCERTAINTY WILL LEAD TO MORE EFFECTIVE USE OF THE DATA. THE TECHNICAL DETAILS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE VIA PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND THESE RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE GLOBAL BODY OF KNOWLEDGE FOR IMPROVED LAND COVER MONITORING.

PROJECT TITLE  EVALUATING FORECASTS OF COASTAL CHANGE AND THE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF RESTORATION ACTIONS ONBARRIER ISLANDS AND BARRIER SHORELINESPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  4 9 2023 THROUGH 4 8 2028COASTAL AREAS IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR SEA TURTLES, SHOREBIRDS, AND OTHER SPECIES WHILE ALSO PROTECTING MAINLAND COASTS AND COASTAL COMMUNITIES FROM WAVES AND STORM SURGE. ACTIVITIES TO RESTORE THE COAST IN THIS REGION ARE WIDESPREAD BECAUSE SEA LEVEL RISE, STORMS, AND OTHER FACTORS ARE DRIVING SIGNIFICANT LAND LOSS. TO MAKE EFFECTIVE USE OF AVAILABLE RESOURCES LIKE FUNDING AND SAND, COASTAL COMMUNITIES, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND OTHERS NEED TO BE ABLE TO EVALUATE AND PREDICT THE IMPACT OF FUTURE THREATS, INCLUDING POTENTIALLY DEVASTATING STORMS, IN THE CONTEXT OF THIS CHANGING LANDSCAPE. THERE ARE SEVERAL UNCERTAINTIES IN UNDERSTANDING AND FORECASTING THE IMPACTS OF STORMS ON THE BARRIER ISLANDS AND COASTS OF THE NORTHERN GULF, AS WELL ASIN UNDERSTANDING HOW THIS SYSTEM HAS EVOLVED THROUGH RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES. FOR THIS EFFORT, THE WATER INSTITUTE WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) TO DEVELOP AND APPLY SKILL ASSESSMENTS FOR FORECASTING COASTAL CHANGE ON BARRIER ISLANDS, SPECIFICALLY ALONG THE COAST OF LOUISIANA  CHARACTERIZE THE IMPACTS OF COASTAL CHANGE ON COMMUNITIES AND STAKEHOLDERS  AND EVALUATE THE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF RESTORATION PROJECTS ON COASTAL RESILIENCY IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO. IN ADDITION, THE WATER INSTITUTE WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE USGS IN IMPROVING UNDERSTANDING OF THE EVOLUTION OF THE COASTAL SYSTEM, INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION AND QUANTIFICATION OF THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF DRIVERS SUCH AS STORMS AND RELATIVE SEA LEVEL RISE. UNDER THIS RESEARCH, THE WATER INSTITUTE WILL COLLABORATE WITH USGS TO IDENTIFY DATA AND TOOLS THAT CAN BE USED TO ASSESS THE ACCURACY OF COASTAL MODELS SUCH AS THE USGS TOTAL WATER LEVEL AND COASTAL CHANGE FORECAST SYSTEM. THE WATER INSTITUTE WILL ALSO HELP IDENTIFY WHAT UNCERTAINTIES MAKE COASTAL CHANGE PREDICTIONS INACCURATE AND HOW TOOLS MAKING THESE PREDICTIONS CAN BE IMPROVED. PEOPLE WHO LIVE AND WORK NEAR THE COAST WILL ALSO BE INTERVIEWED AND THEIR INPUT EVALUATED TO IDENTIFY HOW COASTAL CHANGE IMPACTS THEM AND WHAT OPPORTUNITIES MAY EXIST TO IMPROVE COASTAL CHANGE TOOLS TO BE MORE USEFUL FOR THEM. THESE INTERVIEWS WILL BE DEVELOPED AS GEO REFERENCED NARRATIVES (I.E., THE LOCATION WHERE THE STORIES ARE TOLD IS CAPTURED AND SAVED), WHICH WILL BE DONE WITH SOFTWARE SUPPORTED BY CASE WESTERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY. LASTLY, THE WATER INSTITUTE WILL HELP DETERMINE WAYS FOR EVALUATING WHAT THE OVERALL IMPACT OF COASTAL RESTORATION PROJECTS HAVE BEEN ON THE NORTHERN GULF. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN A FINAL REPORT AND PRESENTED AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES AND OTHER FORUMS, AND THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE REGIONAL PLANNING FOR STORMS AND TO MAXIMIZE THE BENEFIT OF COASTALRESTORATION.

ENHANCING CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES IN WESTERN ALASKA  LINKING POLLINATOR DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE TO SUBSISTENCE BERRY PRODUCTION IN A RAPIDLY CHANGING ENVIRONMENTMATTHEW L. CARLSON, PHD  PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR  ALASKA CENTER FOR CONSERVATION SCIENCE  UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGEPROPOSAL ABSTRACT SUMMARYBERRIES ARE A KEY SUBSISTENCE RESOURCE IN ALASKAN NATIVE COMMUNITIES, WHERE THEY ARE PART OF A PORTFOLIO OF WILD FOODS THAT HAVE PROVIDED PRIMARY SUBSISTENCE FOR MILLENNIA AND HAVE BEEN INTEGRAL TO MAINTAINING CULTURAL COHESION AND PHYSICAL TIES TO THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE. DESPITE THE IMPORTANCE OF BERRY PRODUCING PLANTS, RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THEIR VULNERABILITY TO CLIMATE CHANGE, PARTICULARLY IN THE PERMAFROST UNDERLAIN PORTIONS OF THE YUKON KUSKOKWIM DELTA THAT SUPPORT BERRY COMMUNITIES  AND MUCH LESS IS KNOWN ABOUT THEIR INSECT POLLINATORS. CLOUDBERRY (LOCALLY KNOWN AS SALMONBERRY, AQAVSIK, ATSALUGPIAQ, OR AQEVVIK AMONG OTHER NAMES) IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT IN ALASKA AND IS COMPLETELY DEPENDENT ON INSECT VISITATION FOR FRUIT PRODUCTION. THIS PROJECT LEVERAGES EXISTING BERRY MONITORING RESEARCH AND A CITIZEN SCIENCE NETWORK TO PROVIDE NOVEL INFORMATION ON POLLINATOR ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY, AS A CRITICAL INPUT TO FORECASTS OF SUBSISTENCE CHANGES AND VULNERABILITIES IN WESTERN ALASKA. KEY PRODUCTS AND OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF BASELINE INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGY AND BIODIVERSITY OF INSECT POLLINATORS, RELATIONSHIPS OF POLLINATORS TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND BERRY PRODUCTION, AND DEVELOPMENT OF K 12 EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS TAILORED TO WESTERN ALASKA COMMUNITIES.THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE (UAA) WILL PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC SUPPORT AND TRAINING TO USGS ECOLOGISTS IN POLLINATOR SAMPLING METHODS. UAA WILL ALSO ASSIST IN THE PRODUCTION OF OUTREACH MATERIALS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 23-5 1 26PROJECT TITLE: TONGUE RIVER 2100: FUTURE TONGUE RIVER STREAMFLOW ESTIMATES TO ENABLE NORTHERN CHEYENNE DATA-DRIVEN WATER MANAGEMENT AND PLANNINGPROJECT SUMMARY: THE TONGUE RIVER (TR) DRAINS FROM HEADWATERS IN WYOMING INTO MONTANA. THE NORTHERNCHEYENNE TRIBE (NCT) HOLDS A STORAGE WATER RIGHT IN TR RESERVOIR, USED FOR IRRIGATION AND ECONOMIC LEASINGACTIVITIES. THE HYDROLOGY OF THE TR IS LITTLE STUDIED AND THERE IS CONCERN THAT FUTURE FLOW VOLUME AND TIMINGMAY IMPACT WATER AVAILABILITY IN THE WATERSHED. KNOWLEDGE OF FUTURE RIVER FLOW VOLUME AND TIMINGTHROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED IN THE FORM OF STREAMFLOW ESTIMATES WILL HELP SUPPORT DATA-DRIVEN TRIBAL WATERMANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING. ADDITIONALLY, STREAMFLOW ESTIMATES WILL HELP STATE FISH AND WILDLIFEAGENCIES EVALUATE HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR AQUATIC SPECIES, INFORM STATE WATER MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, AND LOCALIRRIGATION AND RESERVOIR MANAGEMENT. THIS PROPOSAL COMBINES 1) PUBLISHED, BUT UN-ROUTED, FUTURE HYDROLOGYESTIMATES, 2) THE APPLICATION OF A RIVER SYSTEM MODEL THAT ACCOUNTS FOR IRRIGATION WITHDRAWALS AND RESERVOIROPERATIONS, AND 3) TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FROM A NCT WATER MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONAL TO PROVIDE FUTUREESTIMATES OF TR FLOW THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED THAT ARE TAILORED TO TRIBAL WATER MANAGEMENT NEEDS. THISPROJECT WILL ENGAGE WITH THE PRIMARY PROJECT PARTNER, NCT, TO SELECT FUTURE CLIMATE SCENARIOS AND TO GUIDEANALYSES FOR FUTURE STREAMFLOW ESTIMATES. DAILY FUTURE STREAMFLOW ESTIMATES WILL BE MADE FROM 2070-2099 ATPARTNER-IDENTIFIED POINTS OF INTEREST THROUGHOUT THE TR WATERSHED. PREVIOUS WORK NEAR THE TR AND ACROSS THEWESTERN UNITED STATES SUGGESTS THAT STREAMFLOW TIMING WILL MOVE EARLIER IN THE YEAR AND THAT STREAMFLOWVOLUMES MAY INCREASE. THIS WORK WILL HELP TO BETTER QUANTIFY EXPECTED CHANGES IN THE TR AND THEMETHODOLOGY IS BROADLY TRANSFERABLE TO OTHER WESTERN HEADWATER RIVER WATERSHEDS. IN ADDITION TO A FORMALPUBLICATION AND DATA RELEASE, PLAIN-LANGUAGE RESULTS WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO THE PROJECT PARTNERS AT ACONCLUDING MEETING AND DATA ACCESS   USE TUTORIALS AND LESSONS LEARNED WILL BE RECORDED TO FACILITATE USE OFTHE PROJECT DELIVERABLES AND KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER.

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 1 2023-5 31 2026PROJECT TITLE: INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF FIRE AND HERBIVORY ON FOREST RECOVERY AT ISLE ROYALE NATIONAL PARK AWARD PURPOSE- OVER THE PAST FEW DECADES, MONITORING, RESEARCH, AND MODELLING STUDIES CONDUCTED AT ISLE ROYALE NATIONAL PARK HAVE IMPROVED OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE BROWSING BY MOOSE PLAYS IN ECOSYSTEM DYNAMICS. MOOSE DIRECTLY IMPACT YOUNG TREE COHORTS BY FEEDING ON THEM AND INDIRECTLY IMPACT LONG-TERM FOREST SUCCESSIONAL DYNAMICS BY ALTERING COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN BROWSED AND UNBROWSED TREES. OTHER DISTURBANCES, SUCH AS STAND-REPLACING FIRES, CAN HAVE MORE IMMEDIATE IMPACTS TO PLANT COMMUNITIES AND SET UP THE POTENTIAL FOR INTERACTIONS WITH MOOSE BROWSING AS THE FOREST REGENERATION PHASE OF SUCCESSION IS MOST SUSCEPTIBLE TO BROWSING IMPACTS.  HOWEVER, TO DATE LITTLE HAS BEEN DONE TO ASSESS THE INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF BROWSE PRESSURE AND WILDFIRE ON PLANT SUCCESSION AND NUTRIENT CYCLING.     ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - THE PROPOSED RESEARCH INTENDS TO USE FUNDS IN THIS CESU AGREEMENT TO ADDRESS FOUR OBJECTIVES: 1) CONDUCT A REVIEW OF EXISTING LITERATURE ON THE IMPACTS OF PREVIOUS FIRES ON THE VEGETATION OF ISLE ROYALE, 2) DEVELOP A LONG-TERM VEGETATION AND SOILS MONITORING AND RESEARCH PLAN THAT TAKES ADVANTAGE OF MOOSE EXCLOSURES ON THE ISLAND, 3) COLLECT DATA INSIDE AND OUTSIDE OF EXCLOSURES IN ADJACENT REFERENCE AREAS, AND 4) DEVELOP A REPORT DOCUMENTING EARLY RESPONSES TO BROWSING AND FIRE TREATMENTS.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES- EXPECT THREE REPORTS (ULTIMATELY PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS) TO BE DELIVERED TO PROJECT COLLABORATORS: 1) SYNTHESIS OF PRIOR FIRE ECOLOGY ON THE ISLAND, 2) IMMEDIATE POST-FIRE AND BROWSE EFFECTS, LEVERAGING RECENT WILDFIRES AND MOOSE EXCLOSURES, AND 3) MODELLING OF THESE PROCESSES TO UNDERSTAND BROADER IMPACTS.  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)- AGENCY AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS (USGS, NPS, AND MTU), AS WELL AS THE BROADER RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES.     SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES AND MILESTONESDEC. 2023:TECHNICAL REPORT: LONG-TERM MONITORING PLANSEPT, 2025:DRAFT REPORT: REVIEW SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING LITERATUREOCT, 2026:DRAFT REPORT: EARLY RESPONSES TO BROWSING AND FIRE TREATMENTS

PROJECT PERIOD  4 3 23 4 2 27PROJECT TITLE  EXPLORING PAST AND PRESENT SPAWNING HABITATS FOR NATIVE FISHES IN THE GREAT LAKES TO INFORM RESTORATION AND CONSERVATIONNATIVE CISCOES AND WHITEFISHES (KNOWN AS COREGONINES), ARE CULTURALLY, ECONOMICALLY, AND ECOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT FISHES IN THE GREAT LAKES THAT HAVE BEEN IN VARIOUS STATES OF POPULATION DECLINE FOR OVER A CENTURY. A MULTINATIONAL EFFORT TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE THESE FISHES, THE GREAT LAKES COREGONINE RESTORATION FRAMEWORK, IS CURRENTLY IN THE PLANNING PHASE. RESEARCHERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN WILL TEAM WITH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY GREAT LAKES SCIENCE CENTER AND PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT A COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOPED METHODOLOGY TO CONDUCT A GAP ANALYSIS. THE ANALYSIS WILL CLARIFY AND COMPARE THE HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY HABITAT USE AND DISTRIBUTIONS OF COREGONINES TO INFORM PLANNING RESTORATION EFFORTS. WILL  (1) USE MODELING AND MAPPING TECHNIQUES TO LEARN WHERE CERTAIN COREGONINE SPECIES ONCE OCCURRED, (2) LEARN WHERE THEY ARE LIKELY TO OCCUR NOW, AND (3) COMPARE AND DELINEATE AREAS WHERE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES CAN BE FOCUSED BASED ON MANAGERS NEEDS. THIS WORK INVOLVES COLLECTING AND ANALYZING HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY SPAWNING AND HABITAT DATA, DEVELOPING PREDICTIVE MODELS TO MAP AREAS OF COREGONINE OCCURRENCE AND SPAWNING LOCATIONS, AND COMPARISONS OF HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY MAPS AND DATA TO INFORM MANAGERS ABOUT OPTIMAL LOCATIONS TO FOCUS RESTORATION AND OR CONSERVATION EFFORTS. OUTCOMES AND DELIVERABLES FOR THE PROJECT INCLUDE 1) PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA  2) MODELS AND MAPS DESCRIBING HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY POPULATION AND HABITATS FOR GREAT LAKES COREGONINES, 3) A DECISION MATRIX TOOL THAT WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO EVALUATE EACH OUTCOME FROM HISTORICAL VS. CONTEMPORARY COMPARISONS  4) AN ANNUAL REPORT OF FINDINGS, AND 5) DISSEMINATION OF MODELING RESULTS TO MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES AND IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATION. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS COLLABORATION WILL BE USED IN FURTHER PLANNING IN THE COREGONINE RESTORATION FRAMEWORK, INCLUDING DELINEATING SPATIAL UNITS, THREATS ASSESSMENT AND POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSIS. THE COLLABORATION WILL ALSO GENERATE VALUABLE DATA FOR SCIENTISTS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS OF FEDERAL, STATE, INDIGENOUS, AND PROVINCIAL AGENCIES WHO ARE CHARGED WITH ENSURING SUSTAINABLE FISHERY RESOURCES IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. OUTCOMES OF THIS COLLABORATION THEREFORE ALSO DIRECTLY PROVIDE SCIENCE TO HELP AMERICA ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 31 23 3 30 24PROJECT TITLE   COMPUTER MODELING TO SUPPORT LAKE ERIE NUTRIENT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENTEXCESSIVE NUTRIENT, PHOSPHORUS AND NITROGEN, LOADING TO THE GREAT LAKES HAS CAUSED NUMEROUS ECOSYSTEM PROBLEMS INCLUDING HARMFUL AND NUISANCE ALGAL BLOOMS AND HYPOXIA.  MANY OF THESE PROBLEMS NOW INTERACT WITH OTHER ECOSYSTEM STRESSORS SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN WAYS THAT CONFOUND OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT SYSTEM RESPONSE TO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.  DUE TO THE TRANSBOUNDARY NATURE OF THE GREAT LAKES, THE NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT IS GOVERNED BY THE BI NATIONAL GREAT LAKES WATER QUALITY AGREEMENT (GLWQA) BETWEEN THE US AND CANADA, SPECIFICALLY ANNEX 4 OF THIS AGREEMENT, AND IMPLEMENTED THROUGH THE GREAT LAKES EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE (GLEC).  THE GLEC HAS ESTABLISHED AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROCESS FOR LAKE ERIE NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT WITH A TASK TEAM AND WORKING GROUPS TO PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC INPUT AND ANALYSIS. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE MODELING ANALYSIS AS PART OF AND IN SUPPORT OF THE LAKE ERIE DATA AND MODELING WORKING GROUP OF ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT TASK TEAM, AS PART OF THE REASSESSMENT OF THE NUTRIENT ANNEX OF THE US CANADA GREAT LAKES WATER QUALITY AGREEMENT. THIS INCLUDES PROVIDING ADVICE AND GUIDANCE ON POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF PHOSPHORUS, NITROGEN, AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON FUTURE HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS WESTERN LAKE ERIE, THE CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF NUTRIENT INPUTS TO LAKE ERIE FROM LAKE HURON AND THE DETROIT RIVER, AND GUIDANCE TO THE CURRENT TEAM OF MODELERS FOCUSING ON LAKE ERIE HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS AND HYPOXIA, BASED ON PAST EXPERIENCE.AS A MEMBER OF THE WORKING GROUP, THE RECIPIENT WILL SUPPORT THE TASK TEAM IN CONDUCTING THE BINATIONAL ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT EVALUATION BY RECOMMENDING WHICH ECOSYSTEM MODELS SHOULD BE USED AND IDENTIFYING DATA REQUIREMENTS  ACQUIRING, HARMONIZING, AND SYNTHESIZING DATA REQUIRED TO RUN, CALIBRATE, AND VALIDATE THE CHOSEN MODELS  DECIDING ON MODELING SCENARIOS FOR THE MODELS  RUNNING THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN DEVELOPED WESTERN BASIN HAB MODEL, AND COMPARING MODELLED RESULTS TO IN LAKE OUTCOMES.

GRANTEE NAME  UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOISGRANT NUMBER  G23AC00228PROJECT TITLE  ENHANCING CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES IN WESTERN ALASKA  LINKING POLLINATOR DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE TO SUBSISTENCE BERRY PRODUCTION IN A RAPIDLY CHANGING ENVIRONMENT.PROJECT DATES  04 01 2023 TO 12 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO USE MOLECULAR GENETIC TOOLS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POLLINATION IN THE CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT CLOUDBERRY (RUBUS CHAMAEMORUS) IN THE YUKON KUSKWOKIM DELTA OF WESTERN ALASKA.ACTIVES TO BE PERFORMED  LEVERAGING SAMPLES COLLECTED BY PROJECT PARTNERS, WE WILL 1) EXTRACT DNA FROM POLLINATOR SPECIES COLLECTED VIA CONVENTIONAL SAMPLING, 2) GENERATE COI BARCODE DATA FOR THOSE SPECIMENS OBTAINED AND EXTRACTED IN 1, 3) ACCESSION THOSE SEQUENCES INTO ONLINE DNA REPOSITORIES FOR USE IN DOWNSTREAM BIOINFORMATICS PROCESSES, 4) EXTRACT ENVIRONMENTAL DNA COLLECTED FROM THE SURFACE OF CLOUDBERRY FLOWERS, 5) GENERATE METABARCODING SEQUENCE DATA FROM ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, AND 6) USING BIOINFORMATIC PIPELINES, ASSIGN METABARCODING SEQUENCE READS TO HIGHEST TAXONOMIC LEVEL.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  WE EXPECT THESE DATA TO PROVIDE THE FIRST EVER COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF THE CLOUDBERRY POLLINATOR COMMUNITY. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A POLLINATOR BARCODE SEQUENCE LIBRARY HOSTED ON ONLINE SEQUENCE REPOSITORIES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA ANALYSIS OF POLLINATOR SPECIES VISITING CLOUDBERRY FLOWERS, AND A FINAL REPORT DOCUMENTING OUR RESULTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES WHEREIN CLOUDBERRIES REPRESENT A CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT FOOD SOURCE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 28 23-6 27 27PROJECT TITLE: IMPACTS OF BORDER BARRIER INFRASTRUCTURE ON MIGRATORY BIRDS ALONG THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY OFTEXASTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE SEVERAL REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGIES TO QUANTIFY MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT USE AND MIGRATION BEHAVIOR IN RELATION TO BARRIER INFRASTRUCTURE ALONG THE US-MEXICO BORDER WITHIN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY OF TEXAS. WILL INVESTIGATE HOW HABITAT MODIFICATION AND ARTIFICIAL LIGHT AT NIGHT ASSOCIATED WITH THE US BORDER WALL HAS INFLUENCED BIRD MIGRATION 1) AT A BROAD SPATIAL SCALE BY COMPARING WEATHER RADAR MEASURES OF BIRD NUMBERS ALOFT DURING NIGHTTIME FLIGHTS AND ON THE GROUND DURING DAYTIME STOPOVERS BEFORE AND AFTER THE INSTALLATION OF THE WALL BARRIER, AND 2) AT A FINE SCALE BY COMPARING DIFFERENCES IN THE DIVERSITY OF BIRD SPECIES AND THE NUMBERS OF INDIVIDUAL BIRDS FLYING OVER WALLED VERSUS UNWALLED SEGMENTS OF THE BORDER BY RECORDING THE FLIGHT CALLS AS THEY FLY OVERHEAD AT NIGHT AND DETECTING RADIO-MARKED BIRDS FLYING ACROSS THE BORDER USING AUTOMATED RADIO RECEIVERS. WILL ANALYZE WEATHER RADAR DATA FROM THE BROWNSVILLE, TX RADAR (KBRO) DURING SPRING AND FALL WHEN BIRDS TYPICALLY MIGRATE FROM 2005 TO 2025. WILL DEPLOY 11 RADIO RECEIVERS AND 11 AUDIO RECORDERS ALONG THE TEXAS BORDER TO COLLECT DATA DURING SPRING AND FALL. WILL PERFORM STATISTICAL ANALYSES TO DETERMINE HOW FACTORS SUCH AS DISTANCE FROM BORDER BARRIER, BARRIER TYPE, CURRENT AND RECENT CHANGES IN LAND COVER, AND DISTANCE FROM BRIGHT LIGHT AT NIGHT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SEASONAL BIRD DENSITIES IN THE AIR AND ON THE GROUND DURING MIGRATION. WILL DEVELOP FINE-SCALE MAPS OF WHERE BIRDS CONCENTRATE DURING MIGRATION AND STOPOVER WITHIN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY TO HELP LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES PRIORITIZE CURRENT AND FUTURE HABITAT ACQUISITION, CONSERVATION, AND RESTORATION EFFORTS TARGETED AT MIGRATING BIRDS. WILL USE STATISTICAL MODELS TO MAKE MAPS OF PREDICTED STOPOVER USE AT SPECIFIC AREAS OF INTEREST OUTSIDE THE WEATHER RADAR DOMAIN BUT WITHIN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY AS DESIRED BY MANAGEMENT PARTNERS. WILL ALSO PRODUCE A DATASET OF ACOUSTIC AND RADIO-TAG DETECTIONS OF MIGRANTS BY SPECIES ACROSS THE ARRAY OF SAMPLING STATIONS AS WELL AS ASSOCIATED METADATA. WILL DISSEMINATE RESEARCH RESULTS TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AT CONFERENCES AND PUBLICATION IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. WILL ALSO DISSEMINATE RESULTS VIA A PROJECT WEBSITE TO THE PUBLIC AND VIA WRITTEN REPORTS TO NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES. WE WILL ALSO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY FOR MITIGATING ANY NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF BORDER WALL INFRASTRUCTURE ON MIGRATORY BIRDS. UNDERSTANDING HOW MIGRATING BIRDS RESPOND TO HABITAT CHANGES AND LIGHT POLLUTION WILL ADDRESS MULTIPLE UNCERTAINTIES UNDERPINNING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND MIGRATORY POPULATIONS IDENTIFIED BY THE GULF OF MEXICO AVIAN MONITORING NETWORK. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT LAND MANAGERS AND CONSERVATION PLANNERS, WHO HAVE A CRITICAL NEED TO UNDERSTAND HOW MIGRATORY BIRD PASSAGE AND STOPOVER HABITAT USE ARE IMPACTED BY BORDER WALL INFRASTRUCTURE AND ASSOCIATED LIGHT POLLUTION AND WHERE LIMITED FUNDS SHOULD BE INVESTED FOR LAND PROTECTION AND ACQUISITION FOR PASSAGE MIGRANTS TODAY AS WELL AS INTO THE FUTURE.

PROJECT PERIOD: JUNE 6, 2023 - JUNE 5, 2028PROJECT TITLE: WILDFIRE AND LAND MANAGEMENT IMPACTS ON HABITAT AND SURVIVAL OF JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDERS   UNCHARACTERISTICALLY LARGE, SEVERE, OR FREQUENT WILDLAND FIRES ARE MAJOR THREATS TO ECOSYSTEM INTEGRITY, WILDLIFE SPECIES, AND THEIR HABITATS. UNDERSTANDING HOW TO MANAGE FORESTS TO REDUCE THE LIKELIHOOD OF ADVERSE FIRE EFFECTS TO VALUED RESOURCES, SUCH AS ENDANGERED WILDLIFE SPECIES, IS A CENTRAL CHALLENGE FOR LAND MANAGEMENT. OCCUPYING A NARROW GEOGRAPHIC AREA IN HIGH-ELEVATION, FORESTED LANDSCAPES OF NORTH-CENTRAL NEW MEXICO, THE JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDER (PLETHODON NEOMEXICANUS IS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED, AND OBSERVED DECLINES IN POPULATIONS ARE SUSPECTED TO HAVE RESULTED FROM UNCHARACTERISTIC WILDFIRES IN RECENT DECADES. RESEARCH IS NEEDED TO EVALUATE HOW FOREST MANAGEMENT MAY REDUCE THE RISK OF WILDFIRE-INDUCED IMPACTS TO SALAMANDER POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO UNDERSTAND HOW UNCHARACTERISTIC WILDFIRE IN RECENT DECADES HAS IMPACTED SALAMANDER POPULATIONS AND HOW FOREST MANAGEMENT TOOLS, INCLUDING FOREST THINNING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING, CAN BE APPLIED TO REDUCE THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE WHILE PROTECTING SALAMANDER POPULATIONS AND HABITATS.WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS FOR SALAMANDERS AND DESCRIBE THE FORESTS AT AREAS THAT WERE HISTORICALLY-OCCUPIED BY SALAMANDERS BASED ON DATA FROM THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO. WILL IDENTIFY 30 HISTORICALLY-OCCUPIED SITES THAT INCLUDE 10 UNBURNED SITES, 10 SITES THAT EXPERIENCED WILDFIRE BURNING AT LOW MODERATE SEVERITY, AND 10 SITES THAT BURNED AT HIGH SEVERITY. AT EACH SITE, WILL CONDUCT FIVE SURVEYS IN THE AREA SURROUNDING THE HISTORICAL DETECTION BY TURNING OVER SUITABLE COVER OBJECTS (LOGS, STICKS, ROCKS, BARK) ALONG THE SURVEYORS PATHS AND SEARCHING FOR SALAMANDERS BENEATH THEM. WILL WEIGH, MEASURE, AND INDIVIDUALLY MARK CAPTURED SALAMANDERS AFTER DATA ARE COLLECTED, SALAMANDERS WILL BE RELEASED AT THE LOCATION OF CAPTURE. WILL ALSO COLLECT DATA ON THE HABITATS AT THE IMMEDIATE LOCATION OF CAPTURE AND IN THE SURROUNDING FOREST. PLAN TO COMPARE SALAMANDER POPULATIONS AND THE HABITATS AMONG SITES IMPACTED BY WILDFIRE AT DIFFERENT BURN SEVERITY LEVELS TO UNDERSTAND THE LONGER-TERM IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE ON THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES.THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE AN EXTENSIVE FIELD DATA SET THAT CONTAINS INFORMATION ON THE LOCATIONS OF ENDANGERED JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDERS AND DESCRIPTIONS OF THEIR HABITATS WITH RESPECT TO WILDFIRE. THIS DATA SET WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE LAND MANAGERS THAT ADMINISTER THE CONSERVATION LANDS. WILL DEVELOP INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROTOCOLS THAT FOCUS ON AMPHIBIANS AS SIGNALS OF CHANGES IN ECOSYSTEMS AND DISSEMINATE THOSE OTHERS PARTICULARLY IN STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES WHO CAN APPLY THEM IN OTHER REGIONS. EXPECT TO PUBLISH OUR RESULTS IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS AND PRESENT THE WORK AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES TO SHARE APPROACHES WITH THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY. AS THE PUBLIC HAS INTEREST IN WILDFIRE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, PLAN TO CREATE NEWS BRIEFS AND OTHER SCIENCE COMMUNICATION MATERIALS DESCRIBING THE PROJECT AND ITS OUTCOMES.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 30 23 3 29 24PROJECT TITLE NATIONAL EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSE INFORMATION SYSTEM APPLICATION SUPPORTTHE NATIONAL EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSE INFORMATION SYSTEM (NEDRRIS) IS A PLANNED UNIFIED ACCESS AND REPORTING PORTAL FOR INVASIVE SPECIES DATA. NEDRISS WILL CONSOLIDATE CURRENTLY EXISTING INVASIVE SPECIES DATABASES THAT HAVE LIMITED NATIONAL COVERAGE OF BOTH AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL SPECIES. CURRENTLY, THERE IS ALSO NO CLEAR PATHWAY FOR REPORTING RESPONSES TO BIOLOGICAL INVASIONS, WHICH THIS PROPOSED SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE. THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEDRRIS WILL ALLEVIATE THE PRESENT DATA LIMITATIONS TO DETECT AND RAPIDLY RESPOND TO THE INTRODUCTION, ESTABLISHMENT, AND SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES. THE NEDRRIS WILL PROVIDE A SINGLE ONLINE LOCATION FOR INVASIVE SPECIES INFORMATION, A CATALOG OF SURVEILLANCE CAPACITY FOR BIOLOGICAL INVASIONS, A PORTAL FOR RESOURCE MANAGERS TO SUBMIT MANAGEMENT AND RESPONSE ACTIONS AND A PUBLIC REPORTING TOOL FOR PRIMARY DATA SOURCES IN WHICH REPEATABLE ANALYSES CAN BE PERFORMED AND DATA AND REPORTS CAN BE DELIVERED DYNAMICALLY.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO FACILITATE MANAGEMENT ACTION AND INFORMATION EXCHANGE TO AID IN THE PREVENTION OF THE SPREAD AND ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND WILDLIFE DISEASES. NEDRRIS WILL PROVIDE THE VIRTUAL INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT USERS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS AND SERVE AS A COMMUNICATION HUB FOR THE COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE. THE ONLINE APPLICATION WILL SERVE AS A CONSOLIDATED CENTRAL REPOSITORY FOR EXISTING STAND ALONE DATABASES. DATA VISUALIZATION AND ANALYTICAL SUPPORT WILL BE SUPPORTED IN AN ONLINE DASHBOARD, WHERE PORTFOLIOS AND REPORTS CAN BE GENERATED AND HOTSPOT ANALYSES, ALERTS, AND FORECASTS CAN BE GENERATED. ADDITIONALLY, THE GOALS ARE TOUNIFY ACCESS TO EXISTING INTEGRATOR DATABASES INTO A SINGLE ONLINE LOCATION,SOLIDIFY, PROMOTE, AND EXPAND PRIMARY DATA SOURCES, ANDACCELERATE AND ASSESS MANAGEMENT ACTION TO AID IN THE PREVENTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES SPREAD AND ESTABLISHMENT.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 15 23 9 30 23PROJECT TITLE BIOLOGICAL SOIL CRUST ECOLOGY AND FUNCTION FROM SPACEBIOLOGICAL SOIL CRUSTS (BIOCRUSTS) OCCUR IN DRYLANDS GLOBALLY, WHERE THEY SUPPORT ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONING BY INCREASING SOIL STABILITY, REDUCING DUST EMISSIONS AND MODIFYING WATER AND NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY. BIOCRUSTS ARE VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO CARRY OUT EXPLORATORY RESEARCH THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO BETTER UNDERSTANDING HOW BIOCRUSTS RESPOND TO VARIOUS CLIMATIC CONDITIONS, WHICH HAVE BEEN SIMULATED IN A LONG TERM CLIMATE MANIPULATION EXPERIMENT COMPRISING 50 EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS NEAR MOAB UT. WHILE THE CLIMATE MANIPULATION PROJECT GOES BACK ALMOST 20 YEARS, THE EFFORT OF USING REMOTE SENSING TOOLS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND BIOCRUST BEHAVIOR UNDER THE CLIMATE MANIPULATION TREATMENTS IS RELATIVELY RECENT. THE USGS HAVE COLLECTED A RANGE OF VERY HIGH RESOLUTION REMOTE SENSING DATA ACROSS THE ELECTROMAGNETIC SPECTRUM FROM THE VISIBLE TO THE THERMAL WAVELENGTHS USING DRONES AND HANDHELD INSTRUMENTS.WITH THE FUNDING OBTAINED, THESE HIGH RESOLUTION DATA WILL BE ANALYZED IN ORDER TO ASSESS DIFFERENCES IN SPECTRAL, STRUCTURAL AND THERMAL CHARACTERISTICS OF BIOCRUST COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE CLIMATE MANIPULATION EXPERIMENT. ONE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT IS TO DOCUMENT WHAT ADVANCES THIS PROJECT SETUP (LONG TERM FIELD OBSERVATIONS UNDER WARMING AND PRECIPITATION TREATMENTS COMBINED WITH VERY HIGH RESOLUTION REMOTE SENSING DATA) CAN POTENTIALLY BRING TOWARDS DETECTING, CHARACTERIZING AND MONITORING BIOCRUSTS FROM SPACE.

PROJECT PERIOD  4 1 2023 3 31 2025PROJECT TITLE  CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE MANAGEMENT  A PROACTIVE DECISION FRAMEWORKCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IS A WILDLIFE DISEASE OF SIGNIFICANT CONCERN TO CERVIDS, INCLUDING DEER, ELK, AND MOOSE AND HAS BEEN DETECTED IN 26 STATES AND THREE CANADIAN PROVINCES. GIVEN THE SEVERITY OF THIS DISEASE AND THE CULTURAL, RECREATIONAL, ECONOMIC, AND ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE OF CERVIDS, THERE IS MUCH INTEREST IN CWD MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. HOWEVER, ONCE ESTABLISHED, IS DIFFICULT TO ERADICATE CWD DUE TO CERVID BEHAVIORS, HUMAN BEHAVIORS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL PERSISTENCE OF THE CAUSATIVE AGENT. THIS CHALLENGE MAKES PROACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF POTENTIAL INTEREST TO STATES CURRENTLY WITHOUT CWD. VERMONT IS A CWD FREE STATE, BUT IS BORDERED BY QUEBEC, WHERE CWD WAS RECENTLY DETECTED. VERMONTS STATUS AS A CWD FREE STATE PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO BOTH DEVELOP A PROACTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN AND TO COMPARE HOW STAKEHOLDER AND DECISION MAKER OBJECTIVES AND VALUES MAY DIFFER ACROSS THE CWD LANDSCAPE. THIS RESEARCH PROJECT SEEKS TO BOTH FRAME A VERMONT SPECIFIC CWD DECISION AND TO CONTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO A LARGER TEAM OF RESEARCHERS STUDYING CWD MANAGEMENT AND DECISIONS ACROSS ITS NORTH AMERICAN RANGE.PLANNING FOR A POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHER AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT TO WORK WITH THE VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT AND USGS COLLABORATORS TO ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING 2 OBJECTIVES. FIRST, WE WILL FRAME VERMONTS CWD DECISION TO UNDERSTAND THE SPECIFIC CONTEXT AND VALUES ASSOCIATED WITH THE DECISION. SECOND, WILL WORK WITH OTHER RESEARCHERS WORKING IN LOCATIONS WHERE CWD IS ESTABLISHED TO IDENTIFY COMMONALITIES AND DIFFERENCES IN THE DECISION SPACE ACROSS THE CWD LANDSCAPE. THIS MAY YIELD A GENERALIZABLE FRAMEWORK THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO CWD AND TO OTHER WILDLIFE DISEASE DECISIONS. EXPECT THIS WORK TO GENERATE TWO PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS, A REPORT TO USGS AND VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT, AND A RESEARCH PRESENTATION AT A SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE.
INTERNATIONAL OPENET PILOT STUDY IN MILK RIVER BASIN

PROJECT PERIOD  3 15 23 3 14 25PROJECT TITLE MONITORING OF MICROPLASTIC POLLUTION USING INTEGRATED SENSING TECHNOLOGYMICROPLASTIC, INCLUDING MICROBEADS, FRAGMENTS AND FIBERS ARE PLASTIC SMALLER THAN 5 MM IN SIZE. MICROPLASTIC IN BOTH MARINE AND FRESHWATER SYSTEMS HAS BECOME AN EMERGING ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUE. CURRENTLY, THE INFORMATION OF MICROPLASTIC IS COLLECTED BASED ON FIELD SAMPLING BY LABOR AND ANALYZED IN THE CENTRALIZED LABORATORIES. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE (1) TO EVALUATE THE MICROPLASTIC SENSOR PROTOTYPE IN THE TESTING SITES (EFFLUENT, SLUDGE, WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES, AND OR OTHERS) IDENTIFIED BY THE USGS SCIENTISTS, AND (2) TO EXPLORE OPEN SOURCE DESIGN FOR LOW COST INTEGRATED MICROPLASTIC SENSORS. THE TEAM WILL OPTIMIZE THE WORKFLOW FOR MICROPLASTIC QUANTIFICATION AND IDENTIFICATION IN DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENT BY ENGINEERING SOLUTIONS FOR SAMPLING COLLECTION, PRE TREATMENT AS WELL AS MACHINE LEARNING ALGORITHMS AND EDGE COMPUTING. THE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE TWO THRUSTS.THRUST I. DEVELOPING A MICROPLASTIC SENSOR COMBING COMPUTER VISION AND INTEGRATED SPECTROSCOPY.THRUST II. EVALUATING THE SENSITIVITY AND ACCURACY OF MICROPLASTIC SENSORS USING SPIKED SAMPLES CONTAINING KNOWN AMOUNT OF MICROPLASTIC AS WELL AS FIELD TESTS.IT IS EXPECTED THAT PROPOSED SENSOR WILL PROVIDE SUFFICIENTLY RICH INFORMATION (SIZE, MORPHOLOGY, CHEMICAL COMPOSITION) FOR MICROPLASTIC ANALYSIS COMPARED TO TRADITIONAL LABORATORY ANALYSIS. THE TEAM WILL BRING MATURING TECHNOLOGIES AND PRODUCTS TO PROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO COLLECT, ANALYZE AND DELIVER MICROPLASTIC INFORMATION FOR USGS. THE EXPECTED PRODUCTS INCLUDE SENSOR DESIGNS AND MICROPLASTIC DATA COLLECTED DURING THE FIELD TEST. THE RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS, AMERICAN GEOPHYSICAL UNION (AGU) FALL MEETING, ALABAMA WATER INSTITUTE (AWI) SYMPOSIUM, AND CONFERENCE ORGANIZED BY THE LOCAL, STATE, REGIONAL AND FEDERAL AGENCIES.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 17 23 3 16 25PROJECT TITLE  AQUATIC SWARMING WITH MICRO AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLES AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLES (AUVS) HAVE GAINED BROAD POPULARITY AS EFFECTIVE PLATFORMS FOR SAMPLING OCEANS AND LAKES. THE NEXT FRONTIER IS TO USE A FLEET OF THESE UNDERWATER VEHICLES TO PERFORM ADAPTIVE, DISTRIBUTED SAMPLING. COORDINATED VEHICLES CAN SUPPORT DENSE SAMPLING, PROVIDING HIGH QUALITY MEASUREMENTS TO MODEL FAST EVOLVING FEATURES IN THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT. MULTIPLE CHALLENGES EXIST IN UNDERWATER COMMUNICATIONS AND SWARMING IMPLEMENTATION. THE MAJOR HURDLE LIES IN VARIOUS CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH THROUGH WATER ACOUSTIC COMMUNICATIONS. FURTHER, INTEGRATION AMONG AUTONOMY, UNDERATER WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS, NETWORKING, AND GROUP BEHAVIORS IS NON TRIVIAL DUE TO UNSTABLE COMMUNICATION LINKS, EVOLVING NETWORK TOPOLOGIES, AND DYNAMIC AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS. THE OPERATIONAL GAP IS THAT NO GROUP BEHAVIORS ARE UTILIZED IN UNDERWATER MISSIONS, AND NO RELIABLE THROUGH WATER COMMUNICATION AND NETWORKING SOLUTIONS ARE AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT AQUATIC SWARMING. MANY COMPACT, LOW COST AUVS HAVE EMERGED RECENTLY, SPARKING RENEWED INTEREST IN UNDERWATER SWARMING. PROPOSE TO DEVELOP RELIABLE SWARMING STRATEGIES SUPPORTED BY ACOUSTIC COMMUNICATIONS AND NETWORKING SCHEMES FOR MICRO SIZED UNDERWATER VEHICLES. THE COMBINED COMMUNICATION AND SENSING DESIGN WILL SUPPORT THROUGH WATER MESSAGE EXCHANGES, INTER VEHICLE COORDINATION, AND ADAPTIVE GROUP BEHAVIORS. WILL DEMONSTRATE UNDERWATER SWARMING BASED ON ACOUSTIC AND NAVIGATIONAL MEASUREMENTS COLLECTED IN FIELD TESTS IN A LOCAL LAKE. THE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THREE THRUSTS LISTED BELOW.THRUST I  INTEGRATING AN ACOUSTIC MODEM WITH A COMPACT VEHICLE PLATFORM. THRUST II  DEVELOPING ACOUSTIC NETWORKING AND RANGING METHODS.THRUST III  DEVELOPING SWARMING BEHAVIORS SUITABLE FOR COMPACT PLATFORMS AND LOW DATA RATE ACOUSTIC LINKS.THESE THRUSTS DIRECTLY ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) IN A) PRACTICAL NETWORK PROTOCOLS SUPPORTING VEHICLE COORDINATION AND ADAPTIVE SAMPLING, B) COMMUNICATION AUTONOMY INTEGRATION PROTOTYPES, AND C) INTELLIGENT SWARMING ALGORITHMS. THE PROPOSED EFFORTS WILL PREPARE THE USGS TO IMPLEMENT MULTIPLE VEHICLE ADAPTIVE MISSIONS FOR HIGH RESOLUTION TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL SAMPLING. THE MAIN DELIVERABLE IS AN ACOUSTIC MODEM INTEGRATED INTO A COMPACT VEHICLE THAT WILL BE DEMONSTRATED IN LAKE EXPERIMENTS. ANOTHER DELIVERABLE IS THE NETWORKING AND SWARMING ALGORITHMS SHOWN IN COMPUTER SIMULATIONS. THE TARGET PLATFORM IS A JAIABOT, A MICRO SIZE, HYBRID AQUATIC VEHICLE. THE RESEARCH TEAM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH MULTIPLE PARTNERS, FOR EXAMPLE, THE UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE TEAM AND JAIA ROBOTICS, INC., TO ACHIEVE PROJECT GOALS.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 23 23 3 22 25PROJECT TITLE  IMPROVED PROCESSING AND DELIVERY OF STATIONARY AND MOBILE COSMIC RAY NEUTRON SENSOR DATAPLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY  THE COSMIC RAY NEUTRON SENSOR (CRNS) HAS BEEN USED AS A NON CONTACT, PASSIVE, NEAR SURFACE AREA WIDE SOIL MOISTURE DETECTOR FOR THE LAST 15 YEARS ON 6 CONTINENTS. DUE TO ITS RAPID EXPANSION, DATA STANDARDIZATION AND DISAGREEMENT BETWEEN SCIENTISTS ON THE MOST UP TO DATE PROCESSING ALGORITHMS AND CALIBRATION PROCEDURES HAVE LED TO UNNECESSARY CONFUSION. THIS HAS LED TO DIFFERENT GROUPS PROCESSING CRNS DATA IN DIFFERENT MANNERS WHICH CONFUSES NEW USERS OF CRNS AND DIMINISHES THE TECHNIQUE ITSELF. RECENT EFFORTS HAVE SOUGHT TO STANDARDIZE CRNS DATA PROCESSING, HARMONIZATION, AND DATA STANDARDS THROUGH OPEN SOURCE CODES. IN THE PROPOSED WORK, WILL PROVIDE IMPROVED PROCESSING SCRIPTS FOR BOTH STATIONARY AND MOBILE CRNS FOLLOWING BEST PRACTICES AND UP TO DATE PROCESSING ALGORITHMS FROM THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE. THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA LINCOLN (UNL) WILL BUILD CYBER INFRASTRUCTURE TO INGEST THE STATIONARY CRNS DATA FROM THE VENDOR AND DELIVER IT IN REAL TIME TO THE NATIONAL WATER INFORMATION SYSTEM (NWIS) AS REQUESTED BY USGS. THE TEAM AT UNL WILL ALSO DEVELOP PYTHON SCRIPTS TO PROCESS THE USGS MOBILE CRNS SURVEYS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  1. DEVELOP PYTHON PROCESSING SCRIPTS AND CYBER INFRASTRUCTURE FOR STATIONARY CRNS SYSTEMS AND DELIVERY OF DATA TO NWIS. 2. DEVELOP PROCESSING ALGORITHM FOR MOBILE CRNS SYSTEMS. 3. ASSIST USGS STAFF IN DATA COLLECTION, INTERPRETATION, SITE CALIBRATIONS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPS). 4. ASSIST IN RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION OF CRNS TECHNOLOGY MEASURING FOR SNOW WATER EQUIVALENCE (SWE). 5. INTEGRATE CRNS DATA INTO UNSATURATED ZONE AND HYDROLOGICAL MODELING USING DATA ASSIMILATION (DA) TECHNIQUES. 6. REPORT REGULARLY AND COORDINATE WITH USGS STAFF.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  1. DEVELOPMENT OF CYBER INFRASTRUCTURE AND ADVANCED PROCESSING ALGORITHMS FOR DELIVERING CRNS DATA TO NWIS.2. DEVELOPMENT OF OPEN SOURCE PROCESSING ALGORITHMS FOR MOBILE CRNS SURVEYS.3. DEVELOPMENT OF OPEN SOURCE PROCESSING ALGORITHMS USING CRNS FOR SWE OBSERVATIONS. 4. DEVELOPMENT OF DA ALGORITHMS USING CRNS OBSERVATIONS WITH UNSATURATED FLOW MODELLING. 5. DEVELOPMENT AND CONTRIBUTION TO USGS SOPS FOR USE OF CRNS.6. PARTICIPATION IN CRNS FIELD CAMPAIGNS WITH USGS STAFF. 7. LEAD CRNS TRAINING COURSE(S) FOR USGS STAFF.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  ADVANCING THE CYBER INFRASTRUCTURE AND PROCESSING ALGORITHMS FOR USGS CRNS NETWORKS. CRNS STATIONARY DATA WILL BE DELIVERED TO NWIS FOR WIDESPREAD USE BY THE HYDROLOGICAL COMMUNITY. DEVELOPMENT OF OPEN SOURCE PROCESSING ALGORITHM FOR MOBILE CRNS SURVEYS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  CRNS ALGORITHM DEVELOPMENT AND CYBER INFRASTRUCTURE IMPLEMENTATION WITH R. ROSOLEM AND J. BRADLEY. SWE ALGORITHM DEVELOPMENT WITH D. DESILETS. INTEGRATION OF CRNS OBSERVATIONS WITH DA TECHNIQUES FOR UNSATURATED ZONE FLOW WITH A. LARIOS.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 17 23 3 16 25PROJECT TITLE  SUPPORTING THE DEVELOPMENT AND EXECUTION OF A TECHNOLOGY TRANSITION FRAMEWORKPURPOSE  THE USGS IS DEVELOPING PARTNERSHIPS WITH UNIVERSITIES TO INVEST IN TECHNOLOGIES AT ANY TECHNOLOGY READINESS LEVEL, THOUGH PROTOTYPE, ALPHA, AND BETA TECHNOLOGIES THAT CAN BE FIELD DEPLOYED FOR EVALUATION WITHIN THE SPECIFIED AWARD PERIOD ARE OF GREATEST INTEREST. TECHNOLOGIES SHOULD ULTIMATELY BE SCALABLE FROM REGIONAL TO NATIONAL MONITORING NETWORKS. HOWEVER, THE SUCCESSFUL RETURN ON INVESTMENT, AND TRANSITION OF THOSE TECHNOLOGIES INTO ROUTINE USGS OPERATIONS REQUIRES A CLEAR TECHNOLOGY TRANSITION FRAMEWORK, MARKET RESEARCH, AND INSTRUMENT EVALUATIONS. A WELL DEVELOPED FRAMEWORK OF TECHNOLOGY EVALUATION WOULD HELP NGWOS ACHIEVE ITS MISSION OF IMPLEMENTING INNOVATIVE MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES AND METHODS WITHIN THE USGS NATIONAL MONITORING NETWORK AND THROUGHOUT THE WATER MONITORING COMMUNITY. THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE (UMCES)  LED ALLIANCE FOR COASTAL TECHNOLOGIES (ACT) PROGRAM IS PERFECTLY SUITED (I.E., EXTENSIVE EXPERTISE AND EXPERIENCE) TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS AND HAS BEEN SELECTED FOR A CESU COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO WORK DIRECTLY USGS ON EFFORTS TO ACCELERATE THE OPERATIONAL READINESS OF PRIORITY WATER MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES. OBJECTIVE 1, DEVELOPMENT OF THE TTF. ACT WILL ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FRAMEWORK THAT FACILITATES AND INCENTIVIZES NEW NEEDED INNOVATIONS AND A ROBUST PROCESS TO GUIDE THE TRANSITION OF TECHNOLOGIES FROM THE IDENTIFICATION OF SPECIFICATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS THROUGH MARKET RESEARCH, PROTOTYPE BETA TESTING AND INDEPENDENT VERIFICATIONS, AND INTO USGS OPERATIONS. ACT WILL ALSO ASSIST THE USGS IN DEVELOPING STANDARDIZED TESTING PROTOCOLS AND TEMPLATES FOR USGS INSTRUMENT EVALUATIONS. OBJECTIVE 2, MARKET RESEARCH. ACT WILL SUPPORT INFORMAL MARKET RESEARCH ON NEW WATER MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES THROUGH HOLDING ONE WORKSHOP FOCUSED ON THE CURRENT NEEDS AND STATUS, STANDARDIZATION, POTENTIAL ADVANCEMENTS, AND OBSTACLES IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF SENSORS AND SENSOR PLATFORMS FOR STUDYING, MONITORING, AND PREDICTING THE STATE OF FRESH AND COASTAL WATERS. OBJECTIVE 3  INSTRUMENT EVALUATIONS. ACT WILL DEVELOP AND COORDINATE NO RISK BETA TESTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR NEW OR IMPROVED TECHNOLOGIES PUT FORWARD BY INDUSTRY AND ACADEMIA AT A USGS LOCATION (TBD).  THIS WILL PROVIDE THE DEVELOPERS, VENDORS, AND UNIVERSITIES WITH REAL WORLD CLIMATIC CONDITIONS WITHOUT DIRECT USGS EVALUATION OR SUPPORT (BEYOND FACILITATING ACCESS TO SELECT BETA TEST LOCATIONS AND USGS DATA ALREADY BEING COLLECTED). ACT ALSO WILL COORDINATE AND OVERSEE INDEPENDENT INSTRUMENT VERIFICATION OF TRL 8 OR 9 SENSORS OF INTEREST TO USGS. EACH OBJECTIVE WILL HAVE APPROPRIATE PROGRESS REPORT EMAILS CALLS MEETINGS, AND A FORMAL FINAL REPORT AFTER THE COMPLETION OF SPECIFIC TASKS. ACT WILL ALSO DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF THIS EFFORT THAT ARE OF VALUE TO THE BROADER COMMUNITY (E.G., PUBLICLY AVAILABLE REPORTS ON THE ACT WEBSITE, PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND OR PRESENTATIONS AT CONFERENCES).

GRANTEE NAME   GREAT BASIN BIRD OBSERVATORYGRANT NUMBER   TBDPROJECT TITLE  APPLIED ECOLOGY OF GREATER SAGE GROUSE AND SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS AT LOCAL AND REGIONAL SCALES  A PROPOSED STUDY TO COORDINATE ONGOING FIELD LOGISTICS AND DATA COLLECTIONAWARD PURPOSE  THIS AGREEMENT IS ESTABLISHED TO FACILITATE COOPERATION BETWEEN USGS AND GREAT BASIN BIRD OBSERVATORY (GBBO) IN THE COLLECTION OF FIELD DATA RELEVANT TO THE ECOLOGY OF GREATER SAGE GROUSE AND THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM IN THE GREAT BASIN ECOREGION. THIS RESEARCH FOCUSES ON, AND THE FIELD DATA COLLECTION IS RELATED TO, FOUR HIGHLY INTEGRATED RESEARCH OBJECTIVES  1) PREDICTING THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE INVASIVE GRASS CYCLES ON SAGE GROUSE POPULATION DYNAMICS AND SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE AND RESISTANCE  2) PREDICTING THE IMPACTS OF MINING OPERATIONS AND COMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE ON SAGE GROUSE HABITAT SUITABILITY, 3) CONTINUED REFINEMENTS TO PROTOCOLS AND STRATEGIES FOR LOCAL SAGE GROUSE POPULATION RECOVERY THROUGH POPULATION AUGMENTATION AND TRANSLOCATIONS, AND 4) DEVELOPING A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF DIRECT AND INDIRECT PREDATOR IMPACTS ON SAGE GROUSE POPULATIONS LOCALLY, REGIONALLY, AND RANGE WIDE, WITH A FOCUS ON COMMON RAVENS AS NEST PREDATORS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS AGREEMENT, GBBO WILL HIRE, TRAIN, AND PROVIDE LOGISTICAL SUPPORT FOR FIELD TECHNICIANS WHO WILL BE TASKED WITH COLLECTING FIELD DATA RELATED TO GREATER SAGE GROUSE DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION, AND HABITAT USE ACROSS MULTIPLE SUB POPULATIONS (STUDY STIES) IN SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS WITHIN NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA. GBBO WILL ALSO MONITOR PREDATOR COMMUNITIES, TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS, WILDFIRE, AND VEGETATION STRUCTURE AND COMPONENT DATA.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  GBBO WILL PROVIDE USGS WITH ELECTRONIC COPIES OF ALL FIELD DATA CONTAINING INFORMATION COLLECTED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WITHIN 30 DAYS OF FIELD COLLECTION.GBBO WILL PROVIDE USGS WITH MONTHLY ACCOUNT SUMMARIES OF EXPENSES.GBBO AND USGS WILL EXCHANGE COPIES OF ANY REPORTS OR PEER REVIEWED ARTICLES DOCUMENTING STUDY RESULTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  DESCRIPTIONSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  DESCRIPTION

PROJECT TITLE  USE AND VALIDATION OF MICRO UNCREWED UNDERWATER VEHICLES FOR WATER OBSERVING SYSTEMSPROJECT PERIOD  03 01 2023 THROUGH 08 31 2024THE UMASS DARTMOUTH SCHOOL FOR MARINE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY (SMAST) WILL FIELD TEST AND VALIDATE A 5 VEHICLE JAIABOT HYDRO UNCREWED UNDERWATER VEHICLE (UUV) SYSTEM AGAINST TRADITIONAL SAMPLING AND ANALYTICAL APPROACHES FOR WATER QUALITY MONITORING. FIELD TESTS OF THE JAIABOT HYDRO WILL MEASURE CONDUCTIVITY, TEMPERATURE AND DEPTH BOTH IN PROFILE AND DURING TRANSIT. THE SYSTEM S USER INTERFACE WILL ENABLE LOCATION, SHORT RANGE TELEMETRY, AND POINT TO POINT MISSION PLANNING AND EXECUTION. DRIFT MEASUREMENTS OF SURFACE AND SUBSURFACE VECTORS WILL FURTHER BE MADE FOR QUICK CHARACTERIZATION OF FLOW FIELD PREDICTION VALIDATION. FINALLY, FULL WATER DEPTH VEHICLE DIVES WILL BE USED TO MEASURE BOTTOM DEPTH AND THEREBY BATHYMETRY AS A FUNCTION OF GEOGRAPHICAL POSITION.FOLLOWING SUCCESSFUL FIELD VALIDATION TESTS IN A VARIETY OF LOCAL ENVIRONMENTS (RIVERS, TIDAL RIVERS, ESTUARIES, LAKES AND OPEN WATER EMBAYMENTS) THE 5 VEHICLE UUV SYSTEM (FROM MISSION PLANNING, TO EXECUTION, TO DATA DOWNLOAD) WILL BE DEPLOYED FOR DEMONSTRATION AND FIELD VALIDATION PURPOSES IN THE DELAWARE RIVER NEAR PHILADELPHIA, PA. ADDITIONALLY, AS PART OF SENSOR DEVELOPMENT FOR FUTURE APPLICATIONS, SMAST WILL WORK WITH JAIA ROBOTICS IN COLLABORATION WITH UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA RESEARCHERS TOWARD INCORPORATING A MICRO MODEM CAPABILITY INTO THE JAIABOT. THE COMBINED PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STAFF ON TESTING AND EVALUATING THE SYSTEM TO HELP WITH DEVELOPING SALIENT CHARACTERISTICS FOR UUVS IN LARGE RIVERS SUCH AS THE DELAWARE.FIELD VALIDATION OF A 5 VEHICLE JAIABOT HYDRO SYSTEM WILL ENABLE THE TEAM TO BECOME FAMILIAR WITH THE JAIABOT SYSTEM, INCLUDING OPERATION AND DATA RECOVERY, INCLUDING MISSION PLANNING, SYSTEM OPERATION, SENSOR SELECTION AND KEY PERFORMANCE PARAMETERS IN ORDER TO DEVELOP DESIRED SALIENT CHARACTERISTICS FOR FUTURE USE. THE LONG TERM GOAL OF THIS EFFORT IS TO FACILITATE THE INTEGRATION OF AUTONOMOUS WATER QUALITY SAMPLING INTO ONGOING WATER OBSERVING SYSTEMS, WITH THE GOAL OF ENHANCING THEIR CAPABILITIES FOR FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND MONITORING.

PROJECT PERIOD: 5 1 23-4 30 24 PROJECT TITLE: MOVEMENT ECOLOGY OF NATIVE FISH IN THE CUYAHOGA RIVER IN RELATION TO A LARGE DAM REMOVALPROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY DAM REMOVALS ARE INCREASING IN FREQUENCY AS DAMS AGE OUT AND POSE A PUBLIC SAFETY HAZARD. SOME OF THESE STRUCTURES HAVE POSED A SIGNIFICANT IMPEDIMENT TO FISH PASSAGE FOR MORE THAN 100 YEARS, INCLUDING THE GORGE DAM ON THE CUYAHOGA RIVER. WITH THE INCREASE IN DAM REMOVALS IN THE U.S., MANY STUDIES HAVE INVESTIGATED CHANGES IN FISH DISTRIBUTION FOLLOWING REMOVAL, BUT PRE-REMOVAL DATA ARE OFTEN INADEQUATE TO ADDRESS OTHER KINDS OF ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS. ENSURING THAT ADEQUATE BASELINE DATA ARE COLLECTED PRIOR TO DAM REMOVAL IS NECESSARY TO ASSESS THE RESTORATION IMPACTS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO ESTABLISH BASELINE DATA ON MOVEMENT PATTERNS OF NATIVE FISH SPECIES IN RELATION TO GORGE DAM PRIOR TO ITS REMOVAL. THIS RESEARCH WILL USE BIOTELEMETRY TO INVESTIGATE HOW NATIVE FISHES ARE USING SPACE AROUND THE GORGE DAM. WILL TAG AND TRACK FISHES FROM AT LEAST THREE FOCAL NATIVE SPECIES REPRESENTING A RANGE OF MOVEMENT STRATEGIES. INDIVIDUALS WILL BE TAGGED WITH ACOUSTIC TRANSMITTERS, RELEASED, AND MONITORED FOR FINE-SCALE MOVEMENT USING ACTIVE AND PASSIVE BIOTELEMETRY. THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN DESIGNED AND TIMED TO PROVIDE BASELINE INFORMATION DIRECTLY RELEVANT TO MANAGERS OF CUYAHOGA RIVER RESOURCES. WILL DELIVER AN EVALUATION OF FISH POPULATION ECOLOGY IN THIS SYSTEM BEFORE PLANNED DAM REMOVAL TAKES PLACE SO THAT MANAGERS AND COLLABORATING RESEARCH SCIENTISTS CAN ROBUSTLY ASSESS CHANGES THAT OCCUR DURING AND FOLLOWING DAM REMOVAL.

AWARD PURPOSE  LISTENING  TO SOCIAL MEDIA CAN PROVIDE CRITICAL INSIGHTS EARLY IN EMERGENCY SCIENCERESPONSES AND, LATER, FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A SOCIAL MEDIAMONITORING DASHBOARD, WHICH WILL TRACK AND VISUALIZE EMERGENT TRENDS FOR VOLCANOES,EARTHQUAKES, AND LANDSLIDES, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THESE COMPOUNDING AND CASCADING FACTORS.GATHERING CRITICAL INTELLIGENCE VIA A CUSTOMIZED SOCIAL MEDIA MONITORING PLATFORM CANINCLUDE  RAPID EMERGING TOPIC DETECTION, SENTIMENT FLUCTUATION, INFLUENTIAL USERS, VESTEDCOMMUNITIES, AND VIDEOS AND IMAGES OF THESE NATURAL HAZARDS. A FEATURE OF THIS PROJECT IS TODETECT MISINFORMATION AND RESPOND TO IT QUICKLY BEFORE INACCURACIES SPREAD RAPIDLY ONLINE ANDIN THE MEDIA. A TAILOR MADE SOCIAL LISTENING DASHBOARD WILL ALSO FACILITATE GATHERING SOCIALMEDIADATA FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES, ALLOWING USGS SCIENTISTS TO EXPAND OUR KNOWLEDGE ABOUTHUMAN BEHAVIOR AND RISK ISSUES DURING NATURAL HAZARDS CRISES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED PHASE 1  ANALYSIS OF DASHBOARD DESIGN REQUIREMENTS. WE WILL IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE MAJORDASHBOARD CAPABILITIES REGARDING RESPONSES IN ONLINE SOCIAL MEDIA UNDER SPECIFIC EVENT PLATFORM USER SCENARIOS, AND CORRESPONDINGLY INVESTIGATE DATA ANALYSIS METHODS PLATFORMS THATARE SUITABLE TO SUPPORT THESE CAPABILITIES. PHASE 2  DEVELOPMENT OF SOCIAL MEDIA MONITORINGDASHBOARD. THE DASHBOARD WILL CONSIST OF DATA COLLECTION, DATA STORAGE AND PROCESSING, DATAANALYSIS AND VISUALIZATION, AND USER INTERFACE. PHASE 3  CASE STUDIES AND EVALUATIONS. WE WILLVALIDATE THE SOCIAL MEDIA MONITORING DASHBOARD AND EVALUATE THE USEFULNESS OF THE DASHBOARDWITH INSIGHTS GAINED VIA CASE STUDIES. LEVERAGING FEEDBACK FROM DOMAIN EXPERTS, WE WILLIDENTIFY A NUMBER OF USAGE SCENARIOS, AND USE THE DASHBOARD TO CONDUCT VARIOUS EVALUATIONS.PHASE 4  IMPLEMENTATION. WE WILL FIRST TRAIN RESPONDERS TO EMERGENCY EVENTS. A SEPARATETRAINING WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR RESEARCHERS TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A SOCIAL MEDIA MONITORING DASHBOARD TO ASSIST MULTI HAZARDRESPONSE. THE DASHBOARD CAN AUTOMATICALLY ANALYZE PUBLIC ACTIVITIES IN ONLINE SOCIAL MEDIA.THE DATA OBTAINED AND CORRESPONDING ANALYSIS RESULTS ARE VISUALIZED THROUGH THE DASHBOARD,WHICH ALLOWS USERS TO EXPLORE SPECIFIC EVENTS, TOPICS, TIME DURATIONS, COMMUNITY SENTIMENT,ETC. USGS SOCIAL MEDIA ACCOUNTS CAN QUICKLY ADAPT MESSAGING TO COMMUNICATE RISK ANDHAZARDS FACTORS IN AN IMPACTFUL WAY. FURTHERMORE, CASE STUDIES OF HAZARD EVENTS CAN LEAD TOFURTHER RESEARCH AND OR PUBLIC RESPONSE STRATEGY DESIGN.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES NATURAL HAZARDS RESEARCHERS, EMERGENCY RESPONDERS, RISK MANAGEMENT, GENERAL PUBLICSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES N A

PROJECT PERIOD  2 21 2023 2 20 2025PROJECT TITLE ADVANCING IMAGE BASED HYDROLOGY FOR USGS STREAM GAGE APPLICATIONSPLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION OF AWARD PURPOSE GROUND BASED OBSERVATIONS FROM FIXED MOUNT CAMERAS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO FILL AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN ENVIRONMENTAL SENSING, INCLUDING DIRECT MEASUREMENT OF WATER LEVELS AND QUALITATIVE OBSERVATION OF RESEARCH SITES. ALL OF THIS IS THEORETICALLY POSSIBLE FOR ANYONE WHO CAN INSTALL A TRAIL CAMERA. EASY ACQUISITION OF GROUND BASED IMAGERY HAS RESULTED IN MILLIONS OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMAGES STORED, SOME OF WHICH ARE PUBLIC DATA, AND MANY OF WHICH CONTAIN INFORMATION THAT HAS YET TO BE USED FOR SCIENTIFIC PURPOSES. THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO DEVELOP AND DOCUMENT KEY IMAGE PROCESSING AND MACHINE LEARNING WORKFLOWS, PRIMARILY RELATED TO SEMI AUTOMATED IMAGE LABELING, TO INCREASE THE USE AND VALUE OF EXISTING AND EMERGING ARCHIVES OF IMAGERY THAT IS RELEVANT TO ECOHYDROLOGICAL PROCESSES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE GAUGECAM TEAM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA   LINCOLN AND UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA AT KEARNEY WILL DEVELOP A HIGH USABILITY GRAPHICAL USER INTERFACE THAT INTERACTS WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY S HYDROLOGIC IMAGERY VISUALIZATION AND INFORMATION SYSTEM (HIVIS) WEBSITE FOR (A) ACCESSING IMAGERY VIA PUBLIC APPLICATION PROGRAMMING INTERFACE (API), (B) AUTOMATED FILTERING OF IMAGE ARCHIVES TO IDENTIFY HIGH QUALITY IMAGES, AND (C) SEMI AUTOMATED LABELING OF HIGH QUALITY IMAGES THAT ARE USED TO TRAIN CLASSIFIERS THAT DETECT WATER BODIES IN IMAGE SCENES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESOPEN SOURCE SOFTWARE AND RELATED DATA PRODUCTS ARE THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT. USING THE USER INTERFACE AND WORKFLOWS, WE WILL CREATE DATA PRODUCTS FROM SELECTED HIVIS SITES, CONSISTING OF LABELED IMAGES SUITABLE FOR BUILDING CLASSIFIERS, CLASSIFIERS TO DETECT WATER SURFACES IN IMAGERY, AND DOCUMENT THE PERFORMANCE OF THE CLASSIFIERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESTHE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT THROUGH THE AVAILABILITY OF NEW SOFTWARE AND BY PILOTING THE PROCESSES REQUIRED TO CREATE THE DESIRED DATA PRODUCTS. BECAUSE THE SOFTWARE IS OPEN SOURCE, THE BROADER WATER SCIENCE COMMUNITY WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM THE AVAILABILITY OF NEW SOFTWARE AND DOCUMENTED WORKFLOWS, WHICH WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE VIA HTTPS   GAUGECAM.ORG.SUB RECIPIENT ACTIVITIESPARTICIPANTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA AT KEARNEY WILL TEST SOFTWARE, PARTICIPATE IN IMAGE LABELING TASKS, MAINTAIN A PROTOTYPE CAMERA INSTALLATION, AND PARTICIPATE IN DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT RESULTS.

PROJECT PERIOD:7 10 23-7 11 24PROJECT TITLE: ADVANCING NOVEL APPROACHES FOR VISITOR MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT ON FEDERAL PUBLIC LANDSPURPOSEDATA ON RECREATIONAL USE ARE CRITICAL FOR EVALUATING PROPOSED POLICIES AND MANAGEMENT OPTIONS. HOWEVER, THE DEMAND FOR THESE DATA FAR OUTSTRIPS THE SUPPLY  FEW LAND AGENCIES TRACK VISITOR USE COMPREHENSIVELY AND CONSISTENTLY. THIS IS DUE TO MANY FACTORS INCLUDING THE REMOTE AND POROUS NATURE OF PUBLIC LANDS AND THE CAPACITY OF STAFF TO COUNT AND SURVEY VISITORS.  IN RESPONSE, SCIENTISTS HAVE BEGUN DEVELOPING APPROACHES FOR MONITORING RECREATION ON PUBLIC LANDS USING METHODS THAT INCORPORATE NOVEL DATA SOURCES SUCH AS SOCIAL MEDIA AND MOBILE PHONE LOCATIONS. THIS STUDY WILL TEST AND REFINE THESE NEW APPROACHES AIMED AT IMPROVING THE ACCURACY OF VISITOR MONITORING, STANDARDIZING INFORMATION COLLECTION, AND MAKING ESTIMATION EASIER FOR AGENCY STAFF.ACTIVITIESCO-HOST AN INTERAGENCY WORKSHOP TO DISCUSS THE CURRENT STATE OF KNOWLEDGE AND BEST PRACTICES FOR USING NOVEL APPROACHES FOR VISITOR MONITORING ON FEDERAL PUBLIC LANDS.EVALUATE NEW DATA SOURCES AND TECHNIQUES THAT COULD IMPROVE VISITOR MONITORING, BY EXAMINING THE CONGRUENCE BETWEEN ON-THE-GROUND DATA SUCH AS FIELD COUNTS AND SURVEYS WITH NOVEL DATA SOURCES SUCH AS MOBILE PHONE LOCATION DATA USER-GENERATED SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT AT SELECTED STUDY SITES.CREATE RECOMMENDATIONS TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND UPTAKE OF NOVEL VISITOR MONITORING APPROACHES AND DATA BY LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESAN INTERAGENCY WORKSHOP TO GUIDE RESEARCH INTO NOVEL APPROACHES FOR VISITOR MONITORING.DATASETS OF FIELD-BASED VISITATION ESTIMATES AND NOVEL LOCATION DATA TO THE SAME STUDY SITES.STATISTICAL ANALYSES OF PATTERNS, TRENDS, AND CORRESPONDENCE AMONG DIFFERENT SOURCES OF VISITATION DATA.FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PRACTITIONERS AS TECHNICAL REPORT(S) OR PUBLICATION(S).INTENDED BENEFICIARIESTHIS PROJECT BENEFITS PRACTITIONERS WHO MONITOR RECREATION ON FEDERAL LANDS BY RECOMMENDING ACTIONS TO INCREASING ACCURACY AND EFFICIENCY OF MONITORING PROGRAMS.  IMPROVED VISITOR INFORMATION ULTIMATELY BENEFITS THE PUBLIC THROUGH INCREASED CAPACITY BY AGENCIES TO IMPROVE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ON LANDS AND WATERS MANAGED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 22 23 3 21 25PROJECT TITLE MERCURY CONCENTRATIONS IN LICHENS AT THE SULPHUR BANK MERCURY MINETO APPROPRIATELY REMEDIATE THE EPA SUPERFUND SULPHUR BANK MERCURY MINE (SBMM) SITE, A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE MERCURY (HG) CONTAMINATION PATHWAYS IS NECESSARY. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO GATHER DATA ON THE ATMOSPHERIC PATHWAY BY IDENTIFYING AREAS OF ELEVATED GASEOUS MERCURY EMISSIONS AS REVEALED BY THE TOTAL AND SPECIATED HG CONTENT IN NATIVE EPIPHYTIC LICHENS. LICHENS LACK A ROOT SYSTEM AND THUS ABSORB THEIR NUTRIENTS AND MOISTURE PASSIVELY FROM THE ATMOSPHERE MAKING THEM A CONVENIENT BIOINDICATOR OF ATMOSPHERIC HG EMISSIONS. THE PRELIMINARY LICHEN SAMPLING AT THE SBMM IN MARCH OF 2022, REVEALED EXTREMELY HIGH TOTAL HG CONCENTRATIONS OF UP TO 23 PPM, AND LOWER, BUT STILL ELEVATED TOTAL HG CONCENTRATIONS OF NEAR 1 PPM AT THE SHORE OF CLEAR LAKE. THIS DEMONSTRATES THAT THE ATMOSPHERIC PATHWAY IS SIGNIFICANT FOR HG AT CLEAR LAKE AS WELL, AND THAT THE LICHENS CAN IDENTIFY AREAS WITH HIGH GASEOUS MERCURY EMISSIONS AND DEPOSITION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDEVALUATE THE USE OF LICHEN AS A MONITORING TOOL FOR ASSESSING GASEOUS TRANSPORT OF MERCURY AT CONTAMINATED MINE SITESCOLLECT AND ANALYZE LICHEN SAMPLES FOR MERCURY SPECIES (TOTAL MERCURY, METHYLMERCURY,AND REACTIVE MERCURY II) FROM SBMM, AS WELL AS UNCONTAMINATED CONTROL SITES ELSEWHERE IN THE CLEAR LAKE, CA WATERSHED.PROVIDE SPLIT SAMPLES OF DRIED LICHEN TO USGS FOR ANALYSIS OF MERCURY ISOTOPES.COLLABORATE ON INTERPRETIVE REPORTS INCLUDING DATA ON HG GEOCHEMISTRY AND HG ISOTOPES IN LICHEN SAMPLES FROM THE CLEAR LAKE AREA, AND SIMILAR AREAS OF INVESTIGATION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESAT THE END OF THE PERFORMANCE PERIOD, WILL BE PROVIDING THE USGS WITH THE RAW DATA, DIGITALLY IN SPREADSHEET FORM. THAT DATA WILL INCLUDE METADATA SUCH AS THE GPS COORDINATES OF EACH SAMPLING POINT, THE IDENTITY OF LICHEN TO THE GENUS AND IF POSSIBLE, THE SPECIES LEVEL, ALONG WITH ITS CORRESPONDING TOTAL HG CONCENTRATIONS, AND SPECIATED MERCURY CONCENTRATIONS. WILL PROVIDE THE QA QC RESULTS FROM THE ANALYSIS TO VALIDATE FINDINGS. THE SAMPLES WILL ALSO BE PREPARED FOR USGS TO ANALYZE STABLE MERCURY ISOTOPES. WILL ALSO HELP BY PROVIDING INTERPRETATIONS OF THE DATA. THESE DATA WILL BE INCORPORATED IN A MASTER S THESIS, PRESENTED AT INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES, AND ALSO BE PUT INTO A MANUSCRIPT TO BE SUBMITTED TO A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL. THE PI AND MASTER S STUDENTS WILL ALSO MAKE THEMSELVES AVAILABLE TO SPEAK TO THE PUBLIC AND THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES ABOUT THEIR FINDINGS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESTHE USGS, LOCAL TRIBES, COMMUNITY OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS, STATE AND FEDERAL POLICY MAKERS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIESNONE

PROJECT PERIOD  3 1 23 2 29 24PROJECT TITLE CFD MODELING OF FLOWS MEASURED AT THE WEST CRACK BREACH OF GREAT SALT LAKERECORD LOW WATER LEVELS AT THE GREAT SALT LAKE (GSL) HAS WARRANTED ACCURATE ESTIMATION OF WATER, NUTRIENT, AND SALT FLUXES THROUGH THE CAUSEWAY CHANNEL UNDER CURRENT CONDITIONS AND SCENARIOS OF VARYING LAKE LEVELS, NUTRIENT, AND SALINITY CONCENTRATIONS. THE PRIMARY POINT OF EXCHANGE IN THE BETWEEN THE NORTH AND SOUTH SIDES OF THE LAKE IS THE WEST CRACK BREACH, OPENED IN DECEMBER 2016. ACCURATELY ESTIMATING THE TOTAL FLOW AND SALINITY THROUGH THE BREACH IN THE CAUSEWAY IS IMPORTANT FOR PREDICTING THE LONG TERM HEALTH OF ITS ECOSYSTEM AND RELATED INDUSTRIES VIA THE EVOLUTION OF GSL S SALINITY PROFILE. THUS, THE OBJECTIVE OF THE CURRENT STUDY IS TO USE THE COMPUTATIONAL FLUID DYNAMICS MODEL OF THE FLOW THROUGH THE WEST CRACK BREACH TO HELP DECREASE THE UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH FIELD AND INDEX VELOCITY RATED DISCHARGE MEASUREMENTS THROUGH THE WEST CRACK BREACH IN THE RAILROAD CAUSEWAY ON GREAT SALT LAKE. ASSESS SPATIAL VARIATION OF THE MIXING IN THE WATER COLUMN SOUTH OF THE CAUSEWAY. THIS WILL BE AUGMENTED WITH ANALYSIS OF WATER VELOCITY VECTOR MEASUREMENTS WITH UP LOOKING ADCPS, AND WILL HELP IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF NUTRIENT AND SALT MASS MIXING DYNAMICS.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED A) CONDUCT CFD SIMULATIONS OF THE FLOW THROUGH THE WEST CRACK BREACH, WITH THE BOUNDARY CONDITIONS SAME AS THE OBSERVATIONS MADE BY USGS WHILE CONDUCTING THEIR MONTHLY MEASUREMENTS.B) COMPARE THE CFD RESULTS WITH THE DETAILED MEASUREMENTS AT THE BREACH CONDUCTED BY USGS USING MULTIPLE INSTRUMENTS, E.G MECHANICAL FLOWMETER, UP LOOKING ADCP.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  NONE  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  NONE

PROJECT PERIOD  3 1 23 2 29 24PROJECT TITLE ESTIMATING DISTRIBUTION CHANGES OF AT RISK RANID FROGS IN WESTERN NORTH AMERICANATIVE TRUE FROG POPULATIONS, INCLUDING LEOPARD FROGS, YELLOW LEGGED FROGS, AND RED LEGGED FROGS, HAVE DECLINED ACROSS THE WESTERN US. UNDERSTANDING THE EXTENT OF THIS PROBLEM IS CRITICAL TO ADDRESSING IT. HOWEVER, THESE FROGS CAN BE CHALLENGING TO DETECT, ADDING UNCERTAINTY TO THE DISTRIBUTIONAL UNDERSTANDING. IN THIS PROJECT, WILL USE ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) DETECTION TO ADD TO THE UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS AND THE OVERLAP OF THOSE SPECIES WITH THREATS TO THEIR PERSISTENCE IN THE FORM OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND PATHOGENS. THE PREVIOUS COLLABORATIVE WORK FOUND THAT THE ERADICATION OF BULLFROGS ALSO ERADICATED AMPHIBIAN PATHOGENS FROM THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT, DOCUMENTING HOW THESE ERADICATION PROGRAMS CAN BENEFIT NATIVE SPECIES BY REMOVING BOTH THE DIRECT AND THE INDIRECT EFFECTS OF BULLFROG OCCUPANCY. RESTORATION OF NATIVE SPECIES IS A LONG TERM PROCESS, HOWEVER, AND IN THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE STUDY OF THESE PROCESSES. THIS CONTINUED WORK WILL BE CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND HOW THESE PATHOGEN LOADS CHANGE AS NATIVE SPECIES RETURN TO THESE WETLANDS. THIS EXPERIMENT AND MONITORING IS THE FIRST OF ITS KIND AND HAS ALREADY HAD AN IMPACT IN THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY. THE WORK IS MADE POSSIBLE BY THE APPLICATION OF SIMULTANEOUS EDNA DETECTION OF PATHOGENS AND HOSTS. WILL ANALYZE EDNA SAMPLES COLLECTED FOR INVASIVE AND NATIVE SPECIES AND WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH USGS TO INTERPRET THE RESULTS AND THEIR MEANING FOR THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE AMPHIBIAN POPULATIONS. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE SPECIES, THE AGENCIES TASKED WITH PROTECTING AND RESTORING THESE SPECIES, AND THE PUBLIC THAT ENJOYS THEM.

PROJECT PERIOD: 4 10 2023-4 9 2026PROJECT TITLE: THE RUSTING OF ARCTIC RIVERS: USING ORANGE STREAMS TO IDENTIFY AND ASSESS DEGRADED WATER QUALITY CAUSED BY METAL MOBILIZATION FROM PERMAFROST SOILSSTREAMS AND RIVERS PROVIDE ESSENTIAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FOR RURAL COMMUNITIES IN ALASKAS ARCTIC REGION. IN ALASKAS ARCTIC INVENTORY AND  MONITORING NETWORK, RIVERS AND TRIBUTARIES PROVIDE THE SOLE DRINKING WATER SOURCE FOR MANY COMMUNITIES AND HABITAT FOR IMPORTANT POPULATIONS OF RESIDENT AND ANADROMOUS FISH SPECIES THAT ARE HARVESTED FOR SUBSISTENCE, INCLUDING CHUM SALMON, DOLLY VARDEN, AND ARCTIC GRAYLING. THESE ECOSYSTEMS ARE VULNERABLE TO THE EFFECTS OF RAPID CLIMATE CHANGE AND ALTERED DISTURBANCE REGIMES INCLUDING WIDESPREAD PERMAFROST THAW, THAW-INDUCED EROSION, AND WILDFIRES, PROCESSES THAT ALTER THE CONCENTRATION AND FLUX OF ORGANIC CARBON, NUTRIENTS, AND TRACE METALS IN ARCTIC RIVERS.RECENT OBSERVATIONS FROM ARCTIC ALASKA INDICATE THAT WATERS DRAINING PERMAFROST LANDSCAPES MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE TO IRON AND CARBON MOBILIZATION FOLLOWING THAW. THE GOAL OF THE 3-YEAR PROJECT IS TO QUANTIFY THE METALS RELEASED TO ARCTIC STREAMS AND RIVERS DUE TO PERMAFROST THAW. A GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCHER FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA DAVIS WILL WORK WITH FEDERAL RESEARCHERS AT FIELD SITES IN ALASKA. WATER AND STREAM SEDIMENT SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED IN THE LABORATORY FOR METAL CONTENT. THE DATA COLLECTED WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE INTEGRATED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT APPLICATIONS PORTAL. A MINIMUM OF ONE INTERPRETIVE REPORT WILL BE PREPARED ON THE IMPACTS OF METALS ON WATER QUALITY IN NORTHWEST ALASKA. AS PART OF THE EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, MEMBERS OF THE PROJECT WILL DISSEMINATE THE PROJECT RESEARCH FINDINGS THROUGH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND RURAL ARCTIC COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS EFFORT.

PROJECT PERIOD  3 22 23 3 21 24PROJECT TITLE PRODUCING CLIMATE GUIDANCE ON THE KEYSTONE PLANTS IDENTIFIED IN NWF S NATIVE PLANT FINDER FOR THE HABITAT RESTORATION COMMUNITY USE IN RESTORATION PLANNINGPURPOSE OF THE AWARD  IN AN ERA OF CLIMATE CHANGE, LAND AND WATER MANAGERS NEED TO ADDRESS CLIMATE VULNERABILITY OF SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES INTO THEIR WORK TO ENSURE A LASTING IMPACT IN THIS HIGHLY UNCERTAIN TIME. FUNCTIONAL FOOD WEBS ARE ESSENTIAL FOR THE SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION OF ECOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES, AND IN TERRESTRIAL SYSTEMS, FOOD WEBS ARE BUILT ON A FOUNDATION OF COEVOLVED INTERACTIONS BETWEEN PLANTS AND THEIR CONSUMERS. GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF LEPIDOPTERA TO FOOD WEBS AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION, EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE RESTORATION OF DEGRADED LANDSCAPES DEPENDS ON THE INCLUSION OF SUCH  KEYSTONE  PLANTS NATIVE KEYSTONE PLANTS FOR LEPIDOPTERA AND NATIVE BEES SHOULD BE INCORPORATED INTO A RAPIDLY CHANGING WORLD. THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION S DATABASE AND USER FRIENDLY NATIVE PLANT FINDER TOOL IS A SOURCE OF DATA ON LEPIDOPTERA AND NATIVE BEES BUT CURRENTLY LACKS THE INCORPORATION OF GUIDANCE ON THE CLIMATE RESILIENCE OF KEYSTONE PLANTS. THIS PROJECT WILL USE THE SCIENTIFIC CLIMATE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT PROCESS TO UNDERSTAND THE NATIVE PLANT FINDER S KEYSTONE PLANTS RESILIENCE AND WILL USE THESE DATA TO EXPLORE WITH THE RESTORATION LAND MANGERS THE BEST WAY TO PROVIDE SUCH GUIDANCE FOR THEM TO INCORPORATE INTO THE PLANT SELECTION RESTORATION PLANS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED 1) COLLABORATE WITH USGS ON A CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OF THE NATIVE PLANT FINDER S KEYSTONE PLANTS IN THE MID ATLANTIC REGION AS A PILOT FOR ADDITIONAL REGIONS  2) CONVENE HABITAT RESTORATION SPECIALISTS ABOUT THEIR DECISION MAKING PROCESS ON PLANT AND WILDLIFE SPECIES SELECTION AND USE OF CLIMATE LENS IN THIS WORK  AND 3) CREATE AND SHARE OUTREACH MATERIALS OF THE RESULTS FOR HABITAT RESTORATION SPECIALISTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES 1) DETERMINE CLIMATE VULNERABILITY OF KEYSTONE VASCULAR PLANTS (TREES SHRUBS HERBACEOUS) FROM NWF NATIVE PLANT FINDER DATA (CATERPILLAR HOST DATA AND NATIVE BEE DATA) IN THE MID ATLANTIC REGION OF THE EASTERN TEMPERATE FORESTS ECO REGION  2) IDENTIFY THE RESTORATION COMMUNITY S DECISION MAKING PROCESS ON PLANT SELECTION FOR INCORPORATION OF CLIMATE RESILIENT KEYSTONE PLANTS AND CLIMATE CHANGE. PRODUCTS INCLUDE  SCIENTIFIC PROFESSIONAL PUBLICATION OF VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT RESULTS  WRITTEN MATERIALS AND ORAL PRESENTATIONS TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO THE RESTORATION COMMUNITY ON KEYSTONE PLANTS AND CLIMATE CHANGE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT RESTORATION ECOLOGISTSSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD)  N A
