DEPTH) AND BY EXPERIMENTALLY DESICCATING SEDIMENTS TO ESTIMATE HOW DIFFERENT WATER LEVEL REGULATIONS WILL INFLUENCE FLUX RATES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE TWO MANUSCRIPTS  RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN WATER LEVEL ELEVATION AND SEDIMENT NUTRIENT FLUX IN LAKE KABETOGAMA (AUTHORS  BAILEY, LARSON, MAKI, CHRISTENSEN, WILDE, MCWHORTER) AND NUTRIENT STIMULATION OF NATURALLY OCCURRING PHYTOPLANKTON COMMUNITY GROWTH, COMPOSITION AND TOXICITY IN LAKE KABETOGAMA (AUTHORS  LARSON, BAILEY, MAKI, CHRISTENSEN, WILDE, MACWHORTER, LOFTIN).INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE VISTORS TO VOYAGEURS NATIONAL PARK AND OTHERS WHO RELY ON WATER FROM THE PARK LAKES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT PERIOD  02 13 23 02 12 27PROJECT TITLE UNDERSTANDING OVERWINTERING AND LONG TERM DEMOGRAPHY OF IMPERILED BUMBLE BEESTHE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND RESEARCH RELATED TO THE LONG TERM STUDY OF BUMBLE BEES AND THEIR OVERWINTERING HABITAT. BUMBLE BEES ARE IMPORTANT POLLINATORS OF AGRICULTURAL CROPS AND WILDLAND FLOWERS. DESPITE A GROWING INTEREST IN BUMBLE BEE CONSERVATION AND ECOLOGY, ONE OF THE KEY LIMITING FACTORS IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR POPULATIONS IS A LACK OF LONG TERM (I.E., MULTI YEAR) DATA ON COUNTS OF QUEENS, WORKERS, AND MALES AT A REPEATEDLY MEASURED SET OF SITES. ADDITIONALLY, OUR UNDERSTANDING OF WHERE BUMBLE BEES OVERWINTER AND THE IMPACTS OF VARIOUS HUMAN DISTURBANCES (E.G.S., DEVELOPMENT, PRESCRIBED BURNS), LIMITS THE ABILITY OF RESEARCHERS TO MAKE INFORMED RECOMMENDATIONS TO LAND MANAGERS OR FEDERAL AGENCIES. THE WORK PROPOSED HERE IS INTENDED TO ESTABLISH A NETWORK OF LONG TERM MONITORING SITES ACROSS THE RANGE OF THE FEDERALLY LISTED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) AND TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON THE OVERWINTERING LOCATIONS AND RESPONSE TO DISTURBANCE OF THE THREATENED WESTERN BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS).ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED OBJECTIVE 1  TWO YEARS OF FIELD STUDIES ON THE POTENTIAL OVERWINTERING LOCATIONS OF THE WESTERN BUMBLE BEE AT SITES OF KNOWN FORAGER OCCURRENCE IN COLORADOOBJECTIVE 2  ESTABLISHMENT OF A BUMBLE BEE REARING PROGRAM AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WITH SURROGATE SPECIES (E.G. THE BROWN BELTED BUMBLE BEE) TO AID IN EXPERIMENTS TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS OF PRESCRIBED BURNING AND OTHER DISTURBANCES ON BUMBLE BEE QUEENS DURING OVERWINTERING  YEARS 2 AND 3OBJECTIVE 3  THE COORDINATION OF A LONG TERM STUDY NETWORK FOR THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE ACROSS THE MIDWESTERN US  YEARS 1 AND 2 AND THEREAFTER WITH SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENTDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OBJECTIVE 1  PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLE DETAILING THE FINDINGS OF OUR FIELD EFFORTS  PRESENTATION(S) AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES  TRAINING OF A MASTER S STUDENTOBJECTIVE 2  PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLE DETAILING THE IMPACTS OF PRESCRIBED FIRE ON QUEEN OVERWINTERING SUCCESS  PRESENTATION(S) AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES  TRAINING OF A MASTER S STUDENT (SAME AS OBJ 1)OBJECTIVE 3  PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLE(S) ON RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE INTERANNUAL VARIATION  COORDINATION OF A NATIONAL RESEARCH NETWORK WITH WORKING GROUP MEETINGS  PRESENTATIONS OF RESULTS AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES  TRAINING OF A PHD STUDENTINTENDED BENEFICIARIES U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICEVARIOUS STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES (COLORADO, IOWA, MINNESOTA, ILLINOIS, WISCONSIN, WEST VIRGINIA, VIRGINIA, MARYLAND)

PROJECT PERIOD  2 17 23 2 16 24PROJECT TITLE  ASSESSING FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROCESSES AND PATHWAYS IN FLOODPLAIN FORESTS ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER USING DENDROCHRONOLOGYTHE MISSISSIPPI RIVER IS AN ICONIC BODY OF WATER THAT PROVIDES CRITICAL SERVICES LIKE DRINKING WATER. THE FORESTS SURROUNDING THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER ARE CRITICAL IN HELPING MAINTAIN CLEAN WATER BY REDUCING EROSION AND PROVIDING FILTERING. HOWEVER, THESE FLOODPLAIN FORESTS ARE VERY UNDERSTUDIED WHICH LEAVES A LOT OF OPEN QUESTIONS INCLUDING SOME REALLY BASIC QUESTIONS SUCH AS HOW OLD ARE THE FORESTS  AS WELL AS HOW DID THE FOREST ESTABLISH  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE TREE RINGS COLLECTED FROM HUNDREDS OF TREES ACROSS THREE STATES IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER (MINNESOTA, WISCONSIN, AND IOWA) TO UNDERSTAND THE AGE OF DIFFERENT TREE SPECIES IN THE FOREST. BY UNDERSTANDING THE AGE, CAN BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THESE FORESTS ESTABLISHED. ADDITIONALLY, CAN LOOK AT THE ANNUAL GROWTH RATE OF TREES AND SEE HOW THAT IS LINKED WITH CLIMATIC VARIABLES SUCH AS TEMPERATURE AND PRECIPITATION TO SEE IF TREES GREW MORE DURING WET YEARS COMPARED TO DRY YEARS  THE COMBINED DATA CAN BE USED TO HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT THAT INCREASES THE RESILIENCE OF FLOODPLAIN FORESTS TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND ALLOWS THESE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE CRITICAL SERVICES.DURING THE GRANT, WILL BE MEASURING HUNDREDS OF CORES TO BE ABLE TO GATHER INFORMATION ON THE AGE OF DIFFERENT TREE SPECIES FOUND IN THE FOREST. WILL ALSO BE MEASURING EACH ANNUAL RING. WILL USE DIFFERENT METHODS FOR STATISTICAL ANALYSIS THAT CAN HELP US UNDERSTAND HOW A TREE IS GROWING AND IF THERE HAVE BEEN DISTURBANCES WHICH ALLOW THE TREE TO GROW MORE. WILL SUMMARIZE INFORMATION INTO GRAPHS AND FIGURES AND SHARING THESE WITH COLLEAGUES WHO WORK ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER. WILL THEN WORK WITH THOSE COLLEAGUES TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND WHAT KINDS OF MANAGEMENT MAY BE MORE APPROPRIATE GIVEN SOME OF THE INFORMATION WE LEARN. THIS CAN PROVIDE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION SO MANAGERS CAN MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING MANAGING FORESTS. ADDITIONALLY, WITH THIS INFORMATION MANAGEMENT ACTION CAN HELP INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF THESE ECOSYSTEMS.THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED WIDELY BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER. ADDITIONALLY, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS ALONG OTHER RIVER BODIES BOTH LOCALLY AND NATIONAL CAN USE OUR METHODS AND OUR INFORMATION TO INFORM THEIR MANAGEMENT SINCE SPECIES CAN BE COMMON ACROSS LARGE AREAS. FINALLY, SINCE FLOODPLAIN FORESTS PROVIDE CRITICAL SERVICES THERE ARE DIRECT AND INDIRECT BENEFITS TO INDIVIDUALS WHO USE AND RECREATE ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER.

PROJECT PERIOD  9 1 23 8 31 25PROJECT TITLE SYNTHESIZING PATTERNS AND DRIVERS OF CHANGES IN LAKE ZOOPLANKTON COMMUNITY DYNAMICS WORLDWIDEGLOBAL CHANGE IS A THREAT TO BIODIVERSITY. SYNTHESES OF PLANT AND ANIMAL COMMUNITY DYNAMICS FROM LOCAL TO GLOBAL SPATIAL SCALES, DEVELOPED WITH COMPREHENSIVE, LONG TERM DATA, ARE NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND HOW BIODIVERSITY LOSS IS LIKELY TO IMPAIR HOW ECOSYSTEMS FUNCTION AND THE SERVICES THEY PROVIDE. LONG TERM DATA SERIES ARE AVAILABLE FOR MARINE AND TERRESTRIAL SYSTEMS, BUT LONG TERM DATA FOR INLAND WATERS REMAIN ALARMINGLY UNDER REPRESENTED AND UNDER FUNDED. TO BETTER ADDRESS THE RECOGNIZED BIODIVERSITY CRISIS IN FRESH WATERS, THE PROJECT TEAM HAS ASSEMBLED THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE DATASET ON FRESHWATER ZOOPLANKTON MICROSCOPIC ANIMALS ABSOLUTELY VITAL TO HEALTHY FRESHWATER AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS. USING THE DATASET AND TEAM SCIENCE APPROACH, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL MEET SEVERAL TIMES OVER TWO YEARS TO ANSWER FOUR LINKED, TIMELY QUESTIONS ABOUT FRESHWATER ZOOPLANKTON DYNAMICS  (1) HOW CAN ZOOPLANKTON COMMUNITIES BE USED AS INDICATORS OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE ACROSS THE WORLD  (2) HOW DO IMPORTANT CHARACTERISTICS OF ZOOPLANKTON, SUCH AS THEIR BODY SIZE, INFLUENCE CRITICAL LAKE FEATURES SUCH AS WATER QUALITY, ALGAL BLOOMS, AND FISH COMMUNITIES  (3) HOW DO ZOOPLANKTON COMMUNITY DYNAMICS AND THEIR INFLUENCE ON LAKE FEATURES RESPOND TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER STRESSORS, AND CAN EXPECT THE SAME RESPONSES IN DIFFERENT TYPES OF LAKES (SHALLOW VS DEEP, FOR EXAMPLE) IN THE SAME LOCATION, OR DIFFERENT RESPONSES IN THE SAME TYPES OF LAKES IN DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE WORLD  (4) DOES SAMPLING MANY DIFFERENT TYPES OF LAKES ONCE PER YEAR PROVIDE THE SAME INFORMATION ABOUT IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON ZOOPLANKTON COMPARED TO SAMPLING THE SAME LAKE OVER LONG PERIODS OF TIME  RESEARCH AND ANALYSES WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER REVIEWED JOURNALS AND REPORTS. WILL FACILITATE THE CONTINUED USE OF THE DATA SET AND ANALYSES BEYOND THE END OF THE PROJECT BY DEVELOPING A USER FRIENDLY DATASET AND INTERFACE WITH PARALLEL OPEN ACCESS OUTPUTS TO SERVE OTHER RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, AND RESOURCE MANAGERS. TOGETHER, WILL ADDRESS FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS RELATED TO FRESHWATER BIODIVERSITY CHANGE WORLDWIDE WITH THE GOAL TO BETTER MANAGE FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS IN THE MIDST OF GLOBAL CHANGE. BY CREATING A FLEXIBLE, REUSABLE DATA PRODUCT, WILL ENABLE SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS AROUND THE GLOBE TO CONTINUE EXPLORATION AND ANALYSIS OF FRESHWATER COMMUNITY DYNAMICS BEYOND THE SCOPE AND DURATION OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT PERIOD  2 8 23 2 7 27PROJECT TITLE STATISTICAL SUPPORT AND RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT FOR DOI MONITORING PROGRAMSPROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY  TWO EXISTING NATURAL RESOURCE MONITORING PROGRAMS WILL RECEIVE NEEDED STATISTICAL SUPPORT FROM THE SCOPE OF WORK OUTLINED IN THIS PROPOSAL, THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT) AND THE EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK. BOTH PROGRAMS RELY ON LONG TERM MONITORING TO MAKE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ABOUT SPECIES OF PARTICULAR INTEREST. TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT PROGRAMS CONTINUALLY SCRUTINIZE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE DATA COLLECTION PROCESSES (E.G., STUDY DESIGN) AND STATISTICAL MODELING USED WITH THE BEST AVAILABLE INFORMATION ABOUT THE SYSTEM. AS MORE DATA ARE COLLECTED AND IN TURN, MORE IS LEARNED ABOUT THE SYSTEM OF INTEREST, OPPORTUNITIES ARISE TO EXPAND STATISTICAL METHODOLOGY TO BETTER ALIGN WITH THE DATA BEING COLLECTED AND TO ADJUST THE STUDY DESIGN (E.G., RE ALLOCATE SAMPLING EFFORT). THE FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED FOR STATISTICAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW METHODS THAT BETTER HANDLE IDIOSYNCRASIES OF BAT ACOUSTIC DATA AND IMPROVE MODEL BASED ESTIMATES OF HOW BAT POPULATIONS ARE CHANGING OVER TIME, AND TO ASSESS THE SYNERGY BETWEEN THE STUDY DESIGN AND MONITORING OBJECTIVES OF THE EVERGLADES PROGRAM.THE WORK FROM THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A MUCH NEEDED GUIDE FOR NABAT PARTNER SCIENTISTS THAT ALIGNS COMMON RESEARCH QUESTIONS RELATED TO STATUS AND TRENDS FOR SPECIES OF PARTICULAR INTEREST WITH THE MOST APPROPRIATE METHODOLOGY TO DATE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR NABAT PARTNERS THOUGH TECHNICAL REPORTS, AND STATISTICAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT FOR BAT ACOUSTIC DATA. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF STATISTICAL RAND D WITHIN THE NABAT THRUST IS TO OBTAIN THE MOST ECOLOGICAL INFORMATION OUT OF ACOUSTIC BAT SURVEYS AS POSSIBLE, WHICH IN TURN WILL STRENGTHEN INFERENCES AND AID IN CONSERVATION RELATED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. A POST DOCTORAL RESEARCH FELLOW IS CURRENTLY WORKING UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF DR. KATHARINE BANNER (ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF STATISTICS, MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY) AND DR. KATHRYN IRVINE (RESEARCH STATISTICIAN, NORTHERN ROCKY MOUNTAIN SCIENCE STATION, NOROCK) TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING PROJECT DELIVERABLES FOR NABAT (INTENDED BENEFICIARY).NABAT  HOW TO  STATUS AND TRENDS PAPER  ANTICIPATED PUBLICATION DURING YEAR (1 PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPT) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO NABAT  ALL FINAL STATISTICAL REPORTS TO COLLABORATORS WITH DEADLINE 6 MONTHS AFTER DATA RECEIVED BY MSU FOR ALL SUB TASKS ADVANCEMENT OF STATISTICAL METHODS FOR BAT ACOUSTIC DATA  ANTICIPATED PUBLICATION YEAR 2 (1 PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPT) THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE PROGRAM IN THE EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK WITH SYNTHESIZING CURRENT MONITORING EFFORTS AND USING THAT INFORMATION TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE WORKPLAN FOR STATISTICAL ASSESSMENT OF MONITORING INDICATORS OF INTEREST WITHIN THE PARK. A SKILLED GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANT WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH DR. S IRVINE AND BANNER TO COMPLETE WORK FOR THE EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK (INTENDED BENEFICIARY)MAY 2024   FINAL PROJECT REPORT INCLUDING,R CODE AND OR OTHER       CODE ASSOCIATED WITH ANALYSES AND SIMULATION INVESTIGATIONS WITH PROPER       META DATA AND USGS OPEN DATA REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC ACCESS. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE IMPORTANCE OF GROUNDWATER TO MAINTAINING COOL STREAM TEMPERATURES FOR SALMON IN THE BEAVER CREEK BASIN, KENAI PENINSULA, ALASKA USING A GROUNDWATER AND STREAM TEMPERATURE MODEL. BEAVER CREEK WAS SELECTED FOR THIS STUDY FOR ITS 1) HIGH CONSERVATION PRIORITY STATUS HIGH SENSITIVITY TO RISING AIR TEMPERATURES, 3) PROXIMITY TO DEVELOPMENT, 4) HIGH VALUE FOR BOTH HUMANS AND SALMON, 5) POTENTIAL TO SERVE AS A MODEL SYSTEM FOR BROADER APPLICATION IN SUSTAINABLE GROUNDWATER MANAGEMENT, AND 6) A DECADE OF HISTORICAL DATA ON DISCHARGE, STREAM TEMPERATURES, AND GROUNDWATER LEVELS. NEW CONTINUOUS DATA TO BE COLLECTED FOR THE STUDY INCLUDES STREAM DISCHARGE, GROUNDWATER ELEVATIONS AND TEMPERATURES IN 3 5 SHALLOW WELLS AND POTENTIALLY 1 DEEP WELL, AND STREAM TEMPERATURE AT 12 15 LOCATIONS.STREAM DISCHARGE WILL BE SIMULATED USING A GROUNDWATER FLOW MODEL COUPLED TO A SOIL WATER BALANCE MODEL DRIVEN BY CLIMATE INPUTS. STREAM BASE FLOWS FROM THE GROUNDWATER MODEL WILL IN TURN BE FED TO A STREAM TEMPERATURE MODEL TO SIMULATE DAILY STREAM TEMPERATURES. THE MODELS WILL BE CALIBRATED TO HISTORIC AND CURRENT BASEFLOW, GROUNDWATER ELEVATIONS, AND STREAM TEMPERATURE DATA. MODEL SCENARIOS WILL LOOK AT HOW CHANGES IN DEVELOPMENT (LAND USE AND PUMPING) AND CLIMATE (AIR TEMPERATURE AND PRECIPITATION) AFFECT STREAM BASE FLOW AND TEMPERATURE, AND THE IMPLICATIONS OF ANY CHANGES RELATIVE TO SALMON THERMAL THRESHOLDS.THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE EMPIRICAL DATA AND MODELING RESULTS FOR BALANCING ECOLOGICAL AND DEVELOPMENT GOALS OF THE KENAI BOROUGH. THE MODEL WILL HELP IDENTIFY IF CURRENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN BEAVER CREEK ARE SERVING THE BOROUGH S GOALS BY SIMULATING VARIOUSGROUNDWATER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND ANALYZING THE POTENTIAL IMPACT ON ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND WATER SUPPLY FOR STAKEHOLDERS SUCH AS THE CITY OF KENAI. THE KENAI WATERSHED FORUM (KWF) WILL FACILITATE DATA COLLECTION AND HELP ENSURE THAT THE APPROACH AND FINDINGS ARE ALIGNED WITH THE COMMUNITY S NEEDS THROUGH THEIR INTERACTIONS AND RELATIONSHIPS WITH VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS. THE APPROACH AND FINDINGS WILL BE TRANSFERRABLE TO OTHER NEARBY REGIONS WITH GROUNDWATER DOMINATED BASINS WITH SALMON HABITAT, SUCH AS THE MAT SU BOROUGH.

PROJECT PERIOD  2 1 23 1 31 25PROJECT TITLE  WATER, WATER EVERYWHERE  ADAPTING WATER CONTROL OPERATIONS AND FLOODPLAIN CONSERVATION PLANNING TO GLOBAL CHANGENC SEA GRANT AND NCSU BAE WILL PARTICIPATE IN A MULTIDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATIVE PROJECT LED BY THE USGS WETLAND AND AQUATIC RESEARCH CENTER AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) TO DEVELOP QUANTITATIVE, SCENARIO BASED MODELING FOR THE ROANOKE RIVER BASIN USING PUBLICLY AVAILABLE MODELS THAT ARE COMMONLY SPECIFIED FOR RESERVOIRS. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THE MODELING EFFORT WILL BE TO ASSESS ONGOING CLIMATE CHANGE, AS WELL AS KEY IMPACTS, UNCERTAINTIES, AND RISK TO STAKEHOLDER VALUES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO  (1) IDENTIFY CHANGES IN THE TIMING, MAGNITUDE, DURATION, AND FREQUENCY OF DECISION RELEVANT INFLOWS INTO KERR RESERVOIR ACROSS THE PERIOD OF RECORD  (2) CHARACTERIZE THE MODELED INFLOWS INTO KERR RESERVOIR BASED ON CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS FROM THE USGS PRECIPITATION RUNOFF MODELING SYSTEM (PRMS) FOR 1952 2099  (3) ASSESS PAST AND FUTURE FLOODPLAIN HYDROLOGY AND FLOODPLAIN INUNDATION, INCORPORATING PRMS RESULTS INTO CORPS  SUITE OF MODELS (HEC RESERVOIR SIMULATION MODEL, HEC RAS)  (4) EXAMINE IMPLICATIONS FOR DOWNSTREAM FLOODPLAIN VEGETATION AND FISHERIES USING THE CORPS  SPATIAL ECOSYSTEM PROCESS MODEL AND (5) CHARACTERIZE RISK OF DAM MANAGEMENT AND DOWNSTREAM RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITH PROJECTIONS OF LIKELY RECURRENCE OF HIGH FLOW EVENTS WITHIN AND ACROSS YEARS. NC SEA GRANT AND NCSU BAE WILL RUN THE HYDRODYNAMIC MODELS AND ASSESS HYDROLOGY IMPACTS IN THE BASIN.TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES, THE NCSU TEAM WILL SERVE ON THE ROANOKE RIVER WORKING GROUP TEAM LED BY USGS WETLAND AND AQUATIC RESEARCH CENTER. NCSU WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ADVICE AND MODELING TO THE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION. WILL OBTAIN ALL EXISTING FLOW RECORDS AND MODELS FOR KERR RESERVOIR AND THE ROANOKE RIVER FROM TNC AND THE US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS. THESE MODELS AND FLOW RECORDS WILL BE REVIEWED AND THE MOST APPROPRIATE MODEL COMBINATION OF MODELS WILL BE SELECTED FOR THE STUDY ANALYSIS. NCSU WILL DEVELOP INUNDATION MAPS TO EVALUATE IMPACTS OF VARIOUS FLOW REGIMES ON RIPARIAN AREAS OF THE ROANOKE RIVER. THE MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO A) COMPARE DOWNSTREAM FLOODING IMPACTS FOR VARIOUS KERR RESERVOIR RELEASE PROTOCOLS (QRR, EXISTING), B) PROJECT FUTURE FLOODING IMPACTS CONSIDERING CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS UNDER VARIOUS DAM RELEASE PROTOCOLS, C) QUANTIFY EXCEEDANCES OF HYDRAULIC THRESHOLDS THAT RESULT IN NEGATIVE ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCES TO FISHERIES AND FORESTED FLOODPLAINS FOR BOTH PAST AND FUTURE SCENARIOS, AND D) QUANTIFY FLOODING OF ALL AGRICULTURE AND FORESTED AREAS ALONG THE STUDY REACH CONSIDERING SEASON, DEPTH AND DURATION.NCSU WILL PREPARE SHORT PRESENTATIONS TO COMMUNICATE AND VISUALIZE RESULTS OF THE MODELING AND FLOOD INUNDATION RESULTS TO THE WORKING GROUP DURING REGULAR GROUP MEETINGS. WILL ALSO PREPARE A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING THE MODELING METHODS AND RESULTS AND WILL PRESENT THESE RESULTS AT THE NC WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH INSTITUTE S ANNUAL CONFERENCE. A MANUSCRIPT OUTLINING THE FLOODPLAIN INUNDATION MODELING AND THE ASSOCIATED IMPLICATIONS TO ROANOKE RIVER ECOLOGY WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR JOURNAL SUBMISSION. ALL HEC RAS MODELING RESULTS AND INUNDATION MAPS WILL BE RELEASED TO USGS AND OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS AS REQUESTED. THIS EFFORT WILL PROVIDE THE ROANOKE RIVER STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS AND LANDOWNERS ALONG THE RIVER WITH MODELING RESULTS THAT WILL HELP THEM TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND QUANTIFY THE BENEFITS AND IMPACTS OF VARIOUS RESERVOIR MANAGEMENT AND FLOW RELEASE SCENARIOS ON THE DOWNSTREAM ROANOKE RIVER INCLUDING IMPACTS TO BOTH PRIVATE PROPERTY AND TO RIPARIAN ECOLOGY. THESE RESULTS WILL AID THE US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS WITH FUTURE DECISIONS ABOUT RESERVOIR RELEASE MANAGEMENT PLANS. NO SUB RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE CURRENTLY PLANNED FOR THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 30 23 1 29 24PROJECT TITLE EVALUATING NATIVE FISH PRESENCE, PREY RESOURCES, AND HABITAT AT RESTORATION SITES TO INFORM BENEFICIAL REUSE OF DREDGED MATERIALINTERCONNECTED ESTUARINE TIDAL WETLANDS, MUDFLATS, AND SHALLOW SUBTIDAL AREAS PROVIDE VITAL NURSERY HABITAT (COLOMBANO ET AL. 2020) AND PREY RESOURCES (DAVIS ET AL. 2018A, WOO ET AL. 2019, DE LA CRUZ ET AL. 2017, 2020) TO HELP SUSTAIN NATIVE FISHES. TIDAL WETLANDS HAVE LARGELY BEEN LOST IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY ESTUARY DUE TO LAND RECLAMATION FOR FARMING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT (CLOERN AND JASSBY 2012). TO ADDRESS THESE LOSSES, EXPANSIVE TIDAL WETLAND RESTORATION IS ONGOING FOR THE REGION OVER THE COMING DECADES. PREVIOUS WORK HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT RESTORING COMPLEX GEOMORPHOLOGY TO TIDAL WETLANDS CAN INCREASE HABITAT ACCESSIBILITY FOR NATIVE FISHES (SIMENSTAD AND CORDELL 2000, ELLINGS ET AL. 2016), AND MAY ALSO ENHANCE FOOD WEBS LEADING TO INCREASED PREY AVAILABILITY (DAVIS ET AL. 2018B, WOO ET AL. 2018) AND FOOD EXPORTS THAT CAN BE INCORPORATED INTO THE PELAGIC FOOD WEB TO SUPPORT ZOOPLANKTON AND PELAGIC FISHES SUCH AS LONGFIN SMELT (LFS, SPIRINCHUS THALEICHTHYS  GRIMALDO ET AL. 2009). BENEFICIAL REUSE OF DREDGE MATERIAL HAS BEEN USED IN SOME PROJECTS TO INCREASE CHANNEL COMPLEXITY TO IMPROVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES FOR FISH AND OTHER SPECIES (USACE 1998, THORNE ET AL. 2019, FOLEY ET AL. 2020, DUSTERHOFF ET AL. 2021). FOR EXAMPLE, LEWIS ET AL. (2019) DOCUMENTED ADULT AND JUVENILE LFS WITHIN THE SHALLOW WETLANDS AND TRIBUTARIES OF SAN PABLO BAY, INCLUDING THE PETALUMA RIVER SYSTEM, ESPECIALLY IN YEARS OF HIGH FRESHWATER FLOWS. FOR A VARIETY OF DECLINING NATIVE FISH SPECIES, SUCH AS LFS, A MORE COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG MARSH GEOMORPHIC CHARACTERISTICS, HABITAT AVAILABILITY, AND INVERTEBRATE PREY RESOURCES, IS NEEDED TO INFORM MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS (COWIN AND BONHAM 2013, LEWIS ET AL. 2019, THORNE ET AL. 2019, CA DWR 2020, SLOANE ET AL. 2021).HERE, WILL CONDUCT AN INTERDISCIPLINARY PROJECT THAT COMBINES A CLASSIC SURVEY METHOD (OTTER TRAWL SURVEYS) AND AN EMERGING TECHNOLOGY (EDNA ANALYSIS) TO EXPLORE PATTERNS IN THE DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT USE BY FISHES IN RESTORED WETLANDS THROUGHOUT SAN PABLO BAY, MANY OF WHICH UTILIZED DREDGED MATERIAL. RESULTS WILL BE COMBINED WITH ON GOING ASSESSMENTS OF BENTHIC AND PELAGIC FOOD WEBS, GEOMORPHOLOGICAL FEATURES, AND SIMULTANEOUSLY COLLECTED WATER QUALITY DATA IN ORDER TO EXPLORE TAXON SPECIFIC PATTERNS AS WELL AS COMMUNITY LEVEL PATTERNS IN HABITAT USE. THE REPORTS AND MANUSCRIPTS RESULTING FROM THIS WORK WILL INFORM THE MANAGEMENT OF LONGFIN SMELT, WHICH IS CURRENTLY MANAGED BY CDFW (LISTED UNDER CESA) AND WILL SOON BE MANAGED BY USFWS (AFTER LISTING UNDER ESA IN 2023), AND OTHER IMPORTANT NATIVE WETLAND FISHES BY QUANTIFYING RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN AQUATIC COMMUNITIES AND VARIOUS WETLAND HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING GEOMORPHOLOGY, RESTORATION HISTORY, AND TROPHIC RESOURCES. FURTHERMORE, RESULTS WILL AID IN THE PERMITTING AND DESIGN OF ONGOING AND PLANNED RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGHOUT THE SAN FRANCISCO ESTUARY.

PROJECT PERIOD  2 3 23 2 2 25PROJECT TITLE CHARACTERIZING BURN SEVERITY AND POTENTIAL VEGETATION RECOVERY AT HIGH SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTIONSWILDFIRES IN WESTERN U.S. DRY FORESTS ARE INCREASINGLY BURNING LARGE AREAS AT HIGH SEVERITY. IN LARGE CONTIGUOUS SEVERELY BURNED PATCHES, NEAR COMPLETE OVERSTORY TREE MORTALITY CHALLENGES NATURAL FOREST REGENERATION PROCESSES, WHICH REQUIRE NEARBY SURVIVING TREES TO SERVE AS SEED SOURCES. EVALUATING BURN SEVERITY PATTERNS   AND THUS REGENERATION POTENTIAL   ACROSS LARGE WILDFIRES GENERALLY RELIES ON SATELLITE IMAGERY DUE TO ITS READY AVAILABILITY AND SPATIALLY CONTINUOUS COVERAGE. HOWEVER, THE IMAGERY DATASETS TRADITIONALLY USED HAVE RELATIVELY COARSE PIXELS (E.G.,   30 M FOR LANDSAT), WHICH CAN CONTAIN MULTIPLE TREES AND MAY MISS SMALL PATCHES OF SURVIVING TREES ( FIRE REFUGIA ) THAT HAVE CRITICAL VALUE AS SEED SOURCES FOR REGENERATION. RELATEDLY, TREES THAT INITIALLY SURVIVE THE FIRE   BUT THAT SUSTAINED INJURIES   MAY ULTIMATELY DIE IN THE FOLLOWING YEARS, WITH IMPLICATIONS FOR THEIR VALUE AS SEED SOURCES.WILL USE TRADITIONAL SATELLITE IMAGERY DATA SOURCES SUCH AS LANDSAT ALONG WITH NEWER AND ALTERNATIVE HIGHER RESOLUTION IMAGERY SOURCES, SUCH AS SENTINEL 2, NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL IMAGERY PROGRAM (NAIP) ORTHOMOSAICS, AND DRONE IMAGERY, TO UNDERSTAND THE PREVALENCE OF SMALL FIRE REFUGIA AND DELAYED MORTALITY. AIM TO UNDERSTAND HOW NEWER, FINER SCALE IMAGING TECHNOLOGIES IMPROVE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY SMALL FIRE REFUGIA AND TO UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL FOR POST FIRE RECOVERY ACROSS BURNED LANDSCAPES. THE WORK, WHICH FOCUSES ON RECENT LARGE WILDFIRES IN THE WESTERN US, TAKES ADVANTAGE OF EXISTING GROUND REFERENCE PLOT DATA CAPTURING POST FIRE CANOPY CONDITIONS. THE WORK WILL (A) ADDRESS ECOLOGICAL QUESTIONS ABOUT FIRE MORTALITY AND SEED SOURCE AVAILABILITY, (B) HELP REFINE BEST PRACTICES IN USE OF LANDSAT VS. ALTERNATIVE IMAGERY DATA SOURCES FOR FIRE SEVERITY CHARACTERIZATION, AND (C) IMPROVE ABILITY TO PRIORITIZE POST FIRE RECOVERY EFFORTS SUCH AS TREE PLANTING. THE PROJECT WILL DELIVER SCIENTIFIC DATA AND ANALYSES THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLES.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE FIRE ECOLOGY RESEARCHERS, FOREST MANAGERS DEVELOPING POST FIRE RECOVERY PLANS, AND COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON HEALTHY FORESTS FOR THEIR WELLBEING.

PROJECT PERIOD  2 1 23 1 31 24PROJECT TITLE DEEP LEARNING FOR AUTOMATED DETECTION AND CLASSIFICATION OF WATERFOWL, SEABIRDS, AND OTHER WILDLIFE FROM DIGITAL AERIAL IMAGERYAWARD PURPOSE. THIS PROJECT FUND CONTINUES ACTIVE COLLABORATION BETWEEN USGS AND THE PI ON DEVELOPING DEEP LEARNING ALGORITHMS THAT AUTOMATE THE PROCESS OF DETECTING AND CLASSIFYING WATERFOWL, SEABIRDS, AND OTHER MARINE WILDLIFE SPECIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED.1. PROPOSE SOUND PREPROCESSING METHODS THAT MAINTAIN THE DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS OF BIRD SPECIES, MARINE MAMMALS, MANMADE OBJECTS, AND POSSIBLY SEA TURTLES.2. DEVELOP AN UNSUPERVISED LEARNING METHOD TO SELECT IMAGES TO ANNOTATE IN TERMS OF SAMPLING UNCOMMON SPECIES, SUCH AS STORM PETRELS, SHEARWATER, OR OTHER HIGH PRIORITY GROUPS.3. DEVELOP A SEMI SUPERVISED LEARNING CLASSIFIER UTILIZING BOTH UNLABELED AND LABELED DATA.4. DEVELOP A HIERARCHICAL CLASSIFIER THAT CAN DELIVER CONFIDENT PREDICTIONS AT AN APPROPRIATE TAXONOMY LEVEL. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES. USGS WILL PROVIDE HUMAN ANNOTATED DIGITAL AERIAL IMAGERY FOR ALL SPECIES OF INTEREST. UM WILL PROVIDE MACHINE LEARNED AND PREDICTED ANNOTATIONS OF AERIAL IMAGES. THE PROJECT HAS TWO MILESTONES DETAILED BELOW.BY 06 30 2023 1. BRIEF SUMMARY OF PROPOSED PREPROCESSING AS WELL AS PYTHON CODE TO IMPLEMENT THE APPROACH. PROVIDE MODEL WEIGHTS FOR BEST TRAINED PERFORMING MODEL.2. A REPORT, OR MANUSCRIPT FOR PEER REVIEW, THAT SUMMARIZES THE APPROACH AND REASONING BEHIND METHODS. PYTHON CODE WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE THROUGH A PRIVATE GITHUB REPOSITORY, AND A SAMPLING OF DATA WILL BE PRIORITIZED.BY 12 31 2023 1. BRIEF SUMMARY AND PRESENTATION ON UPDATED CLASSIFICATION PERFORMANCE WITH HIERARCHY.2. DELIVER MODEL WEIGHTS BIASES OF ALL TRAINED MODELS AS A DIRECTORY OF FILES ALONG WITH ALL CODE ORGANIZED IN A REPOSITORY.3. DRAFT A MANUSCRIPT FOR SUBMISSION TO A SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL.THE IMAGERY AND ANNOTATION DATABASE AND RESULTS FROM THESE MACHINE LEARNING MODELS WILL HELP BOEM, USFWS, AND USGS IDENTIFY THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF AVIAN AND MARINE WILDLIFE SPECIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES.   THE BUREAU OF OCEAN ENERGY MANAGEMENT (BOEM) ENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES PROGRAM   THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) DIVISION OF MIGRATORY BIRD MANAGEMENT (DMBM) BRANCH OF MIGRATORY BIRD SURVEYS  THE USGS UPPER MIDWEST ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES CENTER (UMESC).

PROJECT PERIOD  2 6 23 2 5 26PROJECT TITLE UNDERSTANDING ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES FOR RESTORING RARE PLANT SPECIES TO THEIR NATIVE HABITATS UNDER INCREASING LAND USE AND CHANGING REGIONAL CLIMATEWHITE MARGINED BEARDTONGUE (PENSTEMON ALBOMARGINATUS) IS A RARE EDAPHIC, ENDEMIC PLANT THREATENED BY DEVELOPMENT IN CLARK COUNTY, NEVADA. DUE TO DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND THE VAGARIES OF PLANT EMERGENCE AND VIABLE SEED SET IN THE DESERT, ALTERNATIVE PLANT PROPAGATION METHODS ARE NEEDED TO OBTAIN PLANT MATERIAL FOR CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS. PROPAGATION OF PLANTS VIA VEGETATIVE CUTTINGS IS A POSSIBLE ALTERNATIVE THAT CAN PROVIDE MORE RELIABLE PLANT MATERIAL FOR THESE EFFORTS. SPECIES SPECIFIC CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION GUIDELINES ARE NEEDED FOR LAND MANAGERS TO PROTECT BEARDTONGUE POPULATIONS AND ENSURE THEIR PERSISTENCE. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE THE USE OF VEGETATIVE CUTTINGS AS A VIABLE METHOD OF PROPAGATION FOR THE SPECIES FOR USE IN CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE  1) STUDY NURSERY GROWING CONDITIONS (SOIL TYPE, POT SIZE) FOR CUTTINGS AND HOW THEY AFFECT PLANT TRAITS (PLANT SIZE, ROOT TO SHOOT RATIO) TO OPTIMIZE SUITABILITY FOR REINTRODUCTION SURVIVAL AND 2) DETERMINE WHICH ECOLOGICAL FACTORS (E.G. NURSE PLANT ASSOCIATION, TIMING OF OUT PLANTING) ARE IMPORTANT FOR PLANT SURVIVORSHIP, GROWTH, AND REPRODUCTION OF OUT PLANTINGS. TO TEST OBJECTIVE 1, PLANTS FROM SEVERAL POPULATIONS WILL BE PROPAGATED IN A GREENHOUSE TO TEST METHODS SUCH AS 1) SOIL MEDIUM WHICH AFFECTS DRAINAGE AND NUTRIENT STATUS (E.G., 80  VS 50  SAND), AND 2) POT TYPE (E.G., DEEP, NARROW VS WIDE, SHALLOW POTS) TO PROMOTE HEALTHY ROOT GROWTH. TO TEST OBJECTIVE 2, WILL USE A FACTORIAL EXPERIMENT TO TEST EFFECTS OF FIELD VARIABLES SUCH AS NURSE PLANT EFFECTS (PLANTINGS IN CANOPIES VS INTERSPACES BETWEEN EXISTING PERENNIAL PLANTS) AND SEASON OF OUT PLANTING (FALL VS. SPRING) ON OUTPLANTING SUCCESS. ALSO, WILL RECORD HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS ASSOCIATED WITH EACH PLANTING, SUCH AS SLOPE, ASPECT, SOIL TYPE AND TEXTURE. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT DELIVERED TO CLARK COUNTY AND CONTRIBUTE TO CLARK COUNTY S ANNUAL PROJECT REVIEW PRESENTATIONS. QUALITY CHECKED DATA FOR ALL GREENHOUSE AND FIELD DATA WILL ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLE TO CLARK COUNTY. ULTIMATELY, AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION AND ACCOMPANYING FACT SHEET WILL BE PRODUCED TO DISSEMINATE FINDINGS TO SCIENTISTS AND PRACTITIONERS. PROJECT RESULTS WILL INFORM LAND MANAGERS INTERESTED IN RELOCATING PLANTS BACK INTO POPULATIONS TO INCREASE NUMBERS AND GENETIC DIVERSITY OR CREATE NEW POPULATIONS IN NEW, SUITABLE HABITAT. THIS WILL HELP LAND MANAGERS MITIGATE HABITAT AND POPULATION LOSS FROM DEVELOPMENT AND PROMOTE SPECIES PERSISTENCE.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 17 23 1 16 24PROJECT TITLE INTEGRATING MULTIPLE DATA SOURCES TO DEVELOP CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES FOR INLAND FISH AND RECREATIONAL FISHINGPLAIN LANGUAGE PUBLIC SUMMARY MANY AGENCIES COMPILE DATA FROM RECREATIONAL ANGLERS BECAUSE RECREATIONAL FISHING HAS GREAT SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE IN THE U.S. IN 2020 ALONE, MORE THAN 42 MILLION PEOPLE PARTICIPATED IN FRESHWATER FISHING. HOWEVER, CLIMATE CHANGE MAY AFFECT THE NUMBERS, SIZES, AND SPECIES OF FISH AVAILABLE TO ANGLERS. AGENCIES TASKED WITH MANAGING FISHERIES OFTEN KEEP RECORDS OF ANGLER CATCH AND HARVEST TO BETTER MANAGE FISHERIES. EXISTING TOOLS CAN BE USED TO DETERMINE HOW FISH SPECIES IMPORTANT TO ANGLERS MAY CHANGE IN GROWTH OR ABUNDANCE. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL USE EXISTING DATABASES IN ANGLER COUPLED WITH ONGOING STUDIES TO RELATE REGIONWIDE TRENDS IN ANGLER EFFORT, CATCH, AND HARVEST TO ENVIRONMENTAL METRICS. THIS WORK CAN HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR PREDICTED FISH AND ANGLER BEHAVIOR IN A CHANGING CLIMATE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDIMPLEMENT AND MAINTAIN EXISTING DATABASES ON ANGLER CATCH AND HARVEST, AND CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS ON FISH RELEVANT TO ANGLER DATA AND LITERATURE FOCUSED ON CLIMATE EFFECT ON FISHES.TEST HYPOTHESES BASED ON EXISTING DATA AND TOOLS RELATED TO ANGLER CATCH AND HARVEST, AND EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON DATA FROM EXISTING TOOLS RELATED TO ANGLER CATCH AND HARVEST, EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON FISH, AND ONGOING CASC FUNDED PROJECTS TO BETTER INTEGRATE HOW CLIMATE CHANGE MAY AFFECT NOT ONLY THE FISH RESPONSE (E.G., GROWTH, RECRUITMENT), BUT ANGLER RESPONSES TO THOSE POTENTIAL CHANGESDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES PROPOSE A PERPETUITY PROTOCOL FOR BOTH ALL DATABASES USED BY 1) MAINTAINING PUBLIC ACCESSIBILITY TO A PORTION OF EACH DATABASE TO MAXIMIZE TRANSPARENCY, ALONG WITH ARCHIVING COMPLETE PROVIDED DATASETS FOR TRACEABILITY OF ALL DATA, 2) IDENTIFY A PRACTICABLE SCHEDULE TO ENSURE CONSISTENT AND STREAMLINED DATABASE UPDATES, AND 3) INGRAIN ADAPTABILITY IN BOTH THE CREELCAT AND FICLI DATABASE STRUCTURE TO ENSURE FLEXIBILITY AS FUTURE NEEDS CHANGE.PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO TEST THE HYPOTHESES MENTIONED ABOVE. ANTICIPATE SEVERAL MANUSCRIPTS FROM THESE EFFORTS, PARTICULARLY AS WILL OBTAIN MORE DATA TO INCLUDE IN FICLI AND CREELCAT, ONE INITIAL PUBLICATION WILL LINK EXISTING GROWTH DATA FROM COOPERATORS WITH CREELCAT CATCH STATISTICS TO DETERMINE HOW FISH GROWTH AND ANGLER PREFERENCES CHANGE OVER A LATITUDINAL GRADIENT.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)MAINTAINING THESE DATABASES FROM THE 43 STATES THAT CONTRIBUTED TO CREELCAT HAVE UP TO DATE RECORDS OF ANGLER CATCH AND HARVEST, WHICH WILL BENEFIT THEIR STATE LEVEL MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISHES, BUT ALSO BENEFIT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL AGENCIES (E.G., US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE) IN THEIR MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISHES. A PRIMARY BENEFICIARY OF THIS PROJECT IS ANY RESEARCHER, MANAGER, OR POLICY MAKER THAT NEEDS TO UNDERSTAND ANGLER HARVEST AND OR HOW FISH MAY BE AFFECTED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. SINCE THESE ARE BOTH PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATABASES, ANY STAKEHOLDER INTERESTED IN ANGER CATCH AND CLIMATE CHANGE CAN BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARDNONE

PROJECT PERIOD:  4 100 23-4 9 24PROJECT TITLE: GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY FISH AND WILDLIFE ADAPTATION FELLOWSHIP PROGRAMRESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF MULTIPLE DISCIPLINES HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF PROBLEMS AND SOLUTIONS IN CONSERVATION AND SUSTAINABILITY. HOWEVER, BIODIVERSITY CHALLENGES IN THE FORMS OF HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION, HUMANWILDLIFE CONFLICT, INFECTIOUS DISEASES, ETC., STILL PRESENT ONGOING RESEARCH NEEDS. IN OTHER INSTANCES, RAPID URBANIZATION AND INCREASING NATURAL DISASTERS EXACERBATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE HAVE PRODUCED NOVEL ECOLOGICAL CHALLENGES. THESE CHALLENGES CALL FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS WITH EXPANSIVE KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE IN NATURAL SCIENCE, SOCIAL SCIENCE, AND PUBLIC POLICY. THE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AND POLICY (ESP) AT GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY IS UNIQUELY POISED TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH THE TRANSDISCIPLINARY TRAINING ESSENTIAL FOR ADDRESSING SUCH CHALLENGES. THE AWARDED PROJECT AIMS TO RECRUIT GMU-ESP UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO THE FISH AND WILDLIFE ADAPTATION FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM TO WORK WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS NATIONAL AND REGIONAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (NRCASC). THESE FELLOWS LEARN TO DEVELOP POLICY-INFORMING PRODUCTS TO MANAGE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON FISH AND OR WILDLIFE RESOURCES. FURTHERMORE, THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES FELLOWS WITH THE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO INTERACT WITH AND LEARN FROM PROFESSIONAL COMMUNITIES OUTSIDE OF ACADEMIA.II. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDTHE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INTENSIVE FELLOWSHIPS TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE FELLOWS. SELECTED FELLOWS WILL WORK AT THE NRCASC WITH SPECIFIC RESEARCH PROJECTS IDENTIFIED BY THE APPLICANT. FELLOWS WILL FOCUS THEIR PROJECTS ON THE APPLICATION OF RESEARCH TO HABITAT AND SPECIES MANAGEMENT IN FEDERALLY OWNED PUBLIC LANDS, INCLUDING FWS REFUGES AND NATIONAL PARKS. FELLOWS WILL THEREBY LEARN ABOUT AGENCY DECISION-MAKING TOOLS AND PROCESSES WHILE PRODUCING PART OR ENTIRE POLICYINFORMING TOOLS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO OFFER ANNUAL ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE INQUIRY AND METHODS WORKSHOPS IN YEARS 1-5. THE WORKSHOPS AIM TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES IN STATISTICAL OR GEOSPATIAL ANALYSES, PROMOTING THE AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF DATA ANALYTIC TOOLS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE POLICYMAKING. THEY WILL CREATE A COMPETITIVE POOL OF INTERNS FOR THE GMU-USGS FISH AND WILDLIFE ADAPTATION FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM.III. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESDURING THE PROJECT PERIOD FROM 2023-2027, TWELVE STUDENTS WILL GAIN INTENSIVE FELLOWSHIP EXPERIENCES. ALSO, AROUND 180 STUDENTS WILL BE TRAINED IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE INQUIRY AND METHODS WORKSHOPS IN YEARS 1-5. THE EXPECTED PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE RESEARCH PROJECTS SELECTED BY USGS NRCASC OR STUDENT-IDENTIFIED PROJECTS MENTORED BY CAREER SCIENTISTS. MULTIMEDIA VIDEO CLIPS FEATURING THE WORKSHOPS WILL BE PRODUCED BY THE AWARDED PROJECT.IV. INTENDED BENEFICIARIESTHE AWARDED PROJECT WILL BENEFIT FELLOW STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN THE USGS NRCASC PROJECTS, WHILE THE NRCASC WILL BENEFIT FROM DATA COLLECTION AND MINING ANALYSIS BY FELLOWS. THE ANNUAL WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS ARE OTHER BENEFICIARIES AS THEY WILL BE EDUCATED WITH HANDS-ON, PRACTICE-BASED TRAINING IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR WILD ANIMALS AND FISH, AS WELL AS DATA ANALYSIS TOOLS.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 26 23 1 25 24PROJECT TITLE CE QUAL W2 MODELING  ILLINOIS RIVERA 16 MILE STRETCH OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER NEAR UTICA, ILLINOIS, BETWEEN THE MARSEILLE LOCK AND DAM AND THE STARVED ROCK LOCK AND DAM HAVE EXPERIENCED HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) THAT SECRETE TOXINS THAT CAN AFFECT ANIMALS AND HUMANS. ONE OF THESE TOXINS IS MICROCYSTIS WHICH HAS BEEN MEASURED IN THIS PART OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER AT CONCENTRATIONS ABOVE THE HEALTH ADVISORY LIMIT. TO CONTROL THESE HABS, A COMPUTER SIMULATION MODEL OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER WILL BE DEVELOPED AND USED TO ASSESS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO UNDERSTAND THE CAUSES OF THE HABS AND HOW TO MITIGATE THEM.THE USGS IS WORKING ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF A WATER QUALITY AND HYDRODYNAMIC MODEL FOR THIS STRETCH OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER. THIS DEVELOPMENT WILL BE IN COOPERATION WITH PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY. THE USGS WILL ASSIST IN PERFORMING FIELD SAMPLING WORK THAT SUPPORTS THE MODEL. THESE DATA INCLUDE WATER LEVEL, VELOCITY, TEMPERATURE, NUTRIENT, ALGAE, AND ORGANIC MATTER IN THE SYSTEM. THE USGS WILL ALSO ASSIST IN SETTING UP THE MODEL WITH COOPERATION OF PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY STAFF.SETTING UP THE MODEL INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING STEPS  (1) COMPILING FIELD DATA FOR THE ILLINOIS RIVER MODEL DOMAIN (THE 16 MILE STRETCH) AND FILLING IN GAPS IN THE DATA IF MISSING DATA ARE IDENTIFIED, (2) CONVERTING THE FIELD DATA INTO FILES FOR USE IN THE COMPUTER MODEL (SUCH AS THE MODEL BATHYMETRY OR GRID, TIME SERIES OF FLOW RATES, TEMPERATURE AND OTHER WATER QUALITY VARIABLES), (3) USING THE MODEL TO MATCH MEASURED DATA WHICH IS TERMED CALIBRATION AND TO UNDERSTAND FACTORS THAT CONTROL THE GROWTH OF HABS, AND (4) APPLICATION OF THE MODEL TO MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR REDUCING THE GROWTH OF HARMFUL ALGAE THAT PRODUCE TOXINS.PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY WILL ALSO WORK WITH THE USGS TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE IN THE GROWTH AND MOVEMENT OF ALGAE THAT PRODUCE AND RELEASE TOXINS. THIS COLLABORATIVE APPROACH BETWEEN PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE USGS WILL PROVIDE TIMELY ON GOING PEER REVIEW BASED ON THE EXPERIENCE OF PSU WITH THE MODEL AND TRAINING OF USGS STAFF IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MODEL.BY UNDERSTANDING THE GROWTH OF HARMFUL ALGAE THROUGH THIS MODELING EXERCISE, MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES WILL BE FOR REDUCING ALGAE GROWTH AND THE RELEASE OF ALGAE TOXINS WILL BE AN OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT.THE PLANNED PRODUCTS INCLUDE A JOINTLY AUTHORED RESEARCH REPORT ON MODELING HABS IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER AND A JOURNAL PAPER OUTLINING THE USE OF THE MODEL TO MITIGATE HABS.THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE OF THE STATE OF ILLINOIS. ALSO, THIS PROJECT MAY HAVE AN INFLUENCE ON OTHER REGIONS OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER TO FURTHER IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN THIS RIVER BASIN.

PROJECT PERIOD  2 1 2023 1 31 2025PROJECT TITLE SSESSING CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS AND IDENTIFYING AREAS OF HIGH CONTAGIONAWARD PURPOSE  CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IS A LETHAL PRION DISEASE IN DEER SPECIES, AND IS ONE OF THE TOP THREATS TO DEER IN PARTS OF NORTH AMERICA. ONE OF THE BIGGEST ISSUES INHIBITING THE MANAGEMENT OF CWD IS THAT BIOLOGISTS CAN ONLY TEST IF AN ANIMAL WAS INFECTED WITH CWD AFTER IT HAS DIED. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND A MASTER S STUDENT (FROM EASTERN SHOSHONE) IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ZOOLOGY AND PHYSIOLOGY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING (UW) TO DEVELOP A METHOD THAT ALLOWS BIOLOGISTS TO ASSESS WHETHER A LIVE ANIMAL HAS OR DOES NOT HAVE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD). KNOWLEDGE OF LIVE ANIMAL DISEASE STATUS WILL THEN BE USED TO HELP IDENTIFY CWD HOTSPOTS AMONG RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY MULE DEER IN THE GREATER WIND RIVER REGION OF WYOMING. CWD PREVALENCE IN THIS REGION IS OVER 60  AMONG ADULT MALE MULE DEER AND IS A HIGH PRIORITY REGION FOR THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT, TRIBES OF THE WIND RIVER RESERVATION (NORTHERN ARAPAHO AND EASTERN SHOSHONE), AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THE PORTION OF THE BUDGET ALLOCATED TO UW IS SPECIFICALLY DEDICATED TO STUDENT SUPPORT, INCLUDING STIPEND AND BENEFITS, TUITION AND FEES, TRAVEL, COMPUTER AND SOFTWARE, AND MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES. THERE IS ALSO FUNDING FOR A FIELD TECHNICIAN TO SUPPORT THIS WORK.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED UNDER THIS PROJECT INCLUDE CAPTURE, GPS COLLARING, AND BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING OF MULE DEER IN THE GREATER WIND RIVER REGION. BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES SUCH AS EAR PUNCH BIOPSIES WILL BE USED TO OPTIMIZE THE REAL TIMING QUAKING INDUCED CONVERSION (RT QUIC) ASSAY FOR NONLETHAL CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DETECTION. FINE SCALE COLLAR DATA WILL BE USED TO ASSESS MOVEMENT ECOLOGY IN THIS REGION AND TO COMPARE MIGRATORY STRATEGIES OF INFECTED AND NONINFECTED MULE DEER. FURTHER ASSESSMENT OF COLLAR DATA WILL EXAMINE HABITAT USE AND LANDSCAPE COMPOSITION AS RELATED TO CWD STATUS, WHICH WILL INFORM RISK OF CWD ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE AN OPTIMIZED PROTOCOL FOR EAR PUNCH SAMPLING AND NONLETHAL CWD TESTING VIA RT QUIC, AS WELL AS A PROCESSED GPS COLLAR DATASET THAT CAN BE USED FOR VARIOUS DOWNSTREAM ANALYSES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IDENTIFICATION OF MULE DEER BEHAVIORS, LIFE HISTORY STRATEGIES, AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS THAT PROMOTE EXCEPTIONALLY HIGH CWD PREVALENCE IN THIS GEOGRAPHIC REGION. FINDINGS WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MITIGATE CWD TRANSMISSION IN THE GREATER WIND RIVER AND MAY BE APPLIED TO OTHER REGIONS TO REDUCE SPREAD. THIS WORK WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS AND WILL BE PRESENTED AT RELEVANT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS FROM WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT AND THE TRIBES OF THE WIND RIVER RESERVATION (NORTHERN ARAPAHO AND EASTERN SHOSHONE). INFORMATION ABOUT WHY THIS SPECIFIC HERD HAS SUCH HIGH CWD PREVALENCE WILL BE USEFUL TO WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS OUTSIDE WYOMING AS WELL. AS THE MASTER S STUDENT ON THIS PROJECT, TUCKER RUSSELL WILL RECEIVE TRAINING IN DISEASE LAB WORK, ANALYSES OF GPS COLLAR DATA, AND WRITING AND PRESENTING SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH. DR. JEROD MERKLE, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ZOOLOGY AND PHYSIOLOGY AT UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING, WILL ADVISE TUCKER RUSSELL. NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE IDENTIFIED AT THIS TIME.

TITLE  NATIONAL WATER USE WELLS PROJECT PROJECT PERIOD  02 01 2023  03 31 2025THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A METHODOLOGICAL FRAMEWORK TO LINK IRRIGATED CROPLANDS TO THE SPECIFIC WATER SOURCES SUPPLYING THESE CROPLANDS. VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY(VIRGINIA TECH) HYPOTHESIZE THAT WATER INFRASTRUCTURE (E.G., SURFACE CANALS, PIPELINES, GROUNDWATER WELLS) ARE A KEY PREDICTOR OF AN IRRIGATED CROPLAND S WATER SOURCE. IMPORTANT DELIVERABLES FROM THIS TWO YEAR PROJECT INCLUDE NOVEL WATER USE AND WATER INFRASTRUCTURE DATA PRODUCTS, A PROOF OF CONCEPT MODELING FRAMEWORK, AND PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS ONGOING EFFORTS OF THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) WATER AVAILABILITY AND USE SCIENCE PROGRAM TO IMPROVE WATER USE AND AVAILABILITY ESTIMATES ACROSS ALL SECTORS AND TO DETERMINE SOURCES OF WATER FROM STREAMS, LAKES, AND AQUIFERS AND ASSOCIATE THESE SOURCES WITH THE POPULATIONS AND PLACES SERVED. FURTHERMORE, FINDINGS AND PRODUCTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT OTHER USGS INITIATIVES, SUCH AS IMPROVED REPRESENTATION OF ANTHROPOGENIC INFLUENCES WITHIN HYDROLOGIC MODELS AND DATA TO SUPPORT REFINED DOMESTIC AND PUBLIC SUPPLY WATER USE ESTIMATES. THIS AGREEMENT WILL ENABLE DATA COLLECTION AND SHARING, AS WELL AS PILOT INVESTIGATIONS, THAT WOULD NOT OTHERWISE BE POSSIBLE WITHOUT THIS COLLABORATION.

PROJECT TITLE  DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF A PROTOTYPE MODEL OF BENTHIC MAT TO INFUSE CARBON DIOXIDE.PROJECT DATE DECEMBER 12, 2022 THROUGH DECEMBER 11, 2023.AWARD PURPOSE  THE UPPER MIDWEST ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES CENTER (UMESC) IS EXPLORING METHODS TO MANAGE AND CONTROL (DREISSENA POLYMORPHA) AND QUAGGA MUSSELS (DREISSENA BUGENSIS) IN WATER BODIES ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. UMESC RESEARCHERS AND ENGINEERS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF WISONSIN PLATTEVILLE (UWP) HAVE PREVIOUSLY COLLABORATED TO DEVELOP EQUIPMENT TO EFFICENTLY INFUSE GASEOUS CO2 INTO WATER TO CREATE A NOXIOUS CHEMICAL BARRIER THAT CAN REPEL SEVERAL SPECIES OF FISH AND INHIBIT THE SETTLEMENT OF DREISSENID MUSSELS. THE NEXT PHASE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP AND EVALUATE A LIGHT WEIGHT AND PROTABLE DEVICE TO ERADICATE INVASIVE MUSSELS FROM THE BENTHIC ZONES OF SUITABLE LAKES AND PONDS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  WITH SUPPORT FROM USGS AND UWP, THE PROJECT WILL DESIGN, CONSTRUCT AND FIELD TEST A DEVICE TO INFUSE CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) IN THE BENTHIC ZONE OF A WATER BODY FOR ERADICATION OF INVASIVE MUSSLES. ENGINEERING DESIGN STUDENTS AT THE UWP WILL DEVELOP AND EVALUATE VARIOUS DESIGNS. UMESC RESEARCHERS WILL SELECT A DESIGN THAT MEETS REQUIRED SPECIFICATIONS AND SENIOR ENGINEERING STUDENTS WILL CONTRUCT AND VERIFY A PROTOTYPE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  FROM THIS EXPERIMENT, THE PROJECT TEAM EXPECTS, A DEVELOPMENT OF A DESIGN FOR A CO2 BENTHIC MAT AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FULL SCALE PROTOTYPE OF A CO2 BENTHIC MAT AND VERIFY PERFORMANCE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  BENEFICIARIES USGS, UWP, PUBLIC

PROJECT TITLE ESTIMATING GROUNDWATER WITHDRAWALS USING SATELLITE DATA IN THE MISSISSIPPI ALLUVIAL PLAINPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE   12 27 2022 THROUGH 6 30 2023PROJECT DESCRIPTION   CHANGES IN GROUNDWATER STORAGE DUE TO EXCESSIVE WITHDRAWALS PRIMARILY FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES,THREATEN FOOD, WATER, AND ENERGY SECURITY. GROUNDWATER IS A KEY COMPONENT OF THE WATER CYCLE,AND MONITORING GROUNDWATER WITHDRAWALS IS A CRUCIAL STEP IN WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT ANDMITIGATING THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF OVERUSING GROUNDWATER. HOWEVER, VERY FEW REGIONS OF THE U.S. AND WORLD MONITOR THEIR IRRIGATION WATER USE AT THE LOCAL SCALE NECESSARY TO IMPLEMENTSUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT SOLUTIONS. IN THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT SEEKS TO DEVELOP REMOTE SENSING METHODOLOGIES AND ALGORITHMS THAT ESTIMATE IRRIGATION WATER USE AT THE LOCAL SCALE (1 KM, BOTHANNUAL AND MONTHLY) IN THE MISSISSIPPI ALLUVIAL PLAIN (MAP).ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORME   THE RECIPIENT WILL ADVANCE THE MODEL BY INCORPORATING ANNUAL AND REAL TIME WITHDRAWAL DATAINTO A NOVEL MACHINE LEARNING ALGORITHM. THIS APPROACH IS EXPECTED TO BETTER LEVERAGE AVAILABLEDATASETS AND IMPROVE THE ESTIMATES OF MONTHLY WITHDRAWALS.DELIVERABLES   THE DELIVERABLES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE ESTIMATES OF GROUNDWATER WITHDRAWALS AT THE 1 KM RESOLUTION FROM 2003   2020, AND THE CODE AND METHODS NEEDED TO CONTINUE ESTIMATINGGROUNDWATER WITHDRAWALS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES   THEMISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND OTHER AGENCIES THAT ARE TASKED WITH MANAGING WATER RESOURCES IN THE MISSISSIPPI ALLUVIAL PLAIN.SUBRECIPIENT  NONE.

PROJECT TITLE DEMOGRAPHY AND GENETICS OF MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRRELS IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIAPROJECT PERIOD  1 5 23 1 4 27AWARD PURPOSEMOHAVE GROUND SQUIRRELS ARE LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND  NEAR THREATENED  WITH A DECREASING POPULATION TREND BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR CONSERVATION OF NATURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES. CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL, INC., A CHESAPEAKE WATERSHED COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNIT PARTNER, WILL ASSIST THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WITH ORGANIZATION AND ANALYSIS OF MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRREL DEMOGRAPHIC DATA, INCLUDING ESTIMATING SURVIVAL RATES AND POPULATION SIZE  AS WELL AS ASSIST IN WRITING A SPECIES GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDUSING EXISTING MARK RECAPTURE DATA ON MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRRELS, CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL, INC. WILL WORK WITH THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TO DEVELOP STATISTICAL MULTI STATE MODELS TO UNDERSTAND SURVIVORSHIP, REPRODUCTIVE RATES, AND EVEN MOVEMENT OF ANIMALS WITHIN THIS POPULATION. WE WILL ALSO CREATE A GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRRELS, CONTRACTING WITH AN EVOLUTIONARY GENETICIST TO DEVELOP A PLAN MODELED AFTER THAT PREPARED FOR THE PACIFIC POCKET MOUSE AND OTHER SPECIES. THIS PLAN WILL MAKE INITIAL RECOMMENDATIONS FOR DIFFERENT CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS AND DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH THE MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS AND TO CONSERVE GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN EACH MANAGED POPULATION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESDELIVERABLES INCLUDE A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION WITH UPDATED MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRREL DEMOGRAPHIC ANALYSES AND ESTIMATED SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTION RATES, AS WELL AS A GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE SPECIES. RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL FILL GAPS IN KNOWLEDGE PERTAINING TO THE MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRREL AND WILL ALLOW WILDLIFE MANAGERS TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION PLANS FOR THE SPECIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)THIS PROJECT BENEFITS THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND STATE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES THAT ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONSERVATION OF MOJAVE GROUND SQUIRRELS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIESDEVELOPMENT OF GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN

PROJECT TITLE CASE CONTROL EPIDEMIOLOGICAL STUDY OF CORAL VIROMES TO ASCERTAIN THE ETIOLOGY OF SCTLDPROJECT PERIOD  12 6 22 12 5 23PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSESTONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS DISEASE (SCTLD) IS ONE OF THE MOST CATASTROPHIC FACTORS TO HAVE AFFECTED CORAL REEFS IN FLORIDA AND THE CARIBBEAN. SCTLD AFFECTS APPROXIMATELY 25 CORAL SPECIES AND HAS SPREAD IN A WAVE ORIGINATING NEAR MIAMI, FLORIDA, SINCE 2014. IT IS STRONGLY SUSPECTED THAT AN EMERGING VIRUS IS CAUSING SCTLD. THIS IS DUE TO THE PATTERN OF SPREAD OF THE DISEASE, THE PRESENCE OF VIRUS LIKE PARTICLES IN AFFECTED CORALS, AND EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES SHOWING THAT THE DISEASE CAN BE TRANSMITTED FROM SICK TO HEALTHY CORALS. THE PROJECT WILL USE ADVANCED TECHNOLOGIES IN DNA SEQUENCING TO IDENTIFY VIRUSES IN CORALS AFFECTED AND UNAFFECTED BY SCTLD. DATA WILL THEN BE ANALYZED TO IDENTIFY WHICH VIRUSES ARE MOST STRONGLY ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASE. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE CAYMAN ISLANDS, WHERE ONE ISLAND (GRAND CAYMAN) IS HEAVILY AFFECTED AND ANOTHER (CAYMAN BRAC) IS DISEASE FREE. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF TESTS, PREVENTIVE MEASURES, AND TREATMENTS FOR THIS SERIOUS DISEASE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDEXTRACT NUCLEIC ACIDS FROM CORAL SAMPLES ALREADY COLLECTED FROM THE CAYMAN ISLANDS AND ALREADY SHIPPED TO THE USA.PREPARE DNA AND CONDUCT SEQUENCING USING NEXT GENERATION DNA SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGIESANALYZE SEQUENCE DATA TO IDENTIFY VIRUSES USING COMPUTATIONAL APPROACHESPERFORM INFERENTIAL STATISTICS TO IDENTIFY VIRUSES MOST STRONGLY ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASEDESIGN SPECIFIC MOLECULAR TESTS FOR DISEASE ASSOCIATED VIRUSESDISSEMINATE RESULTS TO STAKEHOLDERSDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESDELIVERABLE 1  METAGENOMIC SEQUENCE DATASETS FROM 90 CORAL SAMPLES, INCLUDING SPECIES MATCHED CASES AND CONTROLS AND CORALS MANIFESTING DIFFERENT DEGREES OF DISEASE SEVERITY.EXPECTED OUTCOME 1  GENERATION OF APPROXIMATELY 90 MILLION DNA SEQUENCES SUITABLE FOR VIRUS IDENTIFICATION.DELIVERABLE 2  BIOINFORMATIC AND STATISTICAL ANALYSES OF 90 SEQUENCE DATASETS TO IDENTIFY VIRUSES AND TO ASSESS WHICH VIRUSES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SCTLD OCCURRENCE AND SEVERITY.EXPECTED OUTCOME 2  A LIST OF VIRUSES AND THEIR GENETIC SEQUENCES THAT IDENTIFIES VIRUSES ASSOCIATED STATISTICALLY WITH SCTLD.DELIVERABLE 3  SPECIFIC MOLECULAR LABORATORY TESTS FOR VIRUSES STRONGLY ASSOCIATED WITH SCTLD.EXPECTED OUTCOME 3  APPROXIMATELY 1 10 POLYMERASE CHAIN REACTION ASSAYS DESIGNED.DELIVERABLE 4  A FINAL REPORT AND PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DETAILING FINDINGS.EXPECTED OUTCOME 4  A REPORT PRESENTED TO USGS AND STAKEHOLDERS, AND APPROXIMATELY 1 3 PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.DELIVERABLE 5  TRAINING OF A POST DOCTORAL SCHOLAR.EXPECTED OUTCOME 5  INCLUSION OF POST DOCTORAL SCHOLAR IN LABORATORY AND STATISTICAL ANALYSES, PREPARATION OF REPORTS AND MANUSCRIPTS, AND STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESSTAKEHOLDERS IN ALL LOCATIONS AFFECTED BY SCTLD, INCLUDING GOVERNMENTS, NON GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, AND THE PUBLIC. STAKEHOLDERS IN THE STATE OF FLORIDA WILL BENEFIT SPECIFICALLY, BECAUSE CORALS IN FLORIDA ARE HEAVILY AFFECTED.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  NOT APPLICABLE

PROJECT PERIOD  1 17 23 1 16 24PROJECT TITLE CLIMATE DRIVERS AND FLATWOODS SALAMANDER PHENOLOGY AND DEMOGRAPHYTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW AMPHIBIANS RESPOND TO ENVIRONMENTAL CUES, SUCH AS TEMPERATURE AND RAINFALL, THAT ARE FORECASTED TO CHANGE FROM HISTORICAL PATTERNS, AND HOW THIS COULD INFLUENCE POPULATIONS OF AMPHIBIANS IN THE FUTURE. THE FOCUS IS ON THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FLATWOODS SALAMANDERS. THERE IS CONCERN THAT IF THE SALAMANDERS MIGRATE TO OR FROM BREEDING PONDS BASED ON CUES THAT ARE NO LONGER PROVIDING ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT WHEN PONDS ARE LIKELY TO BE FILLED WITH WATER, THE ABILITY OF THESE ANIMALS TO BREED SUCCESSFULLY COULD BE IMPAIRED. BY EVALUATING THE LIKELY SUCCESS OF BREEDING EVENTS EACH YEAR, COMBINED WITH INFORMATION ON SURVIVAL OF ADULTS, WE CAN CREATE POPULATION OR DEMOGRAPHIC MODELS TO PREDICT CHANGES IN POPULATIONS. UNDERSTANDING HOW POPULATIONS OF SALAMANDERS ARE LIKELY TO GROW, PERSIST, OR DECLINE IS IMPORTANT WHEN PLANNING CONSERVATION INVESTMENTS. CAN USE HISTORICAL INFORMATION ABOUT HOW PONDS FILL BASED ON WEATHER CONDITIONS, TO BUILD MODELS THAT WILL PREDICT POND FILLING AND DRYING PATTERNS IN THE FUTURE. THIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE INFORMATION ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL CUES, PREDICTED CHANGES IN WEATHER PATTERNS AND POND HYDROLOGY, AND SALAMANDER POPULATION MODELS IN ORDER TO ENSURE THAT FORECASTS OF SALAMANDER POPULATION VIABILITY ACCOUNT FOR A MORE COMPLETE RANGE OF FUTURE POSSIBILITIES.WILL PLAN TO CONDUCT FOUR MAJOR ACTIVITIES. WILL SUMMARIZE INFORMATION ON MOVEMENT OF FLATWOODS SALAMANDERS ON EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE TO AND FROM BREEDING PONDS USING 10 YEARS OF DATA. USING FORECASTS BASED ON ALTERNATIVE CLIMATE SCENARIOS, WILL SIMULATE THE TIMING OF SALAMANDER BREEDING EVENTS. WILL PREPARE MODELS OF POND FILLING AND DRYING AND MAKE PROJECTIONS BASED ON THE SAME FORECASTED CLIMATE SCENARIOS. WILL DEVELOP POPULATION VIABILITY MODELS FOR FLATWOODS SALAMANDERS THAT INCORPORATE PREDICTIONS OF BREEDING SUCCESS AND FAILURE BASED ON CLIMATE FORECASTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL COMPLETE STATISTICAL ANALYSIS THAT WILL BE USED IN MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND OR A GUIDE TO POPULATION MODELING FOR FLATWOODS SALAMANDERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT RESEARCHERS STUDYING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ANIMAL BEHAVIOR AND WEATHER PATTERNS, HYDROLOGY, AND AMPHIBIAN POPULATION BIOLOGY. THIS WORK WILL ALSO BE VALUABLE TO MANAGERS AND OTHERS CONCERNED WITH CONSERVATION OF AMPHIBIANS.

PROJECT TITLE ASSESSING THE EFFICACIES OF PASSIVE VERSUS ACTIVE RESTORATION ON HEAVILY DISTURBED CATTLE GRAZING SITES IN THE MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVEPROJECT PERIOD  12 12 22 12 11 25LEGACIES OF CURRENT AND FORMER LIVESTOCK GRAZING IN MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVE (MOJA) CREATE AREAS OF GRAZING ALTERED SOILS AND VEGETATION, CALLED  PIOSPHERES , WHEREIN DISTURBANCE INTENSITY IS HIGHEST NEAR CATTLE WATERING AREAS BUT ATTENUATES WITH DISTANCE AWAY FROM THESE AREAS. THE CENTERS OF THESE PIOSPHERES ARE DEVOID OF WOODY VEGETATION AND ARE INCREASINGLY MISTAKEN FOR PRIMITIVE CAMPSITES DUE TO THEIR VISIBILITY, DESPITE NOT BEING DESIGNATED AS SUCH BY MOJA. LIVESTOCK AND BURROS WERE REMOVED FROM MOJA  20 YEARS AGO TO PROMOTE PASSIVE RESTORATION, AND MOJA HAS PERFORMED ACTIVE RESTORATION ON SEVERAL PIOSPHERES IN THE LAST  7 YEARS (SOIL RIPPING, BROADCAST SEEDING, SUPPLEMENTAL IRRIGATION) TO ACCELERATE VEGETATION AND SOIL RECOVERY AND DISCOURAGE INTENSIFIED VISITOR USE AND DISTURBANCE OF THESE SITES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO  1) EVALUATE SOIL RECOVERY AND PLANT COMMUNITY ASSEMBLY AFTER  20 YEARS OF PASSIVE RESTORATION FOR PIOSPHERE SITES THAT REPRESENT DECREASING DISTURBANCE INTENSITIES (I.E., HIGH, MODERATE AND LOW LIVESTOCK USE ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASING DISTANCES FROM WELLS, WITH THE COMPOUNDING INFLUENCE OF VISITOR USE OF PIOSPHERES AS CAMPSITES)  2) EVALUATE OUTCOMES OF ACTIVE RESTORATION EFFORTS (SOIL RIPPING, SEEDING, IRRIGATION) CONDUCTED BY MOJA STAFF ON ADDITIONAL PIOSPHERES  3) IDENTIFY ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC FACTORS DRIVING PLANT COMMUNITY REASSEMBLY RECOVERY BY TESTING RESTORATION TECHNIQUES ACROSS SEVERAL PIOSPHERES THAT REPRESENT DIVERSE TOPOGRAPHIC AND CLIMATIC CONTEXTS. TO QUANTIFY LONG TERM RECOVERY TRAJECTORIES FROM LIVESTOCK GRAZING (I.E., PASSIVE RESTORATION), WILL RE SAMPLE PERMANENT TRANSECTS THAT WERE MEASURED IN SPRING 2001 2003 (PRE LIVESTOCK REMOVAL AND 1 2 YEARS POST REMOVAL) AND 2009 2010 (8 10 YEARS POST REMOVAL) AT 10 WELLS DURING SPRING 2022 AND 2023 (20 YEARS POST REMOVAL)  EACH WELL HAS THREE POINTS AT EACH OF THREE DISTANCES AWAY FROM THE CENTER POINT (100 M, 400 M, AND 1600 M, COINCIDING WITH HIGH, MODERATE, AND LOW GRAZING INTENSITY). TO COMPARE THE OUTCOMES OF PASSIVE VS. ACTIVE RESTORATION, WILL RE VISIT AND RE MEASURE THE EIGHT WELL FOOTPRINTS (I.E., WITHIN 100 M OF WATER POINT) THAT WERE ACTIVELY RESTORED (SOIL SURFACE RIPPING, SEEDING WITH HERBACEOUS PERENNIALS, AND SUPPLEMENTAL IRRIGATION) AND THE FOUR UNTREATED SITES THAT SERVED AS PASSIVE RESTORATION (ESTABLISHED BY MOJA STAFF DURING 2014   2015). WILL IMPLEMENT A CONTROLLED EXPERIMENT TO TEST WHICH FACTORS INFLUENCE THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIVE VEGETATION ON RECOVERING PIOSPHERES. FACTORIAL COMBINATIONS OF TREATMENTS TO TEST BARRIERS TO ESTABLISHMENT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN COORDINATION WITH AND APPROVED BY MOJA STAFF TO INCLUDE  A) SURFACE DECOMPACTION VS. NO DECOMPACTION, B) BROADCAST SEEDING, SEEDLING OUTPLANTING, VS. NONE, C) GRANIVORE HERBIVORE EXCLUSION VS. NO PROTECTION, AND D) HERBICIDE MANUAL REMOVAL OF INVASIVE ANNUALS VS. NO REMOVAL. IN ADDITION TO ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT, WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AT LEAST ONE PRESENTATION AT A REGIONAL OR NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC MEETING, ASSIST IN THE CREATION OF QUALITY CHECKED DATA AND ULTIMATELY PRODUCE AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION AND ACCOMPANYING FACT SHEET. PROJECT RESULTS WILL INFORM THE MOJA BACKCOUNTRY CAMPSITE MANAGEMENT PLAN BY IDENTIFYING THE CHARACTERISTICS OF PIOSPHERES THAT PROMOTE ECOLOGICAL RECOVERY.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 17 23 1 16 24PROJECT TITLE TEMPERATE DEPENDENT OUTCOMES OF PRIORITY EFFECTS IN POND BREEDING SALAMANDERSPLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION  THE TIMING OF WHEN ORGANISMS PERFORM DIFFERENT ACTIVITIES IN THEIR LIFE CYCLES (I.E., PHENOLOGY), SUCH AS WHEN THEY UNDERGO MIGRATIONS OR EMERGE FROM HIBERNATION, HAS BEEN SHIFTING WITH GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE. HOW SHIFTS IN PHENOLOGY AFFECT DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF AN ORGANISMS  BIOLOGY IS NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD, INCLUDING HOW ORGANISMS INTERACT WITH COMPETITORS OR PREDATORS. FURTHERMORE, SHIFTS IN SPECIES INTERACTIONS MAY BE COMPOUNDED BY THE DIRECT EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, SUCH AS WARMING TEMPERATURES. STUDIES ADDRESSING SYNERGIES BETWEEN DIFFERENT EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, SUCH AS WARMING TEMPERATURES AND SHIFTS IN PHENOLOGY ARE RARE. THIS WORK WILL ADDRESS THIS GAP IN KNOWLEDGE BY EXPERIMENTAL MANIPULATING THE INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF WARMING DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE WITH SHIFTS IN PHENOLOGY, USING POND BREEDING SALAMANDER AS A MODEL SYSTEM.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED ON LARVAL RINGED AND MARBLED SALAMANDERS IN OUTDOOR MESOCOSMS ON THE SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY EDWARDSVILLE CAMPUS. THE RELATIVE TIMING OF HATCHING OF EACH SPECIES, AS WELL AS THE WATER TEMPERATURE EARLY IN DEVELOPMENT, WILL BE MANIPULATED IN A FULLY FACTORIAL DESIGN. EXPERIMENTS WILL BE MONITORED THROUGH METAMORPHOSIS TO DETERMINING RATES OF SURVIVAL AND BODY SIZE, KEY METRICS OF ORGANISM FITNESS. DATA WILL BE ANALYZED AND THEN WRITTEN UP AS A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE MAIN HYPOTHESIS IS THAT THE MAGNITUDE OF CHANGE IN SPECIES INTERACTION STRENGTHS BETWEEN LARVAL STAGES OF RINGED AND MARBLED SALAMANDERS DUE TO PHENOLOGICAL SHIFTS IS DICTATED BY WATER TEMPERATURE. SPECIFICALLY, SPECIES INTERACTIONS WILL BE STRONGER (I.E., HIGHER PREDATION RATES AND OR STRONGER COMPETITIVE EFFECTS) EARLY IN THE SEASON AND AT WARMER WATER TEMPERATURES COMPARED TO COOLER TEMPERATURES AND LATER IN THE SEASON. EFFECTS GENERATED BY MARBLED SALAMANDERS WILL ALSO BE STRONGER DUE TO THEIR KNOWN NEGATIVE COMPETITIVE EFFECTS ON RINGED SALAMANDERS.ALONG WITH A FINAL REPORT TO USGS, THIS WORK WILL PRODUCE AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPT. BECAUSE THIS WORK WILL CONSTITUTE A SIGNIFICANT ADVANCE IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS ON PHENOLOGICAL SHIFTS, A HIGH IMPACT JOURNAL WILL BE TARGETED, SUCH SCIENTIFIC REPORTS, ECOLOGY OR JOURNAL OF ANIMAL ECOLOGY. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL ALSO BE PRESENTED AT NATIONAL CONFERENCES SUCH AS THE JOINT MEETINGS OF ICHTHYOLOGY AND HERPETOLOGY OR THE ECOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA. ALL UNDERLYING DATA AND ANALYTICAL CODE WILL ALSO BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE TO THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) AND THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AT LARGE (E.G., VIA DRYAD).INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE GENERAL SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS WORK AS IT WILL BUILD KNOWLEDGE ON IMPORTANT AND TIMELY TOPICS (CLIMATE CHANGE AND SHIFTS IN PHENOLOGY). THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE USGS BECAUSE IT CAN PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION ON AMPHIBIAN ECOLOGY, A KEY RESEARCH FOCUS IN THIS ORGANIZATION. SPECIFICALLY, IT CAN PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE ON CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES MONITORED BY THE USGS, SUCH AS THE FLATWOODS SALAMANDERS, WHERE EXPERIMENTAL MANIPULATION IS NOT POSSIBLE, LEADING TO IMPROVED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE METAGENOMICS AND BIOINFORMATICS TO UNDERSTAND BIODEGRADATION OF HALOGENATED CONTAMINANTS, INCLUDING PFASPROJECT PERIOD  12 12 22 12 11 27PROJECT DESCRIPTION  THE PROJECT WILL EVALUATE DATA OBTAINED FROM FIELD SAMPLES AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS WITH THE GOAL OF ASSESSING THE FATE, POTENTIAL FOR BIODEGRADATION AND MITIGATION OF HALOGENATED CONTAMINANTS IN CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER, STORMWATER AND SEDIMENT. WILL FOCUS ON CHLORINATED SOLVENTS, POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS (PCBS), AND PER  AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) AND EVALUATE IF MICROORGANISMS PRESENT IN THE ENVIRONMENT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BIODEGRADE THESE CONTAMINANTS. THESE COMPOUNDS SHARE THE COMMON CHARACTERISTIC THAT THEY ARE TOXIC AND ARE DIFFICULT TO BREAK DOWN. CHLORINATED SOLVENTS ARE AMONG THE MOST FREQUENTLY FOUND CONTAMINANTS IN GROUNDWATER, PCBS ARE COMMONLY ASSOCIATED WITH SEDIMENT AND PARTICLE BASED CONTAMINATION IN STORMWATER AND PFAS ARE OFTEN FOUND TOGETHER WITH OTHER CONTAMINANTS IN WATER AND SEDIMENT. PFAS HAS RECENTLY RECEIVED MUCH MORE ATTENTION AND HAVE BEEN TERMED  FOREVER CHEMICALS  SINCE THEY ARE HARD TO DEGRADE. WILL ALSO ASSESS CONTAMINANTS PRESENT IN STORMWATER RUNOFF, SINCE MAJOR (RE) CONTAMINATION CAN TAKE PLACE NEAR STORMWATER DISCHARGE POINTS. REMOVAL OF CONTAMINANTS FROM STORMWATER BEFORE IT IS DISCHARGED TO A WATERBODY WILL PREVENT AND OR REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF TOXIC CHEMICALS THAT WILL ENTER THE FOOD CHAIN AND CAUSE HARM TO THE ORGANISMS IN THE FOOD CHAIN AND THEREBY ALSO HUMANS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  IN THE PROJECT, WILL UTILIZE EXISTING DATA FROM FIELD AND LABORATORY STUDIES AT USGS AND UMD TO IDENTIFY THE KEY MICROBIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES THAT ARE PRESENT AND INVOLVED IN BIODEGRADATION OF HALOGENATED CONTAMINANTS IN GROUNDWATER, SEDIMENT AND STORMWATER. WILL ALSO CALCULATE THE NUMBER OF BACTERIA THAT ARE INVOLVED IN THE DEGRADATION OF THE TOXIC COMPOUNDS IN THE DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTS TO FIND IMPORTANT BARRIERS FOR BIODEGRADATION. FINALLY, WILL USE THIS KNOWLEDGE TO GENERATE AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF BIODEGRADATION OF THESE TOXIC COMPOUNDS THAT HELP DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR MITIGATION OF HALOGENATED COMPOUNDS IN STORMWATER INCLUDING MIXING WITH CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE FACTORS, MECHANISMS AND PROCESSES INVOLVED IN BIODEGRADATION OF HALOGENATED CONTAMINANTS IN GROUNDWATER, STORMWATER, SOIL AND SEDIMENT SAMPLES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  IN ADDITION TO A FINAL REPORT, THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL PUBLISH FINDINGS IN PEER REVIEWED JOURNALS AS WELL AS PUBLICATIONS IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL MAGAZINES. WILL ALSO MAKE THE DEVELOPED BIOINFORMATICS DATABASE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. IN ADDITION, DOCUMENTATION OUTLINING THE METHODS USED FOR ESTABLISHING THE DATABASE AND ANALYZING THE DATA WILL BE MADE PUBLICALLY AVAILABLE SO OTHER RESEARCHERS WILL BE ABLE TO BENEFIT FROM THE PERFORMED ANALYSES AND DEVELOPED TOOLS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  WILL PRESENT RESEARCH RESULTS TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND APPROPRIATE PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATIONS IN ADDITION TO LOCAL, STATE, REGIONAL AND FEDERAL AGENCIES (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO USGS, DOD, USEPA) AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. ANOTHER IMPORTANT TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER MECHANISM IN THIS PROJECT IS PROGRESSIVELY PURSUING EDUCATION OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AT UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN STEM. THIS TRANSFER MECHANISM, ALTHOUGH NOT IMMEDIATE, IS AN EXTREMELY IMPORTANT COMPONENT TO RESEARCH AND FOR DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE AND RESULTS.

THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY HAVE A COMMON INTEREST IN THE OPERATION OF A JOINT PROGRAM OF RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH WHICH HAS BEEN CONTINUOUS SINCE 2007. THIS JOINT PROGRAM IS REFERRED TO BY THE PARTIES IN PRACTICE AS THE USGS-PSU PARTNERSHIP  UPP . THIS AGREEMENT CONTINUES AND MAKES POSSIBLE COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH AND INVESTIGATIONS OF WATER SUPPLY, WATER QUALITY, HYDROLOGIC HAZARDS, AND HYDRO-BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES WHICH ARE OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE TO OREGON AND THE NATION. USGS AND PSU WILL CONTINUE AND EXPAND THEIR JOINT RESEARCH THAT FOCUSES ON THE SCIENTIFIC BASIS FOR MANAGEMENT OF WATER RESOURCES IN OREGON AND THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. THIS COLLABORATION GOES BEYOND SITE AND BASIN STUDIES AND HAS GENERATED SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATIONS THAT IMPROVE THE  STATE OF THE SCIENCE  AND FURTHER UNDERSTANDING OF HYDROLOGIC, GEOLOGIC, AND BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES. USGS AND PSU HAVE ESTABLISHED ANNUAL REPORTING AND EVALUATION MECHANISMS, AND ANNUALLY CONVENE A UPP ADVISORY GROUP COMPOSED OF USGS AND PSU SCIENTISTS THAT ADVISE AND GUIDE THE PROGRAM. IN ADDITION, PSU HAS DESIGNATED A UPP MANAGEMENT TEAM TO IMPLEMENT PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES AND PROVIDE OPERATIONAL SUPPORT.USGS EMPLOYS A WIDE RANGE OF SCIENTISTS INVOLVED IN GEOLOGIC, HYDROLOGIC, GEOPHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL, AND GEOGRAPHIC STUDIES. AS NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT NEEDS BECOME MORE COMPLEX, THE SCIENCE NEEDED TO SUPPORT THEM IS BECOMING MORE MULTIDISCIPLINARY. USGS  CAPACITY TO ENGAGE IN MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH HAS BEEN AND WILL CONTINUE TO BE EXPANDED BY COLLABORATING WITH RESEARCHERS AT PSU, WHO HAVE COMPLEMENTARY EXPERTISE AND INTERESTS. CURRENT PSU ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND FACILITIES, UNDER A COOPERATIVE PROGRAM, PROVIDE FOR JOINT RESEARCH AND CONSULTATION IN SCIENTIFIC MATTERS AND PARTICIPATION BY INTERESTED STUDENTS.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 19 23 1 18 27PROJECT TITLE EXAMINATION AND REPOPULATION OF ENDANGERED PLANTS IMPACTED BY BORDER WALL CONSTRUCTION IN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEYTHIS PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GROW THOUSANDS OF ENDANGERED PLANTS FROM SEEDS COLLECTED FROM ENDANGERED PLANTS IMPACTED BY RECENT BORDER WALL CONSTRUCTION IN SOUTH TEXAS, AND THEN TO STRATEGICALLY TRANSPLANT THE NEWLY GROWN PLANTS INTO SOUTH TEXAS HABITATS TO PRESERVE THREATENED POPULATIONS AND INCREASE THE OVERALL ABUNDANCE OF ENDANGERED PLANTS IN THE REGION.ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DOING IN PERSON SURVEYS TO MEASURE THE HEALTH OF ENDANGERED PLANT POPULATIONS THAT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY BORDER WALL CONSTRUCTION, COLLECTING SEEDS FROM HEALTHY POPULATIONS, RETROFITTING AN EXISTING PLANT NURSERY FOR PRODUCTION OF ENDANGERED PLANTS, PLANTING SEEDS AND GROWING THOUSANDS OF NEW ENDANGERED PLANTS, DOING EXPERIMENTS TO FIND WAYS TO INCREASE GERMINATION AND SURVIVAL AFTER TRANSPLANTATION OF ENDANGERED PLANTS, ASSESSING DIFFERENT HABITATS TO SELECT THE BEST PLACES TO TRANSPLANT NEWLY GROWN PLANTS, TRANSPLANTING THE NEW PLANTS INTO THE BEST HABITATS TO ACHIEVE CONSERVATION GOALS, MONITORING THE TRANSPLANTED PLANTS OVER TIME, AND DOING MORE EXPERIMENTS TO FIND WAYS TO INCREASE THE SURVIVAL AND PERFORMANCE OF TRANSPLANTED ENDANGERED PLANTS AND THE RESILIENCE OF ENDANGERED POPULATIONS.OVER FOUR YEARS, THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES  3 ANNUAL REPORTS AND 1 FINAL REPORT, 5 PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, 5 PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATIONS, NEW ENDANGERED PLANT POPULATION DESCRIPTIONS, UPDATED DISTRIBUTION MAPS FOR THE FOCAL ENDANGERED SPECIES, A SEED BANK (STOCKPILE) OF ENDANGERED PLANT SEEDS, A NEW ENDANGERED PLANT PROPAGATION FACILITY, NURSERY STOCK (THOUSANDS OF YOUNG PLANTS) OF ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES, A SEED CATALOGUE DOCUMENTING THE CONTENTS OF THE SEED BANK, SUPPLEMENTED OR NEWLY CREATED POPULATIONS OF ENDANGERED PLANTS, MONITORING DATA ON TRANSPLANTATION EFFORTS, AND A REPOPULATION DATABASE DESCRIBING ALL OF THE TRANSPLANTATION EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES MANAGING LAND OR WORKING IN THE REGION, INCLUDING U.S. FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE, U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION, AND TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WITH POPULATIONS OF ENDANGERED PLANTS  MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC INTERESTED IN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION OR SOUTH TEXAS ECOSYSTEMS  STUDENTS AND STAFF EMPLOYED THROUGH THIS PROJECT  RESEARCHERS STUDYING THESE SPECIES OR SYSTEMS  AND THE ENDANGERED SPECIES THEMSELVES.NO SUBRECIPIENTS ARE INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOWSHIPPROJECT PERIOD 03/18/2022 - 03/17/2023THIS AWARD FUNDS A GEOSCIENTIST TO SPEND A YEAR IN A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE OR COMMITTEE.- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED;THE FELLOW WILL CONTRIBUTE SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE TO A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE THROUGH CONSTITUENT MEETINGS, DRAFTING LEGISLATION AND COMMUNICATIONS. THE FELLOW WILL ALSO PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT THE POLICY PROCESS TO THE LARGER GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY, ALLOWING FOR MORE EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE TWO.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES;IN ADDITION TO BRINGING SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE TO A CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE, THE FELLOW WILL PUBLISH 2 ARTICLES INGSA TODAY AND SPEAK TO THE GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE NEXUS OF SCIENCE AND POLICY.- INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)AS THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT CONTINUES TO ADDRESS MANY ISSUES WITH GEOSCIENCE COMPONENTS, TIMELY, ACCURATE GEOSCIENCE INFORMATION AND ANALYSIS ARE VITAL TO INFORMED POLICY DECISIONS.A CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOW IS IN A UNIQUE POSITION TO PROVIDE SUCH EXPERTISE.PREVIOUS GSA-USGS CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOWS HAVE WORKED IN THE U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND SENATE ON A WIDE RANGE OF ISSUES, INCLUDING NATURAL RESOURCE POLICY, SCIENCE EDUCATION, CLIMATE CHANGE, INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND SCIENTIFIC COOPERATION, AND NATURAL HAZARD MITIGATION.THE PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM THESE CONTRIBUTIONS TO POLICY AND THE GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY BENEFITS FROM INCREASED ENGAGEMENT AND UNDERSTANDING ABOUT POLICY.PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY CHARACTER LIMITATION AS 1 PAGE OR LESS (NO MORE THAN ~4000 CHARACTERS) AND USE OF 12 PT. FONT AND TIMES NEW ROMAN IS RECOMMENDED.THE CONGRESSIONAL SCIENCE FELLOWSHIP, JOINTLY SPONSORED BY THE GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA (GSA) AND THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) SINCE 1986, CONTRIBUTES TO MORE EFFECTIVE USE OF SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL KNOWLEDGE IN GOVERNMENT BY MAKING AVAILABLE THE EXPERTISE AND SKILLS OF A GEOSCIENTIST TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. THE PRINCIPAL MISSION OF THE FELLOWSHIP IS TO BRING HIGH-QUALITY SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE AND UNBIASED INFORMATION TO THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS.FURTHERMORE, THROUGH ARTICLES, TALKS, AND SEMINARS, FELLOWS SHARE THEIR POLICY EXPERIENCE AND KNOWLEDGE WITH THE BROADER GEOSCIENCE COMMUNITY, INCREASING THE USE AND CREATION OF SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE TO ADDRESS SOCIETAL ISSUES.

THE DELTA SCIENCE PROGRAM  DSP  WAS ESTABLISHED TO BRING WORLD CLASS SCIENCE TO ALL ACTIONS WITHIN THE CALIFORNIA BAY DELTA SYSTEM INCLUDING  ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION, WATER SUPPLY RELIABILITY, WATER USE EFFICIENCY AND CONSERVATION, WATER QUALITY, AND FLOOD MANAGEMENT  E G , LEVEE STABILITY   THE MISSION OF THE SCIENCE PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE THE BEST POSSIBLE, UNBIASED SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION FOR WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL DECISION MAKING IN THE BAY DELTA SYSTEM  THAT MISSION IS CARRIED OUT THROUGH FUNDING RESEARCH, SYNTHESIZING AND COMMUNICATING SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION TO POLICYMAKERS AND DECISION MAKERS, PROMOTING INDEPENDENT SCIENTIFIC PEER REVIEW, AND COORDINATING WITH DELTA AGENCIES TO PROMOTE SCIENCE BASED ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT

GRANTEE NAME  DR  ALLISON SIMLER WILLIAMSON  DEPARTMENT OF BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES  BOISE STATE UNIVERSITYGRANT NUMBER  G22AC00600PROJECT TITLE  PREDICTING SEED ESTABLISHMENT FOLLOWING RESTORATION TREATMENTSAWARD PURPOSE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO IMPROVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES THROUGH CAREFUL AND THOROUGH TESTING OF THE DROUGHT FORECASTING TOOL, A COMPONENT OF THE LAND TREATMENT EXPLORATION TOOL DEVELOPED BY USGS  DROUGHT AND RELATED ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES ARE MAKING IT MORE DIFFICULT FOR NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PUBLIC RANGELANDS, ESPECIALLY INVOLVING SEEDING  NEW TOOLS ARE BEING DEVELOPED TO ASSIST WITH THIS PROCESS, BUT RARELY ARE THESE TOOLS ADEQUATELY TESTED AND ADDITIONAL DATA ARE OFTEN NEEDED TO BETTER PARAMETERIZE THEM  THE PROPOSED RESEARCH SUPPORTED BY THIS AWARD WILL FILL THIS ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE GAP AND ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS ON PLANT ESTABLISHMENT FOLLOWING RESTORATION SEEDING EFFORTS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  USING A DATABASE OF MORE THAN 50,000 TREATMENTS ON BLM LANDS ACROSS 14 STATES, WE WILL  1  QUANTIFY THE PREDICTIVE PERFORMANCE OF THE DROUGHT FORECASTING TOOL, AND 2  IDENTIFY CONTROLS OVER PLANT ESTABLISHMENT ASSOCIATED WITH REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION TREATMENTS IN RANGELANDS  WE WILL CONDUCT A RETROSPECTIVE INVESTIGATION OF RESTORATION SEEDING PROJECTS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELIABILITY AND UNCERTAINTY OF THE DROUGHT FORECASTING TOOL IN RELATION TO RESTORATION OUTCOMES  THEN, WE WILL DEVELOP ANALYSES THAT QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF INTERANNUAL VARIATION IN DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND OTHER GLOBAL CHANGE DRIVERS ON PLANT ESTABLISHMENT FOLLOWING SEEDING FOR SEVERAL FOCAL TAXA RELEVANT TO DRYLAND RESTORATION ACTIONS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE  1  2 3 SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLES ADDRESSING THE EXPERIMENTAL QUESTIONS DESCRIBED ABOVE  2  PUBLISHED NOVEL DATA USED IN MODELS  3  PUBLISHED METADATA  4  SCIENTIFIC PRESENTATION OF MAJOR FINDINGS  5  QUARTERLY REPORTS OF PROGRESS  1 2 PAGE MAXIMUM, BULLETED   6  FINAL REPORT  2 4 PAGES MAXIMUM, SUMMARY OF MAJOR FINDINGS AND LINKS TO JOURNAL ARTICLE S  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS AND RESTORATION SCIENTISTS WORKING IN DRYLAND ECOSYSTEMS IN THE WESTERN U S , VIA IMPROVEMENT OF THE PREDICTIVE ACCURACY OF THE LAND TREATMENT EXPLORATION TOOL AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE CONTROLS ON THE ECOLOGICAL OUTCOMES OF SEEDING TREATMENTS SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  A POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHER WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING THE STATISTICAL MODELS FOR THIS RESEARCH, PRESENTING THE FINDINGS TO PARTNERS AND AT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, PUBLISHING THE FINDINGS, AND WORKING WITH SOFTWARE DEVELOPERS TO INTEGRATE RESULTS INTO DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS  DR  SIMLER WILLIAMSON AND THE DEPARTMENT OF BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES AT BOISE STATE UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE MENTORSHIP, STATISTICAL SUPPORT, COMPUTING SUPPORT, AND GENERAL INFRASTRUCTURE  E G , OFFICE SPACE  FOR THIS POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCHER
