PLANETARY SCIENCE IS HEAVILY DEPENDENT ON COLLECTING, PROCESSING AND ARCHIVING LARGE QUANTITIES OF SPATIAL DATA TO SUPPORT A RANGE OF ACTIVITIES TO MAXIMIZE THE SCIENTIFIC RETURN FROM FEDERALLY FUNDED SPACECRAFT MISSIONS  TWO KEY COMPONENTS OF THIS WORK ARE THE DEVELOPMENT OF COMPUTATIONAL TOOLS TO SUPPORT PROCESSING PLANETARY SCIENCE DATA INTO HIGHER ORDER DATA PRODUCTS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF INFRASTRUCTURES TO MAKE DATA DISCOVERABLE AND EXPLOITABLE  KEY COMPUTATIONAL TOOLS INCLUDE DATA PROCESSING PIPELINES THAT INPUT RAW SPACECRAFT DATA AND OUTPUT DATA PRODUCTS READY FOR FURTHER POST   PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS  TO ADDRESS THE COMPLEXITY OF STORING, DISCOVERING, ACCESSING, AND UTILIZING SPATIAL DATA, THE PLANETARY RESEARCH COMMUNITY IS IN THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING CONCEPTUAL SPATIAL DATA INFRASTRUCTURE  SDI  MODELS AND CYBERINFRASTRUCTURES  THE PLANETARY SDI  PSDI  THAT IS IN THE PROCESS OF BEING DEVELOPED IS AKIN TO THE EXISTING U S  NATIONAL SPATIAL DATA INFRASTRUCTURE  NSDI  THAT IDENTIFIES SPATIAL DATA, SPATIAL DATA PRACTITIONERS, AND SPATIAL DATA INTEROPERABILITY AS ISSUES OF NATIONAL IMPORTANCE  THIS USER MOTIVATED EFFORT SERVES AS A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PSDI THAT ENABLES EFFECTIVE LONG RANGE PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT, AND EFFICIENTLY ACCESSES AND USES SPATIAL DATA FOR NASA PLANETARY SCIENCE EXPLORATION AND RESEARCH  PSDI DESCRIBES THE FACETS AND BOUNDS WITHIN WHICH SPATIAL DATA PLANNING SHOULD OCCUR, AND SEEKS TO IDENTIFY, UNDERSTAND, AND CODIFY SPATIAL DATA USAGE AND ACCESS REQUIREMENTS, TECHNOLOGIES, POLICIES, STANDARDS, AND REGULATORY ISSUES  THE PSDI FRAMEWORK DESCRIBES THE THEORETICAL BOUNDS AND SCAFFOLDING TO SUPPORT MORE FOCUSED SDIS TO ADDRESS NEAR TERM NEEDS OF FEDERAL SCIENTISTS, ENGINEERS AND MISSION PLANNERS  RECOGNITION OF THE NEED FOR A PSDI FRAMEWORK IS JUST THE INITIAL STEP IN DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE SPATIO TEMPORAL DATA EXPLOITATION STRATEGIES OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DECADES OBJECTIVESPARTICIPATE IN ALL MOON OR EUROPA SPATIAL DATA INFRASTRUCTURE  SDI  GOVERNING BOARD MEETINGS TO SUPPORT DRAFTING AND MAINTENANCE OF GOVERNMENT DOCUMENTS, DRAFTING AND MAINTENANCE OF OUTREACH DOCUMENTS, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, AND STEWARDSHIP OF ANY DATA BEING BROUGH UNDER THE GOVERNANCE OF THE SDI DELIVERY OF ANY APPROPRIATE DATA PRODUCTS, CREATED UNDER OTHER AGREEMENTS FOR THE PURPOSES OF SUPPORTING THE PLANETARY SCIENCE COMMUNITY, TO AN SDI COMPLIANT DATA PROVIDER

PROJECT TITLE LONG LEAD CROP YIELD FORECASTING AND CROP CONDITION OUTLOOKS IN FEWS NET COUNTRIES WITH LIMITED CROP YIELD OBSERVATIONSPROJECT PERIOD 9 21 2022 9 20 2025FOOD INSECURITY IS ON AN UNPRECEDENTED RISE GLOBALLY  ACCORDING TO THE U S  AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT S  USAID  ESTIMATES FOR 2022, 107 MILLION PEOPLE ACROSS 29 COUNTRIES WILL NEED EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE  BETTER IDENTIFICATION AND EARLIER WARNING OF CONDITIONS LEADING TO FOOD INSECURITY IS CRITICAL TO REDUCE ITS IMPACTS ON LIVES AND LIVELIHOODS  AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION OUTLOOKS  E G  PROJECTIONS OF AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION BEING AVERAGE, ABOVE AVERAGE OR BELOW AVERAGE  ARE ONE OF THE KEY COMPONENTS IN FOOD INSECURITY EARLY WARNING  HERE, PROPOSE TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURAL OUTLOOKS SEVERAL MONTHS BEFORE THE CROP HARVEST, ESPECIALLY IN COUNTRIES WITH LIMITED TO NO CROP YIELD DATA  WILL DO THIS THROUGH TWO PRIMARY GOALS   I  ADVANCE THE LEAD TIME FOR CROP YIELD FORECASTING AND CROP CONDITION OUTLOOKS BY USING AGROCLIMATIC FORECASTS AS PREDICTORS IN MACHINE LEARNING MODELS, AND  II  EXPAND THE FOCUS OF CURRENT FORECAST MODELS TO INCLUDE FAMINE EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS NETWORK S  FEWS NET  MONITORING COUNTRIES WHERE SUB NATIONAL CROP YIELD DATA ARE EITHER NON EXISTENT OR SEVERELY LIMITED TO THE POINT THAT MACHINE LEARNING METHODS CANNOT BE IMPLEMENTED  WILL ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS THROUGH TWO PRIMARY ACTIVITIES   I  INCREASE THE LEAD TIME OF CROP FORECASTS USING CLIMATE AND HYDROLOGIC FORECASTS  E G  FORECASTS OF RAINFALL, TEMPERATURE, SOIL MOISTURE  AS PREDICTORS, AND  II  EXPERIMENT WITH THE  AREA OF APPLICABILITY   AOA  APPROACH TO PROVIDE CROP YIELD FORECASTS IN COUNTRIES WITH LIMITED TO NO AGRICULTURAL OBSERVATIONS  THE BASIC PREMISE OF THE AOA APPROACH IS TO EXAMINE WHETHER A FORECAST MODEL DEVELOPED FOR ONE REGION CAN BE APPLIED TO A SIMILAR REGION WHERE YIELDS ARE NOT OBSERVED  KEY DELIVERABLE OF THIS PROPOSED WORK INCLUDE RESEARCH ADVANCEMENT  I  IN THE APPLICATION OF CLIMATE AND HYDROLOGIC FORECASTS TO PROVIDE CROP YIELD FORECASTS EARLIER IN THE SEASON  II  IN PROVIDING SKILLFUL CROP YIELD FORECASTS INTO COUNTRIES WITH LIMITED CROP YIELD DATA,  III  LONG TERM DATASETS TO ALLOW FOR HISTORICAL VALIDATION OF THE PROPOSED METHODS AND CROP YIELD FORECASTS SKILL ASSESSMENT,  IV  4 TO 5 PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS WHICH DOCUMENT THE RESEARCH ADVANCEMENTS AND DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS TO A BROADER COMMUNITY  THE RESEARCH ADVANCEMENTS ARE EXPECTED TO EXPAND THE CAPACITY OF USGS S EARTH RESOURCES OBSERVATION AND SCIENCE  EROS  CENTER IN SUPPORTING FEWS NET S FOOD SECURITY OUTLOOK SCENARIOS GENERATION PROCESS  IMPROVING THE SCENARIO GENERATION PROCESS WILL LEAD TO BOTH MORE ACCURATE AND EARLIER ESTIMATES OF FOOD INSECURITY AND PROVIDING ADDITIONAL CRITICAL TIME NEEDED FOR LAUNCHING FAMINE PREVENTION RESPONSES BY GOVERNMENTS AND DONOR AGENCIES

STREAM DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE REGIMES ARE BEING ALTERED BY THE CHANGING CLIMATE  DOCUMENTING THESE CHANGES ON THE COMMUNITY LEVEL IS CHALLENGING WITHOUT COMMUNITY PARTNERS THAT ARE TRAINED IN PROPER DATA COLLECTION TECHNIQUES  THE USGS JUNEAU FIELD OFFICE IS COLLABORATING WITH THE YAKUTAT TLINGIT TRIBE  YTT , THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA TRIBAL OCEAN RESEARCH  SEATOR  NETWORK, AND THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA WATERSHED COALITION  SAWC  TO INTEGRATE STREAM DISCHARGE AND STREAM TEMPERATURE MONITORING INTO ONGOING TRIBALLY LED CLIMATE ADAPTATION, WATER QUALITY, AND SUBSISTENCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PROJECTS  STREAM DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE DATA IS LIMITED IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA AND IMPROVING THE SPATIAL COVERAGE OF DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE DATA WOULD BE MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL TO USGS AND TRIBAL PARTNERS ACROSS THE REGION  THE ACTIONABLE SCIENCE OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE  1  ENHANCED CAPACITY FOR YTT STAFF AND CONTINUED PARTNERSHIP WITH USGS STAFF,  2  TRAINING IN STREAM DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE MONITORING PROTOCOLS FOR AT LEAST 17 REGIONAL TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS THROUGH THE SEATOR AND SAWC NETWORKS,  3  INCREASED SPATIAL COVERAGE OF STREAM DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE DATA IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA, AND  4  TRIBALLY LED, USGS ASSISTED, MONITORING EFFORTS TO INFLUENCE TRIBAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING, WATER QUALITY MONITORING, AND SUBSISTENCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT EFFORTS STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT APPROACH AND TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER  THE USGS JUNEAU FIELD OFFICE WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH YTT ENVIRONMENTAL STAFF TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND ASSISTANCE ON THE USGS STREAM DISCHARGE PROTOCOL FOR WADE ABLE STREAMS AND TEMPERATURE MONITORING FOLLOWING THE SAWC PROTOCOL FOR THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA STREAM TEMPERATURE MONITORING NETWORKTHE OBJECTIVE OF OUR PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO BUILD UPON THE EXISTING YTT WATER QUALITY MONITORING PROGRAM BY INTEGRATING STREAM DISCHARGE AND TEMPERATURE MONITORING METHODS THAT WILL BE ADDED TO THE BASELINE DATASET USED TO PLAN FOR CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS

PROJECT TITLE  PREVENTING THE EXTINCTION OF HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRDSPROJECT DATES  DATE OF AWARD AND 5 YEARS THEREAFTERAWARD PURPOSE NATIVE HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRDS FACE AN EXTINCTION CRISIS AND SEVERAL SPECIES ARE PREDICTED TO SUFFER EXTINCTION WITHIN A DECADE WITHOUT RAPID AND INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS  RESOURCE MANAGERS SUCH AS NPS AND USFWS NEED TIMELY AND RELEVANT RESEARCH RESULTS TO HELP INFORM EFFORTS TO AVOID EXTINCTION  THESE EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON DEPLOYMENT OF INCOMPATIBLE INSECT TECHNIQUE, CAPTIVE BREEDING, TRANSLOCATION, AND OR DEVELOPING NEXT GENERATION TOOLS FOR CONTROLLING MOSQUITOES AND INCREASING BIRD RESISTANCE TO MALARIA  THE HAWAII COOPERATIVE STUDIES UNIT  HCSU  AT UH HILO HAS STAFF WITH PROVEN EXPERTISE IN THESE AREAS AND HAS THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE RAPID AND FLEXIBLE RECRUITMENT OF QUALIFIED FIELD AND LAB PERSONNEL IN RESPONSE TO FLUCTUATING FUNDING LEVELS  THIS AGREEMENT PROPOSES TO CONTINUE THE STRONG COLLABORATION BETWEEN PIERC AND HCSU TO PURSUE RESEARCH IN SUPPORT OF THIS BIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY, WHICH HAS RECEIVED ATTENTION AT THE HIGHEST LEVELS OF DOI THIS IS A MULTI AGENCY INITIATIVE LED BY USFWS, NPS, USGS, AND DOI OFFICE OF NATIVE HAWAIIAN RELATIONS

PROJECT TITLE  RESTORING DEGRADED HABITATS AND BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON PACIFIC ISLANDSPROJECT DATES  DATE OF AWARD AND 5 YEARS THEREAFTERAWARD PURPOSE PROTECTION OF BIODIVERSITY AND ECOLOGICAL SERVICES ARE HIGH PRIORITIES FOR LAND MANAGERS IN HAWAI I AND THE U S  AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS  MANY OF THESE LANDS HAVE BEEN DEGRADED BY CLEARING FOR AGRICULTURE AND RANCHING, INVASIVE SPECIES ARE RAMPANT, AND CLIMATE CHANGE MAY FURTHER DEGRADE ECOSYSTEMS VIA SEA LEVEL RISE, INCREASED TYPHOON AND FIRE FREQUENCY, AND MORE SEVERE DROUGHT  THESE STRESSORS IMPACT CULTURAL AND COMMUNITY USES, DECREASE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND PREVENT THE RECOVERY AND RESTORATION OF SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN  HAWAII ALREADY HAS THE HIGHEST NUMBER OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED  TAND E  SPECIES AND INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE U S  AND INCREASING NUMBERS OF SPECIES ARE BEING ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  LISTED IN THE U S  PACIFIC TERRITORIES  GIVEN THE ISOLATION OF HAWAI I AND PACIFIC ISLANDS, THE RESILIENCE OF COMMUNITIES OF HAWAI I AND THE PACIFIC IS TIGHTLY LINKED WITH THE HEALTH OF ISLAND RESOURCES THE PRIMARY PARTNERS ARE AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF SPECIES AND TERRESTRIAL LANDSCAPES ON PACIFIC ISLANDS  THIS INCLUDES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , NATIONAL PARK SERVICE  NPS , DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE  DOD , HAWAII STATE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE, GUAM DIVISION OF AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANAS DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND AMERICAN SAMOA DEPARTMENT OF MARINE AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES  THESE AGENCIES WORK WITH THE USGS TO DEVELOP PROJECT IDEAS, COLLABORATE ON FIELD AND LAB WORK, AND ANALYZE INTERPRET ECOLOGICAL DATA FOR RESOURCES UNDER THEIR STEWARDSHIP  THESE PARTNERS TYPICALLY PROVIDE MORE THAN 50  OF THE FUNDING FOR THESE PROJECTS

PROJECT TITLE  DETERMINING FIELD PERFORMANCE IN NEW MEXICO NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS RESULTING FROM EMERGING TECHNIQUES FOR USE IN RESTORING AMERICA S RANGELANDSPROJECT DATES  DATE OF AWARD AND 4 YEARS THEREAFTERAWARD PURPOSE PLANT SPECIES HAVE BEEN ARTIFICIALLY SELECTED, BRED, OR HYBRIDIZED BY HUMANS FOR TENS OF THOUSANDS OF YEARS  SINCE THE 1930S, RANGELAND SPECIES, PARTICULARLY NATIVE GRASSES, HAVE BEEN SELECTED TO OBTAIN A DESIRED TRAIT OR SUITE OF TRAITS TO ENHANCE GERMINATION, ESTABLISHMENT, AND PRODUCTION  THE USDA HAS PRODUCED MORE THAN 500 CULTIVARS THAT ARE USED TO IMPROVE RANGELAND PASTURES MANAGED FOR FORAGE  TRADITIONALLY, CULTIVARS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED TO MEET DESIRED STANDARDS OF UNIFORMITY IN TRAITS SUCH AS SEED GERMINATION RATES, PLANT PRODUCTION, OR FLOWERING AND SEED DEVELOPMENT  TO ACHIEVE ADEQUATE LEVELS OF UNIFORMITY, GENETIC DIVERSITY CAN BE LOST DURING THE DEVELOPMENT PROCESS  THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ADDRESS FOUNDATIONAL QUESTIONS OF HOW RANGELAND FUNCTION CAN BE MAINTAINED THROUGH THE USE OF APPROPRIATE RESTORATION PLANT MATERIALS  IN ORDER TO YIELD AN INTEGRATED, MECHANISTIC PICTURE OF THE EFFECTS TRADITIONAL AND EMERGING PLANT MATERIALS HAVE ON RANGELAND FUNCTION, UNDERSTANDING GENOMIC VARIABILITY IN PLOIDY LEVELS WITHIN AND BETWEEN WILD AND CULTIVATED POPULATIONS IS NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND CRITICAL IMPLICATIONS FOR FORAGE AND THE HOST OF OTHER ECOLOGICAL SERVICES RANGELANDS PROVIDE  INDEED, RANGELANDS ARE ONE OF THE LARGEST PROVIDERS OF AGRO ECOLOGICAL SERVICES IN THE U S , MAKING UP CA  1 3 OF OUR TOTAL NATIONAL LAND AREA, OCCURRING MOSTLY IN THE ARID AND SEMIARID WESTERN U S WE SEEK TO ADDRESS THESE MANAGEMENT CONCERNS BY USING SEED SOURCES AND MATERIALS CURRENTLY BEING SOURCED BY THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT FROM WILD POPULATIONS AS WELL AS THOSE BEING DEVELOPED BY BLM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH RELATED ENTITIES FOR USE IN RESTORATION THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHWEST  THIS WORK WILL IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGEMENT OPTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS FOR USE IN RESTORING PUBLIC LANDS MANAGED BY BLM AND THE US FOREST SERVICE, AND RELATED INSTITUTIONS WORKING TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE DEGRADED RANGELANDS  IN PARTICULAR, WE WILL UNDERTAKE A SET OF TARGETED EXPERIMENTS TO TEST NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS THAT FACILITATE ECOSYSTEM RECOVERY FROM GRAZING IMPACTS  THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL BE DIRECTLY INCORPORATED INTO BLM AND FOREST SERVICE NATIVE PLANT AND RESTORATION MANAGEMENT PLANS THROUGH THE PROJECT S ROBUST STAKEHOLDER COLLABORATION AND ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY

THE HOST OF OTHER ECOLOGICAL SERVICES RANGELANDS PROVIDE  INDEED, RANGELANDS ARE ONE OF THE LARGEST PROVIDERS OF AGRO ECOLOGICAL SERVICES IN THE U S , MAKING UP CA  1 3 OF OUR TOTAL NATIONAL LAND AREA, OCCURRING MOSTLY IN THE ARID AND SEMIARID WESTERN U S  THESE RANGELAND ECOSYSTEMS OFFER MYRIAD IMPORTANT FUNCTIONS SUPPLYING SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNTS OF FOOD TO FEED OUR POPULATION, FORAGE FOR LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE, WATERSHEDS FOR RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES, AND ACTING AS BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOTS  ACCORDINGLY, THERE IS SUBSTANTIAL INTEREST IN RESTORING RANGELANDS FOLLOWING DEGRADATION AND IN THE FACE OF CHANGE ADDITIONAL PARTNERS INCLUDE THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA AND NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY, WHICH ARE COLLABORATING ON RESEARCH, AND THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT AND US FOREST SERVICE ARE BENEFITING STAKEHOLDERS WHO WILL PROVIDE IN KIND CONSULTATION ON RESEARCH PROGRESS AND OUTCOMES

PROJECT TITLE DEVELOPMENT OF POINT OF USE INVASIVE SPECIES EDNA SCREENING APPROACHESPROJECT PERIOD  9 15 22 9 14 24INVASIVE SPECIES ARE ECOLOGICALLY DAMAGING, ECONOMICALLY COSTLY, AND INCREASINGLY PREVALENT THROUGHOUT THE WORLD  ERADICATING INVASIVE SPECIES IS NOTORIOUSLY DIFFICULT  THEREFORE, PREVENTING THEIR INTRODUCTION IS CRITICAL TO CONTROL THEIR SPREAD  MANY INVASIVE SPECIES ORIGINATE VIA TRADE AND COMMERCE, SUCH AS THROUGH THE BALLAST WATER OF SHIPPING VESSELS OR THROUGH THE FOOD TRADE  ENABLING INVASIVE SPECIES SURVEILLANCE AT DISCRETE POINTS OF ENTRY IS A PROMISING AVENUE TO DETECTING AND PREVENTING NEW INVASIONS BEFORE THEY BEGIN  ENVIRONMENTAL  E DNA PROVIDES A MEANS OF DETECTING SPECIES THROUGH THEIR SHED DNA THAT MAY BE PRESENT IN WATER, ON VARIOUS SUBSTRATES, OR IN THE AIR  RECENTLY DEVELOPED TECHNIQUES HAVE SHOWN PROMISE FOR POINT OF USE EDNA BASED MONITORING  HOWEVER, THESE METHODS GENERALLY REQUIRE SAMPLE PROCESSING TECHNIQUES THAT ARE NOT FEASIBLE IN MOST NON LABORATORY SETTINGS  THROUGH THIS RESEARCH PROJECT, WILL IMPROVE THE EASE OF USE FOR THESE EMERGING EDNA SCREENING APPROACHES FOR INVASIVE SPECIES MONITORING USING A TWO STEP RESEARCH PROCESS  FIRST, WILL PERFORM A THOROUGH LITERATURE REVIEW ACROSS DIVERSE FIELDS TO IDENTIFY ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES THAT WILL STREAMLINE THE METHOD S IMPLEMENTATION  SECONDLY, WILL WORK WITH END USER STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP AND VALIDATE NEWLY DEVELOPED TECHNIQUES  WITH GOALS DIRECTED TOWARD END USER EASE OF USE, FREQUENT COMMUNICATION WITH OUR RESEARCH STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT THE LIFESPAN OF THE PROJECT WILL BE CRITICAL TO ITS SUCCESS  TO THAT END, PORT AND CUSTOMS AGENCY PERSONNEL WILL BE ENGAGED TO SHARE RESEARCH PLANS AND FINDINGS AT VARIOUS PHASES OF THE PROJECT, INCLUDING DURING STUDY DESIGN, FOLLOWING COLLECTION OF INITIAL RESULTS, AND UPON COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT  IN ADDITION TO THE NEWLY DEVELOPED METHODS THIS RESEARCH WILL ESTABLISH, DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES SUCH AS THE NORTH AMERICAN INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATION S ANNUAL MEETING AND PUBLICATIONS IN AT LEAST TWO PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS THAT WILL FOCUS ON THE LITERATURE REVIEW AND THE DEVELOPED EDNA DETECTION PROTOCOLS

PROJECT TITLE DWH GULF OF MEXICO MESOPHOTIC AND DEEP BENTHIC COMMUNITY RESTORATION  SEDIMENT GEOCHEMICAL ANDMICROBIAL INDICATORS OF HABITAT QUALITYPROJECT PERIOD  9 21 22 9 20 27THIS WORK BUILDS ON OUR PREVIOUS STUDIES IN THE GULF OF MEXICO IN AREAS IMPACTED BY THE DWH OIL WELL BLOWOUT  DURING THIS PROJECT, WILL DOCUMENT BIOGEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURES AND PATTERNS OF MICROBIAL ACTIVITY IN SEDIMENTS FROM HABITATS THAT WERE IMPACTED BY THE DWH OIL SPILL  WILL COMPARE THESE DATA TO SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM DWH IMPACTED SITES USING MULTIPLE CORER CORES, ROV PUSH CORES AND HOV PUSH CORES  WILL ASSESS CHANGES OVER TIME AND HOW MICROBIAL ACTIVITY AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL DYNAMICS INTERACT TO IMPACT ANIMAL POPULATIONS IN A COMPREHENSIVE MANNER THE GOALS OF THE WORK ARE TO QUANTIFY BIOGEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURES AND MICROBIAL ACTIVITY IN SEDIMENT SAMPLES IN PARALLEL WITH SAMPLES FOR MEIOFAUNAL COMMUNITY METRICS IN AREAS ADJACENT TO IMPACTED AND REFERENCE DEEP SEA SOFT SEDIMENTS  TO QUANTIFY BIOGEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURES AND MICROBIAL ACTIVITY IN PARALLEL WITH SAMPLES FOR MEIOFAUNAL COMMUNITY METRICS IN AREAS ADJACENT TO IMPACTED AND REFERENCE DEEP SEA CORALS  TO ASSESS HOW TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL VARIABILITY OF KEY BIOGEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURES AND MICROBIAL ACTIVITY MEASUREMENTS RELATES TO OBSERVED CHANGES IN MEIOFAUNAL BENTHOS  TO SYNTHESIZE BIOGEOCHEMICAL DATASETS IN COLLABORATION WITH USGS WARC TO ESTIMATE RESPONSE TRAJECTORIES OF COMMUNITIES IMPACTED BY THE DWH OIL SPILL  AND, TO COORDINATE WITH ACADEMIC AND FEDERAL PARTNERS, DOI  USGS, BOEM AND NOAA, TO GENERATE DATA THAT INFORMS RESOURCE MANAGEMENT BIOGEOCHEMICAL DATA ARE CRITICAL FOR UNDERSTANDING AND PREDICTING PATTERNS IN MEIOFAUNAL ABUNDANCE  PARTNERS WILL QUANTIFY THE ABUNDANCE, DIVERSITY, TAXA RICHNESS, AND SPECIES ABUNDANCE RATIOS OF DEEP SEA MEIOFAUNAL COMMUNITIES IN IMPACTED AND CONTROL  REFERENCE SITES  SOFT SEDIMENT SITES AND IMPACTED AND CONTROL  REFERENCE SITES  CORAL SITES  WILL GENERATE A RICH DATA SETS DESCRIBING BIOGEOCHEMISTRY AND MICROBIAL ACTIVITY IN PARALLEL SAMPLES  SUCH DATA ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DEVELOPING A ROBUST UNDERSTANDING OF HOW BIOGEOCHEMICAL FACTORS IMPACT MEIOFAUNAL ABUNDANCE  FURTHERMORE, MICROBIAL ACTIVITY IN SEDIMENTS IS A PRIMARY DRIVER OF BIOGEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURES  MICROORGANISMS OXIDIZE ORGANIC MATTER, EFFECTIVELY REMINERALIZING INORGANIC BUILDING BLOCKS, LIKE DISSOLVED INORGANIC CARBON, AMMONIUM, AND PHOSPHATE, FROM COMPLEX ORGANIC STRUCTURES  MICROBIAL METABOLISM ALSO GENERATES TERMINAL METABOLITES, LIKE THE HYDROGEN SULFIDE GENERATED DURING SULFATE REDUCTION, THAT CAN SHAPE AND LIMIT ANIMAL POPULATIONS  A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF SEDIMENT BIOGEOCHEMISTRY AND PATTERNS OF MICROBIAL ACTIVITY ARE REQUIRED TO DEVELOP A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE FACTORS THAT DRIVE PATTERNS OF ANIMAL COMMUNITY COMPOSITION

PROJECT TITLE LONG TERM COMMUNITY RECOVERY AND DYNAMICS OF DEEP SEA SOFT SEDIMENT METAZOAN MEIOFAUNA AFTER THE DEEPWATER HORIZON OIL SPILL  A RESTORATION IN PLACE STRATEGYPROJECT PERIOD  9 19 22 9 18 27THE DEEPWATER HORIZON  DWH  INCIDENT IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO  GOM  OCCURRED ON APRIL 20, 2010 AT A WATER DEPTH OF 1525 METERS, IN MISSISSIPPI CANYON BLOCK 252, RELEASING AN ESTIMATED 3 19 MILLION BARRELS OF OIL OVER THE FOLLOWING 87 DAYS  AS PART OF THE NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT  NRDA  PROCESS, A STUDY COMPRISING THREE FIELD SURVEYS  2010, 2011, AND 2014  WAS CONDUCTED TO IDENTIFY EFFECTS OF THE SPILL ON THE DEEP SEA, SOFT BOTTOM BENTHOS AND SEDIMENT QUALITY  RESULTS REVEALED A ZONE OF SEVERE TO MODERATE IMPACTS ON DEEP SEA BIODIVERSITY LINKED TO THE DWH WELLHEAD THAT PERSISTED THROUGH 2014 AN OBVIOUS RESTORATION GOAL FOR THE DEEP SEA IS TO RETURN BIODIVERSITY AND OTHER KEY BENTHIC  OCEAN BOTTOM  ATTRIBUTES TO NORMAL REFERENCE RANGE CONDITIONS  HOWEVER, DIRECT REMEDIATION OF DEEP SEA HABITAT IS LOGISTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE DUE TO THE EXTREME DEPTHS AND VAST AREA  THIS RESTORE PROJECT WILL ASSESS NATURAL LONG TERM MEIOFAUNA COMMUNITY RECOVERY OVER TIME, AND THREE CHALLENGES EXIST CONSIDERING DEEP SEA COMMUNITY STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION   1  RATES OF CHANGE IN THE DEEP SEA ARE VERY SLOW,  2  KNOW VERY LITTLE ABOUT HOW ANIMAL COMMUNITY BIODIVERSITY CHANGES OVER TIME IN THE DEEP SEA GULF OF MEXICO, AND  3  THE SPATIAL SCALE OF DEEP SEA BIODIVERSITY VARIATION IN THE GULF OF MEXICO VARIES DRAMATICALLY RELATIVE TO DEPTH, PROXIMITY TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER, OCEAN BOTTOM FEATURES, AND OVERLYING WATER COLUMN PROCESSES  UNTIL UNDERSTAND BASIC TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL DYNAMICS, IT WILL BE DIFFICULT, IF NOT IMPOSSIBLE, TO ASCERTAIN IF CHANGE IS A RESULT OF RECOVERY, SEASONAL DYNAMICS, OR YEAR TO YEAR VARIABILITY  EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO 1  PROVIDE A LONG TERM ASSESSMENT OF DEEP SEA BENTHIC MEIOFAUNA COMMUNITY RECOVERY AT PREVIOUSLY DOCUMENTED  IMPACTED  SITES, CONTINUING THE TIME SERIES THAT WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2010  2  PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY TO INVESTIGATE NATURAL ANNUAL OR SEASONAL TEMPORAL COMMUNITY DYNAMICS  AT UNIMPACTED SITES  IN THE DEEP GULF OF MEXICO, AN IMPORTANT ASPECT OF DEEP SEA ECOLOGY THAT IS PRESENTLY NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD  AND 3  SOFT SEDIMENT COMMUNITIES NEAR DEEP WATER CORALS WILL BE INVESTIGATED TO ASSESS RECOVERY OF THESE COMMUNITIES AND COMPARE THEIR COMMUNITY STRUCTURE TO SOFT SEDIMENT COMMUNITIES FAR FROM CORAL HABITATS  IN TOTAL, 116 STATIONS WILL BE SAMPLED DURING EACH OF THREE FIELD SEASONS IN 2022, 2023, AND 2025, AND AN ADDITIONAL 80 STATIONS WILL BE SAMPLED BY ROV ADJACENT TO DEEP WATER CORAL COMMUNITIES IN THESE SAME YEARS THIS LONG TERM RESTORE RESEARCH PROGRAM WILL HAVE GREAT VALUE FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS OF SCIENTISTS AND OTHERS  PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE RAW DATA, ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND QUANTITATIVE  RESTORATION TARGETS  FOR DETERMINING RECOVERY OF GULF OF MEXICO DEEP BENTHIC RESOURCES FROM DWH RELATED IMPACTS AND SIMILAR EVENTS IN THE FUTURE  THERE WILL BE UNDERGRAD, GRADUATE, AND POST DOC MEMBERS OF THE PROJECT TEAM THAT WILL BE EDUCATED AND ADVANCE THEIR CAREERS  WHERE POSSIBLE, THERE WILL ALSO BE OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE BROADER PUBLIC AND K 12 COMMUNITY  DR  BAGULEY S FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA RENO WILL BE THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND PRIMARY BENEFICIARY OF THIS GRANT  DR  BAGULEY S LAB WILL COLLECT FIELD SAMPLES, PROCESS SAMPLES IN THE LABORATORY AND PRODUCE THE MAJORITY OF THE MEIOFAUNA DEEP SEA COMMUNITY DATA FOR THIS PROJECT  A SUB BENEFICIARY FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE DR  HYUN WOO BANG OF MOKWON UNIVERSITY IN KOREA  DR  BANG S RESEARCH GROUP WILL PROVIDE HARPACTICOID COPEPOD FAMILY IDENTIFICATIONS AND WILL RECEIVE A SUBCONTRACT FROM THIS GRANT

PROJECT TITLE QUATERNARY GEOLOGY AND MINEABLE RESOURCES DERIVATIVE MAPPINGPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  9 19 2022 THROUGH 9 18 2023THIS AWARD WILL FUND GEOLOGIC MAPPING TO BE PERFORMED BY THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PRODUCE TWO NEW MAP PRODUCTS THAT ALIGN WITH THE UNITES STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, NATIONAL COOPERATIVE GEOLOGIC MAPPING PROGRAM S LONG TERM GOALS THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IS PROPOSING QUATERNARY GEOLOGY MAPPING IN PICKAWAY COUNTY, OHIO AND STATEWIDE MINEABILITY DERIVATIVE MAPPING  THESE PROJECTS ARE CONTINUATIONS OF IN PROGRESS FY2021 QUATERNARY GEOLOGY MAPPING IN ADJACENT FAYETTE COUNTY, OHIO, AND STATEWIDE SURFICIAL GEOLOGY DATABASE COMPILATION, RESPECTIVELY  THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING TO COLLECT NEW GEOLOGIC FIELD DATA IN PICKAWAY COUNTY, INCLUDING COLLECTING 12 SAMPLES FOR RADIOCARBON DATING AND 4 SAMPLES FOR OPTICALLY STIMULATED LUMINESCENCE DATING  GEOLOGISTS WILL INCORPORATE NEW FIELD DATA AND PREVIOUS MAPPING TO DELINEATE QUATERNARY GEOLOGY UNITS USING THE FRAMEWORK ESTABLISHED BY MAPPING ADJACENT COUNTIES  THIS COOPERATIVE AGREE ALSO PROVIDES FUNDING TO DERIVE MINEABILITY MAPS OF COMMON NATURAL RESOURCES FOUND ACROSS THE STATE OF OHIO  GEOLOGISTS WILL CLASSIFY AND DEFINE HOW MINEABLE A RESOURCE IS BASED ON INDUSTRY STANDARDS AND THE LOCALIZED GEOLOGY, DERIVED FROM PREVIOUS SURFICIAL GEOLOGY MAPPING UPON COMPLETION OF THESE TWO DISTINCT MAPPING PROJECTS, A COUNTY SCALE  1 62,500  QUATERNARY GEOLOGY MAP CARTOGRAPHIC AND MAPPING SCHEMA STANDARDS THE CITIZENS OF PICKAWAY COUNTY AND THE ENTIRE STATE ARE THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THESE MAPPING PRODUCTS  CITIZENS OF PICKAWAY COUNTY WITHDRAW THEIR DRINKING WATER FROM QUATERNARY AGED GROUNDWATER AQUIFERS  A BETTER DELINEATION OF THE WATER BEARING QUATERNARY GEOLOGY UNITS WILL PROVIDE GREATER INSIGHT INTO THE PRESENT AND FUTURE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT OF THESE GROUNDWATER RESOURCES  MINEABILITY MAPS OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL BENEFIT THE CITIZENS OF OHIO BY IDENTIFYING AREAS OF WHERE RESOURCES CAN BE RECOVERED ECONOMICALLY  THESE AGGREGATE AND SAND AND GRAVEL RESOURCES ARE MULTI BILLION DOLLAR INDUSTRIES IN OHIO AND PROVIDE THE NECESSARY MATERIALS TO IMPROVE CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE LIKE ROADS, BRIDGES, BUILDING FOUNDATIONS, PIPELINES, ELECTRIC SUBSTATIONS, DAMS, AND MORE  THESE MAPS CAN BE USED AS A TOOL FOR CITIZENS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS TO MAKE IMPORTANT ZONING DECISIONS

THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY SPATIAL HOTSPOTS OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE  CWD  TRANSMISSION ASSOCIATED WITH THE MULE DEER AND WHITE TAILED DEER IN THE GREATER WIND RIVER AREA IN WYOMING  IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS A NEW CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE  CWD  DIAGNOSTIC METHOD THAT WOULD FACILITATE ANTE MORTEM TESTING ON RESEARCH PROJECTS CWD IS A WILDLIFE DISEASE OF IMPORTANT ECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND ECOLOGICAL CONCERN  THIS INVARIABLY FATAL, PRION BASED ENCEPHALOPATHY IS ENZOOTIC IN SOUTHEASTERN WYOMING AND HAS NOW BEEN DETECTED IN MOST MULE DEER HUNT UNITS STATEWIDE  ESTIMATED PREVALENCE VARIES GREATLY ACROSS THE STATE BUT IS GENERALLY HIGHEST IN REGIONS WHERE CWD IS LONG ESTABLISHED  RECENT SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS, HOWEVER, HAVE IDENTIFIED HUNT UNITS WHERE CWD HAS ONLY RECENTLY BEEN DETECTED BUT IS MARKEDLY HIGHER IN PREVALENCE  STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE REVEALED 60  PREVALENCE IN ADULT MULE DEER IN THE GREATER WIND RIVER REGION IN 2019, WHICH WAS CONFIRMED DURING SURVEILLANCE IN 2020 AND 2021  THIS REGION IS UNDER MANAGEMENT PURVIEW OF BOTH THE WIND RIVER RESERVATION  WIND RIVER INTERTRIBAL COUNCIL  AND THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT  WGFD   THE HIGH PREVALENCE HAS PROMPTED BOTH GROUPS TO IMPROVE THE EPIDEMIOLOGICAL UNDERSTANDING OF CWD IN THE AREA, ESPECIALLY REGARDING THE ECOLOGY AND BEHAVIOR OF THE IMPACTED POPULATIONS DUE TO THE POTENTIAL FOR A SEVERE MULE DEER POPULATION DECLINE IN THE REGION

PROJECT TITLEDEVELOPING, IMPLEMENTING, AND IMPROVING MODELS AND METHODS TO ACCURATELY REPRESENT WATER AND SUBSURFACE RESOURCES RELEVANT FOR PREDICTING WATER AVAILABILITY AND USE CONCERNS PROJECT PERIOD10 01 2022   09 30 2023AWARD PURPOSETHE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS PART OF A LARGER PROJECT AIMED AT DEVELOPING AN ENTERPRISE ECOSYSTEM OF INTEGRATED AND INTEROPERABLE MODELS AND OR MODEL CODES THAT, WHEN LINKED THROUGH ONE OR MORE MODEL COUPLING FRAMEWORKS, PROVIDE A FLEXIBLE REPRESENTATION OF WATER AVAILABILITY SUITABLE FOR ADDRESSING WMA PROGRAMMATIC NEEDS, BROADER MODELING NEEDS, AND OR EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDER, PARTNER, AND AGENCY NEEDS  IMPLEMENTED MODELS IN THE ECOSYSTEM WILL BE CONSIDERED THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE FOR EACH RESPECTIVE WATER AVAILABILITY COMPONENT INCLUDING THE STATES OF THE WATER CYCLE, WATER USES, WATER QUALITY CONSTITUENTS, AND HYDROECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS MODFLOW6 IS PROVIDING THE INITIAL FRAMEWORK WHICH THE ECOSYSTEM OF CODES MODELS WILL BE COUPLED WITH, AND INTIMATE KNOWLEDGE OF THIS CODE IS IMPERATIVE  PARALLELIZATION SOLUTIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED USING INTEROPERABLE COMPONENTS AND MODERN SOFTWARE ENGINEERING TECHNIQUES AS PART OF THIS PROJECT TO ENHANCE THE EXECUTION TIME OF EXISTING NUMERICAL MODELS PROBLEMS AND PROVIDE AN ABILITY TO COMPUTE LARGER AND MORE RESOURCE INTENSIVE PROBLEMS  THESE SOFTWARE SOLUTIONS WILL BE DOCUMENTED AND IMPLEMENTED THAT INEVITABLY WILL IMPROVE MODELS AND METHODS THAT ACCURATELY AND RAPIDLY REPRESENT ADVANCED, CONSISTENT APPROACHES FOR FORECASTING HYDROLOGIC STATES, FLUXES, AND OUTCOMES FOR WATER AVAILABILITY TO IMPROVE PREDICTIONS OF WATER AVAILABILITY AT A RANGE OF TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL SCALES  ADDITIONALLY, THE CAPACITY OF AN INTEROPERABLE DESIGN ALLOWS MODELS OF FEDERAL, ACADEMIC, NON GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO CONNECT AND INTEGRATE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDIN PARTICULAR, THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES ARE FORESEEN 1  PROVIDE A SENIOR LEVEL SOFTWARE ARCHITECT FAMILIAR WITH ENTERPRISE CAPACITY SOFTWARE  MODFLOW 6  DEVELOPMENT TO AID WITH DESIGN, REVIEW ONGOING DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS, AND PROVIDE MENTORSHIP TO USGS AND DELTARES TEAM MEMBERS 2  CONTINUED COLLABORATIVE PARALLEL DEVELOPMENT A  FINALIZE PARALLELIZATION OF INTERFACE MODEL B  USE PETSC AS INITIAL PARALLEL SOLVER C  DOCUMENTATION D  TRAINING MATERIALS E  IMPLEMENT  WINDOWS  DISTRIBUTION STRATEGIES3  COLLABORATIVELY EVALUATE IMS SOLVER PARALLELIZATION4  PROVIDE DELTARES STAFF TO ASSIST WITH MAINTENANCE AND SUPPORT OF ENTERPRISE CAPACITY SOFTWARE  MODFLOW 6 DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESDELTARES USA WILL DELIVER SUPPORT FOR ENTERPRISE ECOSYSTEM OF INTEGRATED AND INTEROPERABLE MODELS TO COMPLETE THE BUILDOUT OF THE SYSTEM THUS PERMITTING THE STATEWIDE APPLICATION OF THE MODELING SYSTEM DELTARES USA WILL DELIVER PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE VIA A PEER REVIEWED ARTICLE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES ALL PERSONS CONCERNED WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE VIA THE PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLE

PROJECT TITLE UNDERSTANDING SEED ESTABLISHMENT REQUIREMENTS TO ENHANCE DRYLAND RESTORATION SUCCESSPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 24RESTORING VEGETATION IN DRYLAND ECOSYSTEMS IS A MAJOR CHALLENGE FOR RESOURCE MANAGERS  THE PREVAILING DRY CONDITIONS IN DRYLANDS MEANS THAT IN MOST YEARS, CONDITIONS ARE UNSUITABLE FOR SEEDS TO BECOME ESTABLISHED  AS A RESULT, DISTURBANCES LIKE WILDFIRE AND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT OFTEN RESULT IN TRANSFORMATIONS FROM NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT PROVIDE NUMEROUS BENEFITS TO DEGRADED INVASIVE ANNUAL PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE MANY FEWER BENEFITS  THIS RISK OF RESTORATION FAILURE IS A MAJOR CONCERN THAT IS EXPECTED TO GROW IN COMING DECADES WITH CLIMATE CHANGE TO HELP LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR  DOI  IMPROVE THE SUCCESS OF RESTORATION EFFORTS, THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON UNDERSTANDING THE KEY LIMITING PROCESS IN DRYLAND RESTORATION, WHICH IS PROMOTING SUCCESSFUL PLANT REGENERATION FROM SEEDING TREATMENTS  SPECIFICALLY, SEED GERMINATION AND SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT REPRESENT THE CRITICAL BOTTLENECKS FOR RESTORATION SUCCESS  TO UNDERSTAND THIS BOTTLENECK, THIS PROJECT WILL SYNTHESIZE INFORMATION ABOUT REGENERATION REQUIREMENTS, SPECIFICALLY THE MOISTURE AND TEMPERATURE CONDITIONS THAT ENABLE A SEED TO GERMINATE AND SUBSEQUENTLY BECOME ESTABLISHED IN THE PLANT COMMUNITY  THE PROJECT WILL EXAMINE SEVERAL PLANT SPECIES THAT ARE IMPORTANT FOR DRYLAND RESTORATION IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL USE THIS NEW KNOWLEDGE TO DEVELOP MAPS DEPICTING THE PROBABILITY OF SEEDS BECOMING ESTABLISHED, PROVIDING RESOURCE MANAGERS WILL CLEAR INFORMATION ABOUT THE GEOGRAPHIC PATTERNS IN THE CHALLENGE OF DRYLAND PLANT ESTABLISHMENT  USING CLIMATE PROJECTIONS, THIS WORK WILL ALSO ASSESS HOW THE PROBABILITY OF ESTABLISHMENT IS LIKELY TO BE ALTERED BY FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS, PROVIDING VALUABLE INSIGHTS INTO LONG TERM ECOSYSTEM VULNERABILITY TO FAILED RECOVERY FROM DISTURBANCES  OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, DISSEMINATED DATASETS, AND AN IMPROVED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL FOR FORECASTING DRYLAND RESTORATION SUCCESS THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE DOI RESOURCE MANAGERS WORKING TO RESTORE AND REHABILITATE DRYLAND ECOSYSTEMS AFTER DISTURBANCES  THIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE THE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT REGENERATION REQUIREMENTS INTO A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT USES SEASONAL WEATHER FORECASTS TO ESTIMATE THE LIKELIHOOD OF CONDITIONS SUPPORTING PLANT ESTABLISHMENT IF SEEDS WERE SOWN IN THE CURRENT YEAR  THIS TOOL WILL HELP MANAGERS AVOID DROUGHT DRIVEN RESTORATION FAILURE AND MAXIMIZE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION INVESTMENTS

PROJECT TITLE EVALUATING THE IMPACT OF DIFFERENCES IN REMNANT AND RECONSTRUCTION MYCORRHIZAS ON PERFORMANCE OF CONSERVATIVE PRAIRIE PLANT SPECIES PROJECT DATES 09 09 2022 THROUGH 09 08 2023  BUDGET YR  I   09 09 2023 THROUGHT 09 08 2024  BUDGET YR  II AWARD PURPOSE THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP PRACTICAL METHODS BY WHICH LAND MANAGERS CAN IMPROVE ESTABLISHMENT AND RESILIENCE OF PRAIRIE RECONSTRUCTIONS BY IMPROVING AVAILABILITY OF APPROPRIATE ARBUSCULAR MYCORRHIZAL FUNGI  AMF  TO PLANTED SPECIES  WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT IF AMF CHARACTERISTIC OF REMNANT PRAIRIE SOILS ARE IMPORTANT FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF CONSERVATIVE PRAIRIE PLANT SPECIES, THEN THESE PLANT SPECIES WILL SHOW GREATER GROWTH AND LARGER FLORAL DISPLAYS WHEN INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES THAN WHEN INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM SITES PREPARED FOR RECONSTRUCTION  LIKEWISE, IF AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES IMPROVES COMPETITIVE ABILITY OF ESTABLISHED PRAIRIE PLANTS, THOSE GROWN IN SOIL INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES WILL SHOW BETTER GROWTH AND REPRODUCTION WHEN GROWN WITH INVASIVE COOL SEASON GRASSES THAN THOSE IN SOILS INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM SITES PREPARED FOR RECONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  OBJECTIVES IN THE SECOND TIER OF THE STUDY ARE  1  COMPARE PERFORMANCE  HEIGHT, LEAF PRODUCTION, AND BIOMASS  AND AMF COMMUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ROOTS OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES BETWEEN THE TWO INOCULUM TYPES IN THE GREENHOUSE  2  COMPARE COMPETITIVE ABILITY  HEIGHT, LEAF PRODUCTION, AND BIOMASS  AND AMF COMMUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ROOTS OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES RELATIVE TO BROMUS INERMIS OR POA PRATENSIS WHEN INOCULATED WITH REMNANT DERIVED VS  RECONSTRUCTION AMF YEAR 1  GREENHOUSE EXPERIMENTS TO DETERMINE EFFECT OF NATIVE PRAIRIE SOIL ON GROWTH OF NATIVE PRAIRIE SPECIES AND COMPETITION WITH ANNUAL GRASSES  USGS PERSONNEL WILL COLLECT SOIL SAMPLES AND INSTALL MONITOR GREENHOUSE EXPERIMENTS  NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY  NDSU  WILL ADVISE ON SOIL SAMPLING SITES AND EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN YEAR 2  COMPARE AMF COMMUNITIES IN ROOTS OF NATIVES IN REMNANT ENHANCED AND RESTORATION ALONE SOILS AND IN COMPETITION WITH NON NATIVES IN THE TWO TYPES OF AMFSOILS  USGS PERSONNEL WILL EXTRACT DNA FROM ROOT SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM THE GREENHOUSE EXPERIMENTS IN YEAR 1  NDSU WILL ANALYZE GENOMICS OUTPUT FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  NDSU, USGS, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL WORK TOGETHER TO PREPARE MANUSCRIPT, REPORT, AND OUTREACH MATERIALS THAT DESCRIBE RESULTS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY, USGS, AND UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

HISTORY  WHEREAS THE HIGHER LEVELS OF RESOLUTION ARE DESIGNED TO SUPPORT LAND USE PLANNING AND GROUNDWATER PROTECTION WITHIN COUNTIES, THE 1 500,000 SCALE MAPPING AND STRATIGRAPHY SUPPORTS STATEWIDE PROJECT TITLE ONLINE PLATFORM WITH VALUE ADDED SATELLITE IMAGERY FOR MONITORING WESTERN U S A  RIPARIAN ZONES VEGETATION DYNAMICS AND WATER USEPROJECT PERIOD  9 15 22 9 14 27MOST RIVERS IN SOUTHWESTERN USA ARE IMPAIRED BY HUMAN AND CLIMATE DRIVEN CHALLENGES  IMPOUNDMENTS, DIVERSIONS, OVERUSE, AND RECENTLY A SERIES OF PROTRACTED DROUGHTS LASTING FOR DECADES ARE IMPOSING NEW REALITIES AND REQUIRING BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND WISER WATER ALLOCATION  BEYOND THE OBVIOUS PRESSURE ON WATER RESOURCES AND ASSOCIATED SERVICES, THERE IS ALSO AN IMPENDING LOSS OF RIPARIAN FLORA AND FAUNA, SEEN AT TIMES AS COMPETING FOR THESE DWINDLING WATER RESOURCES IN AN ALREADY WATER STRESSED STRESSED REGION  UNDERSTANDING AND ADDRESSING THESE CHALLENGES REQUIRE A MULTI LEVEL APPROACH THAT RELIES ON TIMELY MONITORING, ACCURATE CHARACTERIZATION OF CHANGE, AND ASSESSMENT OF LONG TERM TRENDS MEDIUM RESOLUTION REMOTE SENSING OBSERVATIONS BY PLATFORMS LIKE THE LANDSAT  5, 8, AND NOW 9  HAVE PRESENTED FOR FIVE DECADES A CONSISTENT, DIRECT, LOW COST, AND ACCURATE MEANS OF OBSERVING AND MONITORING ECOSYSTEMS, QUANTIFYING CHANGE, AND ASSESSING TRENDS  THE OBSERVATIONAL DATA FROM THESE SATELLITES ARE USED AS A PROXY FOR PLANT HEALTH, PRODUCTIVITY, WATER USE, CHANGE, AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM PARAMETERS  IN THIS NEW EFFORT WE PLAN TO CONTINUE DEVELOPING OUR CLOUD BASED REMOTE SENSING PLATFORM FOR STUDYING RIPARIAN VEGETATION HEALTH AND WATER USE ALONG THE LOWER COLORADO AND OTHER RIVERS OF THE SOUTHWEST  THE PLATFORM AIMS AT AUGMENTING, FACILITATING ACCESS, VISUALIZATION, AND EXPLOITING LONG TERM MEDIUM RESOLUTION REMOTE SENSING DATA OVER THESE CRITICAL RIPARIAN CORRIDORS  THE PLATFORM WILL PROVIDE DIRECT AND EASY ACCESS TO A SERIES OF VALUE ADDED PRODUCTS GENERATED BY THIS EFFORT AND ASSIST DECISION MAKERS, SCIENTISTS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS IN BETTER UNDERSTAND AND ENGAGING THESE CHALLENGES THIS EFFORT USES A ROBUST DATA PROCESSING PIPELINE BASED ON TIME SERIES DATA FROM LANDSAT  MODIS AND VIIRS TO A LESSER EXTENT   THE PROPOSED PROCESS INVOLVES  1  GENERATING PREPROCESSED HIGH FIDELITY SPECTRAL DATA, 2  VALUE ADDED VEGETATION INDEX TIME SERIES, 3  ETA  WATER USE  BASED ON LOCAL WEATHER STATION AND GRIDDED REANALYSIS DATA FROM PRISM AND DAYMET, AND 4  PRODUCE SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MAPS OF ANOMALIES, CHANGE, AND TRENDS  THESE DATA CAN BE VISUALIZED, EXPLORED, AND ACQUIRED WITHIN THIS USER FRIENDLY ONLINE PLATFORM  LANDSAT 5, 7, 8, AND 9 WILL CONTINUE TO BE THE KEY DATA SOURCES FOR THIS EFFORT  POTENTIAL ET FROM LOCAL AZMET WEATHER STATIONS, PRISM, OR DAYMET WILL ALSO BE USED FOR ETA COMPUTATION  THESE DATA RECORDS WILL PROVIDE KEY OBSERVATIONAL DATA FOR STUDYING RIPARIAN VEGETATION GREENNESS, HEALTH, AND WATER USE  WHILE THE INITIAL EFFORT  2018 2023  FOCUSED ON THE LOWER COLORADO THIS NEW EFFORT WILL EXTEND THE WORK TO COVER MOST KEY RIVERS OF THE REGION, INCLUDING SAN PEDRO, SANTA CRUZ, SALT, GILA, LITTLE COLORADO, AND THE SMALLER RIVERS IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN AZ AS WELL AS ADJACENT REGIONS IN THE FOUR CORNER STATES THIS PROPOSED WORK MEETS MANY OBJECTIVES OF THE CESU NETWORK, AS TO CREATE AND SUSTAIN PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN CESU MEMBERS  USGS SCIENTISTS AND UOFA RESEARCHERS AND GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS  AND TO CONTINUE TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS RELATED TO THE RIVERS OF THE US SOUTHWEST, IN PARTICULAR THE COLORADO RIVER, THEIR CHANGING ECOHYDROLOGY WHILE PROVIDING TIMELY AND RELEVANT INFORMATION FOR FEDERAL AND STATE MANAGERS IN CHARGE OF MONITORING THESE NATURAL ASSETS

BIOSTRATIGRAPHIC INFORMATION  AND PRESENT THEIR FINDINGS TO A WORKING GROUP ASSEMBLED WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE FOUR GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS, SELECTED EXPERTS FROM ACADEMIA, INDUSTRY, AND THE U S ISSUES, FACILITATING CORRELATION OF STRATA AND, WHERE POSSIBLE AND APPROPRIATE, RECONCILING NOMENCLATURAL VARIATIONS ACROSS THE ENTIRE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO BASIN  RESULTS FROM THE STUDY WILL BE BENEFICIAL FOR THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY S EFFORTS TO UPDATE THE NATIONAL GEOLOGIC MAP DATABASE, FOR THE ENERGY INDUSTRY AND ENERGY REGULATORY AGENCIES, FOR EVALUATION OF GEOLOGICAL CO2 STORAGE PROJECTS BY INDUSTRY AND REGULATORY AUTHORITIES, AND FOR STATE AND MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENTS DEVELOPING WATER RESOURCES

PROJECT TITLE  DECISION SUPPORT FOR MULTI SPECIES COASTAL HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON PROPERTIES WITH MULTI USE OBJECTIVESPROJECT PERIOD  09 01 2022   06 30 2026NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, PARTICULARLY AT THE STATE AND FEDERAL LEVELS, ARE ROUTINELY TASKED WITH MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS, OFFERING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND ISSUING BIOLOGICAL OPINIONS VIA REQUIRED CONSULTATIONS THAT AUTHORIZE  TAKE  FOR FEDERAL AND STATE LISTED SPECIES  SUCH RECOMMENDATIONS ADDRESS THE IMPACTS OF PROJECTS ON LISTED SPECIES  MANY PROJECTS FOR WHICH CONSULTATIONS ARE REQUIRED ARE INTENDED TO MEET A HUMAN USE OBJECTIVE  E G , ROAD CONSTRUCTION  AND HAVE OBVIOUS IMPACTS ON LISTED SPECIES  E G , THROUGH HABITAT LOSS OR DISTURBANCE   OTHER PROJECTS ARE INTENDED TO BENEFIT ONE SPECIES BUT MAY NEGATIVELY IMPACT ANOTHER   FOR EXAMPLE, VEGETATION PLANTINGS PROVIDE HABITAT FOR BEACH MICE WHILE REDUCING HABITAT FOR SHOREBIRDS  IN 2019, THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION  FWC  AND U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  APPROACHED SCIENTISTS FROM THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  USGS  SEEKING A FRAMEWORK THAT COULD HELP THEM MAKE BALANCED SPECIES RECOVERY RECOMMENDATIONS AND INFORM THE CONSULTATION PROCESS REGARDING MULTI OBJECTIVE LANDOWNER PROJECTS PURSUANT THE U S  ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND STATE LAWS  THE FWC AND USFWS STAFF IDENTIFIED A NEED FOR A TRANSPARENT DECISION MAKING FRAMEWORK THAT WOULD ALLOW THEM TO CONSIDER RECOVERY NEEDS AND PROJECT RELATED IMPACTS ON MULTIPLE LISTED SPECIES  PARTICULARLY THOSE WITH CONFLICTING HABITAT NEEDS  WHILE ALSO BEING SENSITIVE TO LANDOWNER OBJECTIVES  THIS NEED HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY URGENT FOLLOWING AN HISTORIC HURRICANE SEASON IN THE GULF OF MEXICO, WHEREIN LANDOWNERS HAVE SOUGHT CONSULTATIONS ON A VARIETY OF PROJECTS TO REBUILD INFRASTRUCTURE AND RESTORE COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS  RELEVANT QUESTIONS TO BE ADDRESSED INCLUDE   I  WHERE TO REBUILD OR HOW TO MAINTAIN COASTAL ROADS AND OTHER INFRASTRUCTURE   II  WHERE TO PLACE OVERWASHED SEDIMENTS CLEARED FROM ROADS AND PARKING LOTS  AND  III  WHERE TO PLANT NATIVE VEGETATION THAT WOULD IMPROVE DUNE STABILITY AND BEACH MICE HABITAT  EACH DECISION STANDS TO HAVE AN IMMEDIATE AND DIFFERING IMPACT ON LISTED SPECIES ENDEMIC TO GULF ISLANDS INCLUDING BEACH MICE AND SHOREBIRDS  A NECESSARY FIRST STEP IN DETERMINING IMPACTS TO TARGET SPECIES IS TO COMPILE THE MOST CURRENT INFORMATION AVAILABLE DESCRIBING HABITAT AND LIFE HISTORY NEEDS  FROM THIS INFORMATION, TRADEOFFS IN BENEFITS AND IMPACTS TO TARGET SPECIES CAN BE IDENTIFIED  IN THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW OF HABITAT SELECTION IN SNOWY PLOVERS  CHARADRIUS NIVOSUS  AND BEACH MICE  PEROMYSCUSPOLIONOTUS  IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES  PRIMARY OBJECTIVES ARE TO  1  SYNTHESIZE EXISTING KNOWLEDGE ACROSS BOTH SPECIES  2  ASSESS NICHE OVERLAP AND POTENTIAL CONSERVATION CONFLICTS BETWEEN THESE CO OCCURRING SPECIES  AND 3  IDENTIFY POTENTIAL HABITAT DESIGN CRITERIA TO PROMOTE COEXISTENCE OF THESE SPECIES WITHIN THE SAME GEOGRAPHIC FOOTPRINT  UPON COMPLETION OF THE WORK, THE RECIPIENT WILL DELIVER A TECHNICAL REPORT DETAILING WHAT IS CURRENTLY KNOWN AND UNKNOWN ABOUT HABITAT SELECTION PATTERNS, ENVIRONMENT LANDSCAPE DRIVERS OF HABITAT SELECTION, AND RANGES IN SELECTED CONDITIONS  FOR EXAMPLE, ELEVATIONS BETWEEN 1 3 METERS  WITH APPROPRIATE CITATIONS  THIS REPORT IS INTENDED TO BE USED AS A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL FOR PROJECT PARTNERS

PROJECT TITLE STRATIGRAPHIC AND LITHOLOGIC PROPERTIES OF SUBSURFACE STRATA WITHIN THE MICHIGAN BASINPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  10 1 2022 THROUGH 9 30 2023THE MICHIGAN BASIN IS A CRUSTAL GEOLOGICAL STRUCTURE CENTERED ON THE STATE OF MICHIGAN AND IS COMPRISED OF AS MUCH AS 16,000 FEET OF SEDIMENTARY GEOLOGICAL FORMATIONS OVERLYING CRYSTALLINE BASEMENT  THESE SEDIMENTARY ROCKS CONTAIN EXTENSIVE NATURAL RESOURCES OF MINERALS, CONSTRUCTION AND INDUSTRIAL ROCKS, AS WELL AS, OIL AND GAS  ADDITIONALLY, MANY OF THESE ROCKS HAVE EXTENSIVE BRINE FILLED PORE SPACE THAT MAY BE SUITABLE FOR WASTE DISPOSAL, SEQUESTRATION OF CO2 OR ENERGY STORAGE USING HYDROGEN, COMPRESSED AIR OR OTHER FLUIDS CAPABLE OF CONVERSION TO A KINETIC ENERGY SOURCE FOR FUTURE ENERGY GENERATION  WITH THE ENORMOUS POTENTIAL FOR UTILIZATION OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES FROM WITHIN THE MICHIGAN BASIN, THIS RESEARCH PROPOSES TO DEVELOP DATABASES OF THESE STRATIGRAPHIC UNITS AND THEIR PHYSICAL PROPERTIES FOUR DATA SETS ARE PROPOSED TO BE COMPILED THAT WILL CONTAIN KEY GEOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS NECESSARY TO ASSESS MICHIGAN S SUBSURFACE GEOLOGICAL FORMATIONS  DATA WILL BE COMPILED IN A SERIES OF MICROSOFT EXCEL WORKBOOKS WITH INDIVIDUAL WORKSHEETS REPRESENTING VARIOUS PROPERTIES CHARACTERISTICS FOR EACH STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT  FORMATION  1  TABLE OF MICHIGAN STRATIGRAPHIC UNITS   THIS TABLE WILL INCLUDE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF EACH FORMATION WITHIN THE STATE OF MICHIGAN, ITS DEPTH RANGE, ITS THICKNESS RANGE AND GENERAL MINERALOGICAL AND LITHOLOGICAL COMPOSITION OF EACH UNIT 2  MICHIGAN STRATIGRAPHIC FORMATIONS   GEOLOGIC LITHOLOGIC PROPERTIES   PROPERTIES INCLUDE TEMPERATURE RANGE AT SPECIFIC DEPTHS, THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY, RANGE OF VARIATION IN POROSITY AND PERMEABILITY  FROM WELLS WITH CORE ANALYSES , AND VARIATION IN MINERALOGY OR ROCK CHEMICAL COMPOSITION 3  MICHIGAN STRATIGRAPHIC FORMATIONS   ENGINEERING PROPERTIES   ENGINEERING PROPERTIES TO BE INCLUDED ARE PRESSURE GRADIENT, TEMPERATURE GRADIENT, STATIC BOTTOM HOLE PRESSURE, SEQUENTIAL RESERVOIR PRESSURE RECORDED IN INDIVIDUAL WELLS OVER TIME AND FRACTURE PRESSURE GRADIENT 4  MICHIGAN STRATIGRAPHIC FORMATIONS   FLUID PROPERTIES   FORMATION FLUID PROPERTIES INCLUDE, BRINE SALINITY, BRINE DENSITY, OIL API GRAVITY, OIL DENSITY, OIL VISCOSITY, AND OIL, GAS AND WATER PRODUCTION VOLUMES FROM SPECIFIC FIELDS  AND OIL FORMATION VOLUME FACTOR, GAS OIL RATIO, GAS BUBBLE POINT, AND INITIAL WATER SATURATIONS IN OIL RESERVOIRS THE COMPILATION OF THESE DATA SETS WILL PROVIDE SPECIFIC INFORMATION ABOUT THE STRATIGRAPHIC PACKAGE OF PALEOZOIC SEDIMENTARY ROCKS THAT CONSTITUTE THE COMPLETE STACK OF GEOLOGIC LAYERS OF THE MICHIGAN BASIN  THESE FOUR DATASETS WILL CONTAIN QUANTITATIVE DATA ABOUT MICHIGAN S STRATIGRAPHIC UNITS AND THEIR LITHOLOGIC PROPERTIES DETAILED KNOWLEDGE OF THE DISTRIBUTION, DEPTH, THICKNESS, LITHOLOGIC AND PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL PROPERTIES OF THESE LAYERS WILL PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS WITH SPECIFICS TO ASSESS ENERGY, MINERAL RESOURCES AND WASTE DISPOSAL OPPORTUNITIES IN THE BASIN AND PROVIDE THE NECESSARY  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS

PROJECT TITLE DEMOGRAPHIC MODELS TO PREDICT SMALLMOUTH BASS POPULATION RESPONSES TO RESERVOIR MANAGEMENT AND CLIMATE CHANGEPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23PURPOSE  WATER AVAILABILITY IN THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN HAS DECLINED OVER THE PAST TWO DECADES, PRIMARY DRIVEN BY CLIMATE CHANGE DRIVEN INCREASES IN AIR TEMPERATURES  THE TWO LARGEST RESERVOIRS IN THE SYSTEM, LAKE MEAD AND LAKE POWELL, ARE AT THEIR LOWEST LEVELS SINCE THEY FILLED  WATER MANAGERS ARE CURRENTLY FACED WITH MAKING BROAD DECISIONS ABOUT HOW WATER IS USED, MOVED, AND STORED ACROSS THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN DURING THIS SUSTAINED DROUGHT  THESE WATER MANAGEMENT DECISIONS WILL LIKELY INFLUENCE RIVER ECOSYSTEMS, INCLUDED SEVERAL ENDANGERED FISH SPECIES  A MAJOR CONCERN AS RESERVOIR LEVELS DROP IS WARMER RESERVOIR RELEASE WATER TEMPERATURES WILL FAVOR NON NATIVE FISH SPECIES, ESPECIALLY SMALLMOUTH BASS  THERE IS A NEED TO FORECAST NATIVE AND NON NATIVE FISH RESPONSES TO FUTURE CONDITIONS AND COMPARE RESPONSES TO DIFFERENT RESERVOIR OPERATIONS  OUR GOAL IS TO DEVELOP PREDICTIVE POPULATION MODELS TO ASSESS THE RESPONSES OF FISH POPULATIONS TO FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS AND MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES, INCLUDING DIFFERENT RESERVOIR OPERATIONS AND USE THESE MODELS TO PREDICT FISH RESPONSES ACROSS THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN ACTIVITIES  WILL EXPAND EXISTING SMALLMOUTH BASS MODELS DEVELOPED FOR THE GREEN RIVER SUB BASIN  MODELS WILL BE ADAPTED TO PREDICT SMALLMOUTH BASS RESPONSES ACROSS THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  WILL PRESENT OUR FINDINGS AT RELEVANT STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, SUCH AS THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN RESEARCHER S MEETING OR THE DESERT FISHES COUNCIL ANNUAL MEETING, AS WELL AS AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES SUCH AS THE SOCIETY FOR FRESHWATER SCIENCE ANNUAL MEETING  ONE MEETING WILL BE ATTENDED EACH YEAR OF THE STUDY  WE WILL ALSO PUBLISH AT A MINIMUM ONE HIGH IMPACT JOURNAL ARTICLE DESCRIBING FORECASTED RESPONSES OF SMALLMOUTH BASS ACROSS THE CRB BENEFICIARIES  THE OUTPUT FROM OUR PREDICTIVE MODELS WILL HELP FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS  STATE CONSERVATION AGENCIES, U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, BUREAU OF RECLAMATION, ETC   ACROSS THE BASIN MAKE SHORT TERM DECISIONS ABOUT RESERVOIR OPERATIONS  WE AIM FOR OUR MODEL OUTPUTS TO INFORM UPCOMING RENEGOTIATIONS OF WATER POLICY AND AGREEMENTS  MODELS WILL ALSO BE AVAILABLE TO STAKEHOLDERS AND MANAGERS AS A TOOL TO TEST OUTCOMES OF FUTURE SCENARIOS BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT

PROJECT TITLE ADVANCED COMPUTATIONAL METHODS IN INVASION ECOLOGYPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23CLIMATE CHANGE AND INVASIVE SPECIES ARE TWO OF THE LEADING DRIVERS OF PLANT COMMUNITY DYNAMICS AROUND THE WORLD AND BATTLING INVASIONS CAN BE EXTREMELY COSTLY  INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, IN PARTICULAR, ARE DAMAGING TO ECOSYSTEMS AND ENDANGERED SPECIES  AGGRESSIVE MANAGEMENT OF CURRENT INVASIONS AND MONITORING EFFORTS TO STOP NEW EARLY INVADERS CAN PRESERVE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND IS OFTEN MUCH LESS EXPENSIVE THAN DEALING WITH LONG TERM POST INVASION DAMAGE  EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES RELIES ON KNOWLEDGE OF WHERE SPECIES ARE CURRENTLY ESTABLISHED AND WHERE THEY MAY CAUSE PROBLEMS IN THE FUTURE  RECENTLY, SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS HAVE DRASTICALLY IMPROVED MAPS OF THE CURRENT AND POTENTIAL DISTRIBUTIONS  THESE MODELS LEVERAGE LARGE, AGGREGATED OCCURRENCE DATASETS, AND PREDICT HABITAT SUITABILITY OF SPECIES  HABITATS BASED ON RELATIONSHIPS WITH MAPPED ENVIRONMENTAL PREDICTORS  SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELING IS RAPIDLY IMPROVING BASED ON NOVEL COMPUTATIONAL AND MODELING TECHNIQUES, MORE COMPREHENSIVE SETS OF MAPPED ENVIRONMENTAL PREDICTORS, AND AN EXPONENTIAL INCREASE IN THE AVAILABILITY OF SPECIES OCCURRENCE RECORDS  INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGERS FROM FEDERAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, AND THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE COMMONLY SUGGEST SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELING AS A METHOD TO MODEL INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES BASED ON THEIR POTENTIAL IMPACT TO ECOSYSTEMS AND THREAT TO NATIVE SPECIES THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO DELIVER OCCURRENCE MODELS AND DOWNSTREAM PRODUCTS  E G , MAPS, ONLINE TOOLS  TO FEDERAL PARTNERS TO HELP DISCOVER AND TREAT NEW POPULATIONS OF PROBLEMATIC PLANT INVADERS  IN PRODUCING THESE DELIVERABLES, THERE ARE IMPORTANT QUESTIONS RELATED TO SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS THAT SHOULD BE ADDRESSED, INCLUDING HOW WELL THEY CAPTURE INVASION IMPACTS AND HOW MODEL TRAINING EXTENT DECISIONS RELATE TO INVASIVE RESIDENCE TIME  TO ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOMES, OUR ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON THE IMPROVEMENT OF GEOSPATIAL MODELS FOR THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF INVASIVE PLANTS IN CURRENT AND FUTURE STAGES OF INVASION  WE WILL ITERATE THESE MODELS USING EXISTING DATA SETS, PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED RELEVANT PREDICTORS, AND PRODUCE OUR WORKFLOW WITHIN THE SOFTWARE FOR ASSISTED HABITAT MODELING  EXPECTED RESEARCH OUTCOMES INCLUDE  1  A COMPARISON OF TYPICAL OCCURRENCE BASED MODELS WITH NOVEL ABUNDANCE MODELS AND AN EVALUATION OF THE IMPLICATIONS FOR RISK  2  THE TESTING OF DECISIONS IN THE MODELING PROCESS RELATIVE TO INVASION STAGE, USING GLOBAL VERSUS NATIONAL MODELS  AND 3  QUANTIFIED BIOGEOGRAPHIC PATTERNS OF INVASION NOW AND IN THE FUTURE IN YEAR 1 OF THIS PROJECT, EXPECT SEVERAL HIGH QUALITY DELIVERABLES  FOREMOST, WILL PRODUCE A SPATIALLY ACCURATE AGGREGATE DATASET OF OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE LOCATION RECORDS FOR UP TO 250 SPECIES  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL COMPILE, REVIEW, AND REFRESH A SET OF ENVIRONMENTAL COVARIATES THAT ARE APPROPRIATE TO THE LIFE HISTORY AND PHYSIOLOGY OF THE STUDIED SPECIES  THESE RESULTS WILL BE ORGANIZED SUCH THAT THEY CAN BE QUICKLY INTEGRATED INTO OUR ANTICIPATED ACTIVITIES FOR YEAR 2 AND BEYOND  IN FUTURE YEARS, WE EXPECT DELIVERABLES TO INCLUDE SEVERAL PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS DETAILING THE ANTICIPATED COMPARISONS BETWEEN OCCURRENCE VERSUS ABUNDANCE AND GLOBAL VERSUS INVADED RANGE MODELS  THE STAKEHOLDERS AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES WILL ALSO LEARN OF OUR RESULTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS THROUGH TRADITIONAL FORUMS SUCH AS SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES AND LECTURES AS WELL AS PUBLICLY DISTRIBUTED ONLINE RESOURCES SUCH AS THE INHABIT WEBSITE AND DOI WEBSITES TO REACH A BROADER AUDIENCE

JOINT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED POST FIRE DEBRIS FLOW HAZARD ASSESSMENT IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIAPROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYFOR THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT  UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA, RENO, UNR  WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH TOUNDERSTAND DEBRIS FLOW PROCESSES IN RECENT BURN AREAS IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, WHICH THE USGSWILL USE TO IMPROVE METHODS FOR RAPID POST FIRE HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND EARLY WARNING THE USGS LANDSLIDE HAZARD PROGRAM  LHP  CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON THE PROCESSES AND CONDITIONSLEADING TO LANDSLIDE AND DEBRIS FLOW OCCURRENCE  ONE PROGRAM GOAL IS FORECASTING DEBRIS FLOWHAZARDS FOR AREAS BURNED BY WILDFIRE, WHICH ARE AT ELEVATED RISK TO DEBRIS FLOWS FOR 2 TO 10 YEARSAFTER THE WILDFIRE  THIS GOAL INCLUDES PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR EARLY WARNING IN RECENT AREAS BY THENATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE  NWS   CRITICAL TO THESE EFFORTS IS DEVELOPING METHODS TO RAPIDLY MAPTHE LIKELIHOOD AND POTENTIAL VOLUME OF DEBRIS FLOWS ACROSS BURN AREAS AND ESTIMATING ACCURATETRIGGERING RAINFALL THRESHOLDS THAT NWS USES AS FOR ISSUING WARNINGS THE SUSCEPTIBILITY OF A BURN AREA TO DEBRIS FLOWS VARIES REGIONALLY DUE TO DIFFERENCES IN GEOLOGY,CLIMATOLOGY, TOPOGRAPHY, AND VEGETATION  AND REGIONAL STUDIES ARE NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND THISVARIABILITY  TO DATE, THERE HAS BEEN RELATIVELY LITTLE RESEARCH ON POST FIRE DEBRIS FLOW PROCESSES INNORTHERN CALIFORNIA  INITIAL WORK IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA INDICATES THAT CURRENT MODELS USED FOREMERGENCY POST FIRE DEBRIS FLOW HAZARD ASSESSMENT, WHICH WERE DEVELOPED WITH DATA FROMOUTSIDE THE REGION, MAY NOT BE ACCURATE FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIA S UNIQUE GEOLOGY ANDCLIMATOLOGY GIVEN THE CURRENT MAJOR INCREASE IN THE SIZE AND SEVERITY OF WILDFIRES IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, THEREIS A PRESSING NEED TO BETTER TO BETTER FORECAST POST FIRE DEBRIS FLOW ACTIVITY IN THE REGION  THERE ISALSO A NEED TO UNDERSTAND HOW THE HAZARD AND RAINFALL THRESHOLDS CHANGE WITH TIME AFTER THEWILDFIRE AS VEGETATION RECOVERS  RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION UNDERTAKEN THROUGH THIS PROPOSEDAGREEMENT WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE USGS  ABILITY TO  1  IMPROVE DEBRIS FLOW HAZARDASSESSMENTS FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIA AND  2  REFINE REGIONAL RAINFALL THRESHOLDS  THESE EFFORTS WILLSUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF DEBRIS FLOW EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS DELIVERABLES THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING 1  A REPORT SUMMARIZING THE RESULTS OF FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND LABORATORY MEASUREMENTS 2  DATA FOR EVENTUAL USE IN USGS LED JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS AND USGS HOSTED DATA DISTRIBUTION PLATFORMS FOR THE PUBLIC

PROJECT TITLE USGS IMAGE BASED WATER MONITORING INITIATIVEPROJECT PERIOD  10 1 22 9 30 23AN IMPORTANT MISSION FOR THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  USGS  IS CONTINUAL MONITORING OF WATER LEVELS IN THE HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF RIVERS, STREAMS, AND DRAINAGES ACROSS THE COUNTRY  THE CURRENT USGS MONITORING INFRASTRUCTURE IS BASED ON A NETWORK OF RELATIVELY EXPENSIVE PERMANENT WATER LEVEL GAUGING STATIONS INSTALLED IN MAJOR RIVER DRAINAGES  THE HIGH COST TO PLAN, PERMIT, INSTALL, AND MAINTAIN SUCH STATIONS HAS LIMITED THE NUMBER THAT CAN BE INSTALLED  I E , MAJOR RIVERS AND STREAMS ONLY   GEOGRAPHIC COVERAGE IS SPARSE, WITH SIGNIFICANT GAPS, E G , IN URBAN SUBURBAN AREAS THE USGS HAS STRONG INTEREST IN UPGRADING ITS CURRENT HYDROLOGICAL MONITORING INFRASTRUCTURE BY SHIFTING TOWARDS A ROBUST, INFINITELY EXPANDABLE NETWORK OF SMALL, EASY TO DEPLOY, ACCURATE, AND RELATIVELY INEXPENSIVE  SMART  CAMERA BASED MONITORING STATIONS  THIS INTELLIGENT INFRASTRUCTURE CONTINUALLY ADAPTS THE DATA GATHERING ACTIVITIES AND RATE OF INDIVIDUAL SENSOR ENDPOINTS THROUGHOUT THE NETWORK BASED ON LOCAL WEATHER FORECASTS, REMAINING BATTERY POWER, AND OTHER FACTORS TO OPTIMIZE THE DATA STREAM GATHERED BY THE NETWORK  OVERALL, THIS WILL ALLOW A LARGE INCREASE IN MONITORING DENSITY, FLEXIBILITY, AND VOLUME OF HYDROLOGICAL MONITORING DATA GATHERED BY USGS, WHILE AT THE SAME TIME PROVIDING A DRAMATIC SAVINGS IN OVERALL OPERATIONAL AND MAINTENANCE COSTS UNDER THE NSF FUNDED FLOODAWARE PROJECT, NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY  NAU  HAS DEVELOPED AND OPERATIONALLY DEPLOYED A PROTOTYPE NETWORK IN ARIZONA DEMONSTRATING ALL ELEMENTS OF SUCH A SYSTEM, INCLUDING SOLAR POWERED AND CELLULAR CONNECTED SMART CAMERA ENDPOINTS, A ROBUST, SCALABLE CLOUD BASED DATA COLLECTION INFRASTRUCTURE, AND IMAGE PROCESSING ALGORITHMS TO EXTRACT WATER LEVELS FROM IMAGES UNDER A VARIETY OF CONDITIONS  THE OVERALL AIM OF THIS PROJECT, CALLED THE USGS HYDROLOGICAL CAMERA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM  HYDROCAMS , IS TO ADAPT AND REFINE SPECIFIC ELEMENTS OF THE TECHNOLOGIES DEMONSTRATED BY FLOODAWARE TO PROVIDE A ROBUST FOUNDATION FOR AN IMAGE BASED HYDROLOGICAL MONITORING INFRASTRUCTURE DEPLOYED BY USGS  THE SPECIFIC FOCUS IN THIS FIRST PHASE IS ON HARDENING THE SMART CAMERA ENDPOINT PROTOTYPES, AND DEVELOPING A CUSTOM SERVER SIDE COMMAND AND CONTROL SOFTWARE MODULE TO MEET THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF USGS  SOME SPECIFICS INCLUDE INTEGRATION OF A CORPORATE PARTNER INTERESTED IN COMMERCIALIZING THE SMART CAMERA HARDWARE SYSTEMS TO MASS PRODUCE THE ENDPOINT HARDWARE REFINING AND TESTING OUR  SMART  ENDPOINT FIRMWARE FOR ROBUSTNESS, DYNAMIC ADAPTABILITY, AND SMART POWER MANAGEMENT  CREATING A SCALABLE, CLOUD BASED, COMMAND AND CONTROL MODULE TO ALLOW EASY MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF THE HYDROCAMS NETWORK  IN SUM, THE HYDROCAMS PROJECT HARNESSES THE POWER OF THE  INTERNET OF THINGS  CONCEPT TO INCREASE THE DENSITY AND EFFICACY OF THE USGS WATER MONITORING NETWORK BY SEVERAL ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE, WHILE ALSO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCING OPERATIONAL COSTS  ONCE DEPLOYED AT SCALE BY USGS, THE RESULT WILL BE HIGH GRANULARITY AND SEAMLESS AUTOMATED WATER MONITORING COVERAGE TO SERVE LOCAL , REGIONAL , AND NATIONAL LEVEL SCIENCE, ENGINEERING, AND HYDROLOGICAL MODELING AND MONITORING EFFORTS

PROJECT TITLE WILDFIRE AND LAND MANAGEMENT IMPACTS ON HABITAT AND SURVIVAL OF JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDERS  QUANTIFYING IMMEDIATE AND LONG TERM ECOSYSTEM AND SOIL RESPONSES TO INFORM ENDANGERED SPECIESSTEWARDSHIP AND FOREST RESTORATIONPROJECT PERIOD   8 8 2022 8 7 2023THERE IS A NEED TO IDENTIFY THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE AND THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDER  PLETHODON NEOMEXICANUS , LISTED IN THE FEDERAL REGISTER IN 2013 AND THEIR HABITAT IN ORDER TO GUIDE STEWARDSHIP FOR ONGOING AND PLANNED FOREST TREATMENTS AIMED AT PRESERVING AND RESTORING SUITABLE AND CRITICAL HABITAT AT VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE AND THE SURROUNDING NATIONAL FOREST  THE JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDER  JMS  IS ENDEMIC TO THIS REGION, WHERE FIRE, CLIMATE AND MANAGEMENT ARE ACTIVE AND THREATEN ADDITIONAL HABITAT  RECENT LARGE, HIGH SEVERITY WILDFIRES THAT ARE NOT IN ALIGNMENT WITH NATURAL FIRE REGIMES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS THE GREATEST THREAT TO THE SPECIES, WITH  65  OF ALL HISTORIC LOCATIONS BURNED IN THE 2011 LAS CONCHAS AND 2013 THOMPSON RIDGE FIRES, LEADING TO RAPID DECLINE OF SALAMANDERS  MANAGING FORESTS TO REDUCE THE RISK OF ADDITIONAL CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE HAS LED TO A PUSH TO TREAT FORESTED AREAS RAPIDLY TO REDUCE RISK IN THE FUTURE  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY EXPERIMENTS AND ANALYSES TO ALLOW FOR DEVELOPMENT OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES  TANGIBLE BENEFITS INCLUDE BETTER INFORMED TREATMENT PRESCRIPTIONS, IDENTIFICATION OF CURRENT AND PREDICTION OF FUTURE HIGH VULNERABILITY HABITAT AREAS, PRIORITIZATION OF RESTORATION TREATMENTS, AND REDUCTION OF IMMEDIATE AND SHORT TERM IMPACTS, ALLOWING FOR LONG TERM PERSISTENCE AND RECOVERY OF THIS NARROWLY ENDEMIC SPECIES  FURTHER, RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND WILDFIRE RESPONSES IN OTHER PARKS AND LANDS, AND FOR OTHER AMPHIBIANS THAT ARE SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN ABOVE  AND BELOWGROUND ECOSYSTEMS SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES AT NAU ARE TO  1  IDENTIFY PREY ITEMS THROUGH MUSEUM COLLECTION OF JMS STOMACH CONTENTS TO TARGET THE RIGHT TAXA FOR OUR FIELD STUDIES  THIS WILL OCCUR IN YEAR 1 OF THE PRIMARY TASK AGREEMENT  2  COLLECT SOIL ANIMAL, SOIL EDAPHIC INFORMATION AND HABITAT INFORMATION SITES WITH JMS HISTORIC, CURRENT AND NO OCCUPANCY TO DETERMINE THE KEY VARIABLES THAT CAN PREDICT OCCUPANCY EXPERIMENTS BEFORE AND AFTER TREATMENT TO DETERMINE HOW HABITAT FOR JMS IS ALTERED  PLANNING WILL BEGIN IN YEAR 1, AND MEASUREMENTS WILL CONTINUE IN YEARS 2 AND 3 DEPENDENT ON FUNDING AND FOREST ACCESS  4  USE ALL DATA COLLECTED FROM OUR PART OF THE PROJECT AND FROM OTHER TEAM MEMBERS TO INFORM PREDICTIVE MODEL HABITAT FOR JMS INTO THE FUTURE GIVEN CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES  TIMELINE DEPENDING UPON PARTNERS  5  HELP CREATE GUIDELINES FOR BEST PRACTICES TO PRESERVE HABITAT FOR JMS  TIMELINE DEPENDING UPON DATA COLLECTION AND FUNDING IN YEAR ONE WILL PRODUCE  1 JMS STOMACH CONTENT ANALYSIS  2  DATA COLLECTION PLANS FOR OBJECTIVES 2 AND 3  FOR THE ENTIRE PROJECT ASSUMING CONTINUING FUNDING AGREEMENTS PRODUCTS INCLUDE  1  PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS  2  PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC, NPS AND STAKE HOLDER MEETINGS  3  CONTRIBUTION TO A REPORT AND PREDICTIVE MODELING WITH ALL FINDINGS, RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BEST PRACTICES FOR RESTORATION ACTIONS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF CONSERVATION PRIORITY AREAS  4  AN INDEXED DATABASE OF ALL DATA COLLECTIONS FOR ARCHIVE WITH NPS

PROJECT TITLE EVALUATING SEA LEVEL RISE SCENARIOS AND THE EVERGLADESPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23THE EVERGLADES ECOSYSTEM PROVIDES INVALUABLE SOCIO ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS INCLUDING WILDLIFE HABITATS, STORM BUFFER, AND SUPPORTING LIVELIHOODS INCLUDING FISHING AND ECOTOURISM  SOME THREATS TO THE EVERGLADES ECOSYSTEM INCLUDE SEA LEVEL RISE, URBANIZATION, DEVELOPMENT PRESSURE, AND INVASIVE SPECIES  EVERGLADES RESTORATION IS COMPLEX AND INVOLVES THE INTERACTION OF VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS WITH A MYRIAD OF INTERESTS, PRIORITIES, AND MANAGEMENT  IN ORDER TO ASSESS THE IMPACTS OF SEA LEVEL RISE, IT IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THE PERCEPTIONS, HISTORICAL LEGACIES, BELIEFS, RISKS, AND UNCERTAINTIES THAT EACH OF THE SEA LEVEL RISE SCENARIOS MAY PRESENT, INCLUDING THEIR RIPPLE EFFECTS THROUGHOUT THE ECOSYSTEM AND SOCIETY  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO IDENTIFY THE PRIORITIES OF VARIOUS RECOVER STAKEHOLDERS THAT WILL BE RELEVANT FOR THE EFFECTIVE RESTORATION OF THE EVERGLADES IN THE NEXT DECADE  RECOVER INVOLVES A GROUP OF MANAGERS, SCIENTISTS, NON GOVERNMENTAL AND GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND AGENCIES THAT ARE INVESTED IN RESTORING THE EVERGLADES ECOSYSTEM IT IS PIVOTAL TO UNDERSTAND THE SOCIO ECONOMIC ASPECTS OF ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION BECAUSE IF THE RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS ARE UNINVOLVED OR UNSUPPORTIVE OF THE RESTORATION GOALS, IT CAN DELAY OR SIGNIFICANTLY HINDER THE RESTORATION PROGRESS RECOVER PARTNERS NEED A SYSTEMATIC WAY TO EVALUATE THE IMPACTS OF SEA LEVEL RISE ON THE EVERGLADES RESTORATION  THIS STUDY WILL USE A QUALITATIVE AND SEMI QUANTITATIVE APPROACH TO COLLECTING THE DATA AND UNDERSTANDING THE PERCEPTIONS OF THE VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS  MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE DATA COLLECTION WILL HAVE TWO PHASES  1  SEMI STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS WITH RECOVER STAKEHOLDERS, 2  FOCUS GROUPS  WITH Q METHODOLOGY  TO DISCUSS THE RESULTS OF THE SEMI STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS AND THE NEXT STEPS OF THE PROJECT INCLUDING PRIORITIES AND BEST APPROACHES TO ADDRESS THE IMPACTS OF SEA LEVEL RISE  THE PRODUCTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE 1  WORKSHOP TO SHARE THE RESULTS OF THE QUALITATIVE INTERVIEWS AND FOCUS GROUPS THAT WILL BE SHARE WITH THE RECOVER PARTICIPANTS, PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATION, PRESENTATION AT FLORIDA ASSOCIATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES PROFESSIONALS  FANREP  CONFERENCE, 2023 GREATER EVERGLADES ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION CONFERENCE AND A FINAL REPORT SUBMITTED TO THE U S GEOLOGICAL SERVICE

PROJECT TITLE EDNA METABARCODING TO DETECT NORTHERN WESTERN SPADEFOOT FROM CALIFORNIA VERNAL POOLSPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 24DETECTION OF CRYPTIC AMPHIBIAN SPECIES IN THE WILD CAN BE TIME CONSUMING, EXPENSIVE, INVOLVE INVASIVE SAMPLING METHODS, AND REQUIRE SIGNIFICANT EXPERTISE  DETECTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL DNA  EDNA  PROVIDES A COMPLIMENTARY, SENSITIVE, AND NON INVASIVE METHOD THAT CAN BE PAIRED WITH TRADITIONAL SURVEY TECHNIQUES TO MAXIMIZE DETECTION PROBABILITY OF SPECIES SUCH AS WESTERN SPADEFOOT  SPEA HAMMONDI   IN COLLABORATION WITH USGS SCIENTISTS, WE PROPOSE TO USE EDNA METABARCODING TO DETECT NORTHERN CLADE WESTERN SPADEFOOT IN VERNAL POOLS SAMPLED THROUGHOUT NORTHERN AND CENTRAL CALIFORNIA  USGS SCIENTISTS WILL COLLECT AND FILTER WATER SAMPLES FROM VERNAL POOLS AND WE WILL EXTRACT EDNA AND AMPLIFY IT USING A DNA BARCODING LOCUS SHOWN TO DISTINGUISH WELL BETWEEN AMPHIBIAN SPECIES  METABARCODING LIBRARIES WILL BE CONSTRUCTED AND SEQUENCED ON AN ILLUMINA MISEQ  A VERNAL POOL REFERENCE SEQUENCE DATABASE WILL BE APPLIED TO THE EDNA SEQUENCES TO DETECT WESTERN SPADEFOOT  METABARCODING DETECTIONS WILL BE COMBINED WITH USFGS VISUAL SURVEY DATA IN DYNAMIC OCCUPANCY MODELS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND OCCUPANCY DYNAMICS AND POOL SELECTION ACROSS THE SPECIES  RANGE  DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ANNUAL REPORTS SUBMITTED WITHIN A YEAR OF THE DATE WE RECEIVE FILTERS FOR ANALYSIS  A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED AT THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD, SUMMARIZING ALL RESULTS  THE EDNA METABARCODING DATA WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE IN AN ONLINE REPOSITORY SUCH AS DATA DRYAD AT THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD  ALTHOUGH THE EDNA ANALYSIS MAY NOT CONSTITUTE A STAND ALONE PUBLICATION, WE WILL WORK WITH USGS COLLABORATORS TO PREPARE PRESENTATIONS AND PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS COMMUNICATING THE RESULTS OF THE LARGER OCCUPANCY DYNAMICS STUDY TO WILDLIFE MANAGERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC

PROJECT TITLE USING DOI LONG TERM MONITORING DATA TO BUILD SCALABLE FUEL LAYERS FOR WILDFIRE RISK ASSESSMENT AND FUEL TREATMENT PRIORITIZATIONPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23THE RISK OF LARGE AND SEVERE WILDFIRES HAS STEADILY INCREASED THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES, POSING CRITICAL THREATS TO HUMAN LIFE AND INFRASTRUCTURE, DEGRADING WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND IMPERILING NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES  LAND MANAGERS FROM DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR  DOI , TRIBAL, STATE, AND OTHER AGENCIES ARE CHARGED WITH ASSESSING WILDFIRE RISK AND PLANNING FUEL TREATMENTS AND OTHER MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MITIGATE RISKS TO VALUED ASSETS  HOWEVER, OUR KNOWLEDGE ABOUT FUEL LOADS, AND THE EFFECTIVENESS OF TREATMENTS TO REDUCE FUEL LOADS, MITIGATE WILDFIRE RISK, AND IMPROVE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES REMAINS LIMITED  IN PARTICULAR, DOI AND OTHER AGENCIES OFTEN HAVE LIMITED RESOURCES TO ASSESS FUEL LOADS ACROSS LARGE SPATIAL SCALES AT HIGH TEMPORAL FREQUENCY  THERE IS A SUBSTANTIAL NEED TO SYNTHESIZE EXISTING DOI VEGETATION MONITORING DATA, DETERMINE ITS UTILITY FOR ASSESSING FUEL LOAD, AND INCORPORATE NEW METHODS TO MAP FUEL LOADS AND EVALUATE WILDFIRE RISK MORE ACCURATELY THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS HOW CURRENT DOI LONG TERM MONITORING DATA CAN BE INTEGRATED WITH OTHER FIELD  AND REMOTE SENSING BASED DATA TO BUILD SCALABLE FUEL MODELS TO ASSESS WILDFIRE RISK, TREATMENT EFFECTIVENESS, AND SCENARIO CASTING OF ALTERNATIVE WILDFIRE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  THE SPECIFIC RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE   1  TO COMPARE DOI AND OTHER FIELD BASED MONITORING DATA SOURCES AND THEIR UTILITY FOR CHARACTERIZING FUEL LOAD   2  TO ASSESS THE UTILITY OF DIFFERENT REMOTE SENSING PRODUCTS TO ENHANCE THE SPATIAL SCALE AND TEMPORAL FREQUENCY OF DOI FIELD BASED MONITORING AND COMPARE DIFFERENT METHODS FOR INTERPOLATING FIELD BASED MEASUREMENTS TO LANDSCAPE SCALES  AND  3  TO IDENTIFY THE FUEL CHARACTERISTICS THAT ARE NEEDED FOR MONITORING AND FIRE MODELING BUT ARE MISSING FROM CURRENT FIELD  AND REMOTE SENSING BASED ASSESSMENTS, AND DETERMINE PATHWAYS FOR OBTAINING THESE ADDITIONAL CHARACTERISTICS OF FUEL STRUCTURE WITH NEW MONITORING METHODS WITH THESE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, WE WILL GENERATE A REPORT THAT ASSESSES THE CURRENT STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES OF DOI MONITORING DATASETS TO ASSESS FUEL LOADS, THE UTILITY OF INTEGRATING REMOTE SENSING PRODUCTS AND SPATIAL MODELING TO SCALE UP FIELD BASED MONITORING, AND THE FEASIBILITY OF CONDUCTING NEW MONITORING TECHNIQUES TO ENHANCE THE ABILITY OF RESOURCE MANAGERS TO TRACK CHANGES IN FUEL LOADS ACROSS DOI LANDS  THE REPORT WILL PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS ON HOW TO PROMOTE AND EXPAND NEXT GENERATION FUEL MODELING AND MAKE TOOLS ACCESSIBLE TO RESOURCE MANAGERS  WE WILL ALSO DELIVER A PRESENTATION OF THE REPORT S FINDINGS TO INTERESTED DOI AGENCY STAFF THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE LAND MANAGERS USEFUL TOOLS FOR ASSESSING AND MITIGATING WILDFIRE RISKS  IT WILL SUPPORT THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILDLAND FIRE SCIENCE PROGRAM, DOI OFFICE OF WILDLAND FIRE, AND OTHER DOI PRIORITIES BY IDENTIFYING BEST METHODS FOR MAPPING FUELS, EXPANDING THE UTILITY OF DOI MONITORING DATASETS, ASSESSING FUEL TREATMENT EFFECTIVENESS, AND EVALUATING POTENTIAL WILDFIRE BEHAVIOR AND WAYS TO MITIGATE WILDFIRE RISK  THE PROJECT ADDRESSES EXECUTIVE ORDER 14008  TACKLING THE CLIMATE CRISIS AT HOME AND ABROAD BY HELPING TO MITIGATE INCREASED WILDFIRE RISK CREATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE AND SECRETARIAL ORDER 3372  REDUCING WILDFIRE RISKS ON DOI LAND THROUGH ACTIVE MANAGEMENT BY DEVELOPING STRATEGIES TO REDUCE WILDFIRE RISK

PROJECT TITLE CHARACTERIZING CLIMATE DRIVEN CHANGES TO HYDROLOGY AND FLOODPLAIN FORESTS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER TO INFORM MANAGEMENTPROJECT PERIOD  9 5 22 9 4 23CLIMATE CHANGE IS THREATENING THE HEALTH OF THE FLOODPLAIN FOREST ECOSYSTEMS ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER  NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER ECOSYSTEMS ARE INTERESTED IN DEVELOPING ADAPTATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES  TO IMPROVE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE ECOSYSTEM SCENARIOS, WILL COMBINE TREE RINGS WITH DATA FROM OBSERVATIONS AND MODELS OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROCESSES  USING A LARGE COLLECTION OF TREE CORES   1,000 , WILL QUANTIFY PREVIOUS GROWTH PATTERNS AN HOW THEY RELATE TO FLOODING AND TEMPERATURE  WILL ALSO SIMULATE POTENTIAL FUTURE FLOODING CONDITIONS TO CREATE MAPS TO SHOW WHERE FLOODING MAY CHANGE IN THE FUTURE AND BY HOW MUCH  WILL THEN LINK THESE PIECES OF INFORMATION TO PROJECT FUTURE TRAJECTORIES OF FOREST DEVELOPMENT  WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS ALONG THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER, CENTERING THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AS WE WORK THROUGH DIFFERENT MODELING SCENARIOS  THE RESULTS WILL HELP IDENTIFY PRIME LOCATIONS FOR MANAGEMENT OR AREAS THAT MAY BE MORE RESILIENT TO CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS WITHIN THE FLOODPLAIN FORESTS OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE FIRST OF THREE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ASSIMILATE MULTIPLE SOURCES OF  BIG DATA  TO EXPLORE AND QUANTIFY THE RELATIONSHIP AMONG FOREST STRUCTURE, COMPOSITION, AND AGE WITH IMPORTANT ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS, INCLUDING HYDROLOGY  FOR THE SECOND ACTIVITY WILL USE MULTIPLE FORMS OF DATA TO MAP HOW CURRENT IMPACTS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE ARE INFLUENCING CHANGES IN FLOODING PATTERNS, IDENTIFYING LOCATIONS THAT ARE MORE CLIMATE RESILIENT AND LESS CLIMATE RESILIENT, TO EFFICIENTLY UTILIZE MANAGEMENT RESOURCES  FINALLY, WILL INTEGRATE INFORMATION FROM ACTIVITY 1 AND ACTIVITY 2 WITHIN A LANDSCAPE LEVEL MODEL OF FOREST CHANGE, TO INCREASE MODEL ACCURACY AND PERFORMANCE TO FORECAST POTENTIAL SHIFTS IN VEGETATION COMMUNITY, STRUCTURE, AND COMPOSITION WITH CLIMATE CHANGE AND DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS  ACTIVITY 3   ACTIVITY 3 WILL BRING TOGETHER MULTIPLE PARTNERS FOR BOTH TRAININGS AND SHARING OF KNOWLEDGE, TO LINK THE RESULTS FROM ACTIVITIES 1 AND 2 TO FUTURE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  EXPECT TO PRODUCE MAPS OF FLOODPLAIN FORESTS THAT ARE SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN HYDROLOGY DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE  ALSO WILL PRODUCE A PREDICTIVE MODEL THAT CAN BE USED TO SIMULATE AND TEST POTENTIAL FUTURE FOREST CONDITIONS AND EXPLORE ADAPTATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES  WILL PLAN TO OFFER A TRAINING TO PARTNERS INTERESTED IN USING THE MODEL FOR THEIR APPLICATIONS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE DATA AND INFORMATION FOR NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS ALONG FLOODPLAIN FOREST ECOSYSTEMS WITHIN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER  THIS INCLUDES STATE, FEDERAL, PRIVATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES  ADDITIONALLY, GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER AND THE ROLE THAT FLOODPLAIN FORESTS PLAY IN WATER QUALITY AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, LOCAL RESIDENTS AND VISITORS TO THE REGION WILL BENEFIT FROM THE MULTIPLE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FROM RESILIENT HEALTHY FOREST COMMUNITIES
