THIS PROPOSAL DETAILS A STRATEGY FOR COMPLETING A VEGETATION MAP OF THE TFG UNIT OF KATAHDIN WOODS AND WATERS NATIONAL MONUMENT (KAWW, ALSO REFERRED TO AS THE MONUMENT) IN SUPPORT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS). THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THE TFG UNIT MAPPING PROJECT ARE TO PROVIDE AN ACCURATE, TESTED, AND UP-TO-DATE VEGETATION MAP, UPDATE THE EXISTING VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION FOR THE MONUMENT STANDARDIZED TO THE U.S. NATIONAL VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION (USNVC) AND SUPPORTED BY VEGETATION PLOT DATA COLLECTED WITHIN THE MONUMENT, AND PROVIDE AN UPDATE TO THE EXISTING FIELD KEY TO VEGETATION FOR THE ENTIRE MONUMENT.

PROJECT TITLE:ADVANCING A COUPLED OCEAN-WAVE MODELING SYSTEM TO PREDICT COASTAL STORM IMPACTSPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/22-7/31/23PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY-THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP SOFTWARE TO ENABLE COMPUTER MODELS OF OCEAN CURRENTS AND WAVES THAT PRESENTLY OPERATE SEPARATELY TO BE COUPLED TOGETHER SO THAT THE INFLUENCES OF SHOALING AND BREAKING WAVES ON OCEAN CURRENTS AND COASTAL SEA LEVEL, AND OF OCEAN CURRENTS ON WAVE HEIGHT AND DIRECTION AND THE MOVEMENT OF SEDIMENT, ARE COMPUTED JOINTLY. THE CREATION OF A COUPLED OCEAN-WAVE PREDICTION SYSTEM WILL SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE OUR ABILITY TO FORECAST OCEAN SURGE, WAVES, AND SEDIMENT TRANSPORT TO STUDY COASTAL FLOODING AND THE FATE OF SEDIMENT IN THE COASTAL SYSTEM. THIS WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT HAZARD GUIDANCE, EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS, CONTAMINANT TRANSPORT, LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, EXISTING OR PROPOSED INFRASTRUCTURE AND DEVELOPMENT, AND COASTAL PROTECTION SYSTEMS.ACTIVITIES IN THE SCOPE OF WORK ARE SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT FOR OCEAN AND WAVE MODEL COUPLING THAT ARE FOR WIDESPREAD COMMUNITY USE, AND WRITING OF DOCUMENTATION TO EXPLAIN AND DEMONSTRATE THE USE OF THESE TOOLS. FURTHER SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT WILL BE UNDERTAKEN TO CREATE EASY-TO-USE, PORTABLE, OPEN-SOURCE SOFTWARE TO ENABLE USERS TO QUICKLY CONFIGURE MODELS OF NEW GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS TO DELIVER INFORMATION AT HIGHLY DETAILED SPATIAL SCALES SUITED TO SPECIAL NEEDS OF INDIVIDUAL STAKEHOLDERS.DELIVERABLES WILL BE THE SOFTWARE TOOLS THEMSELVES, DISTRIBUTED VIA CODE REPOSITORIES SUCH AS GITHUB UNDER UNRESTRICTED OPEN-SOURCE LICENSE TERMS. THESE CODES WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY DOCUMENTATION ON THEIR USE COMPRISING EXAMPLE TEST CASES AND USER GUIDES. PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS WILL BE PRODUCED THAT DESCRIBE THE VERACITY OF THE RESULTS OBTAINED IN APPLICATIONS OF THE SOFTWARE.THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WILL BE DATA MANAGERS, EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT PLANNERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO WILL GAIN CAPABILITIES TO BETTER PREPARE FOR FUTURE HAZARDS AND BETTER PLAN FOR INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT AND MARITIME OPERATIONS IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES.

PROJECT TITLE ASSESSING PLUVIAL COASTAL FLOOD RISK AND POTENTIAL CLIMATE INEQUITIES IN NEW YORK CITYPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23RECENT FLOOD DISASTERS ARISING FROM COASTAL STORMS  E G , HARVEY AND IDA  HAVE DEMONSTRATED THE CRITICAL IMPORTANCE OF INCORPORATING RAINFALL INTO ASSESSMENTS OF COASTAL FLOOD RISK  HOWEVER, STUDIES OF PRESENT AND FUTURE COASTAL FLOOD RISK AND ADAPTATION NEARLY ALWAYS NEGLECT RAINFALL AND THUS HAVE BIASES THAT MAY LEAD TO SUBOPTIMAL GOVERNMENT PLANNING DECISIONS  CLIMATE CHANGE IS LEADING TO BOTH INCREASING RAINFALL INTENSITY AND RISING COASTAL FLOODS, WORSENING THESE BIASES AND THE DANGERS THEY REPRESENT VULNERABILITY TO FLOODING, WHICH INCLUDES EXPOSURE, DEFINED AS LIVING IN AN AREA THAT MAY FLOOD, SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SUFFER DAMAGE IF FLOODING OCCURS, AND CAPACITY TO RECOVER, DIFFERS ACROSS COMMUNITIES WITH DIFFERENT SOCIO ECONOMIC CHARACTERISTICS  PRIOR RESEARCH CHARACTERIZES HOW VULNERABILITY TO FLOODING DRIVEN BY COASTAL STORMS DIFFERS IN THE POPULATION IN THE URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS OF NEW YORK CITY  NYC   VULNERABILITY TO NUISANCE, TIDAL, AND PLUVIAL FLOODING IS MUCH LESS WELL DOCUMENTED AND UNDERSTOOD  IMPACTS OF AND THEREFORE VULNERABILITY TO NUISANCE AND PLUVIAL FLOODING CAN DIFFER FROM COASTAL STORM FLOODING  FOR EXAMPLE, ANECDOTAL EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT THE DANGER POSED TO RESIDENTS OF BASEMENT APARTMENTS CAN BE PARTICULARLY ACUTE IN THE CASE OF FLASH FLOODING DRIVEN BY EXTREME RAINFALL  RESIDENTS OF BASEMENT APARTMENTS ARE OFTEN DISADVANTAGED IN MANY WAYS, BEING LOW INCOME, FROM MINORITY RACIAL GROUPS, OR RECENT IMMIGRANTS IN THIS STUDY, WE WILL COMBINE NOVEL MODELING AND ASSESSMENT OF COMPOUND COASTAL PLUVIAL FLOOD HAZARD WITH ANALYSES OF FLOOD VULNERABILITY IN POPULATIONS WITH DIFFERENT CHARACTERISTICS AROUND JAMAICA BAY, NYC  INNOVATIVE HYDRODYNAMIC AND MACHINE LEARNING  ML  MODELS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND APPLIED FOR INTEGRATED FLOOD MODELING FOR JAMAICA BAY, BOTH VALIDATED USING EXISTING CITIZEN SCIENCE OBSERVATIONS AND ULTRASONIC SENSOR MEASUREMENTS OF STREET FLOODING  WE WILL COLLECT AND ANALYZE SOCIAL DATA THROUGH INTERVIEWS AND HOUSEHOLD SURVEYS TO DOCUMENT IMPACTS OF AND RECOVERY FROM FLOODING IN NEIGHBORHOODS THAT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN IMPACTED BY PLUVIAL AND HIGH TIDE FLOODING AND THAT REPRESENT A BROAD RANGE OF NATURAL AND BUILT ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIO ECONOMIC CONDITIONS  WE WILL COMBINE INVESTIGATION OF SOCIAL VULNERABILITY TO PLUVIAL AND HIGH TIDE FLOODING WITH EXISTING UNDERSTANDING OF SOCIAL VULNERABILITY TO COASTAL STORM FLOODING IN URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS, TO ASSESS INEQUITIES IN THE BURDEN OF FLOOD RISK AND INFORM POLICIES THAT CAN ADVANCE EQUITABLE ADAPTATION TO FLOOD RISK THE RESEARCH SUPPORTS THE USGS GOALS OF IMPROVING COASTAL AND FLOOD MODELING AND ITS APPLICATION TO REDUCING SOCIETAL RISK AND IMPROVING COASTAL RESILIENCE  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE FLOOD AND COASTAL MODELING SCIENTISTS, MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENTS, AND COASTAL RESIDENTS VULNERABLE TO FLOODING, PARTICULARLY RACIAL MINORITY, LOW INCOME AND IMMIGRANT COMMUNITIES  RESULTS OF THE STUDY WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE ACADEMIC COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC THROUGH  1  PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS,  2  CONFERENCE AND SEMINAR PRESENTATIONS,  3  DATASET PUBLICATIONS,  4  MODEL SETUP TOOLS AND A HOW TO REPORT FOR INCORPORATING RAIN INTO THE HYDRODYNAMIC MODEL, AND A  5  POLICY BRIEF  THE PROJECT IS DIRECTED BY RESEARCHERS AT THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY, WHO WILL ALSO SPEARHEAD THE FLOOD MODELING ACTIVITIES, AND AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS AT COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY AND BROOKLYN COLLEGE WILL LEAD THE SOCIAL SCIENCE COMPONENTS OF THE STUDY

PROJECT TITLE:CONNECTING SEDIMENT TRANSPORT, WIND WAVES, STORM SURGE AND MARSH VEGETATION IN JAMAICA BAY UNDER VARYING FORCING CONDITIONSPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/22-7/31/23THIS PROJECT BUILDS ON EXTENSIVE PREVIOUS WORK EXAMINING HYDRODYNAMICS AND SEDIMENT TRANSPORT IN THE HUDSON RIVER ESTUARY AND SURROUNDING COASTAL REGIONS, INCLUDING ON SEDIMENT TRANSPORT DUE ASSOCIATED WITH TROPICAL STORMS. THE FOCUS WILL BE ON SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES IN JAMAICA BAY WHETHER THE WETLANDS THERE THAT CAN HELP TO MITIGATE IMPACTS OF COASTAL STORMS. A PRIMARY AIM IS TO CHARACTERIZE HOW SEDIMENT TRANSPORT IN JAMAICA BAY AND SEDIMENT DELIVERY TO THE MARSH DEPENDS ON WIND AND WAVE FORCING CONDITIONS. TO ACHIEVE THIS OBJECTIVE WILL USE STATE-OF-THE-ART MODELING TOOLS WITH REALISTIC FORCING CONDITIONS. WE AIM TO QUANTIFY SEDIMENT TRANSPORT THROUGH ROCKAWAY INLET TO ASSESS VARIABILITY IN THE SEDIMENT SUPPLY TO THE BAY UNDER DIFFERENT STORM AND NON-STORM FORCING CONDITIONS. ALSO AIM TO ASSESS THE EROSION AND DEPOSITION PATTERNS IN THE BAY. THIS INCLUDES QUANTIFYING MARSH EDGE EROSION BY LOCAL WIND WAVES AND ASSESSING HOW DEPOSITION PATTERNS ON THE MARSH PLATFORM AND IN DEEPER CHANNELS DEPENDS ON THE WATER LEVEL AND WAVE CONDITIONS DURING STORM EVENTS.THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH SUPPORT THE GOALS OF THE USGS TO UNDERSTAND THE FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO WETLAND LOSS IN THE JAMAICA BAY REGION AND IN SHALLOW EMBAYMENTS MORE BROADLY. IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES AND THE EROSION OR DEPOSITION OF SEDIMENT IN MARSHES DEPEND ON STORM FORCING CONDITIONS IS CRITICAL FOR ASSESSING THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE ENVIRONMENTS, PARTICULARLY IN THE FACE OF SEA LEVEL RISE AND CLIMATE CHANGE AND WITH THE INCREASING INTEREST IN RESTORATION OF WETLANDS FOR COASTAL PROTECTION.WILL USE THE COUPLED OCEAN-ATMOSPHERE-WAVE-SEDIMENT TRANSPORT MODELING SYSTEM (COAWST) TO EXAMINE THE LINKAGES BETWEEN TIDAL CURRENTS, WIND WAVES, STORM SURGE, SEDIMENT TRANSPORT AND MARSH VEGETATION IN JAMAICA BAY. WILL USE A NESTED GRID APPROACH TO PROVIDE HIGHER SPATIAL RESOLUTION THAN IN PREVIOUS MODELING STUDIES OF JAMAICA BAY, AND THIS WILL ALLOW FOR BETTER REPRESENTATION OF THE SHARP SPATIAL GRADIENTS IN BATHYMETRY BETWEEN THE DREDGED NAVIGATIONAL CHANNELS AND MARSH PLATFORM. TO ASSESS THE ROLE OF STORM EVENTS IN SEDIMENT DELIVERY AND TRANSPORT WITHIN THE BAY, WILL USE HIGH-RESOLUTION ATMOSPHERIC MODEL HINDCASTS FROM NCAR TO FORCE THE SURFACE BOUNDARY CONDITIONS FOR A REALISTIC DISTRIBUTION OF STORM AND NON-STORM CONDITIONS. FROM THE MODEL RESULTS WILL CHARACTERIZE THE DISTRIBUTIONS OF SEDIMENT ACCUMULATION IN JAMAICA BAY AND HOW IT DEPENDS ON THE FORCING CONDITIONS. THE SEDIMENT ACCUMULATION PATTERNS IN THE MODEL RESULTS CAN HELP INFORM WETLANDS RESTORATION EFFORTS BY INDICATING REGIONS OF THE BAY THAT ARE MORE LIKELY TO HAVE SUSTAINABLE SEDIMENT SUPPLY. THE MARSH EDGE EROSION RESULTS WILL ALSO HELP TO IDENTIFY AREAS THAT ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO INCREASED RATES OF WETLAND LOSS AND MAY REQUIRE MORE CONCERTED PROTECTION.

PROJECT TITLE: INTEGRATED ASSESSMENTS: SOLVING WATER AVAILABILITY CHALLENGESTHROUGH AN INTERDISCIPLINARY FRAMEWORK" CHAPMAN CONFERENCEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 11/1/2022THE MAIN RESEARCH OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO HOST AN INTERDISCIPLINARY SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE ON THE TOPIC OF WATER AVAILABILITY. THIS CONFERENCE WILL UNCOVER AND MAKE EXPLICIT DIVERGENT VIEWS, ASSUMPTIONS, DATA TYPES, AND RESEARCH METHODS THAT MAKE IT DIFFICULT FOR SCIENTISTS FROM DIFFERENT DISCIPLINES TO CONDUCT INTEGRATED WATER SCIENCE. THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A FOUNDATION UPON WHICH A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE TO FACILITATE INTEGRATED WATER ASSESSMENTS CAN BE BUILT. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY 1) INTEGRATING DEFINITIONS OF WATER AVAILABILITY AT THE CONCEPTUAL LEVEL; 2) IDENTIFYING METRICS AND METHODS TO MEASURE WATER AVAILABILITY IN AN INTEGRATED WAY; AND 3) PROPOSING BEST PRACTICES TO TRANSLATE AN INTEGRATED UNDERSTANDING OF WATER AVAILABILITY INTO DECISION-MAKING. THE CONFERENCE IS SCHEDULED FOR SEPTEMBER 12-16, 2022, IN GOLDEN, COLORADO. THE CONFERENCE WILL UNCOVER AND MAKE EXPLICIT DIVERGENT VIEWS, ASSUMPTIONS, DATA TYPES, AND RESEARCH METHODS THAT MAKE INTEGRATION DIFFICULT. THE SCIENTIFIC DISCOVERY SPURRED BY THE CONFERENCE WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC THROUGH INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF DRIVERS OF WATER AVAILABILITY AND BETTER COMMUNICATION TO POLICY MAKERS.

PROJECT TITLE A DECISION FRAMEWORK FOR MANAGING EUROPEAN GREEN CRAB INFESTATIONS ON THE COAST OF WASHINGTON AND SALISH SEA SHORELINESPROJECT PERIOD  8 20 22 8 19 25THE STATE OF WASHINGTON HAS RECENTLY EXPERIENCED AN EXPONENTIAL INCREASE IN INVASIVE EUROPEAN GREEN CRAB  CARCINUS MAENAS  POPULATIONS WITHIN MULTIPLE WATER BODIES ON THE OUTER COAST, AS WELL AS LUMMI NATION S SEA POND IN THE INLAND WATERS OF THE SALISH SEA  WHEN ESTABLISHED, THE SPECIES CAN DISRUPT HABITAT SUPPORTING NATIVE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, ALTER NATURAL FOOD WEBS, AND DECIMATE SHELLFISH AND OTHER AQUATIC INDUSTRIES  THE INVASION THEREFORE PRESENTS AN URGENT RISK TO THE STATE S MARINE ENVIRONMENT, MARINE BASED ECONOMY, AND THE CULTURAL IDENTITY OF TRIBAL AND NON TRIBAL RESIDENTS MANAGERS TASKED WITH ASSESSING AND CONTROLLING GREEN CRAB IN WASHINGTON LACK A UNIFIED DECISION MAKING FRAMEWORK TO EVALUATE ERADICATION SUCCESS, ALLOCATE FINITE CONTROL RESOURCES, AND BALANCE COMPETING PRIORITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE  PREVIOUS DECISION MAKING HAS BEEN LARGELY AD HOC AND WITHOUT A MECHANISM TO PRIORITIZE ACTIONS  AS THE RANGE AND ABUNDANCE OF GREEN CRAB EXPANDS IN THE STATE, MANAGERS WILL HAVE TO MAKE DECISIONS UNDER CONFLICTING OBJECTIVES AND WITH UNCERTAINTY, REQUIRING AN APPROACH TO STRUCTURE THINKING, SUCH THAT DECISIONS ARE INFORMED, TRANSPARENT, AND DEFENSIBLE TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE, WILL FIRST DEVELOP A STRUCTURED DECISION MAKING FRAMEWORK TO ASSIST MANAGERS IN MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT ALLOCATION OF RESOURCES AND INTENSITY OF EUROPEAN GREEN CRAB ERADICATION EFFORTS  PLAN TO IMPLEMENT A DECISION ANALYTIC METHODOLOGY, A PROCESS THAT DECOMPOSES DECISIONS INTO THEIR KEY COMPONENTS TO LINK MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES TO DECISION GUIDANCE  THESE STEPS INCLUDE COLLABORATING WITH DECISION MAKERS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO DEFINE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND PERFORMANCE MEASURES  ESTIMATING THE CONSEQUENCES OF MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES  AND CREATING A MECHANISM TO SYSTEMATICALLY EVALUATE TRADE OFFS AND OPTIMIZE RESOURCE ALLOCATION TO MEET DEFINED OBJECTIVES  RECOGNIZING THE PRESENCE OF UNCERTAINTY DUE TO LACK OF INFORMATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES, WE WILL ANALYZE THE ROBUSTNESS OF MANAGEMENT CONSEQUENCES TO THIS UNCERTAINTY WILL MAKE OUR DECISION FRAMEWORK ACCESSIBLE AND IMPLEMENTABLE TO RELEVANT DECISION MAKERS BY CREATING AN INTERACTIVE WEB TOOL  ALTHOUGH THE DECISION FRAMEWORK WILL BE INITIALLY IMPLEMENTED WITH A DEVELOPED SET OF ALTERNATIVES, THE NATURE OF THE INVASION CAN REQUIRE SEQUENTIAL DECISION MAKING, AS WELL AS THE ABILITY TO ALLOCATE NEW SETS OF RESOURCES AND RESPOND TO FUTURE MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS  THE INTERACTIVE NATURE OF THE WEB TOOL WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO VISUALIZE THE CONSEQUENCES AND UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES, AS WELL AS PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE TRANSPARENCY REGARDING THE DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK AND OUTCOMES EXPECT THE DECISION FRAMEWORK AND MANAGEMENT TOOL WILL RESULT IN MAXIMIZED INVESTMENT IN MANAGEMENT RESOURCES, INFORMED ACTIONS, AND FULL INTEGRATION OF SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND CULTURAL VALUES  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A SCIENTIFIC MANUSCRIPT PUBLISHED IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL  AN INTERACTIVE WEB TOOL HOSTED ON THE USGS WEBSITE  AND WORKSHOPS WITH STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL CO MANAGERS TO DETAIL THE DECISION FRAMEWORK AND FUNCTIONALITY OF THE INTERACTIVE WEB TOOL THE AWARD WILL PROVIDE TUITION AND SALARY FOR A GRADUATE STUDENT ENROLLED AT UC BERKELEY TO CARRY OUT THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES IN COLLABORATION WITH UC BERKELEY FACULTY AND USGS PARTNERS BASED IN WASHINGTON STATE  NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE ANTICIPATED WITH THIS AWARD

PROJECT TITLE CONTINUED RESEARCH ON IOCG DEPOSITS OF THE IDAHO COBALT BELT  INTEGRATING MINERALOGICAL DATAACROSS SCALES AND IMPLICATIONS FOR GEOPHYSICAL EXPLORATIONPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  9 1 2022 THROUGH 8 31 2024THE IDAHO COBALT BELT  ICB  IS A NORTHWEST TRENDING BELT OF COBALT     COPPER BEARING DEPOSITS AND PROSPECTS IN THE SALMON RIVER MOUNTAINS OF EAST CENTRAL IDAHO, USA, AND REPRESENTS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT DOMESTIC COBALT RESOURCES IN THE COUNTRY  IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE  EARTH MRI  CONDUCTED BY THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, IT IS THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT TO IMPROVE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF THE GEOLOGIC FRAMEWORK IN THE ICB TO DISCOVER AND ASSESS CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES  ENHANCEMENT OF OUR DOMESTIC MINERAL SUPPLY WILL DECREASE THE NATION S RELIANCE ON FOREIGN SOURCES OF MINERALS THAT ARE FUNDAMENTAL TO OUR SECURITY AND ECONOMY THE PROJECT USES A MULTITUDE OF GEOLOGICAL DATA ACQUIRED ACROSS THE RANGE OF SCALES FROM ACROSS THE ICB  DEPOSITS AND PROSPECTS INCLUDED IN THIS STUDY INCLUDE IRON CREEK AND BLACKBIRD  CORE AND HAND SAMPLES FROM THESE LOCATIONS WILL BE SCANNED USING CONTINUOUS XRF CORE SCANNING, HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGING, AND DENSITY AND MAGNETIC SUSCEPTIBILITY DATA ACQUISITION  CONTINUOUS XRF DATA WILL BE EVALUATED TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE GEOCHEMICAL SIGNATURE AND DISTRIBUTION OF KEY ELEMENTS IN THE SUBSURFACE  HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGING IN CONJUNCTION WITH SUBSEQUENT SEM BASED AUTOMATED MINERALOGY ANALYSIS WILL INFORM THE OCCURRENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF ALTERATION AND ORE MINERALS  MAGNETIC SUSCEPTIBILITY AND DENSITY DATA WILL PROVIDE A KEY LINK BETWEEN THE GEOCHEMISTRY, ALTERATION AND ORE MINERALOGY, INTRUSIVE IGNEOUS ROCK, HOST SILTITES, AND AIRBORNE GEOPHYSICAL DATA ACQUIRED THROUGH EARTH MRI THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ADD VALUE TO THE EARTH MRI CONDUCTED BY THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND WILL INCLUDE THE COLLECTION OF MINERALOGICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL DATA ON HAND SAMPLES AND DRILL CORE, AS WELL AS AIRBORNE SURVEYS, AND INTEGRATION OF THE MINERALOGICAL INFORMATION ACROSS SCALES TO ENHANCE GEOPHYSICAL INVERSE MODELING  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS THAT WILL SUMMARIZE THE RESEARCH ON DRILL CORE AND SAMPLES TO DEMONSTRATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ORE MINERALS AND ALTERATION MINERALS AS WELL AS PETROGRAPHIC INVESTIGATIONS ESTABLISHING WHETHER DIFFERENT ALTERATION STAGES EXIST THAT CAN BE RELATED TO THE EVOLUTION OF THE HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEM  ADDITIONAL ATTENTION WILL BE GIVEN TO THE LINK BETWEEN THE GEOPHYSICAL SIGNAL AND THE MINERALOGY IN CORE AND FIELD SAMPLES UNRAVELING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN GEOPHYSICAL PROPERTIES, AND THE MINERALOGY, TEXTURES, AND ALTERATION OF ROCKS AND DRILL CORE  THE PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A 3 D GEOLOGIC MODEL FOR THE ICB AND THE INCORPORATION OF MINERALOGICAL INFORMATION INTO GEOPHYSICAL MODELING  THE OUTCOME OF THIS STUDY WILL SERVE AS A BLUEPRINT FOR CRITICAL MINERAL EXPLORATION AND ASSESSMENT INCORPORATING HETEROGENEOUS AND DIVERSE DATA ACROSS THE RANGE OF SCALES

PROJECT TITLE CRITICAL REVIEW AND VALIDATION OF AN IMMUNE RESPONSE ASSAY FOR AMPHIBIANSPROJECT PERIOD  9 1 22 8 31 23AMPHIBIANS ARE UNDERGOING A GLOBAL DECLINE DUE TO DISEASE, POLLUTION, AND MULTIPLE OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS  THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS AND VALIDATE A METHOD CALLED THE PHYTOHEMAGGLUTININ ASSAY  PHA , WHICH CAN BE USED TO DETERMINE HOW WELL AN AMPHIBIAN S IMMUNE SYSTEM IS WORKING  THE PHA IS A SIMPLE TEST IN WHICH AN ANIMAL IS INJECTED WITH A SMALL AMOUNT OF A FOREIGN SUBSTANCE, AND THEN SWELLING IS MEASURED AT THE INJECTION SITE TO SEE HOW WELL THE IMMUNE SYSTEM IS WORKING  THE BETTER THE IMMUNE SYSTEM IS FUNCTIONING, THE MORE EASILY AN INDIVIDUAL CAN FIGHT OFF POTENTIALLY HARMFUL INFECTIONS  MEASURING IMMUNITY IN AMPHIBIANS IS ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT BECAUSE EMERGING FACTORS SUCH AS POLLUTION AND CLIMATE CHANGE CAN IMPACT THE ABILITY OF INDIVIDUALS TO BATTLE INFECTION  WE NEED TO UNDERSTAND HOW THESE FACTORS INTERSECT WITH AMPHIBIAN DISEASE TO BETTER PREDICT HOW AMPHIBIANS WILL PERSIST TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, WILL FIRST PERFORM A LITERATURE REVIEW OF PHA STUDIES TO DATE IN AMPHIBIANS AND OTHER ANIMALS  THE LITERATURE REVIEW WILL TELL US WHICH PROBLEMS OTHER SCIENTISTS HAVE ENCOUNTERED WITH THE PHA TEST, WHICH ASPECTS CAN BE IMPROVED UPON, AND WHICH GAPS EXIST FOR USING THE PHA IN THE FIELD TO LOOK AT WILD AMPHIBIAN POPULATIONS AND DISEASE  THE LITERATURE REVIEW IS EXPECTED TO BE PUBLISHED IN A PEER REVIEWED PHYSIOLOGY AND CONSERVATION JOURNAL, AND IT WILL BENEFIT THE SCIENTIFIC AND CONSERVATION COMMUNITY BY AIDING IN THE DESIGN OF BETTER VERSIONS OF THE PHA TO PROTECT AMPHIBIAN POPULATIONS BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE LITERATURE REVIEW, WE WILL CARRY OUT A CONTROLLED LABORATORY PHA STUDY WITH MULTIPLE AMPHIBIAN SPECIES TO FILL MANY OF THE GAPS IDENTIFIED  ANTICIPATED GAPS INCLUDE ENSURING THAT THE PHA TEST DOES NOT HARM AMPHIBIANS, THAT THE METHOD IS REPRODUCIBLE ACROSS SPECIES, AND THAT IT SUCCESSFULLY MEASURES IMMUNITY AND RESPONSE TO DISEASE  THE LAB TEST WILL ALSO HELP US PROPERLY DESIGN THE PHA TO BE USED IN THE WILD WHERE IT IS MOST NEEDED  WE WILL PUBLISH THE RESULTS OF THE LAB STUDY IN A RELEVANT PEER REVIEWED ANIMAL PHYSIOLOGY JOURNAL AND WE EXPECT IT WILL BE HIGHLY CITED BY THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY FINALLY, FOLLOWING THE LABORATORY TEST, WE WILL CARRY OUT A FIELD VERSION OF THE PHA TO SEE HOW WELL IT PERFORMS WITH WILD AMPHIBIAN POPULATIONS  WE ARE ESPECIALLY INTERESTED IN AMPHIBIANS THAT HAVE BEEN AFFECTED BY ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS TO DETERMINE WHETHER CHEMICALS CAN DECREASE THE ABILITY FOR ANIMALS TO FIGHT OFF INFECTION  STUDIES IN THE FIELD WILL TELL US PRACTICALLY HOW IMPORTANT IMMUNITY IS FOR AMPHIBIAN SURVIVAL IN THE MIDST OF GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE  THE FIELD STUDY WILL GENERATE MULTIPLE PEER REVIEWED ARTICLES INVESTIGATING DIFFERENT SPECIES OR LOCATIONS

WESTERN ECONOMIES  HOWEVER, BIG SAGEBRUSH PLANT COMMUNITIES ARE IN DECLINE AND ARE BEINGTRANSFORMED BY MULTIPLE THREATS INCLUDING INVASIVE SPECIES AND CHANGING CLIMATE  CLIMATE CHANGEWILL INFLUENCE MODELING TO ASSESS HOWGRAZING COULD BE ALTERED TO BOTH MINIMIZE THE RISK OF CHEATGRASS INVASION AND SUSTAIN LONG TERMGRAZING OPERATIONS UNDER A FUTURE CLIMATE  SIMULATIONS WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR CURRENT CLIMATE ANDFOR 52 FUTURE CLIMATE SCENARIOS FOR 200 BIG SAGEBRUSH SITES THAT REPRESENT THE RANGE OF CURRENTCLIMATIC CONDITIONS PRESENT ACROSS THE BIG SAGEBRUSH REGION  WE WILL SIMULATE FOUR GRAZINGINTENSITIES  LOW, MODERATE, HEAVY, AND VERY HEAVY GRAZING  FOR CURRENT AND ALL FUTURE CLIMATICSCENARIOS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  AT LEAST ONE PUBLICATION EVALUATING THE SUSTAINABILITY OFCURRENT GRAZING REGIMES UNDER A FUTURE CLIMATE THROUGHOUT THE BIG SAGEBRUSH REGION, AND ASSOCIATEDDATA, WHICH WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE VIA SCIENCEBASE  IN ADDITION, WE WILL PRESENT KEYFINDINGS AT THE ECOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA ANNUAL MEETING AND VIA A WEBINAR DESIGNED TOCOMMUNICATE THESE RESULTS TO RESOURCE MANAGERS AND CONSERVATION PLANNERS WITHIN THE BIGSAGEBRUSH REGION OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE   1  SCENARIO BASED SIMULATION RESULTS OF HOW GRAZING SUSTAINABILITY IN BIGSAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS WILL BE IMPACTED BY CLIMATE CHANGE IN COMING DECADES AND  2  IDENTIFICATIONOF GRAZING REGIMES THAT ARE LIKELY TO BE SUSTAINABLE AND MINIMUM CHEATGRASS INVASION THROUGH THE21ST CENTURY  RESULTS WILL AID DECISION MAKERS, RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND RANCHERS IN IDENTIFYING HOW,WHEN, AND WHERE HISTORICAL GRAZING PRACTICES MAY NEED TO BE MODIFIED IN COMING DECADES INTENDEDBENEFICIARIES  RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND RANCHERS WORKING THROUGHOUT THE BIGSAGEBRUSH REGION, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE WESTERNASSOCIATION FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, THE US FOREST SERVICE, AND THE BUREAU OF LANDMANAGEMENT SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND CODE MAINTENANCE, SIMULATIONMODELING, DATA ANALYSIS AND SYNTHESIS, WRITING OF PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS AND REPORTS, ANDDISSEMINATION OF KEY FINDINGS TO ACADEMIC AND AGENCY AUDIENCES VIA PRESENTATIONS AND WEBINARS

PROJECT TITLE EASTERN BLACK RAIL POPULATION RECOVERY  AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORKPROJECT PERIOD  8 15 22 8 14 23EASTERN BLACK RAILS  LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS JAMAICENSIS  WERE FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED IN 2020  POPULATIONS OF THIS SPARROW SIZED RAIL HAVE DECLINED IN RECENT YEARS OVER THE FULL EXTENT OF ITS RANGE, MUCH OF WHICH IS IN COASTAL AREAS OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES  ONGOING THREATS OF COASTAL DEVELOPMENT AND DISTURBANCE ARE NOW EXACERBATED BY SEA LEVEL RISE AND HIGHER FREQUENCY OF STORMS CAPABLE OF FLOODING THE HIGH MARSH HABITAT THE RAILS INHABIT  THUS, ADDITIONAL SUITABLE HABITAT MUST BE RESTORED CREATED AND MAINTAINED FOR SPECIES PERSISTENCE  ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT IS A PROCESS OF STRUCTURED, ITERATIVE DECISION MAKING BASED ON SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE AND MONITORING TO MANAGE IMPORTANT NATURAL RESOURCES IN A SUSTAINABLE MANNER  HERE, WE APPLY AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK TO PREDICT HABITAT SUITABLE FOR RESTORATION OF EASTERN BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS IN THE ATLANTIC COASTAL REGION BUT FOCUSING ON AREAS OUTSIDE THE TIDAL ZONE  EASTERN BLACK RAILS REQUIRE HIGH MARSH OR SIMILAR HABITAT THAT IS CONSISTENTLY BUT MODERATELY IRRIGATED  ONE APPROACH IS TO CREATE SAVANNAH LIKE HABITAT WITH SUITABLE HYDROLOGY THROUGH EXPERIMENTAL IRRIGATION TREATMENTS  SPECIFICALLY, HYDROLOGIC MODELS AND REMOTE SENSING DATA WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP MAPS IDENTIFYING HABITAT FOR EXPERIMENTAL TREATMENTS AND LAND MANAGEMENT  A SECOND APPROACH IS TO IDENTIFY EXISTING HABITAT THAT COULD BE MANAGED THROUGH PRESCRIBED BURNS  PRESCRIBED BURNS MIMIC HISTORICAL DISTURBANCE REGIMES AND ARE HYPOTHESIZED TO BENEFIT RAIL HABITAT BY PROMOTING HERBACEOUS VEGETATION GROWTH, INCREASING RESISTANCE TO WOODY VEGETATION ENCROACHMENT AND PROMOTING SUITABLE HYDROLOGY  WE WILL USE HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELS TO IDENTIFY HIGH MARSH AND OTHER HABITATS WHERE EXPERIMENTAL MANAGEMENT USING PRESCRIBED FIRE COULD ENHANCE EASTERN BLACK RAIL HABITAT  ONCE SITES ARE IDENTIFIED, WILL CONTACT LAND MANAGERS AND OWNERS TO INVESTIGATE THEIR WILLINGNESS TO PARTNER WITH THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROJECT  WE WILL ALSO DEVELOP ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS FOR LAND MANAGERS  IN COORDINATION WITH STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS ACROSS THE ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN, WE WILL DEVELOP FIELD DATA COLLECTION PROTOCOLS FOR MONITORING RAIL POPULATIONS, MEASURING VEGETATION AND HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS, AND DOCUMENTING MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TO MAINTAIN SUITABLE HABITAT FOR THIS SPECIES BY THE END OF THIS GRANT, WE WILL HAVE CREATED THE FOLLOWING PRODUCTS A DATABASE OF POTENTIAL SITES FOR BOTH IRRIGATION AND FIRE APPLICATION, INCLUDING CONTACT INFORMATION FOR INTERESTED LANDOWNERS MANAGERS AND BENEFITS AND LIMITATIONS OF THE SITE A SPATIAL LAYER WITH THE POTENTIAL SITES MAPPED OUT TWO MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS FOR MANAGERS THAT OUTLINES HOW, WHEN, AND WHERE TO DO MANAGEMENT THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROJECT  FIELD SAMPLING PROTOCOLS FOR BLACK RAIL OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE, VEGETATION, AND HYDROLOGY  SITE TRACKING PROTOCOL AND REPORTING FRAMEWORK FOR SITE MANAGERS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  USGS AND ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE PARTNERS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROJECT  STATE AGENCY PARTNERS RESPONSIBLE FOR BLACK RAIL CONSERVATION  LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS INTERESTED IN BLACK RAIL HABITAT MANAGEMENT WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PROTOCOLS AND GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  AMY SCHWARZER WILL BE A CONTRACTOR  SUBRECIPIENT  ON THE PROJECT FOR ONE YEAR AND WILL CONDUCT THE BULK OF THE PROJECT DUTIES

PROJECT TITLE:INFLUENCE OF PARAGLACIAL PROCESSES ON ROCK SLOPE STABILITY IN PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND, ALASKAPROJECT PERIOD: 7/1/22-6/30/26CYCLES OF GLACIER ADVANCE AND RETREAT GENERATE DAMAGE IN ADJACENT VALLEY ROCK WALLS ACTING AS PREPARATORY FACTORS OF CATASTROPHIC SLOPE COLLAPSE. WHILE THE CONCEPT OF GLACIAL DEBUTTRESSING IS OFTEN INVOKED TO EXPLAIN THE PRESENCE OF ROCK SLOPE FAILURES THROUGH THE LOSS OF A MECHANICAL ICE SUPPORT, IT HAS BEEN SHOWN THAT THE DEBUTTRESSING FRAMEWORK MUST BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE COUPLED THERMO-HYDRO-MECHANICAL STRESSES RESULTING FROM CHANGING BOUNDARY CONDITIONS OVER TIME. TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DEVELOPMENT OF ROCK SLOPE FAILURES IN FJORD-PROXIMAL VALLEYS OF PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND, ALASKA, WILL CONDUCT DETAILED SITE-SPECIFIC CHARACTERIZATION OF ROCK SLOPE MATERIAL PROPERTIES AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, AND USE THESE RESULTS PARAMETERIZE 2D DISTINCT ELEMENT MODELS TO SIMULATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF ROCK MASS PROGRESSIVE FAILURE OVER TIME DURING PERIODS OF BOTH GLACIER ADVANCE AND RETREAT. KEY TO THESE MODELS IS BENCHMARKING RESULTS AGAINST THE MAPPED LOCATIONS, KINEMATICS, AND DISPLACEMENT RATE OF CURRENTLY OBSERVED LANDSLIDES IN THE STUDY AREA. THE PRIMARY OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY ARE A SERIES OF FIELD-INFORMED AND NUMERICALLY-BASED THERMO-HYDRO-MECHANICAL MODELS IDENTIFYING THE TIMING, RATE AND SPATIAL PATTERN OF PARAGLACIAL ROCK SLOPE DAMAGE. THESE RESULTS WILL YIELD NEW INSIGHTS AS TO WHY PARTICULAR SLOPES BECOME CRITICALLY STRESSED, SUCH THAT THEY EXPERIENCE ACCELERATION AND FAILURE IN RESPONSE TO REMOVAL OF ICE SUPPORT, SUPPORTING LANDSLIDE HAZARD CHARACTERIZATION IN THE REGION AND IN THE FUTURE. THE WORK WILL BE COMPLETED BY GEOLOGY AND GEOPHYSICS / GEOLOGICAL ENGINEERING RESEARCHERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH, SUPERVISED BY PI DR. JEFFREY MOORE AND CONDUCTED THROUGH A PHD STUDY LED BY GRADUATE STUDENT MOLLY MCCREARY.
STREAM FLOW PERMEANCE (FLOWPER) AND ROAD/STREAM (ROADSTR) CROSSING SURVEYS

RESEARCHING EFFECTIVE GEOCAMP CURRICULA 07/15/2022 - 12/29/2023THE AMERICAN GEOSCIENCES INSTITUTE (AGI) PROPOSES A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT TO BE CONDUCTEDWITH THE USGS NATIONAL COOPERATIVE GEOLOGIC MAPPING PROGRAM (NCGMP) TO PROMOTE THE GOALS OF THEEDUCATION COMPONENT OF THE NCGMP. THE PROJECT WILL RESEARCH WAYS TO ENCOURAGE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTSTO CONSIDER CAREER OPTIONS IN THE GEOSCIENCES. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, AGI WILL UNDERTAKE A SET OF CLOSELYINTEGRATED ACTIVITIES THAT LEVERAGE AGI'S UNIQUE CAPABILITIES IN GEOSCIENCE EDUCATION AND WORKFORCEDEVELOPMENT.THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ENSURE THAT THE GEOCAMP CURRICULUM WILL INCORPORATE STATE-OF-THE ARTINSTRUCTIONAL STRATEGIES THAT WILL BE APPLIED IN THE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ACTIVITIES USED IN GEOCAMPPROGRAMS. THE ACTIVITIES IN THE CURRICULUM WILL BE BUILT ON A SET OF THEMES HIGHLIGHTING THE PRACTICE,PURPOSES, AND POTENTIAL OF THE GEOSCIENCES GENERALLY, AND GEOLOGIC MAPPING IN PARTICULAR. THE GEOCAMPPROGRAM ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR HIGH QUALITY PROGRAMMING THAT INFORMS AND INSPIRES YOUNG PEOPLE ABOUTTHE FASCINATING AND VITAL WORK DONE BY GEOSCIENTISTS. THE RESEARCH-BASED CURRICULUM MATERIALS THAT ARE TOBE DEVELOPED BY AGI WILL BUILD ON THE ENERGY AND ENTHUSIASM THAT IS INHERENT IN THE WORK OFGEOSCIENTISTS SO THAT IT CAN BE CONVEYED TO YOUNG PEOPLE WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE GEOCAMPS-MANY OFWHOM MAY OTHERWISE NOT HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENCOUNTER THE GEOSCIENCES IN SUCH AUTHENTIC ANDENGAGING WAYS.ALL ASPECTS OF THIS SCOPE OF WORK WILL BE UNDERTAKEN THROUGH RESEARCH-FOCUSED AND DATA-DRIVENPROCESSES. THE RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION INCLUDE THIRD PARTY DATA AND INFORMATION (E.G., IN SCHOLARLYJOURNALS), NON-SENSITIVE DATA AND INFORMATION GENERATED AND INTERPRETED WITHIN THE GEOCAMP PROGRAM(E.G., AGENDAS, TECHNICAL INSTRUCTION), AND SENSITIVE DATA AND INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM PARTICIPANTS(E.G., THEIR RESPONSES TO SPECIFIC PROGRAM ACTIVITIES). SEE THE DATA MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR HOW EACHCATEGORY OF DATA WILL BE MANAGED.THROUGH A PROCESS OF DATA-DRIVEN DESIGN-BASED RESEARCH, THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE A SET OF CURRICULARPRINCIPLES AND ACTIVITIES, AS WELL AS INSTRUCTIONAL APPROACHES THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO HIGHLIGHT LOCALGEOSCIENCE FEATURES IN THE SPECIFIC GEOCAMP SITES.

PROJECT TITLE PREDICTING SUCCESS OF BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OF WEEDS BY GEOGRAPHIC MAPPING OF RELEASE SITES PROJECT PERIOD  8 16 22 8 15 27EVALUATING THE SUCCESS RATE OF BIOLOGICAL CONTROL PROGRAMS  DOCUMENTING BOTH THE RATE OF SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENT OF BIOCONTROL AGENTS AND THEIR EFFECTIVENESS OF PEST CONTROL  HAS NOT BEEN SYSTEMATIC  THIS HAS RESULTED IN UNNECESSARY COSTS TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND COUNTY LAND MANAGERS WHEN REPEATED RELEASE EFFORTS ARE REDUNDANT OR INEFFECTUAL  THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS TO BUILD A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE OF ARTHROPOD BIOCONTROL AGENTS RELEASED AGAINST WEEDY PLANTS  SPECIFICALLY, TO PROVIDE IMPROVED, DETAILED GEOSPATIAL INFORMATION ON THE BIOCONTROL AGENTS RELEASED FOR CONTROL OF WEEDY AND INVASIVE PLANTS  WILL FIRST COMPILE RECORDS OF BIOCONTROL RELEASES FROM PUBLISHED RECORDS, UNPUBLISHED DATA FROM WEED BIOCONTROL RESEARCH GROUPS, AND FROM OBSERVATIONAL DATA  NEXT, WILL USE THIS COMPILED DATA TO DEVELOP GEOSPATIAL MODELS TO PREDICT LOCALITIES WHERE ESTABLISHMENT OF BIOCONTROL AGENTS IS LIKELY TO BE SUCCESSFUL AND LOCATIONS WHERE WORK IS REQUIRED TO OVERCOME CLIMATIC MISMATCHES TOGETHER, COMPLETION OF THESE OBJECTIVES WILL GENERATE A MUCH NEEDED, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE OF BIOCONTROL CONTROL AGENTS OF WEEDY AND INVASIVE PLANTS  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE USEFUL INFORMATION REGARDING THE CURRENT STATUS  ESTABLISHMENT, SUCCESSFUL CONTROL VS  LACK OF ESTABLISHMENT OR INEFFECTIVE CONTROL  OF WEED BIOCONTROL PROGRAMS AROUND THE US  SUCH A DATABASE WOULD PROVIDE GUIDANCE WHERE BIOCONTROL EFFORTS HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL  AND ADDITIONAL EFFORTS SHOULD BE LESS OF A PRIORITY  AND WHERE EFFORTS HAVE BEEN LESS SUCCESSFUL  AND MAY REQUIRE INCREASED RESOURCES TO MAKE THEM SUCCESSFUL  THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN MAPS OF THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION OF BIOCONTROL AGENTS THAT WILL INFLUENCE HOW AGENCIES DECIDE BETWEEN DIFFERENT CONTROL METHODS  THE PROJECT WILL SAVE COSTS IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF BIOCONTROL BY INDICATING HABITAT AND RELEASE CHARACTERISTICS ASSOCIATED WITH SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENT  BY MAPPING WHERE BIOCONTROL AGENTS SPREAD, THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE CONFIDENCE IN SOUND BIOCONTROL PRACTICES AND REDUCE INSTANCES WHERE GEOGRAPHIC UNCERTAINTIES LEAD TO BIOCONTROL FAILURE AND POSSIBLY ENVIRONMENTAL HARM  BY THE END OF YEAR 1  AND CONTINUING AS FUNDING PERMITS , WILL CREATE A DATABASE OF ATTEMPTED AND SUCCESSFUL BIOCONTROL RELEASE SITES THAT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO EXISTING ONLINE DISPLAY TOOLS, BOTH MOBILE APPS AND WEB  SCANNED DOCUMENTATION OF HISTORICAL RECORDS OF BIOCONTROL RELEASES WILL AVOID THE LOSS OF CRITICAL DATA THAT MIGHT OCCUR WITH THE RETIREMENT OF PERSONNEL  WILL OVERLAY AGENT RECORDS ON ALREADY AVAILABLE WEED DISTRIBUTION MAPS FOR A SIMPLE SYNTHESIS OF WHERE THEY ARE ESTABLISHED  IN YEARS TWO AND BEYOND  AGAIN, FUNDING PERMITTING , WILL CREATE MAPS OF HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR WIDESPREAD BIOCONTROL AGENTS BASED ON THEIR RELEASE RECORDS WITHIN THE US  PLAN TO PRODUCE AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION DESCRIBING THE PREDICTORS OF BIOCONTROL RELEASE SUCCESS  ALSO PLAN AT LEAST TWO PRESENTATIONS AT BIOCONTROL AND INVASIVE SPECIES MEETINGS DESCRIBING THIS WORK

PROJECT TITLE:FORECASTING HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA DISPERSAL IN MIGRATING WATERFOWL AND SPILLOVER RISK FOR DOMESTIC POULTRYPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/22-7/31/23MIGRATING WATERFOWL CAN QUICKLY SPREAD GOOSE/GUANGDONG HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA VIRUS (HPAI) ACROSS THE GLOBE, RESULTING IN SPILLOVER OUTBREAKS TO DOMESTIC POULTRY POPULATIONS. SUCH EVENTS REQUIRE DEPOPULATION OF POULTRY FLOCKS TO PREVENT FURTHER SPREAD, AND HPAI OUTBREAKS CAN RESULT IN ANIMAL HEALTH AND WELFARE ISSUES, ECONOMIC LOSSES, AND FOOD SUPPLY DISRUPTIONS. AIM TO PREDICT THE RISK OF HPAI SPILLOVER BY MATHEMATICALLY MODELING CONCURRENT WATERFOWL MIGRATION AND HPAI TRANSMISSION IN WATERFOWL POPULATIONS. WE WILL USE A MECHANISTIC AGENT-BASED MIGRATION MODEL THAT LINKS BIRD MOVEMENT TO DAILY WEATHER PATTERNS, FORAGE AVAILABILITY, AND BIRD ENERGETICS AND PHYSIOLOGY. WILL ADD DISEASE DYNAMICS TO THE MODEL AND INCORPORATE MAPS OF DOMESTIC POULTRY FARM DENSITIES TO ESTIMATE SPILLOVER PROBABILITIES FROM WATERFOWL TO DOMESTIC POULTRY OPERATIONS. IN ADDITION TO AT LEAST TWO PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS, WE AIM TO PRODUCE AN ONLINE AND UPDATABLE DASHBOARD DEPICTING MAPPED NEAR-TERM RISK FOR DOMESTIC POULTRY OPERATIONS IN NORTH AMERICA. THUS, THE WORK WILL INFORM PLANS FOR ORGANIZATIONS CONDUCTING NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL SURVEILLANCE OF HPAI IN WATERFOWL POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS PROVIDE REAL-TIME INFORMATION RELEVANT TO DOMESTIC POULTRY PRODUCERS AND OWNERS ACROSS NORTH AMERICA.

FUNDING   2   ASSESS THE EFFICACY OF CLIMATE ADAPTIVE REFORESTATION TREATMENTS AT PROMOTING TREE RECOVERY FOLLOWING WILDFIRE  SUBSEQUENT FUNDING IF AVAILABLE  THIS RESEARCH IS FOCUSED ON DRYLAND FOREST AND WOODLAND ECOSYSTEMS OF SOUTHWESTERN NATIONAL PARKS  TO ADDRESS THE IMPACTS OF THESE EVENTS, WILL COMBINE RECENT VEGETATION SURVEYS ACROSS VARIOUS VEGETATION TYPES  PONDEROSA PINE, PINON PROJECT TITLE: RADAR REMOTE SENSING ON MANGROVE FORESTPROJECT PERIOD: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 3/30/2023UCLA PI: MARC SIMARDTHE SILVACARBON INITIATIVE SUPPORTS THE DEVELOPMENT OF REMOTE SENSING METHODOLOGIES FOR THE PRESERVATION AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF MANGROVE FORESTS. THIS PROJECT WILL SPECIFICALLY SUPPORT COUNTRIES IN THREE REGIONS: SOUTH AMERICA, AFRICA, AND THE PACIFIC ISLANDS. THE METHODS WILL PRODUCE NATIONAL MAPS OF MANGROVE CANOPY HEIGHT AND BIOMASS. THIS RESEARCH WILL ASSIST THE SCIENCE OF TROPICAL COUNTRIES BY EXPLORING A METHODOLOGY TO ESTIMATE CARBON EMISSIONS FROM LAND COVER CHANGES. TO CALCULATE CARBON EMISSIONS, COUNTRIES REPORTING TO REDUCING EMISSIONS BY REDUCING DEFORESTATION AND FOREST DEGRADATION PROGRAMS MUST (A) IDENTIFY THE GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT OF MANGROVE FORESTS AND (B) ESTIMATE CARBON STOCKS PER HECTARE. UCLA WILL WORK WITH USGS AND COUNTRY STAKEHOLDERS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAPPING AND FIELD MEASUREMENTS. UCLA WILL BRING TOGETHER THESE TWO ELEMENTS TO PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE VIEW OF HOW TO ESTIMATE CARBON EMISSIONS AND TRANSFER THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED TO OUR IN-COUNTRY PARTNER GROUPS VIA TWO WORKSHOPS.

PROJECT TITLE:CHEMICAL ANALYSIS OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN GROUNDWATER SAMPLESPROJECT PERIOD: 6/16/2022-6/15/2027AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS FOR UMBC TO (I) PROVIDE EXPERTISE AND CHEMICAL ANALYSIS OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXPERIMENTAL SAMPLES COLLECTED BY PROJECT PARTNERS AT THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND UNITED STATES ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS AND (II) COLLABORATE ON PROJECTS INVOLVING THE OCCURRENCE FATE, AND TRANSPORT OF PFAS IN ENVIRONMENTAL SETTINGS. PFAS REPRESENT AN INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT CLASS OF CHEMICAL CONTAMINANTS THAT ARE PRESENT IN GROUNDWATER SYSTEMS AT MILITARY FACILITIES, AIRPORTS, AND ELSEWHERE. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP NEW INFORMATION ABOUT THE MOVEMENT OF PFAS IN SUBSURFACE ENVIRONMENTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY INVOLVES ANALYSIS OF 400 SAMPLES FOR PFAS CONCENTRATIONS USING STATE-OF-THE-ART ANALYTICAL METHODS AND QUALITY ASSURANCE AND QUALITY CONTROL PROTOCOLS. THESE SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED BY PROJECT PARTNERS AT A PILOT FACILITY AND DELIVERED TO UMBC FOR PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS. WE WILL ALSO PROVIDE EXPERTISE AND COLLABORATE WITH PROJECT PARTNERS ON DATA INTERPRETATION, EVALUATION, AND REPORTING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PLANNED PRODUCTS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE DETAILED ANALYTICAL METHODS (DOCUMENTS) AND COMPREHENSIVE DATA REPORTS (SPREADSHEETS). IN ADDITION, WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR PRESENTATION, INTERPRETATION, AND DISCUSSION OF ALL DATA FROM ENVIRONMENTAL, EXPERIMENTAL, AND QUALITY ASSURANCE/QUALITY CONTROL SAMPLES THROUGH BOTH IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL MEETINGS WITH THE PROJECT PARTNERS. WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR PERIODIC MEETINGS (E.G., MONTHLY, QUARTERLY) TO DISCUSS THE PROJECTS, SAMPLING CAMPAIGNS, ANALYTICAL RESULTS, AND OTHER DETAILS OF INTEREST TO PROJECT PARTNERS. WITH RESPECT TO EXTERNAL DISSEMINATION, WE EXPECT TO MOSTLY SHARE RESULTS THROUGH PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS LED BY PROJECT PARTNERS, BUT WE WILL EXPLORE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADDITIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE PRIMARY OUTCOME IS EXPECTED TO BE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF PFAS TRANSPORT IN SAND-BASED SUBSURFACE ENVIRONMENTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY: UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, UNITED STATES ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THAT ARE DEALING WITH PFAS-IMPACTED SITES.

PROJECT TITE:FERAL HORSE SURVEY ON TRIBAL LANDSPROJECT PERIOD: 7/1/22-6/30/23THE INTENDED BENEFICIARY OF THIS AWARD IS OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY.FERAL HORSES (EQUUS FERUS CABALLUS) RESIDING ON FEDERALLY-OWNED LAND ARE PROTECTED BY THE WILD FREE-ROAMING HORSES AND BURROS ACT, BUT CURRENT ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES ARE FAR GREATER THAN THE LAND CAN SUSTAINABLY SUPPORT. CONSIDERABLE ATTENTION HAS BEEN GIVEN TO OVERABUNDANT HORSE POPULATIONS ON FEDERALLY-MANAGED LAND, YET RECENT DATA INDICATES THAT OVERABUNDANT FERAL HORSES MAY BE A LARGER ISSUE ON TRIBAL LANDS.  FERAL HORSE GRAZING CAN NEGATIVELY AFFECT WESTERN RANGELANDS IN SEVERAL WAYS INCLUDING DECREASED NATIVE PLANT COVER, SHORTER GRASS HEIGHT, INCREASED SOIL COMPACTION, MORE INVASIVE SPECIES, AND INCREASED PROPORTIONS OF BARE GROUND. HORSE-INDUCED HABITAT ALTERATION IS A THREAT TO BOTH LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE. OVERABUNDANT HORSE POPULATIONS THREATEN THE CAPACITY OF WESTERN RANGELANDS TO PROVISION ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND THIS ISSUE IS LIKELY MOST ACUTE ON TRIBAL LANDS. TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS ARE LARGELY UNDERFUNDED AND THE FUNDING OF NATURAL RESOURCE DEPARTMENTS COME IN FAR BEHIND HUMAN HEALTH CONCERNS. IN FACT, MANY TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS TASK PEOPLE WITHOUT FORMAL NATURAL RESOURCE EDUCATIONS TO SERVE MULTIPLE ROLES. TRIBAL NATIONS ARE IN DESPERATE NEED OF ASSISTANCE IN DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR FERAL HORSES, BUT MANY LACK THE FIRST REQUIREMENT IN CREATING A MANAGEMENT PLAN - A ROBUST ABUNDANCE ESTIMATE. RIGOROUS ESTIMATES SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGERS IN MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, YET MOST FERAL HORSE ESTIMATES ON TRIBAL LANDS ARE BASED ON MINIMUM COUNTS OR GUESTIMATES. STATISTICALLY DEFENSIVE BASELINE ESTIMATES WILL AID TRIBES IN MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND PROVIDE THE SCIENCE SUPPORT THEY NEED TO DEFEND THEIR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO GENERATE STATISTICALLY-DEFENSIBLE POPULATION SIZE ESTIMATES OF FERAL HORSES ON TRIBAL LANDS. WE WILL TRAIN TRIBAL WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS AND/OR RANGELAND MANAGERS TO CONDUCT AERIAL SURVEYS AND ANALYZE COLLECTED DATA. BY HELPING TO ESTIMATE FERAL HORSE POPULATION SIZES AND TRAINING TRIBAL BIOLOGISTS IN SURVEY METHODOLOGY AND ANALYSIS, WE CAN HELP EMPOWER TRIBAL STEWARDSHIP OF FERAL HORSE HERDS. EACH PARTICIPATING TRIBE WILL OWN THE DATA OBTAINED FROM THE SURVEYS. FOLLOWING EACH SURVEY, WILL ALSO PROVIDE THE TRIBES WITH A WRITTEN REPORT INCLUDING A PROJECT NARRATIVE, ESTIMATE OF POPULATION SIZE, AND IMPORTANT NOTES FROM THE SURVEY. A CURATED DATASET WITH ASSOCIATED METADATA AND AN ANNOTATED STATISTICAL CODE WILL BE PROVIDED TO TRIBES AS WELL. IF GIVEN TRIBAL CONSENT, WILL COORDINATE WITH TRIBAL PARTNERS TO PRESENT RESEARCH RESULTS AT THE ANNUAL MEETINGS OF NATIVE AMERICAN FISH AND WILDLIFE SOCIETY, THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY, OR THE SOCIETY FOR RANGE MANAGEMENT AND PRODUCE A PEER-REVIEWED MANUSCRIPT FOLLOWING COMPLETION OF THE WORK.

ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, STATE OF ALASKAPROJECT PERIOD6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2025- AWARD PURPOSE;USGS MINERAL RESOURCES PROGRAM (MRP) GEOLOGISTS HAVE AN ONGOING PROJECT TO OBTAIN MODERN, REGIONAL-SCALE DATASETS FOR THE YUKON-TANANA UPLAND AND TO RECONCILE GEOLOGIC MAPS ACROSS THE ALASKA-YUKON BORDER. SIMILARLY, THE ALASKA DIVISION OF GEOLOGICAL & GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS (DGGS) HAS, AS DIRECTED BY ALASKA'S GEOLOGIC MAPPING ADVISORY BOARD (GMAB), RECENTLY INITIATED A LONG-TERM PLAN TO UPGRADE THE GEOLOGIC MAPS OF THE YUKON-TANANA UPLAND. ALASKA'S GMAB SELECTED THIS FOCUS REGION BASED ON ITS HIGH MINERAL POTENTIAL AND HIGH LEVEL OF INDUSTRY EXPLORATION ACTIVITY TARGETING A WIDE RANGE OF MINERAL COMMODITIES, AS WELL AS ITS DEFICIT OF MODERN AND DETAILED GEOLOGICAL DATA.- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED; DIVISION OF GEOLOGICAL & GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS PROPOSES TO CONDUCT THIS MAPPING IN A MANNER CONSISTENT WITH PAST DGGS EARTH MRI PROJECTS, USING A TEAM BASED APPROACH AND TEN WEEKS OF FIELDWORK. WE WILL RELY ON HELICOPTER SUPPORT AND ADHERE TO PROVISIONS OF THE ANNUALLY UPDATED DGGS FIELD SAFETY MANUAL. IN THE FIELD, DATA COLLECTION WILL BE FACILITATED BY HANDHELD TABLET COMPUTERS PRE-LOADED WITH ALL RELEVANT GEOPHYSICAL, GEOCHEMICAL, AND HISTORICAL/ADJACENT MAP SETS, WITH FINAL GEOLOGIC INTERPRETATIONS SUPPORTED BY POST-SEASON OFFICE AND LABORATORY WORK. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE COMPILED ELECTRONICALLY IN ARCGIS PRO SOFTWARE USING THE GEMS DATA MODEL AND PUBLISHED IN BOTH DIGITAL AND PRINTABLE PDF FORMATS ALONG WITH FGDC-COMPLIANT METADATA. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE SUBDIVIDED INTO MULTIPLE MAP SHEETS AND WILL BE PUBLISHED AS A MULTI-CHAPTER DGGS REPORT OF INVESTIGATIONS SERIES REPORT WHEN ALL GEOCHRONOLOGICAL RESULTS AND INTERPRETATIONS ARE COMPLETE.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES; - GEOLOGIC MAP OF THE MOUNT HARPER PROJECT AREA, EASTERN INTERIOR ALASKA (1:100,000 SCALE), WITH ACCOMPANYING DESCRIPTION OF MAP UNITS, CORRELATIONOF MAP UNITS, AND CROSS SECTIONS- PROJECT-RELATED DATA RELEASES INCLUDING FIELD STATION DATA, GEOCHEMISTRY, ANDGEOCHRONOLOGY- LEVEL-THREE GEMS COMPLIANT DATABASE- APPROXIMATELY 2,500 ARCHIVED NURE STREAM-SEDIMENT SAMPLES STORED IN THEUSGS WAREHOUSE IN DENVER, COLORADO- SAMPLES FOR REANALYSIS WILL BE SELECTED FROM THE EARTH MRI FOCUS AREAS FORALASKA IN COORDINATION WITH USGS- USGS WILL ASSUME RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROCESSING THE SAMPLES AND APPLYINGAPPROPRIATE QA/QC PROTOCOLS- THE RESULTS WILL BE RELEASED AS USGS DATA RELEASES, AS WELL AS THROUGH DGGS

TITLE:COOPERATIVE HYDROGEOPHYSICS AND WATER-RESOURCES RESEARCHBUDGET PERIOD: 06/01/2022 THROUGH 05/31/2023TOTAL PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 06/01/2022 THRU 05/31/2027THE COOPERATIVE HYDROGEOPHYSICS AND WATER-RESOURCES RESEARCH AGREEMENT IS A UNIQUE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) HYDROLOGIC REMOTE SENSING BRANCH (HRSB) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT (UCONN). THE 5-YEAR AGREEMENT ESTABLISHES A NEW PHASE OF A LONG-TERM SYMBIOTIC RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN USGS AND UCONN RESEARCHERS, GRADUATES, AND UNDERGRADUATE PARTNERS. THE PRINCIPAL PURPOSE OF THE AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT AND STIMULATE RESEARCH AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT ON THE USE OF HYDROGEOPHYSICAL METHODS FOR GROUNDWATER RESOURCES INVESTIGATIONS. THROUGH THIS PARTNERSHIP THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOCUSES ON THE DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF INNOVATIVE GEOPHYSICAL METHODS TO SUPPORT GROUNDWATER INVESTIGATIONS; IMPLEMENTS BEST PRACTICES METHODS OF SCIENTIFIC TESTING AND PERFORMING RELEVANT SCIENCE; AND PROMOTES THE TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW GENERATION OF EARTH SCIENTISTS. RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF RAPID, INEXPENSIVE, AND RELIABLE GEOPHYSICAL METHODS TO SUPPORT GROUNDWATER AND SURFACE WATER INVESTIGATIONS. MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE WORK EMPHASIZES THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW GEOPHYSICAL IMAGING METHODS AND IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING METHODS FOR FASTER, LESS EXPENSIVE, AND MORE PRECISE RESULTS FROM DATA FROM THERMAL, ELECTRICAL, ELECTROMAGNETIC, MAGNETIC RESONANCE, AND SEISMIC GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE BULK OF THIS WORK WILL BE PERFORMED BY UCONN GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, OVERSEEN AND GUIDED BY THE UCONN PI AND OTHER UCONN FACULTY IN COLLABORATION WITH SENIOR SCIENTISTS AT THE HRSB. THIS COLLABORATIVE MENTORSHIP WILL RESULT IN INFORMATION PRODUCTS (DATA RELEASES, PRESENTATIONS, AND PUBLICATIONS) AND GRADUATE THESIS THAT FURTHER EARTH SCIENCE RESEARCH. BOTH THE RECIPIENT AND USGS WILL CONTINUE SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT IN THE PROJECT WHICH INVOLVES SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATION AND COLLABORATION WITH NO PROCUREMENT OF GOODS AND SERVICES.

PROJECT TITLE:USING MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND TARGETED SAMPLING TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE BARCODE DATABASE FOR THE FRESHWATER MACROINVERTEBRATES OF THE UPPER COLORADO RIVERPROJECT PERIOD: 7/1/2022-6/30/2023USING MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND TARGETED SAMPLING TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE BARCODE DATABASE FOR FRESHWATER MACROINVERTEBRATES OF THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASINPROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE A SPECIES-LEVEL DNA BARCODING DATABASE FOR THE FRESHWATER INSECTS OF THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN. NEW METHODS IN DNA MONITORING, SUCH AS ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) METABARCODING, RELY ON WELL-CURATED REFERENCE DATABASES THAT CAN BE QUERIED DURING THE DATA ANALYSIS PROCESS. AQUATIC INSECTS ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN GENETIC DATABASES MAKING THEIR DEVELOPMENT A PRIORITY. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO FILL HOLES IN EXISTING DATABASES BY: (1) EVALUATING EXISTING MOLECULAR DATABASES TO DETERMINE WHICH GROUPS OF FRESHWATER INVERTEBRATES FROM THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN ARE UNDERREPRESENTED AND GENERATE A LIST OF PRIORITY TAXA FOR SEQUENCING, AND (2) USING TISSUE SAMPLES FROM REFERENCE COLLECTIONS AND TARGETED SAMPLING TO FILL IN THE GAPS IN REFERENCE DNA BARCODING DATABASES TO FACILITATE EDNA METABARCODING EFFORTS IN THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN. THESE OBJECTIVES WILL PRIMARILY BE FULFILLED BY THE PIS AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TRAINED IN DNA DATABASE CREATION AND CURATION, INSECT COLLECTION AND SAMPLING, DNA EXTRACTION, AMPLIFICATION, AND SEQUENCING. WILL TARGET SPECIES THAT ARE KNOWN FROM THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN BUT NOT WELL-REPRESENTED IN EXISTING DATABASES. WILL THEN PROCURE TISSUES FROM EXISTING MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND TARGETED FIELD SAMPLING TO GENERATE NEW DNA BARCODE SEQUENCES FOR THESE SPECIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESTHIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE A DNA BARCODING REFERENCE DATABASE FOR THE FRESHWATER INSECTS OF THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN. WE WILL TARGET ~600 SAMPLES REPRESENTING 100 DIFFERENT SPECIES OF INSECT. THIS DATABASE WILL BE IMMEDIATELY RELEASED TO THE PUBLIC TO FACILITATE ONGOING BIODIVERSITY MONITORING RESEARCH IN THE AREA. IN ADDITION TO THE NEWLY CURATED DNA BARCODING DATABASE, THE RESULTS FROM THIS WORK WILL BE FORMALLY DESCRIBED IN SCIENTIFIC PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESTHIS PROJECT WILL BE UNDERTAKEN BY DRS. PAUL FRANDSEN AND RILEY NELSON FROM BYU. TWO COLLABORATORS WILL ACT AS EXPERT CONSULTANTS: DR. RALPH HOLZENTHAL FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA AND DR. SCOTT HOTALING FROM UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY. THE DNA BARCODING DATABASE GENERATED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT RESEARCHERS IN THE MOUNTAIN WEST, INCLUDING NASCENT EFFORTS IN BIOMONITORING BY USGS PROFESSIONALS.
ESTUARINE WETLAND AND NEARSHORE ECOLOGY STUDIES ALONG THE PACIFIC FLYWAY

PROJECT TITLE: PECORA 22 CONFERENCE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/10/2022 THROUGH 12/31/2022OBJECTIVE: TO HOLD A CONFEERNCE TO PERFORM A RESEARCH ACTIVITY, COLLECTING AND MAKING AVAILABLE TO STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC, FEED BACK ON THE LANDSAT PROGRAM PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE ASSOCIATION OF STATE FLOODPLAIN MANAGERS, INC., REFENED TO AS ASFPM IN THIS REST OF THIS SUMMARY, SUBMITS THIS APPLICATION UNDER THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER G-G-RDC-22-001. IF SUCCESSFUL, THIS APPLICATION WILL ALLOW ASFPM TO PROVIDE THE SERVICES OF EVENT MANAGER OF THE PECORA 22 CONFERENCE. AS PART OF THESE SERVICES, ASFPM WILL COLLECT FEEDBACK ON THE LANDSAT PROGRAM FROM ATTENDEES OF THE PECORA 22 CONFERENCE, AND MAKE THAT FEEDBACK AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AND STAKEHOLDERS. THE PECORA 22 CONFERENCE IS A FORUM USED TO FOSTER THE EXCHANGE OF SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION AND RESULTS DERIVED FROM APPLICATION OF EMIH OBSERVING PROGRAMS, TECHNOLOGIES, AND DATA TO LEAD TO MORE INFORMED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, POLICY RELEVANT DECISION MAKING, AND OBJECTIVE SCIENTIFIC DISCOURSE AND UNDERSTANDING. IT IS SCHEDULED FOR FY 2023, OCTOBER 23 TO 28, 2022 IN DENVER, COLORADO. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  ASFPM WILL HOST THE EVENT WEBSITE AND REGISTRATION SYSTEM FOR ATTENDEES. ASFPM WILL CONTRACT WITH HOTEL(S) AND VENUES FOR FACILITIES. ASFPM WILL CONTRACT WITH GROUND TRANSPORTATION BETWEEN VENUES. ASFPM WILL PROVIDE ONSITE EVENT MANAGERS TO OVERSEE THE CONFERENCE.

PROJECT TITLE: COMPOUND FLOOD RISK FROM THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF SEA LEVEL RISE ON STORM SURGE, TIDAL ANDGROUNDWATER FLOODING, AND STORMWATER - THE URBAN DRAINAGE COMPONENTPROJECT PERIOD: 08/01/2022 THROUGH 07/31/2024ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE INTERACTION BETWEEN GROUNDWATER AND SEWER NETWORK IN COASTAL URBAN AREAS IS AN EMERGING ISSUE DUE TO SEA LEVEL RISE (SLR), MORE FREQUENT AND INTENSE PRECIPITATION EVENTS, AND THE AGING OF THE NETWORKS IN THE COUNTRY. THE INTERACTION BETWEEN GROUNDWATER AND SEWER NETWORK CAN MANIFEST ITSELF THROUGH PROCESSES CALLED INFILTRATION AND EXFILTRATION. INFILTRATION IS DUE TO GROUNDWATER ENTERING SEWER PIPES THROUGH CRACKS OR DISCONNECTED JOINTS. IT REDUCES THE CAPACITY OF THE SEWER NETWORK WHILE INCREASING THE FLOW WITHIN THE PIPES TRIGGERING FOR OVERFLOWS. EXFILTRATION IS DUE TO THE LEAKAGE OF UNTREATED WASTEWATER AT DAMAGED LOCATIONS OF THE SEWER NETWORK CONTAMINATING THE SUBSURFACE.IN THIS PROJECT TASK TITLED ASSESSMENT OF COMPOUND FLOOD RISK FROM THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF SEA LEVEL RISE ON STORM SURGE, TIDAL AND GROUNDWATER FLOODING, AND STORMWATER, WE WILL DEVELOP AN URBAN DRAINAGE MODEL OF SELECTED LOW-LYING URBAN AREAS IN LONG ISLAND WHICH ARE DENSELY POPULATED AND HAVE AGING INFRASTRUCTURE. THE MODEL WILL BE COUPLED WITH THE GROUNDWATER MODEL DEVELOPED WITHIN OTHER TASKS OF THIS PROJECT. WE WILL THEREFORE INVESTIGATE THE ROLE OF DRAINAGE NETWORKS IN COMPOUND FLOOD MODELING AND DETERMINE THE PROBABILITY OF GROUNDWATER-SEWER INTERACTION.THE ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE PERFORMED ARE: 1) IDENTIFICATION OF THE PARTS WITHIN BROOKLYN AND QUEENS WHERE THE UNCONFINED AQUIFER IS SHALLOW AND MAY INTERACT WITH SEWER INFRASTRUCTURE AND COLLECTION OF DATA; 2) IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SEWER MODEL IN SWMM AND COUPLING WITH THE GROUNDWATER MODEL IN MODFLOW; 3) IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STOCHASTIC MODEL OF SEWER INFILTRATION/EXFILTRATION AND DAMAGE; AND 4) VALIDATE THE COUPLED MODEL, PREDICTION UNDER FUTURE WEATHER SCENARIOS, AND DETERMINATION OF THE PROBABILITY OF GROUNDWATER-SEWER INTERACTION.THE DELIVERABLES CONSIST OF:DELIVERABLE 1- COLLECTION OF MAPS (E.G., SEWER NETWORK, PIPE MATERIAL, PIPE SIZE AND GEOMETRY; LAND USE, AND GEOLOGY) AND DATA (E.G., POPULATION, WATER CONSUMPTION, PRECIPITATION, FLOW MEASUREMENTS, INFILTRATION MEASUREMENTS, AND RENOVATION) TO BUILD SEWER NETWORK MODEL OF THE SELECTED URBAN AREAS. DELIVERABLE 2 - IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SEWER MODEL OF PARTS OF THE NEIGHBORHOODS OF BROOKLYN AND QUEENS COMBINING THE MAPS AND THE DATA COLLECTED.DELIVERABLE 3 - INTEGRATION OF THE SEWER MODEL WITH THAT OF THE GROUNDWATER WITHIN THE SHALLOW AQUIFER DELIVERABLE 4 - IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STOCHASTIC MODEL OF INFILTRATION/EXFILTRATION AND SEWER DETERIORATION.DELIVERABLE 5 - CALIBRATION AND VALIDATION OF THE MODEL FOR THE SELECTED AREAS, PREDICTIONS UNDER FUTURE SCENARIOS, AND CALCULATIONS OF INFILTRATION/EXFILTRATION PROBABILITYTHE PI OF THE PROJECT IS DR. VALENTINA PRIGIOBBE AT STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY (HOBOKEN, NJ). BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PEOPLE OF NEW YORK CITY AND LONG ISLAND.

PROJECT TITLE:MACHINE LEARNING FOR FLOW ESTIMATION USING CAMERA IMAGES AND PHYSICAL KNOWLEDGEPROJECT PERIOD: 6/1/22-5/31/23AWARD PURPOSE: TRADITIONAL PROCESS-BASED MODELS HAVE BEEN WIDELY USED TO SIMULATE WATER PROPERTIES BASED ON GENERAL PHYSICAL RELATIONSHIPS SUCH AS CONSERVATION OF ENERGY AND MASS. HOWEVER, THEY OFTEN SIMPLY AND ABSTRACT UNDERLYING PROCESSES DUE TO THE COMPLEXITY OF UNDERLYING PROCESSES AND THE SPATIAL HETEROGENEITY OF GEOLOGY AND TOPOGRAPHY. ALTERNATIVELY, MACHINE LEARNING METHODS HAS RECEIVED CONSIDERABLE ATTENTION FROM HYDROLOGISTS. ALTHOUGH THESE METHODS ARE CAPABLE OF EXTRACTING COMPLEX PATTERNS FROM DATA, THEY ARE STILL LIMITED FOR MONITORING SMALL HEADWATER STREAMS BECAUSE THE INPUT METEOROLOGICAL DATA ARE OFTEN COLLECTED AT A MUCH COARSER RESOLUTION, WHICH MAY IN TURN DEGRADE THE PREDICTION PERFORMANCE FOR SMALL STREAMS. RECENTLY, HYDROLOGICAL SCIENTISTS HAVE STARTED TO USE LOW-COST CAMERAS TO COLLECT FREQUENT IMAGES TO MONITOR MAJOR STREAM SITES. WITH THESE IMAGE DATA, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EXPLORE THE OPPORTUNITY TO USE MACHINE LEARNING MODELS TO EXTRACT STREAM CHARACTERISTICS AND LEVERAGE SUCH INFORMATION TO AUTOMATICALLY MONITOR STREAM DYNAMICS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT AIMS TO BUILD NEW MACHINE LEARNING ALGORITHMS FOR FLOW ESTIMATION VIA THREE INNOVATIONS. FIRST, A NEW DEEP LEARNING-BASED MODEL WILL BE DEVELOPED TO PREDICT STREAMFLOW USING CAMERA IMAGES, STREAM NETWORK TOPOLOGY, AND METEOROLOGICAL DATA. SECOND, THIS MODEL WILL ALSO BE TRAINED USING A TRANSFER LEARNING STRATEGY TO QUICKLY ADAPT TO A NEW STREAM SITE OR A DIFFERENT TIME PERIOD. THIRD, THE PHYSICAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT UNDERLYING PROCESSES WILL BE INTEGRATED WITH THE MACHINE LEARNING MODEL TO FURTHER IMPROVE ITS GENERALIZABILITY AND INTERPRETABILITY.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PLAN TO CREATE NEW ALGORITHMS FOR FLOW ESTIMATION AND PUBLISH THE ALGORITHMS AND RESULTS IN MAJOR JOURNALS IN HYDROLOGY AND MAJOR CONFERENCES IN DATA MINING AND ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE. WILL ALSO CREATE DATASETS FOR FLOW ESTIMATION USING THE PROPOSED METHODS. THE ALGORITHMS AND DATA HANDLING PROCEDURES WILL BE DEVELOPED IN SUCH A WAY THAT THEY ARE SCALABLE TO DIFFERENT STREAM SITES AND TO DIFFERENT YEARS. SUCH CURATED DATASETS CAN PROVIDE USEFUL INSIGHTS FOR BETTER UNDERSTANDING FLOW DYNAMICS OF A LARGE SCALE AND ALSO GREATLY ASSIST IN DECISION MAKING FOR BETTER WATER MANAGEMENT. FURTHERMORE, THE AVAILABILITY OF THESE DATASETS CAN ALSO CATALYZE USE OF THIS INFORMATION WITHIN THE DATA MINING AND MACHINE LEARNING COMMUNITIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES AND SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THIS AWARD WILL FUND PI JIA'S RESEARCH GROUP ON BUILDING MACHINE LEARNING METHODS FOR FLOW ESTIMATION AND STUDYING ITS IMPACT ON FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. IT WILL ALSO BE USED TO FUND GRADUATE STUDENTS FOR IMPLEMENTING ALGORITHMS AND PREPARING PUBLICATIONS.

PROJECT TITLE: COMPLETION OF MAGNETOTELLURI ARRAY IN CONUS - PHASE 2PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2024AWARD PURPOSE - THIS PROPOSAL IS TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT USGS'S AIM TO COMPLETE THE LONGPERIODMAGNETOTELLURIC (MT) TRANSPORTABLE ARRAY (MTARRAY) SURVEY THROUGHOUT THE REMAININGTERRITORY OF THE CONTERMINOUS UNITED STATES (CONUS). EXECUTIVE ORDER 13865 DIRECTS THESECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR TO: 'TO COMPLETE A MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEY OF THE CONTIGUOUS UNITEDSTATES TO HELP CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE OWNERS AND OPERATORS CONDUCT EMP VULNERABILITYASSESSMENTS'.FROM APRIL 2020 THROUGH MAY 2022 USGS AND OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU) HAVE SITED,PERMITTED, INSTALLED, OPERATED, EXTRACTED, AND CARRIED OUT DATA ANALYSIS AND DATA ARCHIVAL FORMTARRAY UNDER COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT G20AC00094. WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE THIS ACTIVITY FORTWO YEARS UNDER A NEW COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, WITH THE GOAL OF COMPLETING THE MTARRAY OVER THEENTIRETY OF THE CONTERMINOUS US BY THE END OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PERIOD.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - OSU WILL PROVIDE 4X4 FIELD TRUCKS AND SPECIALIZED MTINSTRUMENTATION TO MEASURE THE TIME-VARIATIONS IN THE NATURALLY OCCURRING ELECTRIC AND MAGNETICFIELDS AT GROUND LEVEL TO FIELD CREWS THAT WILL INSTALL AND OPERATE THE EQUIPMENT TYPICALLY FOR 3-6WEEKS PER SITE, COVERING A REGION IN THE SOUTHERN US ADJOINING AND INLAND OF THE GULF COAST ON AGRID OF LOCATIONS SPACED TYPICALLY 70 KM APART. THE STATIONS ARE EXTRACTED AFTER DATA QUALITYSTANDARDS HAVE BEEN MET FOLLOWING DATA ANALYSIS BY OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY AND USGS.A TOTAL OF 116 MT STATION INSTALLATIONS ARE PLANNED EACH YEAR OVER THE TWO-YEAR PERIOD OF THECOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, OF WHICH 101 ARE AT PRIMARY STATION INSTALLATION TARGET LOCATIONS, AND 15PER YEAR ARE RELOCATIONS TO ALTERNATIVE SITES WHEN LOCAL NOISE SOURCES OR OTHER OPERATING FACTORSMAKE THE PRIMARY STATION LOCATION UNSUITABLE FOR ACHIEVING DATA QUALITY STANDARDS. AT EACH STATIONLOCATION, MEASUREMENTS OF VECTOR ELECTRIC AND MAGNETIC FIELDS SAMPLED ONCE EACH SECOND, ANDCALCULATED ELECTROMAGNETIC IMPEDANCE AND MAGNETIC FIELD INDUCTION VECTORS, QUANTITIES SENSITIVETO THE ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES OF THE EARTH'S CRUST AND UPPER MANTLE WILL BE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES,ALONG WITH SUPPORTING METADATA AND DAILY FIELD CREW PRODUCTION REPORTS.BENEFICIARIES - THE MT DATA AND DERIVED DATA PRODUCTS ARE OF DIRECT BENEFIT TO POWER UTILITIES,INDUSTRY GROUPS AND FEDERAL REGULATORS IN THEIR EFFORTS TO PROTECT THE POWER TRANSMISSION NETWORKFROM THE IMPACTS OF SPACE WEATHER (GEOMAGNETICALLY INDUCED CURRENTS OR GICS) ON THETRANSMISSION SYSTEM. OTHER POTENTIAL BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE PIPELINE OPERATORS, ALSO SUBJECT TO RISKFROM GICS, AS WELL AS DOWNSTREAM OPERATORS OF OTHER CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEPENDENT ONUNINTERRUPTED POWER AND PIPELINE PRODUCTS, AND NATIONAL LABS, ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS AND OTHERSAPPLYING THESE DATA TO FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH INTO EARTH STRUCTURE AND GEOSPACE SCIENCE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES - GREEN GEOPHYSICS IS OSU'S CONTRACTOR FOR SECURING SITE USE PERMITSAND FOR PROVIDING FIELD CREWS TO CARRY OUT THE MT STATION INSTALLATIONS. CHAYTUS RESEARCH ANDENGINEERING LLC PROVIDES MT INSTRUMENTATION ENGINEERING SUPPORT FOR OPERATION ANDMAINTENANCE OF OSU'S MT INSTRUMENTATION.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) FEDERALLY OWNED ENERGY AND MINERALS RESEARCH FACILITY (EMRF) IN GOLDEN, CO COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THEUNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) AND COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES.THE USGS GEOLOGY, GEOPHYSICS, AND GEOCHEMISTRY (G3) AND CENTRAL ENERGY RESOURCES (CER), SCIENCE CENTERS PROVIDE UNIQUE RESEARCH AND OPERATIONAL CAPABILITIES IN CRITICAL MINERALS, ENERGY RESOURCE EVALUATION, AND OTHER ESSENTIAL ENERGY AND MINERAL PROGRAM PRIORITIES FOR THE USGS AND DOI.THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (BIL), THE USGS WILL VASTLY EXPAND INVESTMENTS IN CRITICAL MINERALS RESEARCH, ADVANCE THE DATA PRESERVATION OF GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA, AND SUPPORT CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW USGS RESEARCH FACILITY TO SUPPORT ENERGY AND MINERALS RESEARCH. THE USGS IS COMMITTED TO INVESTING IN OUR NATION'S INFRASTRUCTURE AND ADVANCING THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE CLEAN ENERGY SUPPLY CHAIN. A NEW FACILITY WILL ENABLE COOPERATIVE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH, EDUCATIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND TECHNOLOGICAL COLLABORATION TO MAXIMIZE CONTRIBUTIONS TO BASIC AND APPLIED EARTH SCIENCES FOR THE PURPOSE OF SOLVING NATURAL RESOURCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS, AND BENEFITTING LOCAL COMMUNITIES, GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC OF COLORADO AND THE NATION.THE BIL PROVIDES $167 MILLION DIRECTLY TO THE USGS TO SUPPORT THE NEW ENERGY AND MINERALS RESEARCH FACILITY (EMRF). FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF A USGS-OWNED FACILITY TO SUPPORT ENERGY AND MINERALS RESEARCH AND APPURTENANT ASSOCIATE STRUCTURES, THROUGH A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH AN ACADEMIC PARTNER. FUNDING IS PLANNED TO BE AVAILABLE IN FY 2022 UNTIL EXPENDED.ADDITIONAL FY 2023 AND FY 2024 FUNDING IS ANTICIPATED BY THE USGS INFRASTRUCTURE FIVE-YEAR PLAN TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT. ADDITIONAL FUNDING AMOUNTS WILL BE DETERMINED BY THE PROGRAM VALIDATION AND SCHEMATIC DESIGN TASK EFFORTS. USGS ENERGY AND MINERALS SCIENCE CAPABILITIES AND SPACE REQUIREMENTS WILL BE THE HIGHEST PRIORITY.THE U. S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY INTENDS TO ESTABLISH A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES (MINES) FOR THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW FEDERALLY OWNED ENERGY AND MINERALS RESEARCH FACILITY (EMRF) TO BE LOCATED ON LAND OWNED BY MINES. THE NEW LABORATORY AND OFFICE FACILITY WILL SUPPORT USGS AND MINES ENERGY AND MINERAL SCIENCE OPERATIONS.PHASE 1 OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FOCUS ON THE PROGRAM VALIDATION AND SCHEMATIC DESIGN ACTIVITIES OF THE PROJECT. PURSUANT TO THE REQUIREMENTS FOR A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, USGS WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED THROUGHOUT PHASE 1 AND THE ENTIRE PROJECT ENSURING FEDERAL BUILDING REQUIREMENTS ARE INTEGRATED IN THE DESIGN AND THE NEW SPACE SUPPORTS USGS SCIENCE IN FURTHERANCE OF PROGRAMMATIC MISSION REQUIREMENTS.THE PROJECT SHALL BE LOCATED ON THE MINES CAMPUS WITH THE NEW FACILITY BEING ADJACENT TO THE EXISTING USGS GEOLOGIC HAZARDS SCIENCE CENTER.

PROJECT TITLE:HYDRODYNAMIC SUPPORT FOR COASTAL ECOSYSTEM RESTORATIONPROJECT PERIOD: 8/9/2022-8/8/2023AWARD PURPOSENUISANCE ALGAE IN THE NEARSHORE AREAS OF THE GREAT LAKES NEGATIVELY IMPACT ECOSYSTEMS, HUMAN HEALTH AND LOCAL ECONOMIES. THE AIM OF THE CESU AGREEMENT IS TO EXTEND THE DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS COMPONENTS OF THE ONGOING USGS-LED GREAT LAKES INTEGRATED CLADOPHORA MONITORING PROJECT BY COLLECTING HIGH-QUALITY HYDRODYNAMIC AND WATER QUALITY DATA INCLUDING DATA ON CURRENTS, WAVES, TEMPERATURE AND SUSPENDED SEDIMENT CONCENTRATIONS AND COMBINING THE DATA WITH DIFFERENT TYPES OF MODELING APPROACHES TO UNDERSTAND PROCESSES, TO QUANTIFY RATES AND TO MAKE PREDICTIONS. THE NEW DATASETS AND ANALYSES WILL EXTEND THE SCOPE OF THE DATA THAT ARE BEING COLLECTED AND WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF COUPLED PHYSICAL - BIOLOGICAL MODELS IN THE GREAT LAKES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDDEPLOYMENT OF ACOUSTIC DOPPLER CURRENT PROFILERS AND OTHER SENSORS (E.G., THERMISTOR CHAINS, SENSORS TO OBSERVE PARTICLE PROCESSES ETC) AT SELECTED SITES IN THE NEARSHORE AREAS OF GREAT LAKESUSING THE DATA TO DEVELOP AND TEST MODELS FOR HYDRODYNAMICS AND TRANSPORT OF NUTRIENTS AND ALGAEDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:HIGH-RESOLUTION HYDRODYNAMIC AND WATER QUALITY DATAANALYSIS OF OBSERVED DATA AND MODEL OUTPUTSPEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS AT CONFERENCESINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)PUBLIC AND RESEARCHERS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION

PROJECT: AMPHIBIAN DEMOGRAPHY AND RANGE CHANGES IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN WESTRESEARCH IS TO SUPPORT THIS PROJECT HAS MULTIPLE FOCI. THE FIRST FOCUS IS ON ESTIMATING AMPHIBIAN VITAL RATES (E.G., SURVIVAL, RECRUITMENT) AND DETERMINING THE EFFECTS OF DISEASE ON VITAL RATES FOR POPULATIONS IN ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK (COLORADO), BRIDGER-TETON NATIONAL FOREST (WYOMING), AND STATE AND NATIONAL FORESTS IN MONTANA.THE SECOND FOCUS IS TO EXAMINE THE BROAD SCALE PRESENCE OF DISEASE AND ITS EFFECTS ON AMPHIBIAN POPULATIONS IN THE GYE.THE THIRD FOCUS IS TO SUPPORT EFFORTS TO EXAMINE THE CURRENT VERSUS HISTORIC RANGE OF SEVERAL SPECIES OF AMPHIBIAN.DELIVERABLES:QUALITY ASSURED/QUALITY CHECKED DATABASES OF CAPTURE-RECAPTURE HISTORIES, SURVEY RECORDS, DATABASES OF SITE COVARIATE VALUES (E.G., POND PERIMETERS, WATER QUALITY METRICS, SITE PHOTOGRAPHS), AND RAW DATASHEETS, FOR BOREAL TOADS AT THE 6 SITES LOCATED NEAR THE BLACKROCK RANGER STATION IN TETON COUNTY. QUALITY ASSURED/QUALITY CHECKED DATABASES AND RAW DATA SHEETS FOR EGG MASS SURVEYS FOR COLUMBIA SPOTTED FROGS AND CALL SURVEYS FOR BOREAL CHORUS FROGS.UP TO 20 SWABS FROM BOREAL TOADS AT THE 6 SITES (ABOVE). SWABS WILL BE IN LABELED VIALS (SPECIES, DATE, SEX, ID, LOCATION). ADDITIONAL SWABS TO BE DETERMINED (SEE ABOVE) AND A DATABASE INCLUDING ALL SWAB INFORMATION (DETAILED ABOVE). QUALITY ASSURED/QUALITY CHECKED DATABASES OF SURVEY LOCATIONS (I.E., UTMS), SPECIES FOUND, TIMING OF SURVEYS AND RAW DATASHEETS FOR ALL VISUAL ENCOUNTER SURVEYS (I.E., OCCURRENCE DATA) FOR NORTHERN LEOPARD FROGS.  5. PROVIDE A YEARLY PROGRESS REPORT TO THE USGS PIS

PROJECT TITLE:ASSESSMENT OF INFLUENZA A VIRUS DEPOSITION AND VIABILITY IN SIMULATED WETLAND ENVIRONMENTSPROJECT PERIOD: 6/1/22-5/31/23TRANSMISSION OF INFLUENZA A VIRUSES (IAVS) AMONG WILD BIRDS IS PURPORTED TO OCCUR PRIMARILY THROUGH AQUATIC HABITS INCLUDING LAKES, RESERVOIRS, WETLANDS, AND COASTAL AREAS. HOWEVER, HOW IAVS ARE MAINTAINED AND TRANSMITTED AT THE AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS ARE NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD. IN THIS STUDY, WE PROPOSE TO STUDY HOW ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AFFECT THE VIABILITY OF IAVS IN SIMULATED WETLAND ENVIRONMENTS AND FURTHER TO STUDY HOW THE FECAL PARTICLES OF WILD AQUATIC BIRDS TRANSPORT AND SPREAD IAVS ACROSS THESE ENVIRONMENTS, POSING INFECTION RISKS TO WILDLIFE, DOMESTIC ANIMALS, AND HUMANS. SPECIFICALLY, THE VARIATIONS IN PARTICLE SIZE DISTRIBUTION, SETTLING VELOCITY, PARTICLE INDUCED FLOW VELOCITY, AND TURBULENT STATISTICS WILL BE EVALUATED FOR THEIR EFFECTS ON DYNAMICS OF FECAL PARTICLE DEPOSITION, AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, SUCH AS TEMPERATURE, UV DOSAGE AND DURATION, EVAPORATION LEVEL, IN THE WETLAND VIRAL TREATMENT WILL BE SIMULATED FOR THEIR EFFECTS ON IAV VIABILITY. THIS STUDY WILL HELP LEARN THE KEY PARAMETERS IN TRANSPORT AND DISSEMINATION OF FECAL PARTICLES IN WETLAND AND THEIR ASSOCIATION WITH IAV DISPERSION AND FURTHER SHED LIGHT ON THE PARAMETERS FOR A FEW IMPORTANT ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS EFFECTIVELY INACTIVATING IAVS. OVERALL, THIS STUDY WILL HELP FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF POLICIES FOR AVIAN IAV MANAGEMENT AT THE WETLAND SETTINGS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERS AND SCIENTISTS, RESOURCES MANAGERS FOR LAKES, RESERVOIRS, WETLANDS, AND COASTAL WATERS, DECISION MAKER. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL BE DISSEMINATED IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES AND CONFERENCES.

PROJECT TITLE:RESTORATION OF LAKE ONTARIO NATIVE FISH SPECIESPROJECT PERIOD: 06/01/2022-05/31/2023ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITIES HAVE GREATLY IMPACTED FISH POPULATIONS IN THE GREAT LAKES. OF ALL THE GREAT LAKES, FISH POPULATIONS IN LAKE ONTARIO HAVE BEEN IMPACTED THE MOST SEVERELY, INCLUDING THE EXTIRPATION OF ATLANTIC SALMON AND DEEPWATER COREGONINES, SUCH AS BLOATER, AND MAJOR DECLINES IN LAKE STURGEON, DEEPWATER SCULPIN, LAKE HERRING AND AMERICAN EEL. LOSS OF SPAWNING HABITAT AND PERHAPS OVERFISHING ARE THOUGHT TO BE THE MAJOR CAUSES FOR THE LOSS OF ATLANTIC SALMON AND LAKE STURGEON, WHEREAS INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS ALEWIFE AND RAINBOW SMELT ARE CONSIDERED TO HAVE LED THE DECLINE OF COREGONIDS AND DEEPWATER SCULPIN, AS WELL AS ATLANTIC SALMON (I.E. THIAMINE DEFICIENCY). BECAUSE OF THE COMPLEXITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE EXTIRPATION OR DECLINE OF NATIVE FISH SPECIES IN THE GREAT LAKES, THERE IS NO SINGLE REMEDY SUITABLE FOR THE RESTORATION OF ALL SPECIES. UNFORTUNATELY, ALTHOUGH ALEWIFE POPULATIONS IN LAKE ONTARIO ARE DECLINING, THERE ARE NO DEEPWATER COREGONIDS REMAINING IN THE LAKE TO ENABLE NATURAL RECOVERY. CONSEQUENTLY, THE RESTORATION OF DEEPWATER COREGONIDS, AS WELL AS EXTIRPATED ATLANTIC SALMON, MUST AT LEAST INITIALLY RELY ON HATCHERY REARED FISH. THE FOCUS OF THIS NATIVE SPECIES RESTORATION EFFORT WILL BE LAKE ONTARIO AND THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER, WHICH SUPPORTS USGS PROGRAM PRIORITIES AND REQUIREMENTS.THIS EFFORT WILL CONSIST OF THREE SEPARATE THRUSTS GEARED AT RESTORING ATLANTIC SALMON, AND COREGONIDS, IN LAKE ONTARIO AND THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER.ATLANTIC SALMON: FACILITATE THE RE-INTRODUCTION OF EXTIRPATED ATLANTIC SALMON IN LAKE ONTARIO AND THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AND INNOVATIVE RESTORATION TECHNIQUES.DEEPWATER COREGONIDS: FACILITATE THE RE-INTRODUCTION OF EXTIRPATED DEEPWATER COREGONINE FISHES IN LAKE ONTARIO THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AND INNOVATIVE TECHNIQUES WHILE FOLLOWING PROPER DISEASE PROTOCOLS WHEN TRANSFERRING EGGS TO ISOLATION FACILITIES.CISCO: FACILITATE THE RECOVERY OF CISCO IN LAKE ONTARIO THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AND INNOVATIVE REARING TECHNIQUES AND THE EVALUATION OF THE SUITABILITY OF HISTORIC SPAWNING SITES AS STOCKING LOCATIONS.PLANNED PRODUCTS AND DISSEMINATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS- THE MOST OBVIOUS PRODUCT OF THE COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WILL BE THE ANNUAL NUMBER OF FISH THAT ARE REARED AND EXPERIMENTALLY RELEASED FOR RESTORATION PURPOSES AND INFORMATION ABOUT THE SUCCESS OF THOSE RELEASES AND ADULTS RETURNING TO RELEASE SITES. THESE RELEASES WILL FORM THE BASIS FOR PRESENTATIONS, TECHNICAL REPORTS, AND MANUSCRIPTS SUBMITTED TO PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL BE GENERATED AND PROVIDED TO USGS AND FUNDING AGENCIES.

PROJECT TITLE:PREDICTING INVASION HOTSPOTS FOR AQUATIC ORGANISMS ACROSS THE U.S. LANDSCAPEPROJECT PERIOD: 6/1/2022-5/31/2023STREAM ECOSYSTEMS ACROSS THE U.S. CURRENTLY SUPPORT MANY NONINDIGENOUS AQUATIC SPECIES (NAS) FROM A VARIETY OF TAXONOMIC GROUPS WITH NATIVE ORIGINS IN COUNTRIES FROM ACROSS THE GLOBE. THESE ORGANISMS HAVE HAD MANY NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON NATIVE STREAM COMMUNITIES AND THEIR HABITATS AS WELL AS HUMAN USES OF STREAMS, AND IN SOME CASES, HAVE REQUIRED EXTENSIVE EFFORTS TO CONTROL THEIR SPREAD. WHILE STUDIES PROVIDE NUMEROUS INSIGHTS INTO THE LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS AND IMPACTS OF PARTICULAR INVASIVE SPECIES, UNANSWERED QUESTIONS REMAIN ABOUT THE GENERAL NATURE OF NAS IN STREAMS. FOR EXAMPLE, WHAT LOCATIONS MAY BE MOST VULNERABLE TO FUTURE INVASIONS? ALSO, WHICH ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS ARE MOST LIKELY TO PROMOTE ESTABLISHMENT AND SPREAD AFTER INVASIONS OCCUR? TO ANSWER THESE QUESTIONS, IT IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND NOT JUST SPECIFIC CHARACTERISTICS OF INTRODUCED SPECIES BUT ALSO THE FACTORS THAT GOVERN THEIR DISTRIBUTIONS IN STREAM ECOSYSTEMS. THE GOALS OF THIS STUDY ARE TO PREDICT FUTURE RISK OF INVASION BY NAS ACROSS THE CONTERMINOUS U.S. USING COMPLEX STATISTICAL MODELS AND TO PROVIDE NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGERS WITH INSIGHTS INTO THOSE REGIONS AT HIGH RISK, IDENTIFYING "HOTSPOTS" OF FUTURE INVASIONS AND THE FACTORS MOST LIKELY TO FACILITATE INVASION SUCCESS. IN SUPPORT OF THE GOALS, WILL FIRST IDENTIFY THOSE AQUATIC SPECIES LIKELY TO INVADE U.S. STREAMS FROM THE INVASIVE AQUATIC SPECIES WATCH LIST. NEXT, WILL ASSEMBLE LANDSCAPE DATASETS INCLUDING NATURAL LANDSCAPE FACTORS AND HUMAN STRESSORS THAT MAY PROMOTE INVASIONS AS WELL AS CLIMATE VARIABLES THAT MAY INDICATE BROAD SUITABILITY OF HABITATS FOR SPECIES FROM THE WATCH LIST. WITH THESE DATA, WILL DEVELOP SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS TO PREDICT POTENTIAL PRESENCE OF THE WATCH LIST SPECIES. FOLLOWING DEVELOPMENT OF OUR MODELS, WILL MAP THE LIKELY OCCURRENCE OF EACH WATCH LIST SPECIES TO IDENTIFY HOTSPOTS OF INVASION ACROSS THE CONTERMINOUS U.S. DATA DEVELOPED IN SUPPORT OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE SUMMARIES OF NATURAL LANDSCAPE FACTORS AND HUMAN STRESSORS IN STREAM CATCHMENTS AND BUFFERS, SUMMARIES OF CLIMATE DATA, DATA DESCRIBING ACCESS TO WATERBODIES INCLUDING LOCATIONS OF BOAT RAMPS, AND CONNECTIVITY AMONG WATER BODIES. ADDITIONALLY, THE MODELED RESULTS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE IN TABULAR AND SPATIAL FORMATS TO FACILITATE USE BY MANAGERS. ANTICIPATE THAT THE IDENTIFICATION OF LOCATIONS AT RISK OF INVASIONS CAN BE USED BY NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO INFORM THEIR DECISION MAKING RELATED TO REDUCING RISKS FROM INVASIVE SPECIES. THIS INITIAL PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON FRESHWATER SPECIES, BUT THE DEVELOPED FRAMEWORK AND DELIVERABLES MAY BE INFORMATIVE FOR OTHER TAXONOMIC GROUPS AS WELL.
