PROJECT TITLE:DEVELOPING A MACROECOLOGICAL UNDERSTANDING OF INVASIVE PLANT IMPACTS BASED ON ABUNDANCE AND TRAIT DATAPROJECT PERIOD: 05/01/2022-04/30/2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: UNDERSTANDING VARIABILITY IN INVASIVE PLANT IMPACTS CAN PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO COMMUNITY ASSEMBLY AND INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES DEPEND ON HOW THEY ALTER PATTERNS OF ABUNDANCE WITHIN RECIPIENT COMMUNITIES AND ON THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE INVADER AND THE AFFECTED SPECIES. RESEARCH HAS SUGGESTED THAT COMMON SPECIES MAY BE MORE IMPACTED BY INVASIONS, AND THAT SIMILARITY BETWEEN NATIVE AND INVASIVE SPECIES UNDERLIES IMPACT. PROPOSE TO BRING TOGETHER THESE TWO COMPONENTS AND QUANTIFY THE RESULTING RESHAPING OF COMMUNITIES IN A SYNTHESIS OF INVASION IMPACT ACROSS ECOSYSTEMS. FUNCTIONAL TRAITS ARE CHARACTERISTICS OF AN ORGANISM THAT INFLUENCE ITS RESPONSES TO THE ENVIRONMENT AND ITS EFFECTS ON ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES. FUNCTIONAL TRAITS MEDIATE THE SUCCESS OF AN INVASION, THE IMPACTS ON OTHER SPECIES, AND THE CONSEQUENCES FOR ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. THUS, UNDERSTANDING THE INFLUENCE OF FUNCTIONAL TRAITS COULD LEAD TO MORE TARGETED MANAGEMENT OF ECOSYSTEMS WITH THE GREATEST SUSCEPTIBILITY TO INVASIVE SPECIES IMPACTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE MACROECOLOGICAL SYNTHESIS WILL LEVERAGE A RECENT DATA COMPILATION TO ASK: 1) DO INVASIVE SPECIES DISPROPORTIONATELY REDUCE THE ABUNDANCE OF COMMON AND FUNCTIONALLY SIMILAR NATIVE SPECIES?; 2) HOW DO INVASIONS SHIFT TRAIT DISTRIBUTIONS WITHIN COMMUNITIES?; AND 3) HOW DO INVASIONS UNDERLIE BIOTIC HOMOGENIZATION OF SPECIES COMPOSITION, FUNCTIONAL TRAITS, AND PHYLOGENETIC DIVERSITY? THE DATA ARE DERIVED FROM APPROXIMATELY 50,000 PLOTS ACROSS NATURAL AREAS OF THE U.S., WITH AN EMPHASIS ON FEDERALLY MANAGED LANDS. BY INCREASING THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLES OF ABUNDANCE AND FUNCTIONAL TRAITS IN INVASIONS, WORK WILL ADVANCE ECOLOGICAL THEORY AND INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WILL SYNTHESIZE THE IMPACTS OF PLANT INVASIONS TO PROVIDE THE FIRST MACROECOLOGICAL TESTS OF HOW RARITY AND TRAIT DISSIMILARITY ALTER NATIVE SPECIES RESPONSES TO INVASION. THIS WORK WILL LEVERAGE ECOLOGICAL THEORY TO EXPLAIN VARIABILITY IN INVADER IMPACTS, AND WILL PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR MANAGEMENT BASED ON SPECIES' FUNCTIONAL TRAITS. THE EMPIRICAL SYNTHESIS DRAWS ON THE LARGEST COMPILATION OF COMPLETE-COMMUNITY DATA REPRESENTING THE ABUNDANCE AND IMPACTS OF NORTH AMERICAN INVASIVE PLANTS. THIS FULL-COMMUNITY PERSPECTIVE ENABLES LINKAGES TO ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES VIA THE FUNCTIONAL TRAITS THAT PREDOMINATE WITHIN A COMMUNITY. THE WORK WILL QUANTIFY HOW SHIFTS IN OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECT COMMON AND DISSIMILAR SPECIES, AND THEREBY ALTER THE DISTRIBUTION OF FUNCTIONAL TRAITS. TO DATE, THE UNDERSTANDING OF SCALE DEPENDENCE IN INVASION ECOLOGY HAS FOCUSED ON SPECIES RICHNESS, AND THE WORK WILL PRODUCE THE FIRST ANALYSIS OF HOW SPECIES TRAIT DISTRIBUTIONS CAN BE ALTERED BY INVASION FROM PLOT TO ECOREGIONAL SCALES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE WORK WILL SYNTHESIZE UNDERUTILIZED DATA COLLECTED BY FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO INFORM THE MANAGEMENT OF PLANT INVASIONS IN NATURAL AREAS. THE DATA WERE COLLECTED ON FEDERAL AND PRIVATE LANDS, AND REPRESENT SYSTEMS THAT ARE LESS DISTURBED THAN MOST LANDSCAPES WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. AS SUCH, THE RESULTS WILL HIGHLIGHT THE IMPACTS OF INVASIONS IN AREAS WHERE INVASIVE SPECIES ARE ONE OF THE PREDOMINANT THREATS TO BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. HAVE ONGOING COLLABORATIONS WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAND MANAGERS AND PLANNERS, AND AIM TO INFORM ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS TO ADVANCE FUNDAMENTAL SCIENCE.

PROJECT TITLE:IS CONTEMPORARY PRODUCTIVITY A LIMITING FACTOR FOR NATIVE FISHES? ESTIMATING ECOSYSTEM PRODUCTION ACROSS GRADIENTS OF RIVER ALTERATION IN THE COLORADO RIVER BASINPROJECT PERIOD: 04/15/2022 - 04/14/2027AWARD PURPOSE: THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN (CRB) IS ONE OF THE MOST OVERALLOCATED RIVER NETWORKS IN THE WORLD AND IS EXPERIENCING DECLINING WATERSHED RUNOFF DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. MOST FISH SPECIES NATIVE TO THE CRB ARE FOUND NOWHERE ELSE AND HAVE DECLINED DRAMATICALLY COINCIDENT WITH THE DAMMING AND REGULATION OF THE CRB. SUBSTANTIAL RESOURCES ARE INVESTED TO RECOVER THESE FISH SPECIES WITH EFFORTS LARGELY FOCUSED ON RESTORING PHYSICAL CONDITIONS (I.E., HABITAT, FLOW OR WATER TEMPERATURE) AND REMOVING NON-NATIVE FISH SPECIES. THERE HAS BEEN MINIMAL FOCUS ON QUANTIFYING CHANGES TO THE PRIMARY (I.E., PLANTS) AND SECONDARY PRODUCTION (E.G., INSECTS) THAT FUEL NATIVE FISH SPECIES. BASED ON RESEARCH IN OTHER RIVERS, EXPECT PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PRODUCTION (HEREAFTER RIVER PRODUCTIVITY) IN THE CRB IS IMPACTED BY RIVER REGULATION, MODIFIED HYDROLOGY, AND AGRICULTURAL AND MUNICIPAL RUNOFF, WITH CLIMATE CHANGE LIKELY TO BRING FURTHER MODIFICATIONS. IF RIVER PRODUCTIVITY IS LIMITING FISH SPECIES, THEN INCREASING WATER TEMPERATURES AND DECLINING RUNOFF ASSOCIATED WITH CLIMATE CHANGE MAY EXACERBATE THIS LIMITATION. THUS, TO BETTER PREDICT THE IMPACTS OF ONGOING CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE IMPERILED FISH SPECIES OF THE CRB, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO IDENTIFY CURRENT DRIVERS OF RIVER PRODUCTIVITY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PROPOSE TO QUANTIFY RIVER PRODUCTIVITY IN TRIBUTARY RIVERS ACROSS THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN. WE PREDICT EMERGENT ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES (I.E., RIVER METABOLISM) AND CORRESPONDING RETENTION, DIVERSITY, AND QUANTITY OF FOOD RESOURCES FOR FISH (E.G., PRIMARY PRODUCERS, MACROINVERTEBRATES) HAVE BEEN ALTERED BY WATER DEVELOPMENT THROUGHOUT THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN. THEREFORE PREDICT THERE IS SPATIAL VARIATION IN ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES ACROSS A GRADIENT OF RIVER ALTERATION (E.G., WATER ABSTRACTION). WILL USE TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES IN OXYGEN SENSORS AND STATISTICAL MODELS TO QUANTIFY RIVER METABOLISM ACROSS A GRADIENT OF ALTERATION IN TRIBUTARIES OF THE GREEN AND COLORADO RIVERS. WE WILL COUPLE ESTIMATES OF ECOSYSTEM RATES WITH ESTIMATES OF PRIMARY PRODUCER (ALGAE) AND MACROINVERTEBRATE BIOMASS TO ESTIMATE RESOURCE AVAILABILITY ACROSS GRADIENTS OF ALTERATION. WHERE FISH DATA ARE AVAILABLE, WILL ALSO LINK RESOURCE AVAILABILITY TO FISH DENSITY AND CONDITION. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES AT A BROAD SPATIAL SCALE ACROSS THE BASIN, WHERE BASIC KNOWLEDGE OF THESE PROCESSES IS LIMITED.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO EDUCATE THE BROADER PUBLIC ABOUT RIVERS THROUGHOUT THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN THAT ARE CHANGING RAPIDLY DUE TO EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND INCREASED WATER DEMAND. WILL PRESENT OUR FINDINGS AT RELEVANT STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, SUCH AS THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN RESEARCHER'S MEETING, AS WELL AS AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES. WILL ALSO COMPLETE A MINIMUM OF TWO HIGH IMPACT JOURNAL ARTICLES: 1) ASSESSING RIVER METABOLISM AND RESOURCE AVAILABILITY ACROSS GRADIENTS OF RIVER ALTERATION, AND 2) LINKING BROAD-SCALE ESTIMATES OF RIVER METABOLISM AND FISH ASSEMBLAGE DATA.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: FEDERAL, STATE, AND TRIBAL MANAGERS, THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER ENDANGERED FISH RECOVERY PROGRAM AND THE SAN JUAN RIVER BASIN RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION PROGRAM.

PROJECT TITLE:WALLEYE FISHERIES BRIGHT SPOTS IN A CHANGING CLIMATEPROJECT PERIOD: 05/01/2022 - 04/30/2027 HABITAT LOSS, POLLUTION, SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS, AND OVERFISHING HAVE IMPACTED INLAND FISHERIES FOR DECADES. THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE THREATENS TO COMPOUND THESE OTHER FACTORS. OUR PROPOSED WORK FOCUSES ON WALLEYE FISHERIES OF INLAND LAKES OF THE UPPER GREAT LAKES REGION, WHICH HAVE BEEN DECLINING SINCE THE EARLY 2000S. RATHER THAN THE USUAL FOCUS ON UNDERSTANDING WALLEYE POPULATION DECLINES, OUR RESEARCH EMPHASIZES 'BRIGHT SPOTS' - FISHERIES SUCCESS STORIES. WE SEEK TO UNDERSTAND THE DRIVERS ASSOCIATED WITH FISHERIES THAT PERFORM FAR BETTER THAN EXPECTATIONS ('BRIGHT' FISHERIES). WE WILL COMBINE A SUITE OF DIFFERENT APPROACHES TO PROVIDE NEW INSIGHTS INTO WALLEYE FISHERY BRIGHT SPOTS: AN ONGOING WHOLE-LAKE EXPERIMENTAL REMOVAL OF BASSES AND SUNFISHES, OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES OF THERMAL-OPTICAL HABITAT USE, A SYNTHESIS OF HOW WALLEYE FISHERIES RESPONDED TO MANAGEMENT RESTORATION EFFORTS, AND A STATISTICAL ANALYSIS AIMED AT DETECTING CHARACTERISTICS OF LAKES AND MANAGEMENT APPROACHES ASSOCIATED WITH WALLEYE FISHERY BRIGHT SPOTS. MEMBERS OF THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STATE (MI, MN, WI) AND TRIBAL (GLIFWC) BIOLOGISTS TO INTEGRATE PRACTITIONER KNOWLEDGE AND PRODUCE ACTIONABLE RESULTS. COMBINING THE RESULTS OF THESE MULTIPLE APPROACHES WILL YIELD NEW INSIGHTS IN WHAT MAKES FOR A SUCCESSFUL WALLEYE FISHERY AND WILL GENERATE KNOWLEDGE THAT WILL INFORM CLIMATE-SMART FISHERIES MANAGEMENT GIVEN THAT ALREADY-STRESSED FISHERIES ARE INCREASINGLY SUBJECT TO A RAPIDLY CHANGING CLIMATE.

PROJECT TITLE:AGE-0 LAKE WHITEFISH AND ZOOPLANKTON RELATIONS IN THE NORTH CHANNEL OF LAKE HURONPROJECT PERIOD: 04/18/2022-04/17/2023AWARD PURPOSE: LAKE WHITEFISH (LAW) SUPPORT SOME OF THE MOST COMMERCIALLY, RECREATIONALLY, AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT FISHERIES IN THE UPPER GREAT LAKES. HOWEVER, LAW ABUNDANCE AND HARVEST HAVE DECLINED IN LAKE HURON (LH) SINCE THE LATE 1990S, ATTRIBUTED, IN PART, TO CHANGES IN THE ECOSYSTEM SUCH AS THROUGH THE INVASION OF DREISSENID MUSSELS. NEARSHORE ZOOPLANKTON ARE A CRITICAL FOOD SOURCE FOR AGE-0 LAW, BUT INCREASED CONSUMPTION OF PHYTOPLANKTON BY INVASIVE DREISSENIDS HAS INDIRECTLY REDUCED ZOOPLANKTON DENSITY. AGE-0 LAW TYPICALLY OCCUPY BEACH (DEFINED HERE AS ? 1 M DEPTH) OR NEARSHORE (DEFINED HERE AS 1-15 M DEPTH) HABITATS IN THE FIRST FEW MONTHS AFTER HATCHING, AND DECREASED LAW RECRUITMENT IN LH MAY BE THE RESULT OF DECREASED ZOOPLANKTON DENSITY. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO ELUCIDATE SUITABLE NURSERY HABITAT FOR AGE-0 LAW IN LH AND OBTAIN AND COMPARE AGE-0 LAW POPULATION ESTIMATES IN DIFFERENT HABITATS AND REGIONS OF LH. WE (LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY (LSSU)) WILL TARGET SAMPLING IN THE NORTH CHANNEL OF LH, WHICH IS AN AREA NOT THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN IMPACTED AS MUCH BY ECOSYSTEM ALTERATIONS SUCH AS INVASIVE DREISSENIDS AS LOCATIONS FURTHER SOUTH IN LH, WHICH WILL BE SAMPLED BY THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS). THE NORTH CHANNEL IS ALSO MORE PROTECTED; THE AREA IS SEPARATED FROM THE MAIN BASIN BY THE NIAGARA ESCARPMENT, WHICH BLOCKS SOME STRONGER WATER CURRENTS AND WIND VIA FETCH FROM HAVING A GREATER IMPACT ON THAT AREA. THIS PROTECTION, IN ADDITION TO NUMEROUS TRIBUTARIES ENTERING THE NORTH CHANNEL FROM ONTARIO, MAY PROMOTE SUITABLE SPAWNING AND NURSERY HABITATS FOR LAW. THE DATA CAN BE COMPARED TO DATA COLLECTED BY USGS IN SOUTHERN LH TO HELP DETERMINE IF AGE-0 LAW ABUNDANCE PATTERNS ARE SIMILAR ACROSS THE LAKE OR IF THEY DIFFER ALONG THE GRADIENT OF DREISSENID MUSSEL INVASION INTENSITY (LOWER IN THE NORTH, HIGHER IN THE SOUTH). CAN ALSO COMPARE THE DATA TO HISTORICAL AGE-0 LAW AND ZOOPLANKTON DATA TO ASSESS CHANGES IN AGE-0 LAW POPULATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS OVER TIME IN THIS AREA. THESE COMPARISONS COULD SHED LIGHT ON WHETHER CHANGES TO THE ECOSYSTEM MAY BE RELATED TO CHANGES IN ABUNDANCE OF AGE-0 LAW, OR LACK THEREOF. RESULTS CAN HELP SHED LIGHT ON POTENTIAL BOTTLENECKS TO AGE-0 LAW POPULATIONS DURING THEIR CRITICAL FIRST YEAR OF LIFE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WILL SAMPLE BEACH AND NEARSHORE SITES NEAR THESSALON AND BLIND RIVER, ONTARIO. SAMPLING WILL START SOON AFTER ICE OFF AND CONTINUE WEEKLY FOR APPROXIMATELY 14 WEEKS, OR UNTIL NO LONGER CATCH AGE-0 LAW DURING TWO CONSECUTIVE WEEKS. SAMPLING PROTOCOLS WILL BE STANDARDIZED TO MATCH THOSE OF USGS'S FIELD CREWS IN LOWER LH, AND WILL CONSIST OF FIELD GEAR TO SAMPLE FOR LARVAL AND JUVENILE LAW, AS WELL AS ZOOPLANKTON AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RESULTS FROM THE PROPOSED WORK WILL BE SHARED WITH AND PRESENTED TO THE LH TECHNICAL COMMITTEE, THE ST. MARYS RIVER FISHERY TASK GROUP, AND AT LEAST ONE SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE. OUR RESULTS WILL BENEFIT FISHERIES PROFESSIONALS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION ON NURSERY AREAS AND ABUNDANCE OF AGE-0 LAW IN THE NORTH CHANNEL OF LH, AND RELATIONS BETWEEN ABUNDANCE OF AGE-0 LAW AND ZOOPLANKTON. WE ANTICIPATE AT LEAST ONE MANUSCRIPT BEING SUBMITTED TO A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL IN CONJUNCTION WITH USGS. DATA COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE, AFTER PROJECT COMPLETION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND PROVINCIAL AGENCIES THAT MANAGE LAW

ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING FOR OPTIMIZATION OF ENERGY DEVELOPMENT AND USE IN IRAQPROJECT PERIOD: 04/19/2022 THROUGH 12/31/2023NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY (NMSU), LAS CRUCES, PROPOSES A PROGRAM OF COOPERATIVE ACTIVITIES IN COLLABORATION WITH U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IN SUPPORT OF NUMEROUS IRAQ ENERGY DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES INCLUDING NATURAL GAS, OIL, AND SOLAR, AND HYDROELECTRIC. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON THE APPLICATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF TECHNIQUES TO ECONOMICALLY OPTIMIZE CLIMATE-STRESSED, AND SOMETIMES UNRELIABLE ENERGY SUPPLIES IN IRAQ, FOR WHICH WATER SUPPLIES ARE AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTOR. ADDRESSING THESE ARE ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS IN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND GROWTH IN IRAQ, WHICH CONTRIBUTES SIGNIFICANTLY TO IMPROVING SECURITY AND STABILITY OF THE COUNTRY. OUR PLAN IS TO COMBINE UNIVERSITY-BASED RESEARCH IN THE MODELING, MONITORING AND ANALYSIS OF REMOTELY AND ON-THE-GROUND SENSED ESTIMATES OF ENERGY AND WATER RESOURCE VARIABLES WITH SCIENCE ADVISORY, TRAINING, AND DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES OF IRAQI PROFESSIONALS IN THE USE OF ECONOMIC OPTIMIZATION MODELLING FOR IMPROVED ENERGY DEVELOPMENT AND USE EFFICIENCY. WE PROPOSE A TEAM OF NMSU SCIENTISTS ADVANCING THE SCIENTIFIC AND ECONOMIC CAPACITIES OF SELECTED IRAQI PROFESSIONALS. RESEARCH SCIENTISTS IN THE UNITED STATES, WITH FULL ACCESS TO THE LATEST TECHNOLOGY, ARE WELL-SITUATED TO RAPIDLY DEVELOP AND APPLY NEW THEORIES AND TOOLS. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO CONDUCT A DETAILED ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF THE SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC ENERGY USE PATTERNS OF TWO HIGH-PRIORITY AREAS IDENTIFIED IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH IRAQI PROFESSIONALS FROM THE MINISTRY OF WATER RESOURCES AND OTHER RELATED AGENCIES. THIS ANALYSIS PROPOSES EXAMINING THE ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE ASSOCIATED WITH VARIOUS MEASURES TO PUT THE MOST RECENT ASSESSMENT OF ENERGY INTO ECONOMICALLY IMPROVED USE. THE ECONOMIC ANALYSIS WILL BE BASED ON OPTIMIZATION MODELLING INVESTIGATING TRADEOFFS BETWEEN HYDROELECTRIC POWER TO MEET ENERGY DEMANDS COMPARED TO ALTERNATIVE SOURCES OF ENERGY SUCH AS OIL, GAS, AND SOLAR POWER. FOR EXAMPLE, UNDER THE PROPOSED TASK, ENERGY USERS COULD SUBSTITUTE INCREASED INFRASTRUCTURE (AT A COST) FOR REDUCED POWER GENERATION FROM RESERVOIR RELEASES. THE IMPORTANCE OF ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE SUBSTITUTIONS OF WATER CONSERVING INFRASTRUCTURE FOR REDUCED SURFACE WATER SUPPLIES TAKES ON MORE IMPORTANCE IN THE FACE OF GROWING SHORTAGES IN SURFACE WATER SUPPLIES, STRESSED BY DROUGHT AND CLIMATE, RISING DEMANDS FOR URBAN USES, AND INCREASED HYDROLOGIC INFRASTRUCTURE AND ENERGY PRICES IN VARIOUS REGIONS OF THE COUNTRY.DELIVERABLES:1.EVALUATE AND VALIDATE QUALITY OF DATA COLLECTION TO ESTABLISH A BASELINE FOR SCENARIO-DRIVEN MODELS THAT ADDRESS VARIOUS ENERGY- AND WATER-RELATED ACTIVITIES IN THE ARID AND SEMI-ARID AREA OF IRAQ.2.NMSU EXPERTS WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH IRAQI PROFESSIONALS TO DEVELOP A USER'S MANUAL THAT WILL ENABLE THE IRAQI PROFESSIONALS TO DEVELOP MULTIPLE RESEARCH SCENARIOS TO DETERMINE THE BEST USE(S) OF ENERGY AND/OR WATER RESOURCES UNDER SEVERAL COMPETING SOURCES AND ALTERNATIVE USES OF WATER.3.IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH IRAQI PROFESSIONALS, A PROTOTYPE MODEL WILL BE DEVELOPED TO SERVEAS A GUIDE FOR IRAQI PROFESSIONALS TO COLLECT HIGH QUALITY DATA, BOTH WITH TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL RESOLUTION THAT ALLOWS THEM TO CONSTRUCT MORE REAL-LIFE SCENARIO APPLICATIONS FOR THE BEST USES OF WATER RESOURCES UNDER THE CURRENT AND FUTURE WATER AND ENERGY COST AND SCARCITY CONDITIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF IRAQ AND THE IRAQI PROFESSIONALS FROM THE MINISTRY OF WATER RESOURCES ANDOTHER ENERGY-RELATED AGENCIES.

PROJECT TITLE:SYNTHESIS OF THE NEW NORTH AMERICAN TREERING FIRE-SCAR NETWORK: USING PAST AND PRESENT FIRE-CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS TO IMPROVE PROJECTIONS OF FUTURE WILDFIREPROJECT PERIOD: 06/01/2022-05/31/2024INCREASING WILDFIRE ACTIVITY IN MUCH OF NORTH AMERICA IS HAVING SEVERE IMPACTS ON SOCIETY AND ECOSYSTEMS. CLIMATE CHANGE IS A KEY DRIVER OF CHANGING FIRE REGIMES ACROSS NORTH AMERICA, WITH VARYING EXPRESSIONS ACROSS THE CONTINENT. MODERN FIRE RECORDS, WHILE USEFUL, ARE TOO SHORT TO FULLY CHARACTERIZE THE COMPLEX PATTERNS AND NON-LINEAR DYNAMICS OF FIRE-CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS THAT ARE REQUIRED TO UNDERSTAND FUTURE FIRE ACTIVITY IN A WARMER CLIMATE. TREE-RING FIRE SCARS OFFER A UNIQUE PERSPECTIVE BECAUSE THEY ARE SPATIALLY PRECISE, DIRECT EVIDENCE OF FIRES WITH ANNUAL TO SUB-ANNUAL RESOLUTION SPANNING CENTURIES. FOR THE FIRST TIME, HAVE COMPILED TREE-RING FIRE SCAR RECORDS ACROSS NORTH AMERICA (N = 2,593 SITES, 35,602 TREES, >300,000 FIRE SCARS). THE INTERNATIONAL TEAM OF FIRE AND CLIMATE SCIENTISTS WILL SYNTHESIZE THE FIRE SCAR NETWORK AND COMBINE IT WITH MODERN FIRE RECORDS TO CREATE A MULTI-CENTURY RECORD OF FIRE ACROSS NORTH AMERICA. ALSO, WILL USE RECENT ADVANCES IN PALEOCLIMATE METHODS AND THE CONTINENTAL-SCALE NETWORK OF TREE-RING CHRONOLOGIES TO RECONSTRUCT SEASONAL CLIMATE VARIABLES TAILORED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND VARIABILITY IN CLIMATE DRIVERS OF FIRE. WILL USE THESE NEW DATA TO ADDRESS THE CENTRAL QUESTION: HOW WILL CLIMATE DRIVE FUTURE FIRE POTENTIAL IN NORTH AMERICA? SYNTHESIS OF THE NEW NORTH AMERICAN FIRE SCAR NETWORK WILL ENABLE US TO USE HISTORICAL AND MODERN FIRE-CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS TO BETTER PROJECT FUTURE FIRE REGIMES IN A CHANGING CLIMATE ACROSS NORTH AMERICAN FORESTS.WILL FOCUS ON: 1) MULTI-CENTURY SPATIO-TEMPORAL DYNAMICS OF FIRE-CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS ACROSS NORTH AMERICA, 2) CLIMATE DRIVERS OF CHANGING SYNCHRONY OF WILDFIRE (E.G., WIDESPREAD FIRE YEARS), 3) CYCLICAL PROPERTIES OF FIRE OCCURRENCE THAT CAN PROVIDE PREDICTIVE CAPACITY, INCLUDING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OCEAN-ATMOSPHERE OSCILLATIONS (E.G., EL NINO/SOUTHERN OSCILLATION AND ARCTIC OSCILLATION), AND 4) COMBINING HISTORICAL AND MODERN FIRE-CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS TO PROJECT FUTURE WILDFIRE POTENTIAL AT REGIONAL TO CONTINENTAL SCALES. THIS WILL BE AMONG THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE ANALYSES OF THE CLIMATIC DRIVERS OF HISTORICAL FIRE REGIMES ACROSS NORTH AMERICA. THE RESULTS WILL BE USED TO MODEL FUTURE WILDFIRES THAT WILL INCREASINGLY AFFECT SOCIETIES AND DIVERSE EARTH SURFACE PROCESSES. THE BENEFITS OF THESE ANTICIPATED RESULTS SPAN TWO IMPORTANT REALMS: 1) THE BROAD RANGE OF EARTH-SYSTEM SCIENCES AFFECTED BY FIRE AND 2) FIRE MANAGEMENT AND POLICY. FIRE SCIENCE CUTS ACROSS MANY DISCIPLINES (E.G., HYDROLOGY, ECOLOGY, ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCE, BIOGEOCHEMISTRY, DEBRIS FLOW HAZARD), SUCH THAT INFORMATION REGARDING FUTURE FIRE WILL BE VALUABLE WELL OUTSIDE THE TRADITIONAL FIRE-FOCUSED CIRCLES. IN ADDITION, THE TREE-RING FIRE-CLIMATE COMMUNITY IS A TRUSTED RESOURCE OF INFORMATION FOR FOREST AND FIRE MANAGERS.WE EXPECT OUR FINDINGS TO BE USEFUL FOR FIRE RISK PREDICTIONS AND PLANNING IN THE U.S., CANADA, AND MEXICO AND WE WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH MANAGERS AND POLICY MAKERS TO HELP INFORM DECISION-MAKING. LAST, THE PUBLIC AVAILABILITY OF THE NORTH AMERICAN TREE-RING FIRE HISTORY DATABASE WILL FACILITATE FUTURE ADVANCES OF FIRE RESEARCH ACROSS NORTH AMERICA AND MORE BROADLY (E.G., CIRCUMPOLAR FIRE-CLIMATE ANALYSES).

THIS RESEARCH IS TO (I) PROVIDE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXPERIMENTAL SAMPLES AND (II) COLLABORATE ON PROJECTS INVOLVING THE OCCURRENCE AND FATE OF PFAS IN DIVERSE HYDROGEOLOGIC ENVIRONMENTS AND INFRASTRUCTURE, INCLUDING COASTAL WATERSHEDS, SHALLOW SOILS AND SEDIMENTS, GROUNDWATER, AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES. THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH ARE AS FOLLOWS. (1) ACT AS EXPERT CONTACTS FOR CHEMICAL ANALYSIS OF PFAS IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXPERIMENTAL SAMPLES PROVIDED BY USGS; (2) ANALYZE APPROXIMATELY 340 SAMPLES FOR PFAS CONCENTRATIONS USING SOLID-PHASE EXTRACTION (SPE) WITH LIQUID CHROMATOGRAPHY WITH TANDEM MASS SPECTROMETRY (LC-MS/MS); (3) EMPLOY AND REPORT APPROPRIATE QUALITY ASSURANCE AND QUALITY CONTROL (QA/QC) PROTOCOLS DURING ALL PFAS ANALYSES, INCLUDING ANALYSIS OF TRIPLICATE SAMPLES, INCLUSION OF BLANKS AND QUALITY CONTROLS, AND USE OF MASS-LABELED INTERNAL STANDARDS; AND, (4) COLLABORATE WITH USGS PARTNERS ON DATA INTERPRETATION, EVALUATION, AND REPORTING RELATED TO THE OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, FATE, AND TREATMENT OF PFAS IN SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM STUDY SITES OR EXPERIMENTS.

PROJECT TITLE:STANDARDIZING, AGGREGATING, ANALYZING AND DISSEMINATING GLOBAL WILDLIFE GENETIC AND GENOMIC DATA FOR IMPROVED MANAGEMENT AND ADVANCEMENT OF COMMUNITY BEST PRACTICESPROJECT PERIOD: 3/31/2022 - 3/30/24U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY'S (USGS) POWELL CENTER IS SUPPORTING THE PROJECT "STANDARDIZING, AGGREGATING, ANALYZING AND DISSEMINATING GLOBAL WILDLIFE GENETIC AND GENOMIC DATA FOR IMPROVED MANAGEMENT AND ADVANCEMENT OF COMMUNITY BEST PRACTICES." GLOBAL BIODIVERSITY IS RAPIDLY DECLINING, THREATENING HUMANS, ECOSYSTEMS, AND THE SERVICES THAT SOCIETY RELIES UPON. MONITORING AND UNDERSTANDING THE EXTENT OF BIODIVERSITY DECLINES CAN SUPPORT POLICY DECISIONS. GENETIC DIVERSITY IS THE FOUNDATION OF BIODIVERSITY, DETERMINING THE CAPACITY OF POPULATIONS TO ADAPT TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES AND TO SUSTAIN FUNCTION AND STRUCTURE IN ALL ECOSYSTEMS. WHILE THE AVAILABILITY OF GENETIC DIVERSITY DATA HAS EXPONENTIALLY INCREASED IN THE PAST DECADE, GENETIC DATA HAVE BEEN POORLY MOBILIZED TO UNDERSTAND BIODIVERSITY CHANGE AT LARGE SCALES; CONSEQUENTLY, THERE IS LIMITED INTEGRATION INTO MANAGEMENT AND POLICY. TO SOLVE THIS CHALLENGE, LARGE-SCALE SYNTHESIS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY DATA (I.E. A MACROGENETIC ANALYSIS) WILL BE USED TO BETTER ASSESS GENETIC DIVERSITY PATTERNS, THEIR PREDICTORS AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS. WILL COMBINE EXPERTISE ACROSS TAXA, SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES, AND TOPICS IN GENETICS, ECOLOGY AND GEOGRAPHY, TO BUILD A MULTI-SPECIES GENETIC DATABASE ENRICHED WITH INFORMATIVE METADATA. TO UNDERSTAND THE SPATIO-ENVIRONMENTAL DISTRIBUTION, THE RELATIONSHIP OF GENETIC VARIABILITY WITH CLIMATE, SPECIES RICHNESS, AND ANTHROPOGENIC FACTORS WILL BE INTEGRATED. THE DATABASE WILL BE USED TO CREATE GENETIC DIVERSITY MAPS ACROSS BROAD NUMBERS OF POPULATIONS, SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS, OF GREAT VALUE TO CONSERVATION PLANNING AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENTS BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS. THE OUTPUTS OF THE PROJECT WILL THUS BE USEFUL TO RESEARCHERS AND DECISION MAKERS WORKING TO PRIORITIZE THE PRESERVATION OF BIODIVERSITY AND ADAPTIVE POTENTIAL WITH LIMITED RESOURCES. THE PROTECTION OF GENETIC DIVERSITY AS A NATURAL RESOURCE IS CRITICAL FOR SUPPORTING POPULATION RESILIENCE, AND IS INTEGRAL TO INNOVATION, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND NATURE'S CONTRIBUTION TO PEOPLE. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE GATHERING AND HARMONIZING MULTI-POPULATION GENETIC DATASETS FROM DRYAD, DATAONE AND COLLABORATORS AND USGS AFFILIATED SCIENTISTS FOR VARIOUS TAXA; CREATE SPATIOTEMPORAL MAPS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY ACROSS SPECIES, REGIONS, AND HABITATS; CREATE AND SHARE BEST PRACTICES TO IMPROVE FAIR POPULATION GENETIC DATA WITH A MULTI-LINGUAL WEBSITE; AND CREATE AND SHARE BEST PRACTICES FOR INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION OF GENETIC DIVERSITY PRODUCTS FOR CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. PRODUCTS INCLUDE A WEB PORTAL FOR BEST PRACTICES AND SOFTWARE IN SEVERAL LANGUAGES, A USGS SCIENCEBASE DATA RELEASE OF THE ENTIRE AGGREGATED DATASET, AND MANUSCRIPTS DESCRIBING BEST PRACTICES, STANDARDS, METHODS, AND SCIENTIFIC INTERPRETATION. THE PROTECTION OF GENETIC DIVERSITY AS A NATURAL RESOURCE IS CRITICAL FOR SUPPORTING POPULATION RESILIENCE, AND IS INTEGRAL TO INNOVATION, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND NATURE'S CONTRIBUTION TO PEOPLE. THE ANTICIPATED RETURN ON INVESTMENT FOR USGS AND OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES INCLUDES IMPROVED EFFICIENCIES IN DATA RELEASE DEVELOPMENT AND REVIEWING PROCESSES TO ALLOW FOR IMPROVED UPTAKE OF THE INFORMATION BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GROUPS AND FOR POLICY. THE OUTPUTS OF THE PROJECT WILL THUS BE BENEFICIAL TO RESEARCHERS AND DECISION MAKERS WORKING TO PRIORITIZE THE PRESERVATION OF BIODIVERSITY AND ADAPTIVE POTENTIAL WITH LIMITED RESOURCES.

THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP PRACTICAL METHODS BY WHICH LAND MANAGERS CAN IMPROVE ESTABLISHMENT AND RESILIENCE OF PRAIRIE RECONSTRUCTIONS BY IMPROVING AVAILABILITY OF APPROPRIATE AMF TO PLANTED SPECIES. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT IF AMF CHARACTERISTIC OF REMNANT PRAIRIE SOILS ARE IMPORTANT FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF CONSERVATIVE PRAIRIE PLANT SPECIES, THEN THESE PLANT SPECIES WILL SHOW GREATER GROWTH AND LARGER FLORAL DISPLAYS WHEN INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES THAN WHEN INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM SITES PREPARED FOR RECONSTRUCTION. LIKEWISE, IF AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES IMPROVES COMPETITIVE ABILITY OF ESTABLISHED PRAIRIE PLANTS, THOSE GROWN IN SOIL INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES WILL SHOW BETTER GROWTH AND REPRODUCTION WHEN GROWN WITH INVASIVE COOL-SEASON GRASSES THAN THOSE IN SOILS INOCULATED WITH AMF FROM SITES PREPARED FOR RECONSTRUCTION. OBJECTIVES IN THE SECOND TIER OF THE STUDY ARE:COMPARE PERFORMANCE (HEIGHT, LEAF PRODUCTION, AND BIOMASS) AND AMF COMMUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ROOTS OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES BETWEEN THE TWO INOCULUM TYPES IN THE GREENHOUSE.COMPARE COMPETITIVE ABILITY (HEIGHT, LEAF PRODUCTION, AND BIOMASS) AND AMF COMMUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ROOTS OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES RELATIVE TO BROMUS INERMIS OR POA PRATENSIS WHEN INOCULATED WITH REMNANT-DERIVED VS. RECONSTRUCTION AMF.UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR SOIL ANALYSES FOR NPK AND SOIL TEXTURE; SEQUENCING OF DNA EXTRACTS; AND WILL WORK WITH OTHER COOPERATORS AND USGS TO INTERPRET RESULTS AND DEVELOP OUTREACH MATERIALS AND PUBLICATIONS.USGS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR COLLECTING SOIL FROM FIELD SITES AND PREPARING IT FOR ANALYSIS; INSTALLING AND MONITORING GREENHOUSE EXPERIMENTS; DNA EXTRACTION; AND WILL WORK WITH OTHER COOPERATORS AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA TO INTERPRET RESULTS AND DEVELOP OUTREACH MATERIALS AND PUBLICATIONS. USGS WILL COMPILE METADATA AND SUBMIT PROPERLY REVIEWED DATA AND METADATA TO SCIENCEBASE.

OBJECTIVES 1) DESCRIBE CHARACTERISTICS OF NITROGEN, PHOSPHORUS AND CARBON FLUX IN RIVERMOUTHS AND NEARSHORE ZONES IN THE GREAT LAKES, SPECIFICALLY AREAS ASSOCIATED WITH HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (WESTERN LAKE ERIE/MAUMEE BAY AND GREEN BAY, LAKE MICHIGAN).2) CHARACTERIZE DISSOLVED ORGANIC CARBON DYNAMICS IN A LARGE FRESHWATER RIVERMOUTHEXPECTED PROJECT RESULTS1. PHASE 8 (2021-APRIL 2023): INTERPRETATION OF RESULTS. IN COLLABORATION WITH RESEARCHERS AT THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT OF TWO TECHNICAL MANUSCRIPTS IN JOURNAL FORMAT.2. PHASE 8 (APRIL 2022-APRIL 2023): GENERATING DOM DATA. USING SAMPLES PROVIDED BY USGS RESEARCHERS, THE XENOPOULOS-FROST LAB WILL MEASURE DOM CONCENTRATION AND OPTICAL CHARACTERISTICS TO ESTIMATE CHANGES IN DOM PROPERTIES DRIVEN BY SEDIMENT AND WATER COLUMN PROCESSING. SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED AS PART OF EXPERIMENTS BEING PERFORMED ON INTACT SEDIMENT CORES AND WATER COLUMN INCLUBATION EXPERIMENTS IN THE MAUMEE RIVERMOUTH AND MAUMEE BAY. INTACT SEDIMENT CORE EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED 3 TIMES (MAY, JULY, AUGUST) AT 7-12 SITES. WATER COLUMN INCUBATION EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT 3 TIMES AT 3 SITES. METHODS WILL FOLLOW METHODS USED IN PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED STUDIES FROM THE FOX RIVERMOUTH (GREEN BAY, WI; LARSON ET AL. 2020, LARSON ET AL. 2019, PEARCE ET AL. 2021).

THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAS SUBSURFACE DATASETS, MAPS, REPORTS AND BIBLIOGRAPHIC INFORMATION WHICH WILL PROVIDE ASSISTANCE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A GEOLOGIC FRAMEWORK FOR THE ILLINOIS BASIN. AS THE WESTERN EDGE OF THE BASIN RESIDES IN AND ALONG THE MISSOURI BORDER, AVAILABLE DATA FROM MISSOURI INCLUDES INFORMATION ON THE CYPRESS SANDSTONE, ST. PETER SANDSTONE, POTOSI DOLOMITE, EAU CLAIRE FORMATION (BONNETERRE FORMATION), AND MOUNT SIMON (LAMOTTE) SANDSTONE. MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STAFF WILL PROVIDE LOCAL RESEARCH FOR THE ILLINOIS BASIN STUDY INCLUDING CONDUCTING LITERATURE SURVEYS, DATABASE CONSTRUCTION, DATA ENTRY AND REVIEW, AND QUALITY ASSURANCE OF DELIVERABLES.THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL DELIVER ALL FINDINGS IN THE FORM OF A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT AND AN ACCOMPANYING DATABASE, WHICH WILL LIST THE AVAILABLE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY INFORMATION. THE DATABASE WILL PROVIDE THE DATA SOURCE NAME, BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF INFORMATION WITHIN THE DATA SOURCE, AND A HYPERLINK TO THE ELECTRONIC VERSIONS OF REPORTS, MAPS OR DATASETS. THE DATABASE WILL ALSO INCLUDE A COMPREHENSIVE BIBLIOGRAPHY ALONG WITH RELEVANT METADATA.THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL SUBMIT ALL DELIVERABLES TO THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND WILL WORK WITH COLLABORATING PARTIES TO IDENTIFY ILLINOIS BASIN GEOLOGIC INTERVALS THAT ARE CANDIDATES FOR GEOLOGIC ENERGY STORAGE, RESIDUAL OIL ZONES, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, AND COAL-MINE METHANE RESOURCES. THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY

THE INDIANA GEOLOGICAL AND WATER SURVEY (IGWS) WILL PROVIDE DATA FROM PUBLICATIONS AND INTERNAL RESOURCES (WHEN ABLE) FOR GEOLOGIC UNITS IN WHICH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, GEOLOGY, ENERGY & MINERALS SCIENCE CENTER (USGS-GEMSC) HAS PARTICULAR INTEREST FOR GEOLOGIC ENERGY STORAGE WITHIN THE INDIANA PORTION OF THE ILLINOIS BASIN. THE GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS ORIGINALLY UNDER CONSIDERATION INCLUDE THE MISSISSIPPIAN CYPRESS SANDSTONE; ORDOVICIAN ST. PETER SANDSTONE; CAMBRIAN POTOSI DOLOMITE, EAU CLAIRE FORMATION, AND MT. SIMON SANDSTONE. OTHER FORMATIONS MAY BE CONSIDERED AT THE REQUEST OF THE USGS-GEMSC, IF APPLICABLE DATA ARE AVAILABLE.THE IGWS WILL WORK WITH THE USGS-GEMSC AND OTHER STATE AGENCIES INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT TO IDENTIFY AND RANK THE IMPORTANCE OF VARIOUS GEOLOGICAL FORMATIONS FOR GEOLOGIC ENERGY STORAGE IN THE INDIANA PORTION OF THE ILLINOIS BASIN. ONCE FORMATIONS AND ESSENTIAL DATA TYPES ARE IDENTIFIED, THE IGWS WILL EVALUATE AVAILABLE DATA SETS FROM IGWS PUBLICATIONS AND INTERNAL RESEARCH PROJECTS. THE DATA SETS WILL THEN BE FORMATTED PROPERLY FOR USGS-GEMSC CONSUMPTION (SEE DATA MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR FURTHER DETAILS). DATA MAY BE PROVIDED FOR POROSITY AND PERMEABILITY, WATER QUALITY/TDS/SALINITY, EXISTING AND PLANNED ENERGY STORAGE PROJECTS, HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY, LITHOLOGY, TEMPERATURE AND PRESSURE GRADIENTS, BIOSTRATIGRAPHY, AND ROCK PETROPHYSICS, WHEN AVAILABLE. THE DATA WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE USGS-GEMSC IN AN ACCEPTABLE DATABASE FORMAT. THE LIST OF DATA OFFERED IS CONDITIONAL ON AVAILABILITY AND THE PROPRIETARY AND PROTECTIVE NATURE OF AVAILABLE DATA.THE DELIVERABLES ARE SUBJECT TO AVAILABLE RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS AND DIRECTION FROM THE USGS-GEMSC.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, INCLUDING THE USGS-GEMSC, OTHER STATE SURVEYS AND UNIVERSITIES; COMMERCIAL ENTITIES IN THE ENERGY STORAGE INDUSTRY; AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

PROJECT TITLE:ILLINOIS BASIN GEOLOGIC DATA COMPILATION TO SUPPORT UTILIZATION AND STORAGE OF CARBON ANDENERGY GASESPROJECT PERIOD: 4/1/2022 THROUGH 3/31/2025THE ILLINOIS BASIN HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED BY MULTIPLE ENERGY RESEARCH ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES AS A BASINOF INTEREST IN THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT ON THE POTENTIAL FOR UTILIZATION AND STORAGE OF ENERGYRELATEDGASES (CO2, HYDROGEN, COAL MINE METHANE, COMPRESSED AIR) AND FLUIDS (PRODUCED BRINES) INSUBSURFACE GEOLOGIC RESERVOIRS. CHARACTERIZATION AND ASSESSMENT OF SUITABLE SUBSURFACE STORAGE ZONESREQUIRES DIVERSE DATASETS TO EVALUATE STORAGE CAPACITY, CONTAINMENT, AND LONG-TERM VIABILITY OF THESERESERVOIRS. WESTERN KENTUCKY IS LOCATED IN THE ILLINOIS BASIN, AND THE KENTUCKY GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (KGS)MAINTAINS EXTENSIVE GEOLOGIC AND GEOPHYSICAL DATABASES COMPILED FROM DRILLING AND MINING RECORDS, ANDPRIOR RESEARCH PROGRAMS. THESE DATA ARE REQUIRED FOR CONDUCTING ENERGY STORAGE RESEARCH ANDASSESSMENT. THE KGS IS PROPOSING TO WORK WITH THE USGS GEOLOGY, ENERGY, AND MINERALS SCIENCE CENTERTO DEVELOP A DATABASE FROM ITS DATA HOLDINGS ON STRATIGRAPHIC TARGET LAYERS WITHIN THE KENTUCKY PORTIONOF THE ILLINOIS BASIN THAT CAN BE INTEGRATED INTO A STANDARDIZED FORMAT FOR A BASIN-WIDE ASSESSMENT.

STATEMENT OF PROBLEMALLOW FOR SCIENTISTS FROM THE USGS TO COLLABORATE WITH SCIENTISTS FROM THE ILLINOIS STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY ON TOPICS RELATED TO GEOLOGIC ENERGY STORAGE, CARBON DIOXIDE SEQUESTRATION, GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES, INDUCED SEISMICITY, RESIDUAL OIL ZONES, PRODUCED WATER DISPOSAL, AND COAL-MINE METHANE RESOURCES AND ASSOCIATED GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS.OBJECTIVESTHE OBJECTIVES ARE TO IDENTIFY THE APPROPRIATE GEOLOGIC INTERVALS WITHIN THE ILLINOIS BASIN THAT ARE CANDIDATES FOR: 1) GEOLOGIC ENERGY STORAGE (INCLUDING, NATURAL GAS AND HYDROGEN STORAGE, COMPRESSED AIR STORAGE, MINE-SHAFT GRAVITY STORAGE, PUMPED HYDRAULIC STORAGE, AND GEOTHERMAL STORAGE); 2) RESIDUAL OIL ZONES FOR CARBON DIOXIDE STORAGE AND HYDROCARBON RESOURCES RECOVERY; 3) UPDATED CARBON SEQUESTRATION ASSESSMENTS, ALONG WITH PRODUCED WATER STORAGE RESOURCES NEEDED FOR HYDROCARBON PRODUCTION OR CARBON SEQUESTRATION ACTIVITIES; AND 4) USABLE COAL-MINE METHANE RESOURCES THAT COULD REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS RELEASE TO THE ATMOSPHERE; AND B) BUILD REGIONAL (I.E., ACROSS STATE LINES) GEOLOGIC SUBSURFACE DATASETS WITH OTHER STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS.RELEVANCE AND IMPACTTHE ILLINOIS BASIN HAS SOME OF THE LARGEST GEOLOGIC STORAGE RESOURCES IN THE MIDWEST OF THE UNITED STATES AND NEEDS TO BE FURTHER EVALUATED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND STORAGE CAPACITY AND LIMITATIONS OF THE DIFFERENT SUBSURFACE FORMATIONS.

PROJECT TITLE:DATA ANALYSIS OF LEAD EXPOSURE OF PIUTE GROUND SQUIRRELS IN SOUTHWESTERN IDAHOPROJECT PERIOD: 5/1/2022 - 4/30/24LEAD IS AN ENVIRONMENTAL TOXIN WITH NO PHYSIOLOGICAL VALUE TO ANIMALS, YET IT IS WIDELY USED BY HUMANS IN A VARIETY OF SETTINGS, THEREBY REGULARLY EXPOSING WILDLIFE TO LEAD, SOMETIMES WITH DEADLY RESULTS. THE MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDS OF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA IN SOUTHWESTERN IDAHO INCLUDES A MILITARY TRAINING GROUND, THE ORCHARD COMBAT TRAINING AREA, AND SUBSTANTIAL RECREATIONAL SHOOTING. THESE ACTIVITIES RESULT IN DISTRIBUTION OF LEAD THROUGHOUT THESE AREAS, BUT THERE IS LITTLE INFORMATION ON HOW WILDLIFE WITHIN THEM IS EXPOSED TO LEAD.THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAS DATA ON LEAD EXPOSURE OF PIUTE GROUND SQUIRRELS TRAPPED ACROSS THIS AREA AND NOW NEEDS STATISTICAL ANALYSES OF THESE DATA TO UNDERSTAND HOW WILDLIFE IN THE REGION MAYCOME INTO CONTACT WITH LEAD. FIELD WORK, SAMPLE COLLECTION, SAMPLE PREPARATION, AND TOXICOLOGICAL ANALYSES HAVE ALREADY BEEN CONDUCTED. THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL PROVIDE TO CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL THESE DATA FOR ANALYSIS. CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL PROPOSES TO USE MODERN STATISTICAL APPROACHES TO ANALYZE DATA ON LEAD EXPOSURE OF THESE SQUIRRELS, INCLUDING SUMMARY STATISTICS AND A COMPARISON OF LEAD EXPOSURE OF SQUIRRELS IN AREAS WITH LOW LEVELS OF RECREATIONAL SHOOTING, HIGH LEVELS OF RECREATIONAL SHOOTING, AND MILITARY SHOOTING; AS WELL AS TESTING FOR STRENGTH OF RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN COPPER AND LEAD CONCENTRATIONS IN THE SQUIRREL DATA. ALL MANAGEMENT OF THESE DATA WILL BE BY THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND IN CONFORMATION ITS EXISTING DATA MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THESE DATA. CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL WILL WORK WITH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TO PUBLISH THE RESULTS OF THESE ANALYSES IN A PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL. THE SUBMITTED DRAFT OF THAT PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION WILL SERVE AS THE FINAL REPORT FOR THIS PROJECT. CONSERVATION SCIENCE GLOBAL AND THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, BY ADDRESSING THIS INFORMATION NEED, WILL HELP MEET THE AGENCY'S GOALS OF PROVIDING KEY SCIENCE TO DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE PARTNERS SO THEY CAN UNDERSTAND HOW THE ACTIVITIES OF MILITARY TRAINING AFFECT WILDLIFE.

PROJECT TITLE: ANALYSIS OF SPATIAL USE AND MOVEMENTS TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITY ON UNGULATES IN ARID ECOSYSTEMSPROJECT PERIOD: 05/01/2022-04/30/2025A COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDY UNIT (CESU) AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA LAS VEGAS AND USGS WESTERN ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH CENTER WILL GUIDE RESEARCH TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS ABOUT THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON UNGULATES FOUND ON PUBLIC LANDS IN THE ARID SOUTHWEST. THE RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE BASIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT UNGULATE ECOLOGY THAT WILL ASSIST MANAGERS AT FEDERAL, STATE, COUNTY, AND LOCAL LEVELS WHO ARE GRAPPLING WITH MANAGEMENT RESPONSES TO INCREASING HUMAN ACTIVITY AND RECREATION ON PUBLIC LANDS AT JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK AND THROUGHOUT THE ARID WEST AND MANAGEMENT OF THE RISK OF RADIOACTIVE CONTAMINATION TO HUMANS ON THE NEVADA NATIONAL SECURITY SITE (NNSS). IN PARTICULAR THIS RESEARCH WILL (1) QUANTIFY FINE-SCALE SELECTION OF BIGHORN SHEEP HABITAT AND ASSESS KEY THREATS TO DESERT BIGHORN SHEEP FROM REDUCED WATER SOURCES AND INCREASED VISITATION AND USE OF RECREATIONAL TRAILS IN JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK, AND (2) COLLECT INFORMATION ON RADIONUCLEOTIDE BURDENS, MOVEMENTS AND HABITAT USE OF MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS) AND PRONGHORN ANTELOPE (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA) ON THE NEVADA NATIONAL SECURITY SITE AND THE POTENTIAL DOSE TO HUNTERS CONSUMING THEM IF THEY MOVE OFF-SITE. THIS WORK BUILDS ON PREVIOUS RESEARCH TO ASSESS IMPACTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON UNGULATES THROUGHOUT THE MOJAVE DESERT TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS: ARE CURRENT LEVELS OF RECREATIONAL TRAIL ACTIVITY IN JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK AFFECTING BIGHORN SHEEP HABITAT USE, PARTICULARLY IN LAMBING AREAS AND AT WATER SOURCES? WHAT ARE THE RANGE OF MOVEMENTS OF MULE DEER AND PRONGHORN ANTELOPE USING CONTAMINATED WATER SOURCES ON THE NNSS? DO CONTAMINATED ANIMALS LEAVE THE NNSS AND POSE A THREAT TO HUNTERS ON ADJACENT LANDS? THE ANSWERS TO THESE QUESTIONS WILL PROVIDE TIMELY AND RELEVANT INFORMATION FOR MANAGERS AT FEDERAL, STATE, COUNTY, AND LOCAL LEVELS WHO MUST MANAGE INCREASING ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITY THROUGHOUT THE ARID WEST AND ANSWER QUESTIONS ABOUT THE RISK OF RADIOACTIVE CONTAMINATION TO HUMANS TO MITIGATE NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON WILDLIFE AND HUMANS.RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS STUDY INCLUDE: (1) MONITORING BIGHORN SHEEP WITH THE USE OF GPS COLLARS TO CLOSELY EXAMINE SPATIAL USE, MOVEMENT, AND BEHAVIORAL PATTERNS AND ASSESSING VISITOR USE PATTERNS IN AREAS OF THE QUEEN MOUNTAIN REGION OF JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK WHERE BIGHORN SHEEP HABITAT (INCLUDING WATER SOURCES) OVERLAPS WITH VISITOR USE. ADDITIONALLY WE WILL ASSESS THE IMPACT OF RECREATION ON BIGHORN HABITAT USE AND BEHAVIOR AND THE POTENTIAL FOR NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON THE POPULATION. (2) MONITORING THE RANGE OF MOVEMENTS OF GPS-COLLARED DEER AND PRONGHORN ANTELOPE, QUANTIFYING USAGE OF CONTAMINATED WATER SOURCES, AND DOCUMENTING SURVIVAL AND CAUSES OF MORTALITY ON THE NEVADA NATIONAL SECURITY SITE TO ESTIMATE THE POTENTIAL FOR HUNTERS TO HARVEST CONTAMINATED DEER AND PRONGHORN. THE PRODUCTS RESULTING FROM THIS STUDY INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF STATISTICAL MODELS AND SPATIAL LAYERS DEPICTING BIGHORN SHEEP, MULE DEER AND PRONGHORN HABITAT, WATER RESOURCES, AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP TO TRAILS IN JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK AND POTENTIALLY CONTAMINATED LOCATIONS IN THE NEVADA NATIONAL SECURITY SITE AND A PROTOCOL TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL FOR UNGULATES TO BE DISTURBED BY RECREATIONAL HIKERS AND A PROTOCOL TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL FOR HUNTERS TO HARVEST CONTAMINATED MULE DEER AND PRONGHORN

PROJECT TITLE:STATUS OF BUTTERFLIES IN THE UNITED STATESPROJECT PERIOD: 4/1/2022 - 3/31/24BACKGROUND: THE PERVASIVE NATURE OF INSECT SPECIES' DECLINES HAS LED TO THE SPECTER OF AN "INSECT ARMAGEDDON" IN THE POPULAR PRESS. INSECT-DERIVED ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ARE VALUED AT > S57 BILLION IN THE U.S. AND THUS THE LOSS OF INSECTS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO FUNDAMENTALLY DISRUPT NATURAL AND ECONOMIC SYSTEMS. THE CAUSES OF INSECT DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO CHANGES IN CLIMATE, LAND USE AND PESTICIDE USE, BUT THERE IS LITTLE CONSENSUS ON THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF THESE DRIVERS. THERE IS EVEN LESS CONSENSUS ABOUT WHICH SPECIES ARE AT MOST RISK AND ABOUT HOW TO MITIGATE DECLINES AND RECOVER POPULATIONS.ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: SYSTEMATIC EVALUATIONS OF TRENDS ACROSS INSECT TAXA IN NORTH AMERICA ARE NEEDED AS THERE ARE NONE BASED ON SYSTEMATIC MONITORING DATA. WE WILL USE BUTTERFLIES AS A FLAGSHIP TAXONOMIC GROUP FOR SUCH AN ANALYSIS. BUTTERFLIES ARE THE PERFECT VEHICLE FOR THIS APPROACH BECAUSE ARE THE BEST STUDIED OF ALL INSECT GROUPS. WILL INTEGRATE SYSTEMATIC MONITORING DATA FROM MULTIPLE SURVEY PROGRAMS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES TO ESTIMATE SPECIES AND POPULATION-LEVEL TRENDS, ASSOCIATE TRENDS TO BUTTERFLY TRAITS, AND DETERMINE IMPACT OF HYPOTHESIZED ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL INSIGHTS INTO HOW TO MITIGATE DECLINES WHERE THEY OCCUR, AS WELL AS BRING ATTENTION TO THE OVERALL STATUS OF BUTTERFLIES IN NORTH AMERICA.OUR MAIN ANALYSES WILL BE WRITTEN AS A SYNTHETIC MANUSCRIPT ON STATUS OF BUTTERFLIES IN THE UNITED STATES AND SUBMITTED TO A HIGH IMPACT JOURNAL. WILL WRITE 1-2 PAPERS ON THE INFLUENCE OF ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS ON BUTTERFLY TRENDS, DEPENDING ON FINDINGS EMERGING FROM OUR ANALYSES. WILL DEVELOP A CONSERVATION-ORIENTED PAPER ON THE IMPLICATIONS OF THE FINDINGS FOR CONSERVATION OF BUTTERFLIES, POLLINATORS AND OTHER INSECT TAXA. THIS WILL PROVIDE ACTIONABLE INSIGHT AT SCALES AND TIMEFRAMES RELEVANT TO DECISION MAKERS. PLAN TO DEVELOP A WHITE PAPER TO ASSIST AGENCIES AS THEY DEVELOP STATE, REGIONAL, OR FEDERAL MONITORING PROGRAMS. FINALLY, WILL PUBLISH OUR SITE-YEAR INDICES OF ABUNDANCE FROM THIS UNPARALLELED DATASET - INTEGRATED USING NEW TOOLS THAT UNLOCK SPARSE DATA SETS AND ALLOW THE INCLUSION OF DATA COLLECTED USING DIFFERENT METHODOLOGIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WITH REGARD TO NEW KNOWLEDGE ABOUT TRENDS IN BUTTERFLIES WITHIN THE US AND DRIVERS OF THESE TRENDS. IN ADDITION, BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES WHICH OVERSEE, PROTECT AND MANAGE BUTTERFLY POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS AS WELL AS MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT WHICH SPECIES MERIT PROTECTION.

THIS PROJECT IS PART OF THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS (CASC) FELLOWS PROGRAM AND IS DESIGNED TO ADVANCE THE SCIENCE AND IMPACT OF THE CORE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER MISSION WHILE CULTIVATING THE NEXT GENERATION OF CLIMATE SCIENTISTS. WHILE PRODUCING NEW CLIMATE SCIENCE, THIS PROGRAM IMPLEMENTS BEST PRACTICES IN STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATH) RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION AND INVESTS IN TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL PROGRAM ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT LEADING CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE. AT THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO BOULDER, THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE ONGOING EFFORTS BY THE UNIVERSITY AND THE NORTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION CENTER TO EXPAND DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION IN STEM FIELDS. THE PROJECT HAS THREE MAJOR COMPONENTS: THE UNDERGRADUATE SUMMER RESEARCH FELLOWS PROGRAM COMBINING RESEARCH EXPERIENCE WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, PEER MENTORING, AND ADDITIONAL SUPPORT. THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THREE STUDENTS FOR TWO CONSECUTIVE SUMMERS; THE FACULTY PARTNER PROGRAM TO FOSTER TWO-WAY KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AND BUILD RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FACULTY AT TRIBAL COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES AND AT THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, BUILDING A FOUNDATION FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND CAPACITY-BUILDING INITIATIVES AROUND CLIMATE ADAPTATION; AND A SMALL GRANTS PROGRAM TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR STUDENT FELLOWS FROM THE CASC NETWORK. THIS WILL PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR STUDENTS TO ATTEND CONFERENCES, SUPPORT RESEARCH, OR PURCHASE NECESSARY SUPPLIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE HELPING STUDENTS BUILD THE SKILLS, CONFIDENCE, AND EXPERIENCE TO PURSUE STEM CAREERS, AND ENHANCED SUPPORT FOR STUDENTS TO PURSUE THEIR RESEARCH AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES. THE UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH FELLOWS WILL ALSO SHARE THEIR RESEARCH AT A NATIONAL RESEARCH CONFERENCE AFTER THEIR SECOND SUMMER. THE FACULTY PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO AND REGIONAL TRIBAL COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES IN THE AREAS OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION. PROGRAM COORDINATORS WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE OTHER CASC FELLOWS PROGRAMS TO IDENTIFY AND BEST PRACTICES FOR INCREASING EXPAND DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION IN STEM FIELDS.

INVESTIGATE THE USE OF REMOTE SENSING TO RESEARCH A MODEL TO MONITOR DUST SOURCES AND FORECAST POTENTIAL DUST STORM ACTIVITY IN IRAQIN ARID REGIONS OF THE WORLD RECURRENT DROUGHT AND LAND USE PRACTICES HAVE NEGATIVELY AFFECTED THE LANDSCAPE'S VULNERABILITY TO WIND EROSION AND DUST EMISSION INCLUDING IN THE MIDDLE EAST. THIS REGION HAS BEEN INCREASINGLY SUFFERING FROM DUST STORMS IN THE PAST FEW DECADES AND AT TIMES ALMOST THE ENTIRE COUNTRY OF IRAQ IS COVERED WITH DUST. THIS PHENOMENON IS EXPECTED TO INTENSIFY AS DESERTIFICATION IS TAKING OVER A LARGE PORTION OF THE COUNTRY DUE TO SCARCE WATER RESOURCES AND CLIMATE CHANGE. WIND EROSION AND DUST EMISSION IMPACTS NOT ONLY THE LANDSCAPE AND ENVIRONMENT, BUT ALSO HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY.IN THIS PROJECT NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY (NAU) SCIENTISTS ARE COLLABORATING WITH U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) SCIENTISTS TO:USE REMOTELY SENSED SATELLITE IMAGES TO DETECT, MAP, AND MONITOR CHANGE OF THE VEGETATION COVER, WHICH IS DIRECTLY RELATED TO WIND EROSION VULNERABILITY, ON AND NEAR KNOWN MAJOR DUST SOURCES IN AND AROUND IRAQ.WIND EROSION VULNERABILITY MAPS WILL BE GENERATED REPRESENTING DIFFERENT TIMES OF THE YEAR FROM THE REMOTE SENSING ANALYSES. THE MAPS WILL BE USED TO GENERATE A MODEL THAT CAN BE USED TO FORECAST THE POTENTIAL OF DUST STORM ACTIVITY IN THE REGION IN TIME SCALES OF WEEKS TO MONTHS.A SECOND ACTIVITY WILL BE TO TRANSFER THE KNOWLEDGE AND CAPABILITIES TO IRAQI PROFESSIONALS BY BRINGING TOGETHER FIELD SCIENTISTS FROM IRAQ AND RESEARCH SCIENTISTS AT NAU AND THE USGS FOR BOTH ON-LINE INTERACTIONS AND HAND-ON TRAINING AT NAU.THE OUTCOME AND DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A MODEL THAT CAN BE USED TO GENERATE WIND EROSION VULNERABILITY MAPS AT DIFFERENT TIMES OF THE YEAR OF MAJOR DUST SOURCES AND USED TO FORECAST DUST STORM ACTIVITY IN TIME PERIODS OF WEEKS TO MONTHS. THE DELIVERABLES WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE WIND EROSION VULNERABILITY MAPS THAT ARE GENERATED DURING THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT STAGE.THE BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE NAU AND THE IRAQIS. THESE GROUPS WILL ADVANCE THEIR KNOWLEDGE ON MONITORING DUST SOURCES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR AND BE ABLE TO MAKE FORECASTS OF DUST STORM ACTIVITY. ALSO, THE MODEL THAT WILL BE DEVELOPED WILL BE APPLICABLE IN OTHER ARID AND SEMI-ARID LANDSCAPES, INCLUDING THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES.

PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING THE EFFECTS OF SALTWATER INTRUSION IN FOREST STRUCTURE AND ROOT FUNCTIONING OF CYPRESS SWAMPS IN THE BARATARIA BASINPROJECT PERIOD 06/01/2022 - 05/31/2023HUMAN SETTLEMENTS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED MODIFICATIONS OF WATER FLOWS WORSEN SALTWATER INTRUSION EVENTS AND AMPLIFY THEIR NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON NATURAL ECOSYSTEMS. IN THE JEAN LAFITTE NATIONAL AND HISTORICAL PARK AND PRESERVE AREA, LEVEES, AND FLOODWALLS INSTALLED TO CONTAIN FLOOD WAVES FROM STORM SURGES DURING HURRICANES MODIFY NATURAL HYDROLOGIC EXCHANGES BETWEEN THE BARATARIA BAY AND THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER FLOODPLAIN. AS A RESULT, SALTWATER ACCUMULATING IN CHANNELS AND LOW-LYING AREAS CAN REMAIN STAGNANT FOR PROLONGED PERIODS, INCREASING THE EXPOSURE OF ADJACENT SWAMPS TO SALT STRESS. THIS STORM-RELATED STRESS AMPLIFIED BY HUMAN-MADE STRUCTURES, ADDED TO RELATIVE SEA-LEVEL RISE IN THE AREA, IS IDENTIFIED AS THE MAIN DRIVER OF CYPRESS STANDS DECLINE IN THE JEAN LAFITTE PRESERVE AREA.THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE LINKS BETWEEN BELOWGROUND PROCESSES AND FOREST STRUCTURE IN CYPRESS SWAMPS ALONG GRADIENTS OF SALINITY AND WATER LEVELS THROUGH THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: STEM DIAMETER AND CANOPY LEAF AREA INDEX MEASUREMENTS IN THE FIELD AND SAMPLE COLLECTION FOR ROOT GROWTH AND ROOT CONDUCTIVITY MEASUREMENTS IN THE LAB. WE ANTICIPATE CONDUCTING ONE STEM DIAMETER MEASUREMENT CAMPAIGN AND FOUR QUARTERLY LEAF AREA MEASUREMENTS AT SIX JEAN LAFITTE NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE PLOTS. ALSO, FOUR QUARTERLY ROOT GROWTH MEASUREMENTS AND TEN ROOT HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY MEASUREMENTS FROM SAMPLES COLLECTED AT THE SIX PLOTS.THIS PROJECT ADDRESS THE ROLE OF SALINITY IN FOREST STRUCTURE AND ROOT FUNCTIONING. THESE ARE KEY TO GAINING A MECHANISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE LINK BETWEEN FOREST MORTALITY AND SALINITY. THIS INFORMATION IS USEFUL FOR PARK MANAGERS AT THE JEAN LAFITTE NATIONAL AND HISTORICAL PARK AND PRESERVE TO EVALUATE PROJECTED RELATIVE SEA-LEVEL RISE RISKS IN THE REMAINING CYPRESS STANDS AND PLAN ACCORDINGLY.

PROJECT SUMMARY: THROUGH A UNIQUE COLLABORATION BETWEEN AUBURN UNIVERSITY (AU) AND LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY (LSU), THE TWO-YEAR HYDROCLIMATE-LSU PROGRAM WILL ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN CONSORTIUM RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS AND HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES (HBCU) WITH AN AIM OF ACCELERATING THE DEVELOPMENT OF UNDERGRADUATES, GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND FACULTY IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCES. WHILE PRODUCING NEW CLIMATE SCIENCE, THIS PROGRAM IMPLEMENTS BEST PRACTICES IN TEACHING SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH AS WELL AS RECRUITING AND RETAINING STUDENTS. THE PROGRAM ALSO INVESTS IN THE TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW GENERATION OF CLIMATE SCIENTISTS. TO REACH THESE GOALS, THREE EXPLICITLY INTEGRATED INITIATIVES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED: (I) A SUMMER RESEARCH EXPERIENCE FOR THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FOCUSED ON CLIMATE IMPACTS ON WATER SYSTEMS ALONG A HYDROLOGICAL GRADIENT FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO UPPER WATERSHED (AU) TO THE COASTAL ENVIRONMENT (LSU), (II) A DEVELOPMENT AWARD PROGRAM TO INCREASE THE PREPARATION OF CLIMATE SCIENCE STUDENTS AT THE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE LEVELS, AND (III) A VISITING FACULTY SCHOLAR PROGRAM FOR PROJECT PARTNERS FROM SAVANNAH STATE AND JACKSON STATE UNIVERSITIES, BOTH HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEAST US. VISITING SCHOLARS WILL TRAVEL TO LSU INTERACTING WITH UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATORS, FACULTY, AND STUDENTS WITH THE AIMS OF IDENTIFYING OPPORTUNITIES FOR FUTURE COLLABORATION AND DEVELOPING SHARED GOALS IN CLIMATE SCIENCE. THE RESULTS OF THESE COLLECTIVE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE A COHORT OF UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS THAT HAVE BEEN TRAINED AND SUPPORTED IN THE CUTTING-EDGE TECHNIQUES, SKILLS, AND APPROACHES SCIENTISTS USE TO SOLVE PROBLEMS RELATED TO WATER-CLIMATE SCIENCE, WHILE INTEGRATING THE VALUES OF DIVERSITY, EQUITY AND INCLUSION IN THEIR PROBLEM-SOLVING APPROACHES. DISSEMINATION PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE A WHITE-PAPER DETAILING CLIMATE PARTNERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES BETWEEN LSU AND THE VISITING SCHOLARS' HOME INSTITUTIONS, PRESENTATIONS AT NATIONAL CONFERENCES BY PARTICIPATING STUDENTS, AND PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.

THIS PROJECT IS A PARTICIPANT IN THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENTISTS OF TOMORROW (CAST) FELLOWS PROGRAM AND IS DESIGNED TO ADVANCE THE SCIENCE AND IMPACT OF THE CORE MISSION OF THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS (CASCS) WHILE CULTIVATING THE NEXT GENERATION OF CLIMATE SCIENTISTS. WHILE PRODUCING NEW CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE, THIS PROGRAM IMPLEMENTS BEST PRACTICES IN STEM RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION AND INVESTS IN TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL PROGRAM ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT LEADING CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE. AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS, AMHERST, THE CAST FELLOWS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM MINORITY SERVING INSTITUTIONS AND TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS WHO CAN BRING DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES TO THE NORTHEAST CASC COMMUNITY. UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE SCIENTIFIC TRAINING IN STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN, CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE TO SUPPORT THEIR RECRUITMENT INTO SCIENTIFIC FIELDS WITH INCREASING OPPORTUNITIES. UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL ALSO HAVE MENTORING SUPPORT AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AS PARTICIPANTS IN UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS SCIENCE IMPACT PROGRAM FOR STUDENT SCIENTISTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON CUTTING-EDGE, STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE AND WILL CULMINATE IN SCIENTIFIC PRESENTATIONS OR WRITTEN REPORTS. IN ADDITION TO SERVING AS NEAR-PEER MENTORS FOR THE UNDERGRADUATES, GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL ALSO DEVELOP TRAININGS OR PROGRAMMING IN DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, AND/OR JUSTICE FOR THE NE CASC COMMUNITY, WITH A GOAL OF BUILDING A MORE WELCOMING ENVIRONMENT AND SUPPORTING THE RETENTION OF SCIENTISTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. WILL EMBED THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN LABS FOCUSED ON CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE DURING THE SUMMERS OF 2022 AND 2023. GRADUATE STUDENTS WHO CAN BRING DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES TO THE NE CASC COMMUNITY WILL BE SUPPORTED AS NEAR-PEER MENTORS FOR THE UNDERGRADUATES DURING THE SUMMERS AND ACADEMIC YEARS. GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL ALSO SUPPORT TEACHING AND TRAINING OF NE CASC PIS AND FELLOWS IN BUILDING A MORE DIVERSE, EQUITABLE, INCLUSIVE, AND JUST COMMUNITY. A FACULTY MENTOR FROM A MINORITY SERVING INSTITUTION WILL VISIT FOR ONE WEEK TO SERVE AS A MENTOR FOR GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS. WILL SUPPORT THE TRAINING OF THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE, LIKELY INCLUDING PARTICIPATION IN SCIENTIFIC PAPERS AND UNDERGRADUATE THESES. SIMILARLY, WILL SUPPORT THE TRAINING OF TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE. PEER MENTORING ACTIVITIES WILL SUPPORT THE RECRUITMENT OF STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS INTO CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE. TRAINING ACTIVITIES WILL BUILD A MORE WELCOMING ENVIRONMENT WITHIN NE CASC. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER CLIMATE ADAPTATION COMMUNITY BY RECRUITING STUDENTS FROM GROUPS UNDERREPRESENTED IN SCIENCE AND PROVIDING THESE STUDENTS WITH TRAINING IN STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN SCIENCE. THE WORK WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION COMMUNITY BY BUILDING TRAINING ACTIVITIES TO MAKE NE CASC MORE EQUITABLE AND INCLUSIVE, LEADING TO A SCIENTIFIC ENTERPRISE THAT IS MORE WELCOMING AND SUPPORTIVE OF STUDENTS OF ALL BACKGROUNDS.

TO REACH THESE GOALS, THREE EXPLICITLY INTEGRATED INITIATIVES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED: (I) A SUMMER RESEARCH EXPERIENCE FOR THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FOCUSED ON CLIMATE IMPACTS ON WATER SYSTEMS ALONG A HYDROLOGICAL GRADIENT FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO UPPER WATERSHED TO THE COASTAL ENVIRONMENT, (II) A DEVELOPMENT AWARD PROGRAM TO INCREASE THE PREPARATION OF CLIMATE SCIENCE STUDENTS AT THE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE LEVELS, AND (III) A VISITING FACULTY SCHOLAR PROGRAM FOR PROJECT PARTNERS FROM SAVANNAH STATE AND JACKSON STATE UNIVERSITIES, BOTH HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEAST US. USGS WETLAND AND AQUATIC RESEARCH CENTER (WARC) - NORTH ATLANTIC CESUHYDRODYNAMIC AND WATER QUALITY MODELING OF CANAL BACKFILLING RESTORATION AT JEAN LAFITTE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK AND PRESERVEABSTRACTTHE REMOVAL OF SPOIL BANKS AND BACKFILLING CANALS IS A SIMPLE AND COST-EFFECTIVE RESTORATION APPROACH TO ALLEVIATE INUNDATION AND SALINITY STRESS TO VEGETATED WETLANDS, ENHANCING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE HABITATS AND THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THEY PROVIDE, INCLUDING WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT. SINCE 2001, THE JEAN LAFITTE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK AND PRESERVE (JELA) HAS REMOVED SPOIL BANKS AND BACKFILLED SOME OF THE CANALS INSIDE THE BARATARIA PRESERVE TO RESTORE NATURAL HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION. UNDERSTANDING THE PROCESSES AND MECHANISMS INVOLVED IN HYDROLOGY AND WATER QUALITY CHANGES DUE TO CANAL BACKFILLING IS CRUCIAL. MOREOVER, THE EFFECT ON WATER QUALITY COULD BE DIFFERENT UNDER FUTURE SEA LEVEL RISE CONDITIONS. INTEGRATION OF MONITORING AND PROCESS-BASED NUMERICAL MODELING IS URGENTLY NEEDED TO DELIVER PREDICTIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE RESTORATION PROJECT UNDER CURRENT AND FUTURE ENVIRONMENT CONDITIONS.THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROVIDE RESOURCE MANAGERS WITH ROBUST PROCESS-LINKED PROJECTIONS OF WATER QUALITY OUTCOMES OF CANAL BACKFILLING ACROSS THE BARATARIA PRESERVE LANDSCAPE, UNDER BOTH CURRENT AND FUTURE CONDITIONS. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, THIS PROJECT WILL 1) DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE, HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTION, PROCESS-DRIVEN COUPLED HYDRODYNAMIC AND WATER QUALITY MODELING SYSTEM FOR THE PRESERVE; 2) ASSESS AND PREDICT OUTCOMES OF THIS RESTORATION PROJECT ON KEY WATER QUALITY ATTRIBUTES; AND 3) RUN THIS MODELING SYSTEM UNDER A SUITE OF CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIO CONDITIONS. THIS WORK WILL INFORM DECISION-MAKING ON WHETHER TO PURSUE ADDITIONAL CANAL BACKFILLING RESTORATION, AND IT ALSO IS LIKELY TO IDENTIFY SPATIALLY-SPECIFIC (E.G., NEAR MUNICIPAL PUMPING INPUTS) WATER QUALITY CONCERNS OR BENEFITS ARISING FROM CANAL BACKFILLING. THIS WORK ALSO WOULD ENABLE REGIONAL SCIENTISTS, COASTAL RESTORATION PLANNERS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE PROCESSES AND MECHANISMS CONTROLLING WATER QUALITY AND NUTRIENT TRANSPORT IN CANALS AND ADJACENT WETLANDS UNDER VARIOUS SITUATIONS, AND THEREBY ASSISTING ECOSYSTEM-BASED DECISION-MAKING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT BEYOND THE BOUNDARIES OF THE BARATARIA PRESERVE.WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COUPLED HYDRODYNAMIC AND WATER QUALITY MODELING SYSTEM AND SIMULATION RESULTS OF CANAL BACKFILLING RESTORATION PROJECTS UNDER FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE, SEA LEVEL RISE, AND STORMS, RESOURCE MANAGERS WILL BE ABLE TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT SUITABLE RESTORATION PROJECTS AND CONDUCT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING RESTORATION PROJECTS INCLUDING THE CANAL BACKFILLING PROJECTS. A WEB VISUALIZATION TOOL WILL BE DEVELOPED AND DELIVERED TO RESOURCE MANAGERS TO SEE THE CHANGE IN SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL WATER QUALITY STATE VARIABLES UNDER COMBINED RESTORATION EFFORTS AND FUTURE ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES. RESEARCH FINDINGS FROM THIS PROCESS-DRIVEN, FINE RESOLUTION NUMERICAL MODELING STUDY COULD HELP THE LOUISIANA COASTAL PROTECTION AND RESTORATION AUTHORITY FOR STATEWIDE MASTER PLAN DEVELOPMENT TO DETERMINE IF CANAL BACKFILLING COULD BECOME A RESTORATION APPROACH ELSEWHERE ON THE LOUISIANA COAST, SUCH AS IN THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES OR U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE REFUGES.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYRECOGNIZING FISHES IN FRESHWATER HAS BEEN A FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH PROBLEM IN MANY DOMAINSSUCH AS ECOLOGY, BIOLOGY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES. EXISTING WORK MAINLY FOCUSES ON FISHRECOGNITION AT THE SPECIES LEVEL, WHICH COULD NOT EFFECTIVELY ADDRESS SOME FUNDAMENTALCHALLENGES IN FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, SUCH AS POPULATION ESTIMATION, DISEASE DETECTION, ANDINDIVIDUAL GROWTH MODELING. THUS, NEW COMPUTATIONAL APPROACHES FOR FISH RECOGNITION AT THEINDIVIDUAL LEVEL ARE URGENTLY DESIRED. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCEAPPROACHES, SUCH AS CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORKS OR VISION TRANSFORMERS, FOR IMAGE-BASED FISHINDIVIDUAL RECOGNITION. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL MAINLY FOCUS ON THE RECOGNITION AND ANALYSIS OFBROOK TROUT, WHICH IS A SPECIES OF FRESHWATER FISH IN THE CHAR GENUS SALVELINUS OF THE SALMONFAMILY SALMONIDAE. IN ADDITION, THE PROPOSED ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE METHODS WILL BE POTENTIALLYIMPROVED AND REFINED TO DEALING WITH OTHER FISH SPECIES SUCH AS LARGEMOUTH BASS AND BROWN TROUT.THE PLANNED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: (1) DEVELOP BASELINE ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCEMODELS BY EXPLOITING VISUAL FEATURES AND PRE-TRAINED DEEP LEARNING MODELS. (2) IMPROVEINDIVIDUAL FISH RECOGNITION PERFORMANCE, AS WELL AS HANDLING NEW INDIVIDUALS AND EXPLORINGDYNAMIC ENVIRONMENTS. (3) EVALUATE MELANISTIC MARKINGS ASSOCIATED WITH "BLOTCHY BASSSYNDROME" TO ASSESS THE CAPACITY FOR DETECTION OF DISEASED FISH. (4) EVALUATE DEEP LEARNINGMODELS FOR INDIVIDUAL RECOGNITION AND RESPIRATION RATE (VENTILATE RATE) USING VIDEO DATA COLLECTEDIN LABORATORY SETTINGS AND NATURAL STREAMS. THE PROPOSED APPROACHES WILL BE NON-INVASIVE ANDCOST-EFFECTIVE, AND THEY COULD BE POTENTIALLY USED TO REDUCE HUMAN LABOR AND COSTS IN VARIOUSSCENARIOS SUCH AS POPULATION ESTIMATION AND FISH HEALTH MONITORING.THE DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: (1) TECHNICAL REPORTS, WHICH WILLSUMMARIZE AND TRACK THE PROJECT PROGRESS. (2) DATA ANALYSIS, COMPREHENSIVE STUDIES, ANDDEVELOPMENTS OF THE PROPOSED METHODOLOGY. QUANTITATIVE COMPARISONS WILL BE PROVIDED WITH THESTATE-OF-THE-ART APPROACHES FOR IMAGE-BASED AND VIDEO-BASED FISH INDIVIDUAL RECOGNITION. (3)PUBLICATIONS THAT SUMMARIZE THE MAJOR RESEARCH FINDINGS OF THIS PROJECT. (4) SOURCE CODES OF THEPROPOSED METHODOLOGY.

COLLABORATIVE FACILITIES USE COOPERATITIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE UNVIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN - LA CROSSE AND UPPER MIDWEST ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE CENTER FOR THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE OF FEBRUARY 01, 2022 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2023.THE RECIPIENT IS PROVIDING THE USGS WITH 700 SQUARE FEET OF LABORATORY SPACE WITHIN THE COWLEY HALL AND SEPARATE ANNEX FACILITY IN LA CROSSE, WISCONSIN IN ACCORDANCE WITH THEIR PROPOSAL, DATED JANUARY 24, 2022. USGS WILL HAVE APPROXIMATELY (6) LABS AND (4) SUPPORT ROOMS TO ACCOMODATE BIOLOGY AND CHEMISTRY WORK. IN ADDITION, THE USGS WILL HAVE ACCESS AND USE OF THE COWLEY ANNEX FACILITY TO PERFORM EDNA WORK. THIS AGREEMENT WILL ALLOW FOR CONTINUED COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHIN THE SPECIFIC AREAS OF BIOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES.

PROJECT TITLE, SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE CENTER. BRIDGE PROPOSAL, 2022-2024.  ACTUAL PROJECT PERIOD, 2/1/2022 THROUGH 1/31/2024.  EARTHQUAKES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH FUNDAMENTAL UNSOLVED SCIENTIFIC QUESTIONS AND SUBSTANTIAL SOCIETAL AND ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE. IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING, FORECASTING, AND PREPARATION FOR EARTHQUAKES REQUIRES SUSTAINED COORDINATED EFFORTS ON MANY FRONTS. THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE CENTER CONDUCTS AND COORDINATES FUNDAMENTAL AND APPLIED RESEARCH ON EARTHQUAKES THAT AIMS TO BE GLOBAL IN IMPACT WHILE USING SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AS A FOCUSED NATURAL LABORATORY. OUR COLLABORATION DEVELOPS DYNAMICAL MODELS OF EARTHQUAKE PROCESSES THAT ARE COMPREHENSIVE, INTEGRATIVE, VERIFIED, PREDICTIVE, AND VALIDATED AGAINST OBSERVATIONS. THE FOCUS ON VALIDATION OF MODEL-BASED PREDICTIONS AGAINST DATA IS A KEY TO GUIDING THE ASSESSMENT OF UNCERTAINTIES AND DRIVING MODELS TOWARDS BETTER REPRESENTATIONS OF REALITY. CENTER'S VALIDATION EFFORTS TIGHTLY COUPLE BASIC EARTHQUAKE RESEARCH TO THE PRACTICAL NEEDS OF PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSIS, OPERATIONAL EARTHQUAKE FORECASTING, EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, AND RAPID POST-EARTHQUAKE RESPONSE.  THE RISK REDUCTION PROBLEM, WHICH REQUIRES ACTIONS MOTIVATED BY USEFUL INFORMATION STRONGLY COUPLES VALIDATED SCIENCE RESULTS TO EARTHQUAKE ENGINEERING.  THIS PROPOSAL WILL SUPPORT CENTER ACTIVITIES FOR 2 YEARS FOCUSING EFFORTS BY A MULTI DISCIPLINARY RESEARCH COMMUNITY TO DEVELOP IMPROVED MODELS FOR EARTHQUAKES AND SEISMIC GROUND MOTION, PROVIDE NEW DATA FOR TESTING THE MODELS, AND IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF UNCERTAINTIES.  THE COLLABORATION WILL PURSUE INNOVATIVE AND TIMELY RESEARCH TO 1, DEVELOP WORKFLOWS TO INTEGRATE AND VALIDATE EXISTING AND FUTURE COMMUNITY EARTH MODELS WITH OBSERVATIONAL RESULTS.  AND 2, ATTEMPT TO DETECT JOINTLY IN ALL COMMUNITY MODELS POSSIBLE UNDERLYING LARGE-SCALE STRUCTURES THAT HAVE LIMITED MANIFESTATIONS IN EACH DATA SET.  AND 3, UPDATE RESEARCH ON OFF-FAULT YIELDING FROM THE USE OF (PLASTICITY) TO THE MORE GENERAL DESCRIPTOR OF (DAMAGE), WHICH INCLUDES CHANGES OF ROCK PROPERTIES DURING FAILURE.  AND 4, INCREASE STUDIES OF DYNAMIC DILATATION (VOLUMETRIC EFFECTS) ACCOMPANYING FAILURE OF FAULT ZONE MATERIALS.  KEY INNOVATIONS WILL INCLUDE 1- INCREASED USE OF MACHINE LEARNING IN BOTH COMPUTATIONAL AND OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES ACROSS THE DISCIPLINARY SPECTRUM OF EARTHQUAKE SCIENCE, 2- INCREASED FOCUS ON NEAR-FAULT STUDIES FOR TESTING AND DEVELOPING MODELS OF EARTHQUAKE PROCESSES, AND 3- IMPROVEMENTS TO RESEARCH COMPUTING, CYBERINFRASTRUCTURE, AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TO SUPPORT THE PLANNED SCIENCE ACTIVITIES. CENTER WILL CONTINUE TESTING AND VALIDATION OF CODES ON KEY COMPUTATIONAL PLATFORMS; MAKE IMPROVEMENTS IN SIMULATIONS AND VALIDATION OF SEISMIC GROUND MOTION TO PROMOTE UP-TAKE BY ENGINEERS; AND CONTINUE DEVELOPMENT OF PHYSICS-BASED EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS.  CENTER ESTABLISHES SUBAWARDS ANNUALLY FOR FOCUSED RESEARCH STUDIES THROUGH A COMPETITIVE PROCESS. OVER 100 PROPOSALS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE CENTER EACH YEAR, INVOLVING WORK BY 200 DISTINCT INVESTIGATORS AND MANY MORE STUDENTS AND EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS.  CENTER ALSO CONNECTS TO THE SOCIAL SCIENCES THROUGH ITS MISSION TO CONVEY AUTHORITATIVE INFORMATION TO STAKEHOLDERS IN WAYS THAT RESULT IN LOWERED RISK AND ENHANCED RESILIENCE. OUR VISION IS TO ENGAGE END-USERS AND THE PUBLIC AT LARGE IN ON-GOING, COMMUNITY-CENTRIC CONVERSATIONS ABOUT HOW TO MANAGE PARTICULAR RISKS BY TAKING SPECIFIC ACTIONS. OUR COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH PROGRAM SEEKS TO PROMOTE THIS DIALOG ON MANY LEVELS, THROUGH MANY DIFFERENT CHANNELS, AND TO INFORM THE CONVERSATIONS WITH AUTHORITATIVE EARTHQUAKE INFORMATION. TOWARDS THIS GOAL, WE WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD NETWORKS OF ORGANIZATIONAL PARTNERS THAT CAN ACT IN CONCERT TO PREPARE MILLIONS OF PEOPLE OF ALL AGES AND SOCIOECONOMIC LEVELS FOR INEVITABLE EARTHQUAKE DISASTERS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY FOR:INVESTIGATING SELENIUM AND MERCURY DYNAMICS AND INFLUENCE ON AQUATIC FOOD WEBS OF THE WESTERN UNITED STATESSELENIUM AND MERCURY CONTAMINATION OF FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS THREATENS THE HEALTH OF ASSOCIATED ORGANISMS, INCLUDING FISH SPECIES THAT ARE MANAGED AND MONITORED AS ECOLOGICALLY, COMMERCIALLY, AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT. IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, IRRIGATION OF SELENIUM-ENRICHED SOILS AND COAL MINING OPERATIONS ARE ONGOING AND EXPANDING REGIONAL UPLAND SOURCES OF SELENIUM AND MERCURY TO SURFACE WATERS. ATMOSPHERIC DEPOSITION OF MERCURY DERIVED FROM GLOBALLY DISTRIBUTED SOURCES ALSO CONTINUES TO BE AN IMPORTANT SOURCE. THE CONTINUAL LOADING AND PERSISTENT INFLUENCE OF SELENIUM AND MERCURY AS WIDESPREAD CONTAMINANTS IN THE REGION UNDERSCORE THE RELEVANCE OF APPLIED RESEARCH EFFORTS THAT WILL INFORM LONG-TERM MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH SERVES TO ADDRESS KNOWLEDGE GAPS ABOUT SELENIUM AND MERCURY AS INDEPENDENT AND INTERACTING CONTAMINANT STRESSORS IN FRESHWATER SYSTEMS.THE RESEARCH SUPPORTED BY THIS AWARD WILL INVOLVE FIELD COLLECTIONS AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS TO INVESTIGATE: (1) FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE SELENIUM BIOACCUMULATION IN FRESHWATER FOOD WEBS; (2) MECHANISMS OF SELENIUM TOXICITY; (3) BIOLOGICAL INTERACTIONS BETWEEN SELENIUM AND MERCURY; AND/OR (3) THE POTENTIAL OF BIOLOGICAL TISSUES AS TRACERS OF CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE. RESEARCH DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES AND TO THE STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITY, AND OPEN-ACCESS PUBLICATION OF ALL RESULTING DATA. THE WORK IS ANTICIPATED TO BE OF INTEREST AND BENEFIT TO THE DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS (TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, AND LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL MANAGEMENT AGENCIES) INVOLVED IN THE MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND REMEDIATION OF SELENIUM AND MERCURY CONTAMINATION ISSUES IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES AND BEYOND, ESPECIALLY IN RELATION TO THE HEALTH OF RESIDENT FRESHWATER FISH POPULATIONS.
